In fact, the US program stemming back to the 1990s is directed at better securing labs which focus on infectious disease outbreaks. Days after Russia invaded Ukraine, with Kyiv engaged in a desperate defense of the country‚Äôs sovereignty, Gabbard said: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs time to put geopolitics aside and embrace the spirit of aloha, respect and love, for the Ukrainian people by coming to an agreement that Ukraine will be a neutral country.‚Äù And she has repeatedly supported dictators, including Assad, suggesting that reports of the 2013 and 2017 chemical weapons attacks were false, and calling for the US to ‚Äújoin hands‚Äù with Moscow following its 2015 intervention in Syria. Establishment Democrats and Republicans have openly questioned whether or not she poses a threat to national security. ‚ÄúI worry what might happen to untold numbers of American assets if someone as reckless, inexperienced, and outright disloyal as Gabbard were DNI,‚Äù wrote Adam Kinzinger, a former congressman who served on the foreign affairs committee with Gabbard in 2018 when Caesar testified. The person close to the intelligence community said that there were continuing concerns about Gabbard‚Äôs contacts in the Middle East, stemming back to the controversial 2017 meeting with Assad ‚Äì an encounter that Gabbard has insisted she does not regret. Those contacts may be explored during a Senate confirmation hearing early next year, the person said. Gabbard was briefly placed on a Transportation Security Administration watchlist because of her overseas travel patterns and foreign connections, CNN reported last month, but was later removed. She does not have a background in intelligence, although the Hawaii native served in the army national guard for more than two decades, and has deployed to Iraq and Kuwait. Moreover, there are concerns that her choice could affect intelligence sharing among US foreign allies, including the tightly knit Five Eyes intelligence group that includes the US, Canada, UK, Australia and New Zealand, as well as Nato and allies in Japan and South Korea. ‚ÄúMuch of the intelligence we get, at least from the human collector side, is from our partners,‚Äù said John Sipher, formerly deputy director of the CIA‚Äôs Russia operations, noting that the cooperation was usually informal, ‚Äúpersonality- and trust-based‚Äù. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre going to be really hesitant to pass [information] to a place that that is becoming more partisan and less professional ‚Ä¶ they would be making their own checklist: ‚ÄòHey, this sensitive thing that we would in the past have passed to the CIA that could do us damage if it becomes public ‚Ä¶ Let‚Äôs just not do that this time.‚Äô‚Äù
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Left  
The article critiques Tulsi Gabbard's foreign policy views and her ties with authoritarian figures, reflecting concerns from within the political establishment. It highlights the perspectives of intelligence experts and politicians who express unease about Gabbard's candidacy, aligning with a more liberal stance that prioritizes accountability in foreign relations. The language used suggests a disapproval of her views rather than neutrality, indicating a bias towards a more critical, left-leaning perspective on her controversial positions and actions.

title: Kind LI teen inspires classmates to donate toys to kids with cancer
body: This gesture is anything but child‚Äôs play. A Long Island high schooler is going above and beyond by donating hundreds of toys to pediatric cancer patients at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. Eliza Liebowitz has been bringing a ‚ÄúCourage Cart‚Äù filled with specially requested action figures, dolls, games, and art supplies to the medical center ‚Äî after being inspired to help ailing youth by a friend‚Äôs time being treated at the renown hospital. 4 A Long Island high schooler is going above and beyond by donating hundreds of toys to pediatric cancer patients at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. Instagram / @cleanyourclosetsoutforchildren ‚ÄúThis is the number one thing I prioritize in my life,‚Äù said the 16-year-old Roslyn High School student. 1/100:15This Day in History Skip Ad Continue watchingThis Day in Historyafter the adVisit Advertiser websiteGO TO PAGEHer initiative became so adored that the Nassau County-based charity Go With Courage partnered with the eager high schooler. Most of the donations have come from outreach Liebowitz did to her neighbors on Long Island. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs so amazing to see this kind of support come from my community,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúEspecially for it to go somewhere that is so needed.‚Äù Explore More UnitedHealthcare CEO was facing DOJ probe for insider trading when he was killed in targeted NYC shooting Message on bullets fired by health care CEO's assassin bears eerie link to book condemning insurance companies UnitedHealthcare CEO Brian Thompson's suspected shooter used fake NJ ID to check into hostel: sources Liebowitz, her mother, Donna, or another volunteer will drop off the many toys streetside to nurses using a large, blue cart. Liebowitz said she wished she could walk them up herself, but strict rules apply when visiting the pediatric floor. ‚ÄúI would love to see their faces, but the nurses always say how grateful the kids are,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúOne jumped up once and said, ‚ÄòThis is exactly [a toy] one of the kids wanted.'‚Äù 4 Eliza Liebowitz has been bringing a ‚ÄúCourage Cart‚Äù filled with specially requested action figures, dolls, games, and art supplies to the medical center. Instagram / @cleanyourclosetsoutforchildren Giving back has always been a focus for the generous teenager. Since age five, she has been doing charity work and organizing blood and food drives, among other relief efforts for disaster victims. Liebowitz‚Äôs motive has always been to do the right thing simply. This endeavor, however, is much more personal after she saw her friend Aidan battle acute myeloid leukemia for half a year in the cancer center. ‚ÄúI tried to relate it to myself and think about how I would have felt in his shoes,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúEven though it can seem so isolating in a hospital, there are so many people who can come together and try to brighten your day, give you the support you need, or even just a toy you want.‚Äù During treatment, Aidan quickly realized he could pay it forward for the younger patients on his floor, too. 4 Since age five, she has been doing charity work and organizing blood and food drives, among other relief efforts for disaster victims. Courtesy Eliza Liebowtiz He became a liaison to Liebowitz and would let her know exactly what other kids wanted to play with. The list included Legos, board games, Ninja Turtles toys and Madlibs. Older pediatric patients could enjoy more age-appropriate gifts, such as video game consoles. The philanthropic teen soon learned what an impact she had. Aidan‚Äôs mother, Randi, who asked the family name not be used, said kids being able to hold onto Barbie dolls and action figures are instrumental. ‚ÄúIt really helps them to feel strong,‚Äù Randi told The Post. ‚ÄúIf they could forget why they are there, even for just a few minutes, that‚Äôs very helpful.‚Äù Liebowitz estimates that she has brought around 300 toys to Memorial Sloan Kettering. ‚ÄúMy heart is full,‚Äù Donna Liebowitz, 55. ‚ÄúI hope this is something Eliza passes down for generations.‚Äù 4 Liebowitz mentioned that another teen in Roslyn is also looking into creating a drive. Instagram / @cleanyourclosetsoutforchildren Inspiring others Aidan received the fantastic news that his cancer went into remission months ago and Randi said he is happily enjoying college life now. Since that time, Liebowitz has rolled along with her ‚ÄúCourage Cart.‚Äù This month, things are taking a new and meaningful turn with new recruits. Liebowitz‚Äôs longtime efforts reached the heart of another classmate, Nathaniel Rubin. He took up a collection and will send over 100 toys to Memorial Sloan Kettering in the coming days. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs very important for me to bring a smile to a child‚Äôs face this holiday season, especially ones in those circumstances,‚Äù Rubin, 17, told The Post. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve been collecting toys all year to do this.‚Äù Liebowitz mentioned that another teen in Roslyn is also looking into creating a drive. She also said this is just the beginning of ‚ÄúCourage Cart.‚Äù The enthusiastic high school junior looks to work with more cancer charities and will launch other missions in Spring 2025. What do you think? Post a comment. For now, though, she‚Äôs taking in the meaningful change already accomplished. ‚ÄúKnowing that other people are getting inspired by what I started, I hope we can keep this going forever,‚Äù Liebowitz said. Those looking to donate can contact Go With Courage or message Liebowitz‚Äôs philanthropic Instagram page, @CleanYourClosetsOutForChildren.
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Left  
The article highlights a charitable initiative by a Long Island teenager to support pediatric cancer patients, promoting an uplifting and community-focused message that aligns with progressive values. It emphasizes the importance of giving back and helping those in need, which is often associated with left-leaning perspectives. The focus on individual stories and community solidarity, without political critique, suggests a gentler, lean left orientation rather than an extreme left bias.

title: Musk-led DOGE sparks ‚Äònew day in America‚Äô energy on Capitol Hill
body: President-elect Donald Trump‚Äôs Department of Government Efficiency was all the buzz Thursday on Capitol Hill, where lawmakers got their first taste of how the Elon Musk-led cost-cutting committee plans to shake up Washington. House Speaker Michael Johnson flashed his excitement by telling reporters that DOGE‚Äôs work marks a ‚Äúnew day in Washington and a new day in America.‚Äù ‚ÄúThis is an important day ‚Äî it is the beginning of a journey,‚Äù the Louisiana Republican said after meeting with Mr. Musk and Vivek Ramaswamy, the Trump allies tasked with weeding out government waste. ‚ÄúLet me be frank about this: Government is too big, it does too many things, and it does almost nothing well.‚Äù That deep-rooted sentiment among fiscal conservatives and small-government advocates feeds the excitement over DOGE‚Äôs potential to upend the big-spending consensus in Washington and usher in an era of accountability. Mr. Musk, with his son Lil X in tow, and Mr. Ramaswamy were given rock star treatment as they made their way through the corridors of Congress, flocked by staff, reporters and security. Social media was littered with Republican lawmakers posing for selfies with Mr. Musk and Mr. Ramaswamy, who met with the chairs of House and Senate committees, the heads of the newly formed bicameral DOGE caucuses, and a larger group of House and Senate Republicans. Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene, the Georgia Republican leading a DOGE subcommittee, said Mr. Musk delivered a crucial message. ‚ÄúHe said something extremely important: Every single payment that the federal government pays out, we need to be checking those payments to see if they are legitimate,‚Äù Ms. Greene told reporters. ‚ÄúThat is something that hasn‚Äôt been done.‚Äù She said Mr. Musk and Mr. Ramaswamy also floated the idea of a ‚Äúnaughty list‚Äù and a ‚Äúnice list‚Äù for lawmakers based on their votes on federal spending. Rep. Aaron Bean, Florida Republican, said Mr. Musk and Mr. Ramaswamy received a standing ovation at their closed-door meeting and that their ‚Äúnaughty list‚Äù idea could have legs. ‚ÄúIf we‚Äôre going to get out of the hole, we have to stop digging, yeah, and so we have to look at ourselves every time we pass a bill that‚Äôs not funded or paid for, we‚Äôre going the wrong way,‚Äù Mr. Bean said. The DOGE commission‚Äôs social media account has been highlighting wasteful and head-scratching ways the government tosses around taxpayer funds. Reports from conservative-leaning groups show that the National Institutes of Health spent $1.8 billion studying racism, including on ‚ÄúPromoting Color Brave Conversations in Families: A Public Health Strategy to Advance Racial Equity,‚Äù and more than $150 billion on illegal immigrants at the federal, state and local levels. They have cited reports from the Government Accountability Office estimating that $100 billion in improper payments were made in the Medicare and Medicaid programs in fiscal year 2023 and the Congressional Budget Office showing Congress allocated $516 billion for programs that had expired under federal law. One report said the Pentagon ‚Äúcan‚Äôt fully account for $824 Billion.‚Äù The jubilance on Capitol Hill belies a tough road ahead to changing Washington‚Äôs spending culture. Federal debt has topped $36 trillion and will soon reach the highest ratio of debt to gross domestic product in history. The previous record was set during World War II when the U.S. defeated two global adversaries and emerged with a strong economy and decreasing deficits. The government is projected to run trillion-dollar deficits for the foreseeable future. The fiscal picture has generated fears that the longer deficits and debt go unaddressed, the more likely the nation will spiral into an economic crisis. It is unclear what authority the new agency will have to implement cost-cutting recommendations. Mr. Musk has suggested that annual government spending cuts should equate to roughly $2 trillion. Another question is how far DOGE will go in tackling the biggest drivers of national spending ‚Äî Social Security, Medicare and Medicaid ‚Äî or whether it will target the Department of Defense, which has failed multiple audits. ‚ÄúThey are looking at everything,‚Äù Mr. Bean said. What is clear is that congressional Republicans and a few Democrats are eager to get involved with DOGE. ‚ÄúThere is a massive amount of waste, fraud and abuse that we have to tackle,‚Äù Ms. Greene said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm looking forward to exposing every single unelected bureaucrat, every single agency that is wasting the American people‚Äôs money, and the big government departments that need to be exposed for how they are not serving the American people.‚Äù Sen. Joni Ernst, an Iowa Republican who recently launched the Senate DOGE caucus, got the conversation rolling Thursday by releasing an ‚ÄúOut of Office‚Äù report highlighting how some federal employees have abused telework policies and turned government buildings into relative ghost towns. Only 6% of the federal workforce goes to the office daily. Ms. Ernst recommended returning federal employees to the workplace or eliminating the federal office buildings that are not being used by selling off properties or ending leases. ‚ÄúUse it or lose it,‚Äù Ms. Ernst said on Fox News.
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Right  
The article presents a favorable view of an initiative led by Elon Musk aimed at government efficiency, highlighting support from Republican lawmakers while criticizing perceived government waste and inefficiency. Such framing aligns with a conservative fiscal agenda, indicating a preference for small government and accountability. The focus on quotes from Republican figures and the emphasis on government spending issues further reflect a lean toward a right-leaning perspective.

title: GOP senator suggests Hegseth wasn‚Äôt an adult 7 years ago: 'It doesn‚Äôt matter'
body: US Senator Markwayne Mullin (R-OK) suggested on Wednesday that Donald Trump defense secretary pick Pete Hegseth was not an adult seven years ago ‚Äî although the MAGA nominee was 37 years old. Associated Press congressional reporter Farnoush Amiri wrote via X: "Asked Sen. Mullin if Hegseth gave members assurances following reports of excessive drinking: 'Listen, all of us, at least all of us, have a time to grow up. We‚Äôre nominating Pete for who he is today not for what he did seven years ago or five years ago or whatever it was.'" Amiri then noted, "I followed up that not all of us are trying to become Secretary of Defense and he said: 'It doesn‚Äôt matter we all have a period of time where you got to grow up. So it's what he can do today moving forward.'" READ MORE: Pete Hegseth‚Äôs mom urges 'female senators' to ignore media reports and confirm him as SecDef The New Yorker reported on Monday that Hegseth had a reputation of drinking on the job in a previous role. A new report NBC News published on Wednesday noted that the right-wing host's Fox News co-workers say Hegseth "was known for showing up to work with alcohol on his breath and dealing with hangovers." One source told NBC that the Trump pick "smelled like alcohol and talked about being hung over as recently as this fall." While some Republican lawmakers ‚Äî like Senators Joni Ernst (R-IA) and Susan Collins (R-ME) ‚Äî are skeptical of confirming Hegseth, others, like Mullin and Senator Kevin Cramer (R-ND) don't see a problem with the allegations. READ MORE: 'Standards have evolved': Senator 'leaning yes' on Hegseth despite misconduct allegations
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Right  
This article features critique and skepticism towards a Trump nominee, accompanied by quotes from Republican senators defending him. However, the framing revolves around defending Hegseth while also acknowledging allegations against him. The language used tends to favor a more conservative viewpoint, aligning with the notion of overlooking past behavior in favor of current capabilities, which is often seen in lean right narratives. The lack of deeper investigation or emphasis on accountability suggests a lean towards a conservative defense of the GOP candidate.

title: US 'Concerned' by Report of Russian Interference in NATO Ally's Election
body: The U.S. has voiced concern over Romania's presidential election after declassified documents showed the NATO member was the target of "aggressive hybrid Russian attacks," according to Reuters.Romania, an Eastern European country that shares a border with Ukraine, held the first round of its presidential election on November 24, where the pro-Russia candidate Calin Georgescu secured victory after previously receiving only single digits in the polls.According to Politico, the Romanian Intelligence Service report, released on Wednesday, found that Georgescu's election campaign on TikTok gained enormous momentum in just two weeks before the election.This was through coordinated accounts, recommendation algorithms and paid promotion, according to Reuters. Calin Georgescu, the independent candidate for presidency who won the first round of presidential elections, speaks after an interview with the Associated Press in Izvorani, Romania, Wednesday, December 4, 2024. The U.S. has voiced its... Calin Georgescu, the independent candidate for presidency who won the first round of presidential elections, speaks after an interview with the Associated Press in Izvorani, Romania, Wednesday, December 4, 2024. The U.S. has voiced its concern over Romania's presidential elections after a Romanian security council shared declassified documents showing Romania had been targeted by Russian hybrid attacks. More Vadim Ghirda)/AP The reports also identified more than 85,000 cyberattacks seeking to exploit vulnerabilities in Romania's election IT system, while obtaining access to data and changing content, Politico reported.The log-in details for Romanian election-related websites were also found to have been posted on a Russian-based cybercrime platform.Newsweek has contacted the President of Romania's office, the White House and the Russian government's press office via email for comment.The U.S. state department released a statement saying, "We are concerned by the Romanian Supreme Council for National Defense (CSAT)'s report of Russian involvement in malign cyber activity designed to influence the integrity of the Romanian electoral process. Data referenced in the report should be fully investigated to ensure the integrity of Romania's electoral process."State department spokesperson Matthew Miller also added that Romania's position in NATO "cannot be turned back by foreign actors seeking to shift Romania's foreign policy away from its Western alliances.""Any such change would have serious negative impacts on U.S. security cooperation with Romania, while a decision to restrict foreign investment would discourage U.S. companies from continuing to invest in Romania," the statement said. Read more Romania Blinken, Russian Foreign Minister Trade Accusations at Security Meeting NATO Chief Pleas for Europe to Boost Defense Spending Ahead of Trump Era TikTok Defends Election Role in Romania Amid EU Allegations of Meddling Putin Ally Calls Zelensky 'An Illegitimate Drug Addict' Georgescu has previously said he would stop the aid given to Ukraine by Romania for its war effort against the Russia and in an interview in 2018, he called Russian President Vladimir Putin one of the few politicians in the world who is a "true leader," The Week reported.The presidential candidate has also been highly critical of NATO, deeming it the "world's weakest alliance" only last week, according to Radio Free Europe.He has also criticized the European Union in the past, according to Politico.However, per the Radio Free Europe report, last week Georgescu said, "I do not want out of NATO, I do not want out of the European Union.""But I do want us to stand firm, not to kneel there, not to accept everything, to do everything in our national interest," he added.Georgescu also dismissed the declassified documents in a TV interview on Wednesday, saying that the proceedings were a "massive desperation of the system," Romanian news channel Realitatea TV reported."Don't please them, don't fall into their game," he said.As no candidate achieved a majority in the first round, the Romanian people will vote again in a runoff election on December 8, which will be between Georgescu and pro-Europe candidate Elena Lasconi.Do you have a story Newsweek should be covering? Do you have any questions about this story? Contact LiveNews@newsweek.com.
Ai bias and explanation:
Center  
The article presents factual information about U.S. concerns regarding Russian interference in Romania's presidential election without apparent bias toward a particular political ideology. It reports on the events and quotes various sources, allowing readers to form their own opinions while emphasizing the U.S. government's official stance. The inclusion of different perspectives regarding the candidates, including pro-Russian sentiments, indicates an effort to provide a balanced view of the situation.

title: Trump Says Defense Nominee Hegseth a 'Winner'
body: President-elect Donald Trump says Pete Hegseth "is a winner" who has received "strong and deep" support despite mainstream media reports the defense secretary nominee faces an uphill battle to be confirmed by the Senate. According to media reports this week, Hegseth's nomination is in jeopardy due to allegations about his personal and professional life. It even was reported that Trump had zeroed in on several potential candidates to replace the Army veteran and TV personality. Trump on Friday said he is sticking with Hegseth. "Pete Hegseth is doing very well. His support is strong and deep, much more so than the Fake News would have you believe," Trump posted on Truth Social. "He was a great student ‚Äì Princeton/Harvard educated ‚Äì with a Military state of mind. He will be a fantastic, high energy, Secretary of Defense, one who leads with charisma and skill. Pete is a WINNER, and there is nothing that can be done to change that!!!" Also on Friday, The Guardian reported that Trump aides have told the president-elect's transition team that they haven't found three Republican senators who are "categorically opposed" to Hegseth's confirmation. Hegseth has been meeting with senators this week in efforts to secure confirmation votes amid allegations of sexual assault and a problematic drinking habit. At the Capitol on Wednesday, Hegseth said he spoke with Trump, who encouraged him to "keep going, keep fighting." Hegseth wrote a Wednesday opinion column for The Wall Street Journal to ostensibly set the record straight and to fight against a "manufactured media takedown." "I look forward to an honest confirmation hearing with our distinguished senators ‚Äî not a show trial in the press," he wrote. It was reported this week that Trump was considering replacing Hegseth with Florida GOP Gov. Ron DeSantis. Sen. Joni Ernst, R-Iowa, a veteran who also has been mentioned as a possible defense secretary nominee, signaled Thursday that she isn't ready to support Hegseth, Politico reported. Charlie McCarthy ‚úâ Charlie McCarthy, a writer/editor at Newsmax, has nearly 40 years of experience covering news, sports, and politics.
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Right  
The article presents a supportive view of Trump's nominee Pete Hegseth, emphasizing Trump's strong endorsement and downplaying media doubts about Hegseth‚Äôs confirmation. The use of phrases like "Fake News" aligns with a right-leaning media perspective that favors Trump's narrative while criticizing mainstream media. Although it reports on skepticism regarding Hegseth's nomination, the overall tone remains favorable towards Trump and his choices, indicative of a lean towards right-wing viewpoints.

title: Why Trump and the Federal Reserve could clash in the coming years
body: WASHINGTON (AP) ‚Äî President-elect Donald Trump campaigned on the promise that his policies would reduce high borrowing costs and lighten the financial burden on American households. WASHINGTON (AP) ‚Äî President-elect Donald Trump campaigned on the promise that his policies would reduce high borrowing costs and lighten the financial burden on American households. But what if, as many economists expect, interest rates remain elevated, well above their pre-pandemic lows? Trump could point a finger at the Federal Reserve, and in particular at its chair, Jerome Powell, whom Trump himself nominated to lead the Fed. During his first term, Trump repeatedly and publicly ridiculed the Powell Fed, complaining that it kept interest rates too high. Trump‚Äôs attacks on the Fed raised widespread concern about political interference in the Fed‚Äôs policymaking. On Wednesday, Powell emphasized the importance of the Fed‚Äôs independence: ‚ÄúThat gives us the ability to make decisions for the benefit of all Americans at all times, not for any particular political party or political outcome.‚Äù Political clashes might be inevitable in the next four years. Trump‚Äôs proposals to cut taxes and impose steep and widespread tariffs are a recipe for high inflation in an economy operating at close to full capacity. And if inflation were to reaccelerate, the Fed would need to keep interest rates high. Because Powell won‚Äôt necessarily cut rates as much as Trump will want. And even if Powell reduces the Fed‚Äôs benchmark rate, Trump‚Äôs own policies could keep other borrowing costs ‚Äî like mortgage rates ‚Äî elevated. The sharply higher tariffs that Trump has vowed to impose could worsen inflation. And if tax cuts on things like tips and overtime pay ‚Äî another Trump promise ‚Äî quickened economic growth, that, too, could fan inflationary pressures. The Fed would likely respond by slowing or stopping its rate cuts, thereby thwarting Trump‚Äôs promises of lower borrowing rates. The central bank might even raise rates if inflation worsened. ‚ÄúThe risk of conflict between the Trump administration and the Fed is very high,‚Äù Olivier Blanchard, former top economist at the International Monetary Fund, said recently. If the Fed hikes rates, ‚Äúit will stand in the way of what the Trump administration wants.‚Äù Yes, but with the economy sturdier than expected, the Fed‚Äôs policymakers may cut rates only a few more times ‚Äî fewer than had been anticipated just a month or two ago. And those rate cuts might not reduce borrowing costs for consumers and businesses very much. The Fed‚Äôs key short-term rate can influence rates for credit cards, small businesses and some other loans. But it has no direct control over longer-term interest rates. These include the yield on the 10-year Treasury note, which affects mortgage rates. The 10-year Treasury yield is shaped by investors‚Äô expectations of future inflation, economic growth and interest rates as well as by supply and demand for Treasuries. An example occurred this year. The 10-year yield fell in late summer in anticipation of a Fed rate cut. Yet once the first rate cut occurred on Sept. 18, longer term rates didn‚Äôt fall. Instead, they began to rise again, partly in anticipation of faster economic growth. Trump has also proposed a variety of tax cuts that could swell the deficit. Rates on Treasury securities might then have to rise to attract enough investors to buy the new debt. ‚ÄúI honestly don‚Äôt think the Fed has a lot of control over the 10-year rate, which is probably the most important for mortgages,‚Äù said Kent Smetters, an economist and faculty director at the Penn Wharton Budget Model. ‚ÄúDeficits are going to play a much bigger role in that regard.‚Äù Occasional or rare criticism of the Fed chair isn‚Äôt necessarily a problem for the economy, so long as the central bank continues to set policy as it sees fit. But persistent attacks would tend to undermine the Fed‚Äôs political independence, which is critically important to keeping inflation in check. To fight inflation, a central bank often must take steps that can be highly unpopular, notably by raising interest rates to slow borrowing and spending. Political leaders have typically wanted central banks to do the opposite: Keep rates low to support the economy and the job market, especially before an election. Research has found that countries with independent central banks generally enjoy lower inflation. Even if Trump doesn‚Äôt technically force the Fed to do anything, his persistent criticism could still cause problems. If markets, economists and business leaders no longer think the Fed is operating independently and instead is being pushed around by the president, they‚Äôll lose confidence in the Fed‚Äôs ability to control inflation. And once consumers and businesses anticipate higher inflation, they usually act in ways that fuel higher prices ‚Äî accelerating their purchases, for example, before prices rise further, or raising their own prices if they expect their expenses to increase. ‚ÄúThe markets need to feel confident that the Fed is responding to the data, not to political pressure,‚Äù said Scott Alvarez, a former general counsel at the Fed. He can try, but it would likely lead to a prolonged legal battle that could even end up at the Supreme Court. At a November news conference, Powell made clear that he believes the president doesn‚Äôt have legal authority to do so. Most experts think Powell would prevail in the courts. And from the Trump administration‚Äôs perspective, such a fight might not be worth it. Powell‚Äôs term ends in May 2026, when the White House could nominate a new chair. It is also likely that the stock market would tumble if Trump attempted such a brazen move. Bond yields would probably rise, too, sending mortgage rates and other borrowing costs up. Financial markets might also react negatively if Trump is seen as appointing a loyalist as Fed chair to replace Powell in 2026. Yes, and in the most egregious cases, it led to stubbornly high inflation. Notably, President Richard Nixon pressured Fed Chair Arthur Burns to reduce interest rates in 1971, as Nixon sought re-election next year, which the Fed did. Economists blame Burns‚Äô failure to keep rates sufficiently high for contributing to the entrenched inflation of the 1970s and early 1980s. Thomas Drechsel, an economist at the University of Maryland, said that when presidents intrude on the Fed‚Äôs interest rate decisions, ‚Äúit increases prices quite consistently and it increases expectations, and ... that worries me because that means inflation might become quite entrenched.‚Äù Since the mid-1980s, with the exception of Trump in his first term, presidents have scrupulously refrained from public criticism of the Fed. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs amazing, how little manipulation for partisan ends we have seen of that policymaking apparatus,‚Äù said Peter Conti-Brown, a professor of financial regulation at the University of Pennsylvania‚Äôs Wharton School. ‚ÄúIt really is a triumph of American governance.‚Äù Yes, most advanced economies do. But in some recent cases, as in Turkey and South Africa, governments have sought to dictate interest-rate policy to the central bank. And soaring inflation has typically followed. Turkey‚Äôs president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, for years pressured the country‚Äôs central bank to cut interest rates even as prices spiked. He even fired three central bankers who had refused to comply. In response, inflation skyrocketed to 72% in 2022, according to official measures. Last year, Erdogan finally reversed course and allowed the central bank to raise rates.
Ai bias and explanation:
Center  
This article presents an analysis of potential conflicts between Donald Trump and the Federal Reserve without displaying overt bias towards either side. It discusses Trump's economic policies and the implications for interest rates while also emphasizing the importance of the Fed‚Äôs independence. The article cites multiple economists, providing a balanced view of the economic situation and each party's role. The language used is neutral, and the article avoids emotional or dramatic language, focusing instead on factual reporting and expert opinions.

title: Pete Hegseth's mother defends son, saying she wrote email "out of love" that called him "abuser of women"
body: The mother of Pete Hegseth, President-elect Donald Trump's embattled pick for defense secretary, defended her son Wednesday morning in an appearance on Fox News, following reporting on an email she sent to her son years earlier accusing him of being an "abuser of women." Penelope Hegseth, appearing on "Fox & Friends" Wednesday morning, said her son and his wife at the time were going through a "very difficult divorce" when she wrote the email in 2018, noting that she wrote it "in haste" and with "deep emotions." "I wrote that out of love," she said. "And about two hours later, I retracted it with an apology email, but nobody's seen that." Hegseth's mother said in the email, published by The New York Times, that she was writing on "behalf of all the women (and I know it's many) you have abused in some way," telling her son to "get some help and take an honest look at yourself." But Hegseth's mother said she was appearing Wednesday on Fox to "tell the truth" to the American people, and to Republican senators on the hill ‚Äî "especially our female senators." Hegseth, a former "Fox & Friends" weekend co-host, has been meeting with Republican senators on Capitol Hill this week and before the Thanksgiving recess, looking to secure support as the chamber prepares to work on the confirmation of Trump intended Cabinet and administration nominees early next year. Meanwhile, Hegseth has faced allegations in a number of negative stories published in recent days of sexual misconduct, financial mismanagement at veterans' charities, repeated intoxication and infidelity. Hegseth has denied the allegations. Hegseth's mother encouraged the senators to "listen to Pete," noting that part of the reason she appeared on Fox was to "discredit the media." She added that she called Fox on Tuesday saying she wanted to speak out on the issue, noting that "I would do anything for my son." Trump selected the 44-year-old Army veteran who served in Iraq and Afghanistan for the top Pentagon post last month. Since then, he's faced intense scrutiny, and amid the scrutiny, Trump is considering selecting Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis as his pick for defense secretary to potentially replace embattled Hegseth, three sources familiar with the transition told CBS News on Tuesday night. Hegseth insisted on Wednesday that he would not be withdrawing his name from consideration. He wouldn't be the first Trump nominee to withdraw: Former Rep. Matt Gaetz, initially Trump's pick to be attorney general, dropped out of consideration just days after he was tapped for the role. "Why would I back down?" Hegseth told CBS News. "I've always been a fighter. I'm here for the fighters. This is personal and passionate for me." Hegseth's mother repeatedly defended her son during the appearance on Wednesday, saying he has changed and noting that "if we all went back seven years, we would see that maybe we are not the people we are today." Hegseth's mother thanked Trump for his "belief" in her son. "Trump knows Pete," she said. "And he knows the Pete of today." Nikole Killion contributed to this report.
Ai bias and explanation:
Center  
This article reports on Pete Hegseth's defense, including his mother's statements and the context of her email without emphasizing a particular political ideology. It provides factual recounting of events, offers multiple perspectives, and mentions both supportive and critical views without skewing toward either side. The language is neutral, and it does not exhibit overt bias toward left or right political viewpoints, maintaining an objective tone throughout.

title: Trump to Appear on NBC‚Äôs ‚ÄòMeet the Press,‚Äô First Network Interview Since Election
body: President-elect Donald Trump will be interviewed on NBC‚Äôs ‚ÄúMeet the Press‚Äù‚Äîhis first network interview since he won the Nov. 5 election, the outlet announced on Dec. 4.The interview will air this Sunday, Dec. 8, said the network, which added that portions of the interview will air ahead of the broadcast. The program airs at 10:30 a.m. ET.‚ÄúMeet the Press‚Äù host Kristen Welker last interviewed Trump in September 2023, when the presidential candidate said, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt consider us to have much of a democracy right now.‚Äù The interview, which was his only one with a network during the 2024 election cycle, attracted 12 million views on YouTube. Story continues below advertisement The days and weeks before Election Day were marked by numerous media appearances from the Republican candidate, including on podcasts and other programs watched by many younger Americans such as Adin Ross‚Äôs stream.Trump was a guest on ‚ÄúThe Joe Rogan Experience‚Äù on Oct. 25. On Nov. 4, the day before Election Day, Rogan endorsed Trump in an X post featuring a podcast with Elon Musk.Since the election, however, the president-elect‚Äôs sole interview has been with Fox News Digital.Related StoriesTrump Makes Raft of Administration Selections12/4/2024UnitedHealthcare CEO Fatally Shot in Targeted Attack, Manhunt Underway; Trump Asks Court to Dismiss Georgia Election Case12/4/2024‚ÄúIn order to Make America Great Again, it is very important, if not vital, to have a free, fair and open media or press,‚Äù Trump said during that interview.Over the years, Trump has appeared several times on ‚ÄúMeet the Press,‚Äù a program he once nicknamed ‚ÄúMeet the Depressed.‚Äù Story continues below advertisement In a 2016 appearance before he was first elected president, Trump defended his speech at that year‚Äôs Republican National Convention, which some in the media characterized as negative.‚ÄúSure, I talk about the problems, but we‚Äôre going to solve the problems,‚Äù he told NBC‚Äôs Chuck Todd.During an interview on the program in 2023, Trump spoke about the possibility of President Joe Biden pardoning his son, Hunter Biden. The younger Biden received a pardon for his convictions on gun- and tax-related charges in addition to sparing him from being charged for any of his actions spanning the decade from Jan. 1, 2014, to Dec. 1, 2024.Trump also said he would consider pardoning those convicted as a result of participating in the ‚ÄúStop the Steal‚Äù rally and protest at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021.Since the election, Trump has named all of his Cabinet nominees and key selections for other senior administration posts. He is expected to have a full agenda on his first day in office. The first hours of the new Trump presidency include executive orders related to illegal immigration, tariffs, energy, as well as ‚Äúdiversity, equity, and inclusion‚Äù initiatives in the U.S. government.
Ai bias and explanation:
Center  
The article presents straightforward information regarding Donald Trump's upcoming interview on NBC without any strong opinions or emotionally charged language. It includes factual reporting on previous appearances by Trump and mentions relevant details like viewership numbers and quotes from Trump. The tone remains neutral and informative, which aligns it with a center classification, avoiding clear bias towards either political side.

title: Trump agrees to DOJ background checks on administration nominees, appointments
body: President-elect Donald Trump‚Äôs transition team said Tuesday that it reached an agreement with the Department of Justice that sets the stage for the department to conduct background checks and start the security clearance process for Trump administration nominees and appointees. The agreement comes amid controversy over some of Trump‚Äôs picks for top positions in the government, including the leadership of the Defense Department, the Department of Health and Human Services, the FBI, and the post of director of national intelligence. An agreement to have the FBI, which is a division of the DOJ, conduct background checks on nominees and appointees could make some U.S. senators more comfortable voting to approve Trump‚Äôs selections for such posts than they would be without such a deal. Susie Wiles, the incoming White House chief of staff, in a statement, said, ‚ÄúThe agreement with the Department of Justice will ensure President Trump and his team are ready on Day 1 to begin enacting the America First Agenda that an overwhelming majority of our nation supported on Election Day.‚Äù The Trump transition team said its memorandum of understanding with the DOJ ‚Äúallows the transition team to submit names for background checks and security clearances.‚Äù ‚ÄúUltimately, this will afford the transition process additional insights, and it facilitates our agency landing teams gaining access to the information they need to prepare for leadership of the federal agencies and departments,‚Äù the transition team said in a statement. The MOU was announced a day after an article in The New Yorker detailed allegations of alcohol abuse, sexual impropriety and mismanagement of two non-profit veterans groups by Pete Hegseth, who Trump has tapped to become the next Defense secretary. Shortly after Trump announced his planned nomination of Hegseth, news broke that the former Fox News anchor had been investigated by police, but not criminally charged, for an alleged sexual assault of a woman at a Republican event in California in 2017. Hegseth has denied any wrongdoing. Trump initial pick for U.S. attorney general, Matt Gaetz, dropped out of contention on Nov. 21 after renewed focus on allegations the former Florida congressman had sex with a girl when she was just 17 years in 2017. Gaetz also denies any wrongdoing. Over the weekend, Trump said he would appoint his long-time loyalist Kash Patel as director of the FBI. Patel last year vowed to target judges, lawyers and journalists who he believed were politically motivated in investigating Trump. ‚ÄúWhether it‚Äôs criminally or civilly, we‚Äôre going to figure that out ‚Äî but yeah, we‚Äôre putting you all on notice,‚Äù Patel told former Trump White House aide Steve Bannon in an interview. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre actually going to use the Constitution to prosecute them for crimes they said we have always been guilty of but never have.‚Äù Trump‚Äôs selection of former Hawaii congresswoman Tulsi Gabbard as director of national intelligence is another controversial pick. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no question I consider her someone who is likely a Russian asset,‚Äù Rep. Debbie Wasserman Shultz, D-Fla., told MSNBC, referring to Gabbard, who would oversee 18 U.S. intelligence agencies as DNI if confirmed by the Senate. The vaccine skeptic and conspiracy promoter Robert F. Kennedy Jr., who Trump has picked to become secretary of HHS, was a heroin user for years as a teen and young adult. Democratic senators have been especially insistent that background checks are needed for all of Trump‚Äôs nominees before they can be considered for confirmation by the Senate. Speaking Tuesday to NBC News, Democratic Sen. John Fetterman of Pennsylvania said Hegseth‚Äôs nomination was part of an ‚Äúongoing dialog‚Äù among senators about Trump nominees. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs really appropriate, though, to have FBI background checks‚Äù to help illuminate the allegations against Hegseth, Fetterman said. ‚ÄúMy God, you know if you‚Äôre going to be in charge of the most lethal organization in the history of humanity ... it would be entirely appropriate too to have a complete background FBI for all of that,‚Äù the senator said. The incoming Republican chair of the Senate Armed Services Committee, which would conduct Hegseth‚Äôs confirmation hearing, said Tuesday that some members of his party have concerns about Hegseth. ‚ÄúThere are questions that some members have, and we‚Äôre going to be looking for an answer,‚Äù Sen. Roger Wicker, R-Miss., told NBC News. - Additional reporting by CNBC‚Äôs Christina Wilkie
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Right  
The article presents information largely favorable to Trump and his administration, highlighting his transition team's agreements and responses to controversies, while including concerns raised by Democrats in a less prominent manner. The language used tends to lean towards a sympathetic portrayal of Trump's actions, indicating a preference for right-leaning perspectives. The inclusion of opposition voices is balanced but serves to highlight the overall positive framing of Trump's decisions.

title: Secret Service Director To Promise ‚ÄòAccountability‚Äô Over ‚ÄòAbject Failure‚Äô At Butler¬†Rally
body: Acting Secret Service Director Ronald Rowe is set to testify Thursday morning before a House task force investigating the attempted assassination of President-elect Donald Trump during a campaign rally in Pennsylvania.Rowe will be questioned by a 13-member independent panel that released a report in October finding the Secret Service responsible for the ‚Äúpreventable‚Äù attempt on Trump‚Äôs life. Rowe is expected to tell lawmakers that disciplinary actions are being taken for the lapses that allowed 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks to get within 150 yards of Trump and shoot him in the ear during a rally in Butler on July 13.‚ÄúEmployees receiving proposals of discipline will be provided due process under agency policy as well as any applicable laws and regulations. But, let me be clear, there will be accountability, and that accountability is occurring,‚Äù Rowe will say, according to a copy of his prepared remarks shared with ABC. ‚ÄúConsistent with applicable laws and regulations, I cannot comment further on specific disciplinary actions underway or being considered.‚ÄùRowe will also say that the agency has made several major changes to securing locations, including more coordination with law enforcement partners. At the Butler rally, numerous communication errors delayed law enforcement‚Äôs response to Crooks, who had been identified as a person of interest more than an hour before he opened fire. ‚ÄúMy goal is to improve our mission effectiveness and rebuild public trust,‚Äù according to Rowe‚Äôs written testimony. ‚ÄúOne of the key systemic changes was the directive to mandate a unified command in a singular location for all protective sites, something that was not done on July 13th in Butler. This co-location enhances our communications and intelligence-sharing mechanisms with state, local and federal partners to better anticipate threats and respond to them more swiftly.‚ÄùAdvertisementOther changes implemented, according to a copy of his remarks shared with Fox News, included using more drones, ensuring radios are in order, and increasing staffing levels for agents protecting Trump.CHECK OUT THE DAILY WIRE HOLIDAY GIFT GUIDERowe‚Äôs prepared testimony says the Butler rally, where Trump was shot, supporter Corey Comperatore was killed, and two other rallygoers were injured, exposed ‚Äúcritical gaps‚Äù in the Secret Service‚Äôs operations and was an ‚Äúabject failure.‚Äù Advertisement‚ÄúJuly 13th was a failure of the Secret Service to adequately secure the Butler Farm Show site and protect President-elect Trump,‚Äù Rowe is expected to say. ‚ÄúWhile I cannot undo the harm that has been done, I am committed to doing everything in my power to ensure that the Secret Service never has a failure like this again.‚ÄùIn its report, the House panel faulted the Secret Service for failing to secure the roof from where Crooks fired at Trump and setting up a security perimeter that allowed people to get within around 150 yards of the stage where Trump was speaking without going through security screening. Investigations by both the Senate and an independent panel formed by Homeland Security Secretary Alejandro Mayorkas have also found the Secret Service liable for the attack. Advertisement
Ai bias and explanation:
Center  
This article provides information about the testimony of the Secret Service Director regarding a security failure during a Trump rally, without showing a clear political lean. It reports facts and quotes from officials while discussing accountability and improvements in security protocols. The focus is on the investigation itself and its findings rather than expressing support or opposition to any political ideology or party.

title: Explosive exchange about 9/11 happens at Secret Service hearing
body: Acting Secret Service Director Ronald Rowe and Republican Texas Congressman Pat Fallon got into a screaming match Thursday at a House panel investigating the assassination attempt against President-elect Donald Trump. Fallon yelled about Rowe's attendance at the 9/11 memorial. He accused Rowe of putting the President's Secret Service detail out of position so he could sit behind him during the 9/11 remembrance ceremony. "Congressman, what you're not seeing is the [lack] of the detail off out of the picture's view. And that is the day where we remember more than 3,000 people that have died on 9/11," Rowe said Thursday. "I actually responded to Ground Zero. I was there going through the ashes of the World Trade Center. I was there at Fresh Kills." Fallon yelled at Rowe, asking if he was the special agent in charge. "I was there to show respect for members that died on 9/11," Rowe yelled back his finger pointing at Fallon. "Do not invoke 9/11 for political purposes," Rowe shouted. "Oh I am not," Fallon responded. "You are sir," Rowe yelled back. "And you are out of line!" "I am an elected member of Congress, and I'm asking you a serious question," Fallon said. "I am a public servant who has served," Rowe yelled back. Fallon accused the acting director of putting the life of the vice president in jeopardy to audition for the job. Earlier, Rowe told the House panel investigating the assassination attempt there is a heightened threat environment, and the Secret Service has already made changes to ensure the assassination attempt doesn't happen again.
Ai bias and explanation:
Center  
The article reports a heated exchange between a Republican congressman and the acting Secret Service director regarding a serious event (the 9/11 memorial) without exhibiting clear ideological bias toward any political party. The focus is on the confrontation and relevant facts surrounding it, making it informational rather than opinionated.

title: Tsunami warning sparks panic along West Coast after 7.0-magnitude earthquake ‚Äî before being canceled
body: A tsunami warning stretching across swaths of the West Coast has been lifted after sparking panic and prompting evacuations. The official warning ‚Äî the National Weather Service‚Äôs most severe advisory ‚Äî was issued after a 7.0-magnitude earthquake shook off the coast of Northern California, near the city of Eureka, at 10:44 a.m. local time Thursday. At least 5.3 million people in California were under the warning, which covered over 500 miles of coastline from Oregon to the San Francisco Bay Area. Many were urged to evacuate or move to higher ground on short notice over fears that a dangerous surge of water would strike just after noon local time. The quake struck off the coast of California on Thursday morning. USGS Sirens wailed across several counties, phones lit up with warnings, beaches were cleared, students were let out of school, the train tunnel connecting San Francisco to Oakland was shut down, and residents hastened to the roadways. 1/1 Skip Ad Continue watchingafter the adVisit Advertiser websiteGO TO PAGEBut just before the wave was supposed to strike, officials lifted the warning, allowing Californians to breathe a sigh of relief. Start and end your day informed with our newsletters Morning Report and Evening Update: Your source for today's top stories Thanks for signing up! Enter your email address Please provide a valid email address. By clicking above you agree to the Terms of Use and Privacy Policy. Never miss a story. Check out more newsletters ‚ÄúIt was a strong quake, our building shook, we‚Äôre fine but I have a mess to clean up right now,‚Äù said Julie Kreitzer, who owns a market near the quake‚Äôs epicenter in the heart of the warning zone. Her building was undamaged ‚Äî none have been reported severely affected so far ‚Äî but its interior was trashed by the shaking. ‚ÄúWe lost a lot of stuff. It‚Äôs probably worse than two years ago. I have to go, I have to try and salvage something for the holidays because it‚Äôs going to be a tough year,‚Äù she said. The tsunami warning included San Francisco. USGS The shocks were felt as far south as San Francisco, where they continued for several seconds. At a middle school near the epicenter in Eureka, lights swayed overhead and students sheltered under their desks. ‚ÄúThe kids were so great and terrified. It seemed to go back and forth for quite a long time,‚Äù said Eureka Mayor Kim Bergel, who also works at the middle school. Not everybody heeded the warnings, however. In Pacifica ‚Äî just south of San Francisco ‚Äî some surfers were spotted flouting advisories and recklessly heading straight for the coastline. They stood watching the waves as friends snapped photos of the scene. Explore More Powerful 6.0 magnitude earthquake rocks the coast of Oregon NJ once had huge volcano in same county where new fault line resides Newly discovered fault line blamed for intensity of last April‚Äôs Big Apple quake ‚Äîand could be concerning future threat Aftershocks continue to be felt across the region, which is a normal occurrence whenever earthquakes strike. The Golden State caught a lucky break with this quake ‚Äî events that register 7.0 and up on the Richter scale are considered especially dangerous. 200What do you think? Post a comment. San Francisco‚Äôs devastating 1906 quake, which killed 3,000, clocked in at 7.9. Seismology experts have been cautioning for years that California ‚Äî which is bisected by the volatile San Andreas Fault Line ‚Äî is overdue for ‚Äúthe big one,‚Äù a quake which could bring about devastation similar to the 1906 disaster. With Post wires
Ai bias and explanation:
Center  
The article presents a factual account of a tsunami warning triggered by a significant earthquake without displaying particular political leanings or biases. It focuses on the events and reactions of local residents while providing necessary context about the earthquake's potential dangers. The tone remains neutral and informative, avoiding sensationalism or subjective interpretations, which aligns it with a centrist perspective.

title: The Tulsi Gabbard Smears Are Unfounded, Unfair, and Unhelpful
body: If one read only the legacy press and listened to Democrats, one would think that president-elect Donald Trump has just nominated a Kremlin stooge to oversee America‚Äôs intelligence community.Trump‚Äôs choice to be his director of national intelligence, Tulsi Gabbard, a former Democratic congresswoman, has been tarred as ‚Äúlikely a Russian asset‚Äù by Rep. Debbie Wasserman Schultz (D-FL). The New York Times last week devoted a feature-length story to how Gabbard has become a ‚Äúfavorite of Russia‚Äôs state media.‚Äù Hillary Clinton once claimed Moscow was ‚Äúgrooming‚Äù her to run for president. Former congressman Adam Kinzinger, writing in The Bulwark, called her ‚Äúoutright disloyal.‚Äù Gabbard certainly has very different views than Clinton and Kinzinger on foreign policy and the intelligence community. But her neutrality on Ukraine‚Äôs war for survival and her openness to diplomacy with despots also places her out of step with the mainstream of the Republican majority (not to mention most Democrats) in the Senate. She will have some explaining to do in her nomination hearing.I happen to think Gabbard is far too credulous when it comes to some of the world‚Äôs most despicable tyrants. Her past remarks about Russia‚Äôs invasion of Ukraine were horrendous. Consider her video message from February 27, 2022, three days after Russia unilaterally invaded Ukraine. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs time to put geopolitics aside and embrace the spirit of aloha, respect and love, for the Ukrainian people by coming to an agreement that Ukraine will be a neutral country.‚ÄùShe uttered those words when Ukraine was at risk of extinguishment by the Russian army. There was no room for both sides at that moment. The Ukrainians were the victims; the Russians were the aggressors. And yet Gabbard believed Russia should be rewarded by preemptively closing off Ukraine‚Äôs prospect of joining NATO‚Äôs defensive alliance, even after the country had historically been invaded and starved by its powerful neighbor. No thanks. This post is for paying subscribers only Subscribe now Already have an account? Sign in
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Left  
The article critiques the portrayal of Tulsi Gabbard by establishment Democrats and mainstream media, primarily focusing on her perceived alignment with Russian interests. The language used exhibits a tendency to favor left-leaning perspectives, particularly in its disapproval of Gabbard's positions. However, it also contains criticisms against her that could resonate with some centrist audiences, indicating a slight leaning left rather than a purely leftist stance.

title: It‚Äôs Time for the Government to Abolish ‚ÄòRace‚Äô
body: Since 1976, the U.S. Census has been forbidden by law to ask Americans about their religious identity. And yet it is allowed to ask Americans about their racial identity. To make matters worse, instead of relying on self-identification for ethnicity and race, the federal government insists that every American choose an identity from a small set of official ‚Äúraces‚Äù approved by. . . the Office of Management and Budget (OMB).Yes, you read that right. The bureaucracy that assigns Americans to this or that official ‚Äúrace‚Äù in the twenty-first-century U.S. version of the Nuremberg Laws is OMB. According to USA.gov, ‚ÄúThe Office of Management and Budget (OMB) oversees the performance of federal agencies, and administers the federal budget.‚ÄùWhy is OMB given the task of formulating the number of ‚Äúraces‚Äù into which the American population is supposed to be divided? For the answer, we must go back to the aftermath of the civil rights revolution of the 1960s, which struck down racial segregation in employment, voting, housing, and other areas. Having outlawed Jim Crow, the civil rights movement then split into a color-blind liberal wing led by Bayard Rustin and others, who argued that the next step should be race-neutral economic reform, and a color-conscious wing, associated with black radicals, who demanded racial quotas in hiring and university admissions and black-majority congressional districts. The color-blind liberals lost the argument.Radical Chicano activists like those of the Mexican American Legal Defense and Education Fund (MALDEF) jumped on the racial-preferences bandwagon and argued for the recognition of a pan-Hispanic ‚Äúrace‚Äù whose members would be eligible for race-based affirmative action like blacks. Some ‚Äúwhite ethnics‚Äù like Irish Americans and Italian Americans argued unsuccessfully that they, too, should be included in affirmative action, because their groups had been discriminated against by Anglo American Protestants for generations.To forestall conflicting and arbitrary racial and ethnic classifications, Caspar Weinberger, secretary of health, education, and welfare in the Nixon administration, ordered the Federal Interagency Committee on Education (FICE) to come up with a consistent system of classifying Americans by race and ethnicity. The recommendations led to OMB Statistical Policy Directive No. 15, adopted in 1977, which mandated the classification of all Americans as members of one of five official races: American Indian or Alaskan Native; Asian or Pacific Islander; Black; White; and Hispanic.Why five arbitrary pseudo-races? Why not three? Or 17? Who knows. However, in March 2024, OMB announced that the five official races of the United States will be expanded to seven, beginning with the 2030 census. ‚ÄúNative Hawaiian or Pacific Islander‚Äù will be separated from the ‚ÄúAsian‚Äù category, and a new Middle Eastern or North African (MENA) category will be added.The seven official races that are scheduled to be identified in the 2030 census are as arbitrarily defined and ludicrous as the former set of five used by OMB and the Census Bureau from 1977 to 2024. Even without the inclusion of Pacific Islanders, the ‚ÄúAsian‚Äù category is as absurd as ever, lumping together South Asians with East Asian nationalities like Chinese, Koreans, and Japanese. Jews, Arabs, and Iranians (Iran originating from the word for ‚Äúhomeland of the Aryans‚Äù) will cease to be ‚Äúwhite‚Äù for U.S. government purposes and will now be ‚Äúnon-whites‚Äù in the MENA category. The ‚Äúwhite‚Äù category will continue to exclude blond, blue-eyed Paraguayans of exclusively German descent‚Äîthey are ‚ÄúHispanic or Latino,‚Äù you see‚Äîbut will continue to include ethnicities as diverse as Portuguese and Danes. This post is for paying subscribers only Subscribe now Already have an account? Sign in
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Left  
The article critiques the government's race classification system and advocates for its abolition, reflecting a left-leaning perspective that promotes racial equity and challenges traditional categorizations. It highlights historical injustices and frames the classification as a bureaucratic imposition, consistent with left-wing critiques of systemic racism and a desire for more inclusive identity recognition. The language used suggests a push for progressive reforms, indicating a "Lean Left" classification rather than a strictly partisan or moderate stance.

title: Judge in Trans Whistleblower Case Defers Prosecution‚Äôs Gag Order Request, Delays Trial
body: Houston, Texas ‚Äî A federal judge has delayed the Department of Justice‚Äôs criminal trial against Dr. Eithan Haim until February, two months after it was set to begin. Haim is the surgeon-turned-whistleblower who exposed Texas Children‚Äôs Hospital (TCH) last year for continuing to transition minors after hospital leadership announced it would shut down the transgender medical program. U.S. District judge David Hittner scheduled the final pre-trial conference for February 6 and jury selection for February 10, with the trial most likely starting the latter date presuming all jurors are selected. The Reagan-appointed judge ruled that he would continue the hearing without prejudice, meaning the trial is postponed. The decision came Tuesday afternoon during a motion hearing in which Hittner was considering the government‚Äôs motion for a gag order against the defendant and his attorneys. Hittner deferred the gag order at this time, but the judge said he ‚Äúwill not hesitate‚Äù to reconsider one. Hittner noted he has never issued a gag order in his decades-long career as a federal judge. The DOJ wanted to silence Haim and his legal team, keeping them from taking to social media to criticize the federal prosecutors and complain about what they see as an unfair case. The prosecutors claimed the sheer volume of the social-media posts constituted ‚Äúonline bullying‚Äù and demonstrated ‚Äúinflammatory language,‚Äù while the defense lawyers cited Haim‚Äôs First Amendment rights in arguing that he can post about the legal proceedings. Haim‚Äôs lawyers, who filed a renewed motion to dismiss the case entirely, declined to immediately comment about the outcome of the motion hearing. Attorney Marcella Burke later told National Review: ‚ÄúWe feel very confident that Dr. Haim will be vindicated.‚Äù The U.S. Attorney‚Äôs Office for the Southern District of Texas could not be reached for comment. From the beginning, Haim‚Äôs lawyers have rigorously disputed the DOJ‚Äô
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Right  
The article discusses a legal case involving a conservative whistleblower and highlights the defense's emphasis on First Amendment rights. The language used, such as mentioning a "Reagan-appointed judge" and framing the prosecution's actions as an attempt to silence dissent, suggests a sympathetic view towards the whistleblower and aligns with a conservative perspective that values free speech and individuality against government overreach.

title: Powell: Fed‚Äôs independence from politics is vital to its interest rate decisions
body: WASHINGTON (AP) ‚Äî Chair Jerome Powell said Wednesday that the Federal Reserve‚Äôs ability to set interest rates free of political interference is necessary for it to make decisions to serve ‚Äúall Americans‚Äù rather than a political party or political outcome. Speaking at the New York Times‚Äô DealBook summit, Powell addressed a question about President-elect Donald Trump‚Äôs numerous public criticisms of the Fed and of Powell himself. During the election campaign, Trump had insisted that as president, he should have a ‚Äúsay‚Äù in the Fed‚Äôs interest rate policies. In his remarks Wednesday, Powell said, ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre supposed to achieve maximum employment and price stability for the benefit of all Americans and keep out of politics completely.‚Äù Despite Trump‚Äôs comments, the Fed chair said he was confident of widespread support in Congress for maintaining the central bank‚Äôs independence. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not concerned,‚Äù he said, ‚Äúthat there‚Äôs some risk that that we would lose our statutory independence. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs very, very broad support for that set of ideas in Congress, in both political parties, on both side of the Hill.‚Äù On the topic of interest rates, Powell said the Fed can afford to cut its benchmark rate cautiously, because the economy is doing better than the Fed thought it was in September, when it collectively predicted four rate cuts in 2025 after three cuts in 2024. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not quite there on inflation, but we‚Äôre making progress,‚Äù Powell said. ‚ÄúWe can afford to be a little more cautious.‚Äù The Fed has been aiming to deliver a ‚Äúsoft landing‚Äù for the economy, whereby the central bank‚Äôs interest rate hikes manage to help reduce inflation to its 2% target without causing a recession. History has shown it‚Äôs a rare and difficult feat. Yet the economy appears largely on track for such an outcome. The job market has slowed. And inflation is down sharply, though in recent months it has remained stuck modestly above the Fed‚Äôs target, which could make the policymakers reluctant to cut rates much further. Several other Fed officials have said this week that they expect to keep reducing rates, without committing to a reduction at their next meeting later this month. On Monday, Christopher Waller, an influential member of the Fed‚Äôs Board of Directors, said he was ‚Äúleaning‚Äù toward a rate cut when the central bank meets in two weeks. Waller added, though, that if forthcoming data on inflation or hiring appears worse than the Fed expects, he might favor keeping rates unchanged. On Tuesday, Mary Daly, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, said she supported further lowering rates, without commenting specifically on a timetable. ‚ÄúWhether it‚Äôll be in December or some time later, that‚Äôs a question we‚Äôll have a chance to debate and discuss at our next meeting,‚Äù Daly said in an interview on Fox Business News. ‚ÄúBut the point is, we have to keep policy moving down to accommodate the economy because we want a durable expansion with low inflation.‚Äù
Ai bias and explanation:
Center  
The article presents factual information focused on Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's comments regarding the independence of the Fed from political influence, emphasizing a balanced approach to interest rates without showing bias towards any political party. The language used is neutral and does not promote a particular ideological perspective, adhering to a journalistic standard of objectivity typical of center-leaning news reporting.

title: Democrats are urging Biden to cancel student debt for thousands of borrowers before Trump takes office
body: A group of Democratic lawmakers want President Joe Biden to quickly process student-debt cancellation applications for thousands of borrowers before it's too late. On Wednesday, 75 Democratic lawmakers, led by Sens. Dick Durbin and Ed Markey and Rep. Maxine Waters, sent a letter to Education Sec. Miguel Cardona urging him to discharge unprocessed borrower defense applications, which are applications student-loan borrowers can submit if they believe they were defrauded by the school they attended. If approved, the loans they took out to attend that school would be discharged. With President-elect Donald Trump taking office in under two months, the lawmakers said debt relief would become a lot more uncertain under his leadership. "We're here today to demand that the Department of Education deliver on President Biden's commitment to debt relief and process all outstanding borrower defense relier before President Trump slams the door shut on borrowers on January 20," Markey said during a Wednesday press conference. "Borrowers who attended fraudulent schools and have struggled with debt for years or even decades cannot afford to wait any longer." The lawmakers urged Biden during their press conference to cancel the loans of borrowers who applied for borrower defense in the next 50 days. In their letter, they added that the relief should include the thousands of borrowers already approved for relief who are still waiting for their balances to be wiped out. The lawmakers also wrote that the department should use its authority to enact group discharges for borrowers who attended schools "with documented histories of predatory practices," along with processing any remaining applications. Democratic Rep. Bobby Scott also urged the Education Department in late November to approve student-debt relief applications not just for borrower defense but for Public Service Loan Forgiveness. During his first term, Trump proposed eliminating the program, which cancels any remaining debt for public sector workers after 10 years of qualifying payments. An Education Department spokesperson told Business Insider that the department "remains committed to getting borrowers whose colleges took advantage of them all the relief they are entitled without further action on their part." The spokesperson said that the department paused payments for borrowers with approved discharges and recommended that borrowers with questions on the status of their applications call the borrower defense hotline at 1-855-279-6207. Biden's Education Department has canceled student debt for nearly 5 million borrowers over the past years, including $28.7 billion for over 1.6 million borrowers who were defrauded by their schools. However, thousands of borrowers are still waiting for their borrower defense applications to be processed, and time is running out. Durbin said on the Senate floor on Monday that it's "critical" Biden discharge those borrowers' loans "as quickly as possible" because, under Trump's first term, his Education Department ran up a backlog of borrower defense claims, leaving impacted borrowers waiting years for relief. "History shows that a second Trump Administration is likely to do everything in its power to prevent these students from receiving relief again," Durbin said on Monday. "But our nation's students, who are simply trying to better their lives deserve better." Trump has not yet provided details on how he will approach student-loan forgiveness. However, some higher education experts previously told Business Insider that relief would likely not be his priority. Preston Cooper, a senior fellow at the conservative-leaning American Enterprise Institute, said that Trump would likely "take a bit more of a skeptical attitude" with borrower defense applications because the Education Department can determine if a borrower qualifies. "If it's a loan cancellation program that leaves a lot more discretion up to the Department of Education, we could certainly see some major swings in policy," Cooper said.
Ai bias and explanation:
Left  
This article predominantly reflects a left-leaning viewpoint by focusing on the Democratic lawmakers' push for student debt cancellation and highlighting the urgency for action before the transition to a Trump administration. The framing of Trump's potential actions as detrimental to borrowers and the references to the positive measures taken by Biden's administration suggest a clear partisan bias favoring Democratic policy priorities.

title: Ex-Proud Boys leader Enrique Tarrio is set to testify at a retired police officer‚Äôs trial
body: WASHINGTON (AP) ‚Äî Former Proud Boys national chairman Enrique Tarrio is expected to testify on Thursday at the trial of a retired Washington, D.C., police officer accused of leaking confidential information to the far-right extremist group leader after Tarrio and other Proud Boys burned a stolen Black Lives Matter banner. WASHINGTON (AP) ‚Äî Former Proud Boys national chairman Enrique Tarrio is expected to testify on Thursday at the trial of a retired Washington, D.C., police officer accused of leaking confidential information to the far-right extremist group leader after Tarrio and other Proud Boys burned a stolen Black Lives Matter banner. Attorneys for former Metropolitan Police Department Lt. Shane Lamond plan to call Tarrio as their first defense witness for Lamond‚Äôs federal trial on charges that he obstructed justice and made false statements about his communications with Tarrio. Justice Department prosecutors rested their case against Lamond on Wednesday. Tarrio is serving a 22-year prison sentence related to the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the U.S. Capitol by a mob of Donald Trump supporters. A jury convicted him and other Proud Boys leaders of seditious conspiracy for a plot to stop the peaceful transfer of presidential power from Trump to Joe Biden after the 2020 election. U.S. District Judge Amy Berman Jackson will decide the case against Lamond after hearing testimony without a jury. On Monday, the judge said Tarrio was waiting for the outcome of last month‚Äôs presidential election before deciding whether to testify at Lamond‚Äôs trial. President-elect Trump, who repeatedly has vowed to pardon people convicted of Capitol riot charges, suggested he would consider pardoning Tarrio. Tarrio was sentenced to more than five months in jail for burning the banner that was stolen in December 2020 from a historic Black church in downtown Washington, and for bringing two high-capacity firearm magazines into the district. Tarrio was arrested in Washington two days before the Jan. 6 siege. The Miami resident wasn‚Äôt at the Capitol when a mob of Trump supporters stormed the building and interrupted the congressional certification of Biden‚Äôs 2020 electoral victory. During the trial‚Äôs opening statements on Monday, a prosecutor said Lamond was a ‚ÄúProud Boys sympathizer‚Äù who warned Tarrio about his impending arrest for the banner‚Äôs destruction and later lied to investigators about their communications. Lamond, who met Tarrio in 2019, had supervised the intelligence branch of the police department‚Äôs Homeland Security Bureau. He was responsible for monitoring groups like the Proud Boys when they came to Washington. Lamond‚Äôs indictment accuses him of lying to and misleading federal investigators when they questioned him in June 2021 about his contacts with Tarrio. One of the government‚Äôs last witnesses was acting MPD Capt. Nicole Copeland, who supervised the police investigation of the banner burning. Copeland testified on Wednesday that it would have helped investigators to know that Tarrio had privately confessed to Lamond. The Proud Boys leader also publicly admitted on social media and on a podcast that he had burned the banner. Lamond, of Stafford, Virginia, was arrested in May 2023. He retired from the police department that same month. ___
Ai bias and explanation:
Center  
This article provides an objective account of legal proceedings involving Enrique Tarrio and a police officer, presenting facts without evident bias. It includes perspectives from both legal representatives and authorities, focusing on the case's details rather than promoting a particular political viewpoint. The language used is neutral, and it avoids emotionally charged terms, which aligns with a center classification in media bias.

title: Podcaster Alex Cooper Mocks Kamala Team Spending $100,000 on ‚ÄòCall Her Daddy‚Äô Set: My Studio ‚ÄòDoesn‚Äôt Even Cost Six Figures‚Äô
body: Alex Cooper, host of the popular podcast Call Her Daddy, knocked the Kamala Harris campaign team for spending $100,000 to build mockup of her set, saying her own studio does not even cost six figures. Following the November election, in which Donald Trump beat Kamala Harris in an Electoral College landslide, reports surfaced that the Kamala campaign spent over six figures to recreate the studio for Alex Cooper‚Äôs podcast. As Fox News reported at the time: The Harris campaign spent a massive sum of money for a podcast that got a fraction of the viewership President-elect Trump won on ‚ÄúThe Joe Rogan Experience,‚Äù according to a new report. The Washington Examiner publish a report Friday with details on how the Harris campaign spent their $1 billion war chest, with one particular expenditure raising some eyebrows. ‚ÄúA source familiar with the matter told the Washington Examiner that the Harris campaign spent six figures on building a set for Harris‚Äôs appearance on the popular Call Her Daddy podcast with host Alex Cooper,‚Äù The Examiner wrote. ‚ÄúThe interview came out in October and was reportedly filmed in a hotel room in Washington, D.C.‚Äù Speaking at the New York Times‚Äô DealBook Summit, Cooper said that her own studio set does not cost six figures and even said that the studio built by the Kamala team was not as ‚Äúnice.‚Äù ‚ÄúThe Harris campaign spent like $100,000. Do you know about this?‚Äù asked Andrew Ross Sorkin. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs hilarious,‚Äù said Cooper.
