He's going to seize the opportunity and work the problem."Musk and Ramaswamy have been tasked by Trump to advise on cutting federal government spending and removing elements of bureaucracy he, and they, view as unnecessary. Read more Steve Bannon issues warning to America's wealthy Republican calls fears Liz Cheney may be Trump admin target "nonsense" Gavin Newsom responds after 7.0 earthquake hits California In another positive post in favor of a Democrat, Gaetz reshared a thread from Federal Trade Commission (FTC) chair Line Khan, who posted on Tuesday about data brokers buying and selling Americans' data.Khan said the FTC had worked to ban Mobilewalla and Gravy Analytics from selling sensitive location data, a practice Gaetz described as "crazy stuff"."Thank you Chair Khan for fighting back," he posted.Gaetz reaching across the aisle, even without a position in Congress or the next Cabinet, comes at a time when Republicans and Democrats have mostly been at odds with one another when it comes to policy decisions.With a slim majority in the House, the GOP members left may need to follow Gaetz's example in his recent X posts and seek to find common ground with Democrat colleagues to move legislation forward.
Ai bias and explanation:
Center  
The article presents a neutral perspective on Matt Gaetz's recent praises for Democratic lawmakers, focusing on factual reporting of his comments without overtly advocating for or against any political ideology. It mentions efforts made by both parties and highlights the rare instances of bipartisan praise, maintaining an objective tone throughout the piece.

title: OPEC+ delays production increase, awaits arrival of Trump administration
body: THE OIL CARTEL, OPEC+ IS EXTENDING ITS CURRENT PRODUCTION CUTS AS IT ANTICIPATES THE RETURN OF PRESIDENT-ELECT DONALD TRUMP AND WAITS TO SEE HOW OIL SANCTIONS AGAINST IRAN AND VENEZUELA MIGHT PLAY OUT. CNBC, CITING SOURCES AND INTERNAL DOCUMENTS, IS REPORTING THAT THE OPEC oil producers‚Äô alliance has DELAYED PLANS TO QUOTE **UNWIND VOLUNTARY CRUDE OIL CUTS** BECAUSE OF A LACK OF GLOBAL DEMAND AND CONFLICT IN THE MIDDLE EAST. MEMBER COUNTRIES PRODUCE ABOUT 40 PERCENT OF THE WORLD‚ÄôS OIL. THE OIL CARTEL IS NOW RESTRICTING ITS PRODUCTION TO ABOUT 40 MILLION BARRELS A DAY, UNTIL THE END OF 2026. IT HAD PREVIOUSLY SET THE END DATE AS DECEMBER OF 2025. MAJOR PLAYERS, SAUDI ARABIA AND RUSSIA, ARE CURRENTLY HOLDING BACK ABOUT 6 MILLION BARRELS PER DAY IN AN EFFORT TO SHORE UP PRICES. THE FINANCIAL TIMES IS REPORTING THAT DONALD TRUMP‚ÄôS THREATS TO SLAP TARIFFS ON SOME OIL PRODUCERS IS AN EFFORT TO EXERT PRESSURE ON IRAN AND DRIVE DOWN ITS OIL EXPORTS. AMRITA SEN, DIRECTOR OF RESEARCH AT ENERGY EXPERTS SAID ‚Äú I THINK THE TRUMP FACTOR IS A BIG UNCERTAINTY‚Ä¶WE DON‚ÄôT KNOW HOW TARIFFS WILL IMPACT THE PRICE. ‚Äú OIL SUPPLY HAS A LARGE EFFECT ON GAS PRICES THAT AMERICANS PAY. TRIPLE A REPORTS THAT AS OF THIS MORNING, THE NATIONAL AVERAGE PRICE FOR A GALLON OF REGULAR UNLEADED GASOLINE IS 3.02 A GALLON. THAT‚ÄôS DOWN FROM 3.22 A YEAR AGO AND A HUGE DROP FROM JUNE OF 2022 WHEN THE NATIONAL AVERAGE WAS 5.01 A GALLON FOR MORE UNBIASED UPDATES, DOWNLOAD THE STRAIGHT ARROW NEWS AP
Ai bias and explanation:
Center  
The article presents factual information about the OPEC+ production cuts and their relation to the incoming Trump administration without leaning toward a particular political ideology. It mentions the actions of OPEC, economic data on oil prices, and insights from energy experts without including subjective interpretations or political opinions, which reflects a neutral stance typical of center bias.

title: Vance to tour Helene recovery efforts in North Carolina
body: Vice President-elect JD Vance is expected to travel Friday to Fairview, North Carolina, to survey Hurricane Helene recovery efforts, a source familiar with the trip told NBC News. Vance is scheduled to meet with first responders and visit a home renovation project, this person added. He also will meet with the family of Tony Ray Garrison, a fire battalion chief who died while rescuing victims of a Helene-related mudslide in late September. Outside of meetings and events surrounding President-elect Donald Trump‚Äôs transition efforts, the North Carolina visit will be Vance‚Äôs first trip since last month‚Äôs election. Vance surveyed Helene damage during an October campaign trip, touring storm-battered Damascus, Virginia. Appearing that day with Gov. Glenn Youngkin, a fellow Republican, Vance spoke about the importance of federal assistance to recovery efforts there and ‚Äúespecially North Carolina.‚Äù Vance also pledged to ‚Äúdo what we can to help this community and communities all across Appalachia rebuild.‚Äù Flanked by Youngkin and local officials as he took questions, Vance lauded FEMA for providing ‚Äúa lot of resources,‚Äù while also arguing that President Joe Biden's administration ‚Äúcould be doing a whole lot better ‚Ä¶ making people feel like they matter.‚Äù ‚ÄúFor so long, this community has been ignored, and they feel like their government is ignoring them once again,‚Äù Vance said. ‚ÄúWe have got to change that.‚Äù Vance will soon resign his U.S. Senate seat in Ohio, where after taking office in January 2023 he became known for his responsiveness to local crises, such as the toxic train derailment in East Palestine and a string of tornadoes this year in western Ohio.
Ai bias and explanation:
Center  
The article presents a factual account of Vice President-elect JD Vance's upcoming visit to North Carolina for Hurricane Helene recovery efforts. It includes his statements but does not display strong biases or opinions towards either political side. The focus remains on the events and impacts of the recovery efforts without a partisan slant, which is characteristic of a center classification.

title: Families of Israeli Hostages Plead with Trump to ‚ÄòBring Them Back Home‚Äô
body: Seven families of Israeli hostages are pleading with Donald Trump to demand the return of their relatives that Hamas has imprisoned in Gaza for over a year. ‚ÄúImpose the simple and straight logic to bring them back home and turn their darkness into light and freedom,‚Äù they wrote in a letter to the president-elect on Tuesday. The signatories specifically ask Trump to call Qatar‚Äôs Sheikh Tamim bin Hamad al-Thani and ‚Äúdemand an end to these games,‚Äù referring to the stalled hostage deals that have yet to free some 100 captives remaining in Gaza. ‚ÄúWe need a simple American deal with Hamas left in its shadow: Hamas must immediately announce the release of all the living and dead hostages without any conditions and surrender, or all Hamas leaders be immediately deported from the country and will no longer be safe anywhere in the world,‚Äù the families said. ‚ÄúThis is how the war with a terrorist organization in Gaza should end. This is how your term in the White House should begin. It should be with the rehabilitation of Gaza by Qatar and the Gulf states alongside ensuring the security of the citizens of Israel and the return of our loved one‚Äôs home.‚Äù The letter‚Äôs release came one day after Trump warned there will be ‚Äúhell to pay‚Äù if Hamas doesn‚Äôt release the rest of the hostages by Inauguration Day next month. During his 2024 campaign, the former and future president vowed to end the conflict in Gaza that has grown to involve Hezbollah in Lebanon. Israel waged the war against Hamas after the Palestinian terror group massacred nearly 2,000 people and abducted over 250 individuals, including seven Americans. Israeli-U.S. soldier Omer Neutra was one of the latest fatalities confirmed by the Israeli military. Hamas terrorists killed Neutra during the October 7 attack last year and have kept his body ever since. Meanwhile, Edan Alexander is believed to be alive after Hamas released a propaganda video showing him addressing coerced messages to Israeli prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu and Trump. In September, the Israeli military recovered the bodies of six hostages, including Israeli-American Hersh Goldberg-Polin, who were executed by Hamas in a Gaza tunnel shortly before Israeli troops arrived. Those who signed Tuesday‚Äôs letter are Hoshea Haggai, brother of Gadi Haggai and brother-in-law of Judih Weinstein Haggai; Doris Liber, mother of Guy Iluz; Ziv Abud, spouse of Eliya Cohen; Talia and Liran Berman, mother and brother of twins Ziv and Gail Berman; Simona and Dor Steinbrecher, mother and brother of Doron Steinbrecher; Amanda Damari, mother of Emily Damari; and Lishay Lavi, wife of Omri Miran. Of the nine hostages listed, six are believed to still be alive and three were murdered in captivity. Liber expressed her grief in an interview with National Review last November when she visited Capitol Hill to plead for the release of her son and only child. At the time, she didn‚Äôt know if he was alive. Iluz‚Äôs death was announced December 1, 2023. ‚ÄúSymbolically, this year Christmas and the first day of Hanukkah fall on the same day,‚Äù the letter addressed to Trump states. ‚ÄúWe look forward to the miracle of Christmas and the miracle of Hanukkah for us and implore you to ensure we see light for our loved ones.‚Äù Liran Berman said he has the ‚Äúutmost respect‚Äù for the Biden administration, considering the U.S. helped negotiate the breakthrough hostage deal in November 2023. That said, Berman is more optimistic about what a second Trump administration could do to free the hostages. He only gives one caveat for the incoming president. ‚ÄúWe just ask him, beg him, demand him to do a deal before he enters office on the 20th of January, before Christmas even,‚Äù Berman told NR. ‚ÄúWe need them back home as soon as possible. They don‚Äôt have time until he‚Äôs in office. It‚Äôs on him, and it will be his legacy even before entering his administration.‚Äù Send a tip to the news team at NR.
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Right  
The article primarily focuses on the concerns and demands of Israeli families regarding the return of hostages from Hamas, which aligns with a more pro-Israel perspective often found in lean right-leaning media. It emphasizes a call to action directed at Trump, reflecting a favorable view of his potential influence on the situation. The language used is emotionally charged and supportive of Israel, typically characteristic of sources that lean towards a right-wing viewpoint on international issues.

title: Energy CEO Who Drank Fracking Fluid Is Now Trump‚Äôs Oil Evangelist
body: Standing shoulder to shoulder with his employees, Chris Wright, chief executive officer of oilfield services company Liberty Energy Inc., held up his glass in a toast. ‚ÄúTo your health and the longer lives and healthier lives of billions of people around the world from oil and gas,‚Äù Wright said. Then he gulped down a shot of fracking fluid. By quaffing the chemical cocktail of water, bleach, soap and other substances in a 2019 Facebook video, Wright, Donald Trump‚Äôs nominee for energy secretary, sought to refute fracking opponents who argued it would poison aquifers. Five years later, the stunt suggests how he might carry out US energy policy: with a flair for showmanship and an appetite for confrontation. In a slew of TV interviews and speeches, Wright has proclaimed the moral virtues of fossil fuels and championed them as a way to lift people out of poverty. A few years ago, he picked a public fight with The North Face Inc. after the outwear maker declined to make a co-branded jacket with a Liberty competitor because of its oil-industry links. (Wright commissioned billboards that said: ‚ÄúThat North Face puffer looks great on you. And it was made from fossil fuels.‚Äù) He has called greenhouse-gas reduction goals ‚Äúperverse,‚Äù questioned the environmental benefits of electric vehicles and attacked subsidies for wind and solar projects. His outspokenness is poised to set him apart from Trump‚Äôs previous energy secretaries, the comparatively buttoned-up Rick Perry and Dan Brouillette. But Wright, an industry insider who would be taking on his first political role, can be nuanced. A self-professed ‚Äúnerdy guy,‚Äù he frequently gives lectures about the global energy system, using data-heavy charts to illustrate his points. Rather than deny climate change outright, he characterizes it as a ‚Äúmodest phenomenon.‚Äù ‚ÄúWright is literally an evangelist for better human living through the production of more hydrocarbons,‚Äù said Jim Lucier, managing director at Capital Alpha Partners, a research group in Washington. His appointment is indicative of Trump‚Äôs hard pivot toward fossil fuels after years of Biden administration policies that benefited renewables. There‚Äôs actually little Wright can do to boost drilling from a perch atop the Energy Department, which doesn‚Äôt have oversight of federal oil and natural gas leases. But he could revamp the agency‚Äôs clean-energy loan program to fund projects favored by Republicans, a potential boon for gas and nuclear plants. He could also speed the approval of gas exports, cementing America‚Äôs status as a major supplier of the fuel to Europe and Asia. He would also almost certainly be instrumental in fulfilling Trump‚Äôs promises to help the coal industry, build more power plants, expand electrical grids and cut the overall price of energy by half. And he'll serve on Trump's newly created National Energy Council along side North Dakota Governor Doug Burgum, Trump's nominee for Interior Secretary. Wright didn‚Äôt respond to a request for comment. If confirmed by the Senate, Wright would lead a department with about 16,000 employees, more than double the size of his own company's 5,500-person workforce. In addition to promoting advancements in energy technology, the agency is responsible for ensuring the safety of the US arsenal of nuclear weapons. The Energy Department‚Äôs $400 billion green bank could prove to be a tantalizing tool for Wright. Though it was once marked for death under the first Trump administration, Wright could use the loan program to finance projects such as hydrogen production, carbon capture and storage, and small modular reactors. Wright, who has spoken about the benefits of nuclear power, serves on the board of Oklo Inc., an SMR developer chaired by OpenAI CEO Sam Altman, and his company is an investor in geothermal energy and sodium-ion battery technology. The head of Occidental Petroleum Corp., an oil producer that‚Äôs building the world‚Äôs largest plant to pull carbon dioxide directly from the air, said she‚Äôs enthusiastic about Wright‚Äôs nomination and deemed Trump‚Äôs reelection a boon for carbon capture and the oil and gas industry. Occidental is set to receive as much as $650 millionBloomberg Terminal from the Energy Department for carbon capture. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think that President Trump could have picked anyone better,‚Äù Occidental CEO Vicki Hollub said in an interview at a shale conference last month. ‚ÄúWe need someone who understands the importance of our energy independence, and oil and gas development here in the US.‚Äù But emerging clean technologies championed by the Biden administration ‚Äî including those that rival oil and gas, like certain types of batteries ‚Äî could lose a critical funding source. ‚ÄúWe think the Energy Department has an extremely important role to play both in terms of its innovation programs, the research and development and the deployment we‚Äôve seen grow under Biden,‚Äù said Jackie Wong, a senior vice president at the Natural Resources Defense Council. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôd really like to see an energy secretary lean into this and build on it ‚Äî not take it in the opposite direction.‚Äù Like Trump‚Äôs first energy secretary, Perry, Wright is a vocal proponent of liquefied natural gas terminals. US LNG developers need permits from the Energy Department to export gas. While the Biden administration put new authorizations on hold to review the projects‚Äô climate impact, Trump‚Äôs transition team is already crafting an executive order to lift the moratorium. Wright was scheduled to meet Wednesday with with Senator Mike Lee, a Utah Republican who is set to chair the powerful energy committee, and Senator John Hoeven, a North Dakota Republican, who is also on the committee, according to a transition team official. Wright, 59, was born in New Jersey and raised in Colorado, the youngest of four children born within four years to a father who worked in the investment industry and a mother who managed the home. After earning an engineering degree at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, he founded a company called Pinnacle Technologies in 1992. Pinnacle developed a mapping software that was ‚Äúinstrumental in the development‚Äù of oil- and gas-rich shale formations previously thought to be inaccessible, said Paul Vitek, who was chief financial officer at Liberty Resources LLC, a company Wright started to help take advantage of the technology he created. Wright took a subsequent company, now known as Liberty Energy, public in 2018 as the shale boom propelled US oil output to record highs. Wright acknowledges the Earth is warming, but he believes the effects can be managed through human ingenuity ‚Äî a position that puts him at odds with the scientific consensus that the world faces catastrophic impacts if emissions aren‚Äôt slashed. He credits fossil fuels with providing affordable energy that's helped alleviate poverty around the globe. Earlier this year, Wright founded a nonprofit to assist people in developing nations cook with gas stoves instead of dung or wood. He says the costs of curbing fossil-fuel use would be enormous. ‚ÄúIf instead of raising CO2 concentration by 50% we cut it by 50%, that would be a crisis,‚Äù he said, adding that plants need carbon dioxide to grow. He also says Earth is getting ‚Äúmeaningfully greener,‚Äù citing research into leaf size. And Wright sees no long-term increase in damage from natural disasters, though government data suggests otherwise. One thing Wright probably can‚Äôt do is deliver on Trump‚Äôs vow to ‚Äúfrack, frack, frack.‚Äù Oil prices, set by the global market, have slid in recent months on concern that demand will fall short of supply. Concern about a glut, along with pressure to restrain spending and return cash to shareholders, is likely to cause US producers to slow drilling activity. Wright has slammed subsidies for wind and solar power, saying at the Enercom Denver conference earlier this year that ‚Äúthey‚Äôve made electricity more expensive and the grid less reliable.‚Äù But killing the tax breaks outright would require an act of Congress. He‚Äôs argued that the energy-intensive process to manufacture electric vehicles means ‚Äúyou have to drive a Tesla 80,000 miles to get its greenhouse gas emissions down to the level of an internal combustion engine.‚Äù Still, Wright could help fulfill Trump‚Äôs promise to refill the nation‚Äôs emergency cache of oil following the Biden administration‚Äôs drawdown in the wake of Russia‚Äôs invasion of Ukraine. While adding barrels to the Strategic Petroleum Reserve wouldn‚Äôt change producers‚Äô long-term plans, it could provide a modest lift for oil prices in the short term. Jerry Simmons, president of the Domestic Energy Producers Alliance, said to have someone like Wright ‚Äúin a cabinet position is just huge.‚Äù The industry group was founded by oil billionaire and Trump adviser Harold Hamm, who advocated for Wright to be tapped for Energy Secretary. Dan Eberhart, chief executive officer of oilfield services company Canary LLC, said Wright has a deep understanding of the industry. "We can't address climate change or any of the challenges facing us from a place of weakness,‚Äù Eberhart said. ‚ÄúUnder Wright, the Energy Department will champion abundant and affordable energy."
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Right  
The article primarily presents a favorable view of Chris Wright, his stance on fossil fuels, and Trump's energy policies, emphasizing the benefits of oil and gas while downplaying the concerns related to climate change. It highlights industry support for Wright and portrays his anti-renewable sentiment without significant counterpoints, suggesting a lean towards conservative values and pro-industry perspectives often associated with a right-leaning bias.

title: ‚Äò100 Percent Bullsh-t‚Äô: Fox News Talent Shoot Down NBC‚Äôs Smear Campaign Against Pete Hegseth
body: Current and former Fox News talent are calling bull on legacy media‚Äôs latest smear campaign to sink Pete Hegseth‚Äôs bid to lead the Pentagon. On Tuesday, NBC News dropped a malicious hit piece against the Army veteran and former ‚ÄúFox and Friends Weekend‚Äù host, in which 10 allegedly former and current network employees supposedly claimed that Hegseth displayed signs of a drinking problem in the workplace. Curiously, none of the alleged anonymous sources referenced by authors Chloe Melas, Courtney Kube, and Sarah Fitzpatrick identified themselves, citing ‚Äúfear of retaliation.‚Äù The left-wing outlet‚Äôs trafficking of slanderous and unsubstantiated claims of wrongdoing by Hegseth bears a striking resemblance to the smear tactics deployed by media hacktivists in their bid to defeat Brett Kavanaugh‚Äôs 2018 Supreme Court nomination. Lacking any journalistic integrity, these so-called ‚Äúreporters‚Äù ran with any and all claims laundered by the judge‚Äôs accusers with virtually no pushback or skepticism. The publication of Tuesday‚Äôs hit piece received immediate pushback from Hegseth‚Äôs former Fox colleagues and network contributors and guests, who all shot down the allegations of unprofessional workplace conduct. On X, ‚ÄúFox and Friends Weekend‚Äù co-host Will Cain called NBC‚Äôs story, ‚ÄúBullsh-t. 100 percent bullsh-t. Actually ‚Ä¶ horsesh-t,‚Äù and noted in a follow-up post that he ‚Äúwas not contacted by anyone at @NBCNews‚Äù regarding the allegations against Hegseth. ‚ÄúYour story is horsesh-t @NBCNews. Put my name on it. On the record. It‚Äôll be your only on the record source,‚Äù Cain wrote. ‚ÄúSigned, The guy who sat next to him for 8 hours every week for five years starting at 6am.‚Äù ‚ÄúFox and Friends Weekend‚Äù co-host Rachel Campos-Duffy similarly confirmed on X that ‚Äúthe losers @NBCNews never reached out to [her] either,‚Äù and pushed back on the story‚Äôs allegations. ‚Äú@willcain is right ‚Äî your story IS horsesh-t,‚Äù she wrote. ‚ÄúYou now have 2 people who sat next to him 8+ hours a week on the record. Will you retract or correct your story?‚Äù [READ: The Police Report About Pete Hegseth‚Äôs Alleged Sexual Assault Vindicates Him Of Criminality] Campos-Duffy‚Äôs daughter and Fox News guest Evita Duffy-Alfonso also voiced her support for Hegseth, writing on X, ‚ÄúI stand with Pete and his beautiful family in the face of these smears.‚Äù Federalist Editor-in-Chief and Fox News contributor Mollie Hemingway said she has ‚Äúnothing but good things to say about Pete and the anonymously sourced stories don‚Äôt match [her] personal experience in any way. Quite the contrary, in fact.‚Äù ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt stand the propaganda practice of using anonymous sources to smear political opponents, as NBC does here,‚Äù Hemingway wrote on X. I can't stand the propaganda practice of using anonymous sources to smear political opponents, as NBC does here. FWIW, I have nothing but good things to say about Pete and the anonymously sourced stories don't match my personal experience in any way. Quite the contrary, in fact. https://t.co/i2lPDbiAG2 Fox News contributor Lisa Boothe said she has ‚Äúguest co-hosted with [Hegseth] numerous times before,‚Äù and that ‚ÄúNot once did this happen. Not once [has she] heard this from others.‚Äù ‚ÄúThis is such a disgusting and false smear. It is wrong and malicious,‚Äù she wrote on X. ‚ÄúI have routinely sat on the couch with @PeteHegseth for 8 years,‚Äù wrote Dr. Nicole Saphier, a Fox contributor. ‚ÄúNot once did I suspect he had consumed anything other than an egg sandwich and coffee before going on air.‚Äù I have routinely sat on the couch with @PeteHegseth for 8 years. Not once did I suspect he had consumed anything other than an egg sandwich and coffee before going on air. pic.twitter.com/vjDQUpV9il Radio host and frequent Fox News guest Dan Bongino called the allegations against Hegseth, ‚Äú100 [percent] HORSESH-T.‚Äù Fox News contributor and veteran Johnny Joey Jones said the hit pieces against the defense secretary nominee ‚Äúare getting laughable,‚Äù and noted that he‚Äôs ‚Äúdisgusted by the smell of alcohol on someone‚Äôs breath‚Äù and has ‚Äúnever EVER seen Pete drink like that, and have never smelled alcohol on his breath at work.‚Äù [READ: Media Lie About Pete Hegseth‚Äôs Christian Faith To Falsely Smear Him As Racist] Former Fox News producer Breanna Morello said she‚Äôs ‚Äúnever heard‚Äù of the allegations against Hegseth ‚Äúin [her] life,‚Äù noting how the alleged Fox employees cited in the NBC report ‚Äúare anonymous.‚Äù ‚ÄúEveryone spoke highly of him and still does til this day,‚Äù Morello wrote on X. Former Fox producer and independent journalist Kyle Becker detailed on X how he saw Hegseth ‚Äúnumerous times while working at Fox News,‚Äù and ‚Äú[n]ever got the impression he was ever drunk.‚Äù ‚ÄúNo bloodshot eyes. No slurred speech. No disheveled appearance. No wobbly gait. Nothing,‚Äù Becker wrote. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm also calling bullsh-t.‚Äù Fox News contributors Guy Benson, Sara Carter, and numerous other network employees and guests have come out in defense of Hegseth against the unsubstantiated claims published by NBC News. 10 ‚Äúanonymous sources‚Äù for @NBCNews. Here‚Äôs your on the record statements from people who worked with @PeteHegseth. I know there‚Äôs MANY more of you. Drop it here. üëá@dbongino @NBSaphierMD @Johnny_Joey @kylenabecker pic.twitter.com/OkvTY4J5iu
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Right  
The article displays a clear bias towards the right, specifically in its defense of Fox News personality Pete Hegseth against allegations made by NBC News. The language used to characterize NBC's reporting as a "smear campaign" and the repeated emphasis on the credibility of Hegseth's defenders suggest an alignment with conservative viewpoints. Furthermore, the denouncement of anonymous sources and calls for accountability reflect a broader narrative often associated with right-leaning media aiming to undermine perceived left-wing bias in mainstream journalism.

title: Dobbs Was Just the Beginning. Now Trans Rights Are Being Tested at the Supreme Court.
body: On Dec. 4, the U.S. Supreme Court will hear arguments in what is likely to be the most important trans rights case in history. It will have knock-on effects for civil rights jurisprudence that will affect the freedoms and protections of LGBTQ+ Americans, women, medical providers, and parents‚Äô rights to raise their children without interference from the state. Tennessee‚Äôs S.B. 1 bans surgery, puberty blockers, and hormone treatment for the purpose of gender transition for people under 18. On Amicus, Dahlia Lithwick spoke to Chase Strangio, co-director of the American Civil Liberties Union‚Äôs LGBTQ and HIV Project, who will argue United States v. Skrmetti. Strangio will be the first openly trans lawyer arguing at the high court. Their conversation has been lightly edited and condensed for clarity. Dahlia Lithwick: After Dobbs came down, you warned on this podcast about the ways the decision to overturn Roe had just rocket-fueled anti-trans legislation across the country. I would love for you to just remind listeners why Dobbs was never just about abortion and how it connects to the Tennessee ban in Skrmetti. Chase Strangio: They‚Äôre connected for so many reasons‚Äîwhether you look at the equality thread or the autonomy thread in Dobbs, this is about structural efforts to impede people‚Äôs abilities to make decisions for themselves. The way in which Dobbs opened the door in particular for these anti-trans bans is that first they revitalized this case that was not talked about for a long time‚Äîalthough we know Justice Ginsburg hated it‚ÄîGeduldig v. Aiello. This was the case in which the court said that restrictions on benefits related to pregnancy are not sex discrimination. The court allowed this idea to sit dormant for quite a while, but it was reactivated by Justice Alito in Dobbs. So now, when we are talking about things related to medicine, or health, or areas where we can claim that biological differences between men and women justify some differential treatment, we see the erosion of the protections we have worked so hard to build for sex-based protections under law. In the two and a half years since Dobbs was decided, people who have long wanted doctrinal openings to roll back antidiscrimination protections have found a group of people whom there is more public support to target, and they‚Äôve used that to open the door to big possible doctrinal gaps in how everyone can be protected from sex discrimination. I see this happening very strategically. Within a week of Dobbs being decided, it was cited in every single anti-trans-related case we were litigating. And it was cited for the proposition that in essence, special deference is owed to legislatures when they are regulating in the area of medicine when it deals with sex-based differences between men and women. If we take a step back and look at this moment we are in, and the obsession with trans people during the 2024 elections, it wasn‚Äôt really about trans people. What it was about‚Äîthe organizing theme‚Äîwas about gender roles more broadly. They are using these attacks on trans people to re-entrench old notions of what is the proper role of men and women in society. I‚Äôm struck by how the two abortion cases before the court last year were in so many ways not about abortion per se, they were about physicians and their rights, and what kind of care they could give. And it is so striking to see a case like Skrmetti that‚Äôs essentially saying, ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt care what the parents think or what the doctors think.‚Äù It really is amazing that just as the parents are always right until they‚Äôre wrong, so too physicians‚Äîthey‚Äôre always right, until they‚Äôre wrong. The throughline is this deep governmental trust in and reification of parental roles and physicians‚Äô roles, until and unless those parents and physicians make decisions the state disagrees with. It‚Äôs not just an entrenchment of gender roles, it‚Äôs also this notion that doctors are the only important autonomous actor in the abortion context in both cases last year‚Äîbut now, in Skrmetti, they‚Äôre just irrelevant. They‚Äôre wallpaper. There‚Äôs this stunning thing that we‚Äôve seemingly just accepted, as a matter of public discourse, that not only are physicians wallpaper, they‚Äôre part of this vast and far-reaching conspiracy to provide harmful care. We‚Äôre talking about care that is supported by the American Academy of Pediatrics, the Endocrine Society, the American Medical Association. The doctors providing this care are at the most preeminent research institutions in this country, yet somehow the argument is they‚Äôre all conspiring to provide harmful care to minors. If we take a step back, that is quite a conspiratorial argument, and however people may disagree about, or feel discomfort about this, these are still good-faith parents and doctors trying to do right by their patients and their children. But we‚Äôve somehow allowed this conspiracy to fester that actually everyone is just trying to provide harmful care, which is just absurd. You just listed a tiny number of the amicus briefs on your side from medical and mental health groups and serious scientific entities. This is not something they haven‚Äôt thought deeply about. All these professional organizations are on one side, and then, on the other side, the Tennessee brief is teeming with weird deep-state conspiracy theorizing. I worry because we have seen junk science and bad data infiltrate court doctrine and make its way into opinions that then get cited as though that junk science is real. It‚Äôs really scary, and I think it‚Äôs also a function of the fact that the courts no longer really care or look at the factual findings of the district court‚Äîthey will just pull out the latest newspaper article that they see. There is an actual purpose to testing the evidence and seeing whether it holds up, because when we‚Äôve actually gone to trial in these cases, and these witnesses are cross-examined, they have admitted they‚Äôre exaggerating, accepted that there‚Äôs no underlying scientific support for claims they‚Äôre making, pointed to the fact that perhaps it is speculative or based on internet searches or Reddit sites. This is why, when we look at the outcomes of these cases in the district courts‚Äîwhere the judges are the closest to the evidence‚Äîyou have an almost unanimous set of holdings when heightened scrutiny is applied, that these laws [like S.B. 1] just don‚Äôt hold up. When you get more detached from the evidence and it becomes more about vibes, for lack of a better word, it becomes very untethered to what is actually going on, which allows people to say things like ‚ÄúWell, there‚Äôs no long-term studies.‚Äù There are long-term studies. There are studies that are tracking people for periods like six years, which is extraordinarily long in pediatric medicine. This medical research has been provided for decades‚Äîthat isn‚Äôt ‚Äúnew‚Äù in medicine. I think about all of the innovations we‚Äôve witnessed even in my 12-year-old child‚Äôs lifetime. So I think that so much of this is distortion and out-of-context polemics. And this is, again, a callback to the mifepristone case where the challengers were making claims as though no one has ever attempted to use these medicines before, even though there was decades of research. If there is a thematic, background set of principles that can come forth in our argument, it is that this is not the federal government displacing Tennessee. This is Tennessee displacing the loving, reasoned, painstaking decisions of parents who are trying to do right by their children. Children who were in anguish, and are now doing better, because of the health care Tennessee now bans.
Ai bias and explanation:
Left  
This article emphasizes the negative implications of anti-trans legislation and critiques governmental overreach into personal and medical decisions related to LGBTQ+ rights. It focuses on the importance of autonomy and civil rights for marginalized groups, particularly in the context of recent Supreme Court cases, which aligns with left-leaning viewpoints. The language and framework used reflect a commitment to social justice and equality, indicating a perspective that strongly advocates for the rights of transgender individuals amidst what it describes as harmful legislative actions.

title: More than 80 years later, Pearl Harbor still worth remembering
body: NEWS AND OPINION: Is it important to remember the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor on Dec. 7, 1941? Yes. Of course. ‚ÄúPearl Harbor and World War ll is the line in the sand between the Old World and the New World. America was changed radically and forever. We were ‚ÄôFortress America‚Äô walled off by two giant oceans before Pearl Harbor ‚Äî isolationism ratified by the bipartisan Neutrality Acts. But the nation was internationalist during and after the war,‚Äù presidential historian Craig Shirley said in a written statement shared with Inside the Beltway. He is the author of five books on Ronald Reagan along with ‚ÄúDecember 1941: 31 Days that Changed America and Saved the World,‚Äù a bestseller published in 2011 by Thomas Nelson. ‚ÄúFDR and Winston Churchill quite literally saved the world from left wing Nazism and chauvinistic Japan. But the world changed in other ways. Before World War II, anybody above the rank of Second Lieutenant was denigrated through such books as ‚ÄôAll Quiet on the Western Front‚Äô and other popular literature,‚Äù Mr. Shirley said. ‚ÄúBut during and after the war, men like George Patton and Douglas MacArthur became revered. The workplace changed for women and Blacks. After World War II, the only two countries that had planes in the air were America and England ‚Äî hence English became the official language of the air, and this continues today,‚Äù Mr. Shirley said. WEATHER OR NOT Is a white Christmas in store for the nation? ‚ÄúBitterly cold air has spread across much of the northern and eastern United States this week, but AccuWeather expert meteorologists say a pattern change on the horizon could lead to milder air and less snow on the ground before the holidays,‚Äù a report released Thursday by AccuWeather said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been a cold start to December for much of the eastern half of the nation. Don‚Äôt expect the cold to stick around too much longer. We expect a pattern shift in mid-December with a change from a cold Polar air mass to a milder Pacific air mass, especially for the central and eastern United States,‚Äù Paul Pastelok, AccuWeather‚Äôs lead long-range forecaster, said in a written statement. ‚ÄúThis can lead to snow melt for many areas that received snow at the start of the winter season, not leaving too much snow around just before Christmas,‚Äù he said. Stay tuned. AccuWeather will issue the official 2024 white Christmas forecast in mid-December. In the meantime, the organization‚Äôs meteorologists have reviewed cold-weather records to determine which major U.S. cities have the highest odds of experiencing a white Christmas. ‚ÄúHistorical data from 1991-2020 shows that none of the 25 most-populated cities in the United States have much more than a one-in-three chance of getting an inch or more of snow on the ground on Christmas morning,‚Äù AccuWeather said. APPLAUSE FOR KELLY The Heritage Foundation has offered some formal congratulations to former Sen. Kelly Loeffler. The Georgia Republican was just appointed to lead the Small Business Administration in President-elect Donald Trump‚Äôs upcoming administration. ‚ÄúKelly‚Äôs inspiring journey, from growing up on a farm in Illinois to building a successful career in business and public service, is a testament to her dedication, hard work, and passion for the American Dream,‚Äù Kevin Roberts, president of the foundation, said in a written statement shared with the Beltway. Small businesses, he said, are struggling under high taxes, excessive regulations and anti-growth policies. ‚ÄúHer unwavering commitment to faith, family, and hard work will undoubtedly continue to drive her as she leads the Small Business Administration in empowering small businesses across the country,‚Äù Mr. Roberts said. FOXIFIED In the week of Nov. 25 to Dec. 1, Fox News aired 98 of the top 100 cable news telecasts, drawing an average of 2 million viewers in prime time and 1.4 million between 6 a.m. and 6 p.m. ‚ÄúFor the week, Fox News Channel crushed CNN by 407% with total day viewers and 577% with primetime viewers, and crushed MSNBC by 293% with total day viewers and 334% with primetime viewers,‚Äù the network said in a written statement released Thursday. And the rivals‚Äô specific numbers: In prime time, MSNBC drew a daily average of 595,000 viewers, while CNN pulled in 411,000. During the daytime viewing hours, MSNBC had an average audience of 454,000 while CNN had 332,000 viewers. A pair of weekday shows also had noteworthy numbers. Harris Faulkner‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe Faulkner Focus‚Äù earned an daily average audience of 1.8 million while ‚ÄúThe Story With Martha MacCallum‚Äù drew 1.7 million. Both programs outpaced NBC‚Äôs ‚ÄúToday With Hoda and Jenna‚Äù (1.5 million), ABC‚Äôs ‚ÄúGMA3‚Äù (1.3 million, ‚ÄúNBC News Daily‚Äù (also 1.3 million) and CBS‚Äô ‚ÄúThe Talk‚Äù (1.2 million). ‚ÄúThe Five‚Äù continues to be the most popular show on Fox News with 4.1 million viewers during the week, followed by ‚ÄúJesse Watters Primetime‚Äù (3.5 million); ‚ÄúThe Ingraham Angle‚Äù (3.1 million) and ‚ÄúSpecial Report With Bret Baier‚Äù (2.9 viewers). WEEKEND REAL ESTATE For sale: Historic adobe hacienda and former artist‚Äôs studio built in 1850 in Galisteo Village, New Mexico. Three bedrooms, four baths, substantial library, living room, formal dining room, wood beamed ceilings and tile floors plus several fireplaces. Property features an inner courtyard with koi pond and fountain, covered outdoor walkways plus gallery space and storage areas. Lush greenery, fruit trees and flower gardens, distant mountain views. Priced at $1.3 million through bethcaldarello.com. Enter 202404373 in the ‚ÄúFind a Home‚Äù section of the site. Find the place to enter the number by clicking on the logo at the upper right corner of the page. POLL DU JOUR ‚Ä¢ 32% of registered U.S. voters said they were ‚Äúvery satisfied‚Äù with the choice of presidential candidates in the 2024 election. ‚Ä¢ 20% of registered voters said they were ‚Äúfairly satisfied‚Äù with the choice of candidates. ‚Ä¢ 22% of registered voters said they were ‚Äúnot too satisfied‚Äù with the choice of candidates. ‚Ä¢ 25% of registered voters said they were ‚Äúnot at all satisfied‚Äù with the choice of candidates. ‚Ä¢ 1% had no answer. SOURCE: A Pew Research Center poll of 8,072 registered U.S. voters conducted online or by telephone Nov. 12-17 and released Dec. 4. ‚Ä¢ Follow Jennifer Harper on X HarperBulletin, on Facebook @Harperuniverse. Contact her at jharper@washingtontimes.com
Ai bias and explanation:
Center  
The article presents a balanced overview of various topics related to Pearl Harbor remembrance, weather forecasts, and media ratings without showcasing strong bias towards a particular political ideology. It includes perspectives that highlight historical significance, commentary on weather forecasts, and media performance metrics rather than engaging in partisan rhetoric or advocacy, suggesting a neutral stance that appeals to a broad audience.

title: Biden administration backs off proposed overhaul of apprenticeship programs
body: JEFFERSON CITY, Mo. (AP) ‚Äî President Joe Biden‚Äôs administration has withdrawn a proposed overhaul of workplace apprenticeship programs after facing pushback from business groups concerned about the costs and Republican state attorneys general opposed to new diversity requirements. The U.S. Department of Labor confirmed Wednesday that it won‚Äôt be moving forward with a proposed rewrite of the National Apprenticeship System rules. A department spokesperson declined to explain why the proposal was withdrawn. The agency had previously cited a need to modernize an on-the-job-training system that has remained largely the same since 2008. Registered apprenticeship programs approved by the federal government or states provided training and education for hundreds of thousands of workers in fields ranging from construction to manufacturing to public administration. The proposed rule change would have required apprenticeship program sponsors to recruit people from ‚Äúunderserved communities,‚Äù which it defined to include women, people of color, those with disabilities and people who are lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender, among others. It also would have required state apprenticeship agencies to develop plans for advancing diversity, equity, inclusion and accessibility. A group of two dozen Republican state attorneys general objected, asserting the proposal could have run awry of a U.S. Supreme Court ruling that prohibited race as a deciding factor in college admissions, striking down affirmative action programs. Some business groups asserted that increased oversight and reporting requirements could have driven up costs of apprenticeship programs while other proposed changes could have reduced flexibility and participation. The proposal would have required at least 2,000 hours of paid on-the-job training, eliminating an option to finish sooner for workers who prove their competence. The decision to back off the rule change was welcomed by Associated Builders and Contractors, which has about 450 government-registered apprenticeship programs in 20 occupations. The proposal amounted to ‚Äúa massive increase in red tape‚Äù that would have made the apprenticeship system ‚Äúeven more complicated and less attractive,‚Äù said Ben Brubeck, the group‚Äôs vice president of regulatory, labor and state affairs.
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Left  
The article discusses the Biden administration's withdrawal of a proposed overhaul of apprenticeship programs, emphasizing the opposition from business groups and Republican state attorneys general to diversity requirements. While it covers administrative action fairly, the focus on pushback from conservative groups and the lack of in-depth discussion on the potential benefits of the proposal indicates a slight tendency toward a left-leaning perspective, particularly in supporting diversity and inclusion while acknowledging opposition.

title: House Republicans Say Federal Government Buried 2023 Report Supporting LNG Exports
body: House Republicans say the Biden administration buried a 2023 analysis that cautioned against imposing its January 2024 pause in processing new liquified natural gas (LNG) export permits and continues to dodge congressional requests to provide documents that justified the decision.Those claims were among allegations that GOP panelists lodged against the Department of Energy (DOE) during a 75-minute Dec. 4 hearing staged by the House Oversight and Accountability Committee‚Äôs Economic Growth, Energy Policy, and Regulatory Affairs Subcommittee.‚ÄúReports indicate that before the ban, the White House met with activists and TikTok influencers‚ÄîI‚Äôm not making that up‚Äîwho were adamant the administration take radical steps to address climate change and eliminate fossil fuels,‚Äù said the subcommittee‚Äôs chair, Rep. Pat Fallon (R-Texas). Story continues below advertisement Despite a year of committees requesting documents relevant to the pause with little success, Fallon said it was upsetting to learn through a nonprofit‚Äôs Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request that 97 documents totaling 4,354 pages of LNG analyses were not provided by DOE in response to queries.‚ÄúAs it turns out, there may have already been a 2023 study in existence that the department kept under wraps and is still fighting to withhold,‚Äù Fallon said.‚ÄúIt appears possible that when the information ... did not fit the narrative pushed by the White House, that information was buried in an attempt to clear the way for a more politically favorable analysis.‚ÄùRelated StoriesUS LNG Production Surge Will Double Exports by 2028: EIA9/7/2024Federal Regulator Greenlights Louisiana LNG Terminal, Pipeline6/27/2024Assistant U.S. Secretary of Energy for Fossil Energy and Carbon Management Brad Crabtree denied knowledge of any such study.‚ÄúI‚Äôve not been presented with the document, so I‚Äôm not aware of what you‚Äôre referring to,‚Äù he said, noting that if it exists, it is among many studies that prompted the pause. Story continues below advertisement President Joe Biden announced on Jan. 26 that DOE would not process new LNG export permits to non-free-trade-agreement countries because analytics needed to be updated to ascertain ‚Äúpotential energy cost increases for American consumers and manufacturers‚Äù and ‚Äúthe impact of greenhouse gas emissions.‚ÄùUnder the Natural Gas Act, DOE must review applications to export LNG to ensure they are ‚Äúconsistent with the public interest,‚Äù primarily if exports would raise domestic prices and cause environmental damage. DOE last conducted such a study in 2018.The administration said it would publish DOE‚Äôs draft report by late 2024. Energy Secretary Jennifer Granholm has repeatedly said a draft would be available by December and finalized by February 2025, including on May 23 before the House Oversight and Accountably Committee.Regardless of the study, the permit pause is set to be lifted on Jan. 20, 2025, after President-elect Donald Trump is sworn in. Repealing the pause is among a flurry of ‚ÄúDay One‚Äù executive orders he vows to issue. Story continues below advertisement Crabtree confirmed the report would be published in ‚Äúmid-December‚Äù and would include a 60-day comment period.House Republicans maintain that the Biden administration has never been transparent about the data it used to justify the pause.The House Oversight and Accountability Committee and subcommittees have staged at least 17 hearings on Biden‚Äôs energy policies, including the LNG pause, in the past two years. They‚Äôve requested DOE provide documents related to the pause since March with little success.An LNG tanker is guided by tug boats at the Cheniere Sabine Pass LNG export unit in Cameron Parish, La., on April 14, 2022. Marcy de Luna/Reuters Story continues below advertisement Documents Acknowledged, Not ReleasedThe revelation that nearly 100 documents spanning more than 4,000 pages were not provided in response to queries inadvertently surfaced in a Sept. 13 FOIA request filed by Government Accountability & Oversight (GAO), a Washington-based ‚Äúpublic interest‚Äù watchdog.GOA‚Äôs FOIA specifically sought ‚Äúdocuments and correspondence within the Department of Energy related to a purported 2023 liquefied natural gas export study‚Äù that it claims ‚Äúwas buried by senior agency officials to justify a pause of LNG export authorizations.‚ÄùThe nonpartisan nonprofit says that to support the permit freeze, the administration tossed analyses by DOE‚Äôs National Energy Technology Lab and the U.S. Energy Information Administration and, instead, relied on a 2023 study that was not peer-reviewed and has since been rebuffed.That study, ‚ÄúThe Greenhouse Gas Footprint of Liquefied Natural Gas (LNG) Exported from the United States‚Äù by Cornell University professor David Howarth, maintains, among other claims, that LNG is worse for the climate than coal. Story continues below advertisement Howarth‚Äôs study has been cited as flawed by Natural Allies for a Clean Energy Future‚Äôs research and Berkeley Research Group, which in an April study found that U.S. LNG delivered to Europe and Asia has a greenhouse gas intensity 50 percent to 55 percent lower than the coal it would displace.‚ÄúThe work of Dr. Howarth played no role in the decision,‚Äù Crabtree said. ‚ÄúOur methodology is fundamentally different from that of Mr. Howarth.‚ÄùGAO‚Äôs FOIA seeks ‚Äúany LNG export study transmitted by the National Energy Technology Lab to DOE‚Äôs Office of Fossil Energy and Carbon Management between Jan. 1, 2023 and Oct. 31, 2023.‚ÄùDOE, however, ‚Äúhas unilaterally reinterpreted‚Äù what documents GAO is seeking ‚Äúas applying only to records [DOE] asserts are ‚Äòfinal‚Äô or ‚Äòready for release‚Äô for the public‚Äôs view,‚Äù it maintains. Story continues below advertisement Reps. Russell Fry (R-S.C.), August Pfluger (R-Texas), Scott Perry (R-Pa.), Lauren Boebert (R-Colo.), and Clay Higgins (R-La.) interrogated Crabtree about the undisclosed documents and why DOE is not releasing them.‚ÄúIt is my understanding our team that works on document production has been in cooperative engagement with the committee,‚Äù Crabtree said, adding ‚Äúfour document distributions‚Äù fostered by GAO‚Äôs FOIA have been released and ‚Äúthe next one, I understand, is planned for Friday.‚ÄùHe said 2,000 pages had been made public since September but that he‚Äôs ‚Äúnot part of the process‚Äù‚ÄúSo I can‚Äôt speak to the details of that process. In my role, I have no involvement in it. But if you feel that the department has not been responsive to the committee, I‚Äôm happy to take any specific concerns back to that team,‚Äù he said. Story continues below advertisement Boebert said Crabtree‚Äôs responses ‚Äúmay be the reason why we have to create a ... Department of Government Efficiency, to have actual oversight and accountability on bureaucrats.‚ÄùA heat exchanger and transfer pipes at Dominion Energy's Cove Point LNG Terminal in Lusby, Md., in this file image. Cliff Owen/AP PhotoPodesta No-ShowFallon noted that senior adviser to the president for international climate policy John Podesta was ‚Äúinvited‚Äù to testify and that it was ‚Äúunfortunate‚Äù that he opted not to.‚ÄúThese are questions I would have asked him,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúHow many times did he meet with TikTok influencers on climate issues leading up to or following the announcement of the LNG export ban? Was the White House relying on TikTok influencers for policy advice when it pushed the LNG ban? Did the White House vet them for foreign influence or sponsorship?‚Äù Story continues below advertisement Fallon said Podesta orchestrated these meetings‚Äîseveral panelists said author-activist Bill McKibben, founder of 350.org, ‚Äúthe first global grassroots climate campaign,‚Äù was a participant but suggested he may have had other reasons to lobby for a pause.John Podesta‚Äôs brother, Tony Podesta, ‚Äúis known to have lobbied for foreign LNG companies, including one co-owned by a Qatar state-run energy company,‚Äù he said.Since the pause was imposed, Qatar has ‚Äúsecured long-term LNG export contracts, invested in export infrastructure, and increased capacity, while the United States falls behind competitively,‚Äù Fallon said.Crabtree said he knows nothing of such meetings and said Qatar‚Äôs increased LNG capacity ‚Äúwas years in the making.‚Äù Story continues below advertisement Ranking member Rep. Melanie Stansbury (D-Colo.) called the hearing ‚Äúa rehash of a topic we‚Äôve already covered,‚Äù describing the uproar as ‚Äúa politically manufactured non-issue‚Äù stewing in irony.It‚Äôs ‚Äúinteresting‚Äù that Republicans ‚Äúare suddenly very concerned about having social media influencers involved in government decision-making. I hope that will extend to the new subcommittee that a certain billionaire social media owner is hoping to intersect with right here in this committee in the coming years,‚Äù she said.She said she‚Äôs ‚Äúintrigued‚Äù that colleagues ‚Äúare suddenly very concerned about foreign influence over American energy production,‚Äú alleging that ‚ÄùRussian disinformation‚Äù is heard daily inside the committee.
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Right  
The article reports on House Republicans alleging that the Biden administration has suppressed information regarding LNG exports, using strong language that emphasizes a critical stance towards the administration. The focus on Republican claims and the portrayal of the Department of Energy as non-transparent indicate a subtle bias towards a conservative viewpoint. However, it also includes perspectives from the administration‚Äôs representatives, suggesting a moderate tone, thus positioning it as leaning right rather than explicitly right-wing.

title: Canada bans 324 varieties of guns: ‚ÄòThese firearms can no longer be used‚Äô
body: OTTAWA, Ontario ‚Äî Canada said Thursday it is outlawing another 324 firearm varieties - guns the public safety minister said belong on the battlefield, not in the hands of hunters or sport shooters. Ottawa also said it is working with the government of Ukraine to see how the guns can be donated to support the fight against Russia‚Äôs invasion of Ukraine. The move follows the May 2020 ban of 1,500 makes and models of firearms, a number that grew to more than 2,000 by November of this year as new variants were identified. The latest restriction, announced Thursday by Public Safety Minister Dominic LeBlanc, follows expressions of concern from gun-control advocates that many assault-style firearms were not included in the 2020 ban. ‚ÄúThis means these firearms can no longer be used,‚Äù LeBlanc said. Defense Minister Bill Blair said Canada approached Ukrainian authorities, who expressed interest in some of the guns. ‚ÄúEvery bit of assistance we can offer to the Ukrainians is one step toward their victory,‚Äù Blair said. The federal government says it is working with provinces, territories and police on a planned buyback of prohibited weapons from individual owners. Mass shootings are relatively rare in Canada, but the newly announced measures come on the eve of the 35th anniversary of the √âcole Polytechnique in Montreal, where a gunman killed 14 women before killing himself. The Ruger Mini-14 used by the gunman, Marc Lepine, was among the weapons included in the 2020 ban. Nathalie Provost, a survivor who was wounded in the attack, said Thursday she was targeted for being a woman studying engineering. ‚ÄúThese are just killing weapons, war weapons, military weapons, so I‚Äôm proud we are doing something,‚Äù Provost said. Canada has had far fewer mass shootings than the U.S. in part because of a lack of easy access to guns, though the U.S. population also is far larger than Canada‚Äôs. Officials have acknowledged guns smuggled into Canada illegally are often used by criminals. Opposition Conservative leader Pierre Poilievre called the announcement a ‚Äústunt‚Äù by Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau‚Äôs government that attacks ‚Äúlicensed & law-abiding hunters and sport shooters.‚Äù
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Left  
The article presents a clear pro-gun control stance, emphasizing the benefits of restrictive gun laws and the government's intent to enhance public safety. It highlights quotes from advocates for gun control while providing less emphasis on opposing viewpoints, specifically summarizing the criticisms from the Conservative leader without offering a balanced perspective. The tone and choice of words suggest a preference for stricter regulations, aligning more with left-leaning viewpoints on gun control policy.

title: Hegseth nomination sinking fast in the Senate
body: Senate Republicans say Pete Hegseth, President-elect Trump‚Äôs choice to head the Defense Department, faces a very tough path to confirmation in the Senate and his bleak prospects have been communicated directly to the Trump transition team, which is now mulling other options. Senate sources say there is a block of likely ‚Äúhard no‚Äôs‚Äù in the Senate GOP conference and identify Sens. Susan Collins (R-Maine), Lisa Murkowski (R-Alaska) and Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) as lawmakers who view Hegseth‚Äôs nomination very skeptically. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know that there‚Äôs a real clear path,‚Äù said one Republican senator, adding that colleagues ‚Äúare very apprehensive‚Äù about Hegseth‚Äôs nomination. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs damaging to the president,‚Äù the senator added. ‚ÄúIt doesn‚Äôt help us in the Senate.‚Äù Hegseth waged a significant effort to salvage his nomination Wednesday, including by pledging to Republican senators that he would stop drinking if confirmed as secretary of Defense. And some Republican senators, even those who are defense hawks, think Hegseth could be a good choice to lead the Pentagon, citing his background as a decorated combat veteran and his lack of deep connections to the Defense Department‚Äôs network of generals who tend to resist big changes. But Republicans are also hoping to be spared the headache and embarrassment of public confirmation hearings in which women who have accused Hegseth of sexual misconduct or former colleagues who have accused him of unprofessional behavior might testify. GOP lawmakers say they don‚Äôt want to publicly call for Hegseth to resign based on anonymous allegations. They argue that a key difference between Hegseth and former Rep. Matt Gaetz (R-Fla.), who recently dropped his bid to become attorney general, is that Hegseth‚Äôs accusers haven‚Äôt testified in sworn depositions like Gaetz‚Äôs accusers did. But the accumulation of damaging allegations against the nominee is alarming Republican senators. A second GOP senator said Hegseth appears ‚Äúheaded‚Äù for defeat in the Senate Armed Services Committee or on the Senate floor if he doesn‚Äôt withdraw. The lawmaker said Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.), a staunch Trump ally, has floated Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis (R) as a possible alternative to Hegseth. Another Republican senator familiar with Trump‚Äôs deliberations over what to do about Hegseth‚Äôs nomination said the president-elect himself floated DeSantis‚Äôs name as a potential replacement to a group of people. ‚ÄúI think some of these articles are very disturbing,‚Äù Graham told CBS News on Tuesday. ‚ÄúHe obviously has a chance to defend himself here, but some of this stuff is going to be difficult.‚Äù Asked Wednesday about his conversations with Trump, Graham told The Hill: ‚ÄúI said to him what I said to everybody else.‚Äù Graham argued Hegseth should have a chance to defend himself from allegations of sexual and financial misconduct and excessive drinking. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve known him for a long time. All this stuff is new to me. I‚Äôm not going to tank him because of anonymous sources. Somebody‚Äôs got to come forward and make a credible allegation. He deserves a chance to defend himself. Those accusing him of something need to come forward,‚Äù Graham said. ‚ÄúThe allegations are anonymous. If they‚Äôre true, he‚Äôll have a hard time,‚Äù he said. Sen. Kevin Cramer (R-N.D.), a member of the Senate Armed Services Committee, said Hegseth needs to put a hard stop to his drinking. ‚ÄúI need to be convinced he‚Äôs not going to drink anymore. I know it sounds oversimplistic, but I also think it contributes to all of his other problems, his substance abuse. I‚Äôm way too familiar with it in my own family, and nobody wants a secretary of Defense that‚Äôs got a drinking problem,‚Äù Cramer said. Sen. Roger Wicker (R-Miss.), the incoming chair of the Senate Armed Services Committee, said Hegseth pledged to him at a meeting Wednesday morning that he would stop drinking if confirmed. ‚ÄúI think that‚Äôs probably a good idea,‚Äù Wicker told reporters. Two sources familiar with the matter confirmed to The Hill that Trump is weighing alternative options in the event Hegseth is forced to withdraw, though Trump has not yet signaled he‚Äôs giving up on Hegseth. Trump has spoken with DeSantis about the prospect of the top Pentagon job, and DeSantis is open to the role, one source said. The Florida governor served in the Navy and is aligned with Trump‚Äôs vision to eliminate ‚Äúwoke‚Äù aspects of the military. Trump and DeSantis saw each other Tuesday at a memorial for fallen Florida law enforcement officers. Other names that have been floated for the role include Sen. Joni Ernst (R-Iowa) and Elbridge Colby, who served in a deputy role in the Defense Department during Trump‚Äôs first term. One Senate Republican aide said Ernst has to proceed extremely carefully in how she handles Hegseth‚Äôs nomination if she wants to get the nod as Trump‚Äôs plan B to lead the Defense Department. The source warned that Ernst would enrage Trump‚Äôs MAGA base if she‚Äôs viewed as the senator responsible for sinking Hegseth‚Äôs nomination. Ernst told reporters she had a ‚Äúfrank and thorough‚Äù conversation with Hegseth after meeting with him for 45 minutes Wednesday afternoon. She declined to entertain any speculation about her leading the Defense Department if Hegseth flames out. ‚ÄúPete is the nominee,‚Äù she said. Hegseth has shown no signs of backing down. He penned a Wall Street Journal op-ed claiming he was the target of a ‚Äúmanufactured media takedown.‚Äù He went on Megyn Kelly‚Äôs SiriusXM show, where he said Trump reiterated his support during a conversation earlier Wednesday and likened his situation to that of Brett Kavanaugh, the Supreme Court justice who was confirmed after a bitter process in which he was accused of sexual assault. Hegseth‚Äôs mother, Penelope Hegseth, appeared on ‚ÄúFox & Friends‚Äù to push back on a New York Times report about an email she sent her son in 2017 criticizing his treatment of women. She has since said she regretted sending the note. Penelope Hegseth specifically used the appearance on Fox to appeal to female senators, whom she urged to keep an open mind about her son‚Äôs nomination. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs a changed man. And I just hope people will get to know who Pete is today,‚Äù Penelope Hegseth said. ‚ÄúEspecially our dear female senators. That you would listen to him. Listen with your heart to the truth of Pete.‚Äù One source in Trump‚Äôs orbit noted the media blitz was unusual for the president-elect‚Äôs nominees. Not even Gaetz went on television to try to salvage his nomination as it faltered. While Senate GOP aide warned of the block of ‚Äúhard no‚Äôs‚Äù Hegseth will face in the conference, anpther predicted that more damaging revelations are likely to surface. ‚ÄúIt could always get worse,‚Äù the second aide said. ‚ÄúThe FBI background check is not going to be fun.‚Äù Al Weaver contributed.
Ai bias and explanation:
Center  
This article presents a balanced view of the challenges facing Pete Hegseth‚Äôs nomination without overtly favoring any political ideology. It provides insights from various Senate Republicans, highlighting both their concerns and support for Hegseth, which indicates an impartial approach to the unfolding political drama. The piece includes quotes from multiple lawmakers, avoiding loaded language that favors a specific narrative, and maintains a factual tone that aims to inform rather than persuade.

title: Trump taps Paul Atkins to lead the SEC in crypto-friendly move
body: President-elect Donald Trump has nominated Paul Atkins for chair of the Securities and Exchange Commission. Atkins was an SEC commissioner under President George W. Bush and is a well-known figure in Washington's conservative financial world. He's also an outspoken supporter of the crypto industry and cochairs the Chamber of Digital Commerce's Token Alliance, an industry-led initiative to represent the sector. If confirmed, Atkins will replace Gary Gensler, who has drawn the ire of much of the crypto community and plans to step down as chair on January 20. "Paul is a proven leader for common sense regulations," Trump said in a Truth Social post announcing the pick. He added that Atkins "recognizes that digital assets & other innovations are crucial to Making America Greater than Ever Before." Atkin's nomination puts Trump a step closer to fulfilling his promise to create a more crypto-friendly regulatory regime. On the campaign trail, Trump promised to fire Gensler, who crypto players have criticized for stifling innovation and creating uncertainty with his approach to regulating the industry. Bitcoin and ethereum both rose on the news and were up 3.3% and 7.7%, respectively, around 3:40 p.m. ET. Bitcoin is once again testing the key $100,000 threshold that it nearly cleared last week before reversing course. During his tenure, Gensler led the SEC on a crackdown on crypto issuers for dealing in what the agency said were unregistered securities. Industry insiders soured on his stance, blaming Gensler for pushing crypto business out of the US. Following last month's news that Gensler would resign when Trump takes office, crypto token XRP rallied sharply to become the third largest coin by market capitalization. The token had languished in recent years as the SEC targeted issuer Ripple Labs for violating securities law. The market expects the agency to drop that lawsuit and many other crypto suits under Trump.
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Right  
The article highlights Donald Trump's nomination of Paul Atkins, a figure well-aligned with conservative financial and crypto interests. It reflects a positive perspective on Trump's actions regarding cryptocurrency regulation and portrays the previous SEC chair, Gary Gensler, unfavorably, emphasizing dissatisfaction from the crypto community. The focus on pro-crypto sentiment and the framing of Trump's move as aligning with market interests indicate a bias towards right-leaning economic perspectives and support for deregulation, characteristic of a Lean Right classification.

title: USSS chief says lawmaker politicized 9/11 during Trump assassination hearing
body: Rowe: ‚ÄúDo not invoke 9/11 for political purposes!‚Äù Fallon: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not. I‚Äôm invoking -‚Äú Rowe: ‚ÄúYou are, sir. You are way out of line!‚Äù [Ray] The final Congressional hearing on the assassination attempts on Donald Trump devolved into a screaming match regarding this year‚Äôs 9/11 remembrance ceremony. Congressman Pat Fallon accused Acting Secret Service Director Ronald Rowe of putting the lives of President Biden, Vice President Harris and President-elect Trump at risk by attending the memorial ceremony as an agency representative rather than being on duty. Fallon: You know why you were there, because you wanted to be visible because you‚Äôre auditioning for this job that you‚Äôre not going to get. Rowe: I was there to pay respect to a fallen member of this agency. During the hearing, Rowe presented Congress with multiple changes he‚Äôs making to the agency in order to improve protection. The changes include the creation of a leadership development program. Rowe said they need to identify agents who will make good leaders before they get promoted to GS-15, which is the highest level a federal employee can reach before moving to an executive position. Rowe: We need to hit people and identify leaders earlier on, besides just saying, well, they‚Äôve been here for 18 years, let‚Äôs make them a GS 15 Rowe will also increase training hours for agents so that it is ‚Äúroutine and expected‚Äù, which he describes as a culture change. Rowe: Somehow, along the way, we became disproportionately operational in comparison to time allocated for training. Rowe is also moving the office of investigations into the office of field operations which he says will increase the role of field offices for planning. Rowe said improvements are already underway thanks to the $231 million in supplemental funding Congress gave the agency in September. He said the extra money was crucial. Rowe: The Secret Service historically has had to manage its operations by doing more with less. It is not consistent with achieving a no fail mission. Donald Trump will have the authority to appoint a new Secret Service Director when he takes office in January. Rowe has been serving in an acting capacity since the resignation of Kimberly Cheatle in July.
Ai bias and explanation:
Center  
The article presents a straightforward account of a congressional hearing regarding the Secret Service and does not display significant partisan language or bias. It covers both sides of the argument, providing the perspectives of both Congressman Pat Fallon and Acting Secret Service Director Ronald Rowe, focusing on their exchanges and the operational changes at the agency. The reporting does not lean toward political extremes, aiming instead to deliver factual information about a governmental process.

title: Exclusive ‚Äî Rep. Warren Davidson: Pete Hegseth the ‚ÄòKind of Guy We Need Leading the Department of Defense‚Äô
body: Pete Hegseth is ‚Äúthe kind of guy we need leading the Department of Defense,‚Äù Rep. Warren Davidson (R-OH) said during an appearance on Breitbart News Daily, contrasting him with President Biden‚Äôs Secretary of Defense Lloyd Austin, ‚Äúwho thinks the biggest threat to national security is climate change.‚Äù Davidson said part of his role in the confirmation process of President-elect Trump‚Äôs nominees is peer pressure and ‚Äútrying to influence senators that we have relationships with [and] trying to find out who the senators that, you know, have reservations.‚Äù Inside the Pete Hegseth Confirmation Battle with Matt Boyle As an example, Davidson, a former Army ranger, pointed out that he promoted Pete Hegseth on Wednesday. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs the kind of guy we need leading the Department of Defense. ‚Ä¶ Pete Hegseth was a combat veteran, led infantry line units in combat, and he‚Äôs talked all about how to make the military focused on the combat mission,‚Äù Davidson said, contrasting Hegseth with Austin. ‚ÄúAnd now you‚Äôve got a secretary, Lloyd Austin, who thinks the biggest threat to national security is climate change, who‚Äôs walking around talking about a chairman of the joint chiefs, Milley. He‚Äôs talking about the big risk of white rage in the military and all kinds of woke agenda, which is why, you know, Biden and Obama picked these kind of guys,‚Äù he observed. ‚ÄúAnd how do you get our military back to a lean, mean fighting machine focused on fighting and winning wars, and then a State Department that could actually say no to some of them. And I think Pete Hegseth checks both of those boxes. Like, yes, if we need to win a war, we‚Äôre going to go in and win. But just like Dwight Eisenhower did back in the day in Korea, he said, you know, we don‚Äôt have to get involved in every war we‚Äôre invited to,‚Äù Davidson said. LISTEN: Breitbart ¬∑ Rep. Warren Davidson (R-OH) ‚Äì December 5, 2024 ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs wrap this thing up. And I mean, I think that‚Äôs the time we‚Äôre in right now. We don‚Äôt need to create World War III in Ukraine. We don‚Äôt need to be dragged into another war in the Middle East unnecessarily. And the best way to do that, as Donald Trump has said, is peace through strength,‚Äù he added. Breitbart News Daily airs on SiriusXM Patriot 125 from 6:00 a.m. to 9:00 a.m. Eastern.
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Right  
The article analyzes Rep. Warren Davidson's support for Pete Hegseth as a potential leader for the Department of Defense while criticizing President Biden and Secretary of Defense Lloyd Austin's focus on climate change and other "woke" agendas. The language aligns with conservative viewpoints and emphasizes military strength over social issues, typical of right-leaning media. The bias is evident through the framing of national security debates and the negative portrayal of opposing perspectives, characteristic of a "lean right" media stance.

title: Justice Gorsuch will sit out a pending environmental case, citing ethics code
body: WASHINGTON ‚Äî Supreme Court Justice Neil Gorsuch will not participate in an environmental case being argued next week after having reviewed the court's new ethics code, according to a letter sent Wednesday to lawyers involved. The letter from Supreme Court Clerk Scott Harris did not explain why Gorsuch was recusing himself, saying only that "consistent with the code of conduct" he had decided not to participate. Liberal groups and more than a dozen members of Congress had urged him to recuse himself over his previous links to billionaire Philip Anschutz. Focus on Supreme Court justices and the rules that govern whether they recuse themselves from cases have drawn scrutiny in recent years, spurred largely by revelations about Justice Clarence Thomas‚Äô ties to billionaire Harlan Crow. Justices have resisted codifying rules, but last year they adopted a new code of conduct that critics say lacks an enforcement mechanism. The case Gorsuch opted to sit out revolves around the environmental review process for a railroad in Utah that would ship crude oil out of the Uinta Basin to existing railroads. Anschutz has an interest in the project, as shown by an amicus brief Anschutz Exploration Corp. filed in the case backing it. In a letter last month, Rep. Hank Johnson, D-Ga., wrote on behalf of himself and colleagues that Gorsuch has "a serious and obvious conflict of interest that demands your recusal." He mentioned that Gorsuch, before he became a judge, had represented Anschutz and his businesses and had close ties to him. As an appeals court judge before he was appointed to the Supreme Court, Gorsuch usually stepped aside from cases involving Anschutz. "I applaud Justice Gorsuch for doing the right and honorable thing," Johnson said in a statement. ‚ÄúIt is important that the court show the public that it is not in the pocket of billionaire benefactors." But he added that the court's ethics code should have an enforcement mechanism, which he has introduced legislation to address.
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Left  
The article reflects a Lean Left bias by focusing on the decisions and opinions of liberal groups and Democratic politicians regarding Justice Gorsuch's ethics and recusal, portraying them positively while highlighting concerns about potential conflicts of interest involving wealthy donors. The inclusion of criticism and calls for reform in the Supreme Court's ethics guidelines suggests a progressive viewpoint that emphasizes accountability and the influence of money in politics.

title: A landmark climate change case will open at the top U.N. court
body: THE HAGUE, Netherlands (AP) ‚Äî The top United Nations court will take up the largest case in its history on Monday, when it opens two weeks of hearings into what countries worldwide are legally required to do to combat climate change and help vulnerable nations fight its devastating impact. After years of lobbying by island nations who fear they could simply disappear under rising sea waters, the U.N. General Assembly asked the International Court of Justice last year for an opinion on "the obligations of States in respect of climate change." "We want the court to confirm that the conduct that has wrecked the climate is unlawful," Margaretha Wewerinke-Singh, who is leading the legal team for the Pacific island nation of Vanuatu, told The Associated Press. In the decade up to 2023, sea levels have risen by a global average of around 4.3 centimeters (1.7 inches), with parts of the Pacific rising higher still. The world has also warmed 1.3 degrees Celsius (2.3 Fahrenheit) since pre-industrial times because of the burning of fossil fuels. Vanuatu is one of a group of small states pushing for international legal intervention in the climate crisis. "We live on the front lines of climate change impact. We are witnesses to the destruction of our lands, our livelihoods, our culture and our human rights," Vanuatu's climate change envoy Ralph Regenvanu told reporters ahead of the hearing. Any decision by the court would be non-binding advice and unable to directly force wealthy nations into action to help struggling countries. Yet it would be more than just a powerful symbol since it could serve as the basis for other legal actions, including domestic lawsuits. On Sunday, ahead of the hearing, advocacy groups will bring together environmental organizations from around the world. Pacific Islands Students Fighting Climate Change ‚Äî who first developed the idea of requesting an advisory opinion ‚Äî together with World Youth for Climate Justice plan an afternoon of speeches, music and discussions. From Monday, the Hague-based court will hear from 99 countries and more than a dozen intergovernmental organizations over two weeks. It's the largest lineup in the institution's nearly 80-year history. Last month at the United Nations' annual climate meeting, countries cobbled together an agreement on how rich countries can support poor countries in the face of climate disasters. Wealthy countries have agreed to pool together at least $300 billion a year by 2035 but the total is short of the $1.3 trillion that experts, and threatened nations, said is needed. "For our generation and for the Pacific Islands, the climate crisis is an existential threat. It is a matter of survival, and the world's biggest economies are not taking this crisis seriously. We need the ICJ to protect the rights of people at the front lines," Vishal Prasad, of Pacific Islands Students Fighting Climate Change, told reporters in a briefing. Fifteen judges from around the world will seek to answer two questions: What are countries obliged to do under international law to protect the climate and environment from human-caused greenhouse gas emissions? And what are the legal consequences for governments where their acts, or lack of action, have significantly harmed the climate and environment?
