Young victims trafficked under Joe Biden say they have been mentally and physically tortured to compel their obedience, including heavy doses of drugs plus medieval torments, such as having their fingernails pulled out. A whistleblower at the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) said in November 2024 that Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris created a ‚Äúwhite-glove delivery service‚Äù for putting migrant children into the hands of traffickers and drug cartels. ‚ÄúToday, as we speak, children are preparing to work grueling overnight shifts in slaughterhouses, restaurants, and factories. Some children may die today in jobs they don‚Äôt have the knowledge or skills to do in order to repay never-ending debts to their smugglers and traffickers,‚Äù said whistleblower Tara Lee Rodas. The House Judiciary Committee published a report in November that said foreign nationals linked to human trafficking have used the Biden-Harris ‚Äúparole pipeline‚Äù for Cubans, Haitians, Nicaraguans, and Venezuelans to move freely across the border. The parole pipeline, formally known as the CHNV program, is a bureaucratic fiction created by the Biden administration to keep the number of migrant encounters with the Border Patrol down, masking the severity of the border crisis. According to House Judiciary, the system proved very useful to sex traffickers, who submitted a large number of fraudulent applications from suspicious Internet addresses, the vast majority of them for young women. President Biden appeared very well-versed on the events of 1619 while touring Angola. It is a pity he did not focus more on the events of 2021-2024 while he was in charge of stopping modern-day slavery across the southern border.
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Right  
The article presents a critical perspective on President Biden's speech regarding slavery, framing his administration's policies as contributing to modern-day slavery and human trafficking. It emphasizes negative consequences of Biden's actions and includes a whistleblower account that is highly critical. This focus on the alleged failures of a Democratic leader while contrasting with conservative viewpoints aligns the article more with a lean right perspective, suggesting disapproval of left-leaning policies and ideologies.

title: Trump nominates cryptocurrency advocate Paul Atkins as SEC chair
body: President-elect Donald Trump announced Wednesday that he intends to nominate cryptocurrency advocate Paul Atkins to chair the Securities and Exchange Commission. Trump said Atkins, the CEO of Patomak Partners and a former SEC commissioner, was a ‚Äúproven leader for common sense regulations.‚Äù In the years since leaving the SEC, Atkins has made the case against too much market regulation. ‚ÄúHe believes in the promise of robust, innovative capital markets that are responsive to the needs of Investors, & that provide capital to make our Economy the best in the World. He also recognizes that digital assets & other innovations are crucial to Making America Greater than Ever Before,‚Äù Trump wrote on Truth Social. The commission oversees U.S. securities markets and investments and is currently led by Gary Gensler, who has been leading the U.S. government‚Äôs crackdown on the crypto industry. Gensler, who was nominated by President Joe Biden, announced last month that he would be stepping down from his post on the day that Trump is inaugurated ‚Äî Jan. 20, 2025. Trump, once a crypto skeptic, had pledged to make the U.S. ‚Äúthe crypto capital of the planet‚Äù and create a ‚Äústrategic reserve‚Äù of bitcoin. Money has poured into crypto assets since he won. The value of bitcoin, the largest cryptocurrency, passed $100,000 Wednesday. And shares in crypto platform Coinbase have surged more than 70% since the election. Paul Grewal, chief legal officer of Coinbase, congratulated Atkins in a post on X. ‚ÄúWe appreciate his commitment to balance in regulating U.S. securities markets and look forward to his fresh leadership at (the SEC),‚Äù Grewal wrote. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs sorely needed and cannot come a day too soon.‚Äù Congressman Brad Sherman, a California Democrat and a senior member of the House Financial Services Committee, said he worries Atkins would not sufficiently regulate cryptocurrencies as SEC chair. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôd probably take the position that no cryptocurrency is a security, and hence no exchange that deals with crypto is a securities exchange,‚Äù Sherman said. ‚ÄúThe opportunity to defraud investors would be there in a very significant way.‚Äù Atkins began his career as a lawyer and has a long history working in the financial markets sector, both in government and private practice. In the 1990s, he worked on the staffs of two former SEC chairmen, Richard C. Breeden and Arthur Levitt. His work as an SEC commissioner started in 2002, a time when the fallout from corporate scandals at Enron and WorldCom had turned up the heat on Wall Street and its government regulators. Atkins was widely considered the most conservative member of the SEC during his tenure at the agency and known to have a strong free-market bent. As a commissioner, he called for greater transparency in and analysis of the costs and benefits of new SEC rules. He also emphasized investor education and increased enforcement efforts against those who steal from investors over the internet, manipulate markets, engage in Ponzi schemes and other types of fraud. At the same time, Atkins objected to stiff penalties imposed on companies accused of fraudulent conduct, contending that they did not deter crime. He caused a stir in the summer of 2006 when he said the practice of granting stock options to executives before the disclosure of news that was certain to increase the share price did not constitute insider trading. U.S. Rep. Patrick McHenry, a North Carolina Republican and chairman of the House Financial Services Committee, said Atkins has the experience needed to ‚Äúrestore faith in the SEC.‚Äù ‚ÄúI‚Äôm confident his leadership will lead to clarity for the digital asset ecosystem and ensure U.S. capital markets remain the envy of the world,‚Äù McHenry posted on X. Atkins already has some experience working for Trump. During Trump‚Äôs first term, Atkins was a member of the President‚Äôs Strategic and Policy Forum, an advisory group of more than a dozen CEOs and business leaders who offered input on how to create jobs and speed economic growth. In 2017, Atkins joined the Token Alliance, a cryptocurrency advocacy organization. Crypto industry players welcomed Trump‚Äôs victory in the hopes that he would push through legislative and regulatory changes that they‚Äôve long lobbied for. Trump himself has launched World Liberty Financial, a new venture with family members to trade cryptocurrencies.
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Right  
The article predominantly reflects a pro-Trump perspective, emphasizing the nomination of Paul Atkins, who aligns with Trump's free-market and deregulation views. It highlights positive reactions from cryptocurrency advocates and offers critical remarks from Democratic representatives, framing the narrative around Trump's economic initiatives without extensive analysis or criticism. This positioning suggests a lean towards right-leaning media bias, favoring pro-business sentiment and minimal regulation in the context of cryptocurrency.

title: Police release new photo of suspect sought in killing of UnitedHealthcare CEO
body: The New York police department on Thursday issued a fresh image clearly showing the face of a man they suspect of shooting and killing the UnitedHealthcare CEO, Brian Thompson, early on Wednesday in Manhattan. The manhunt continued and police appeared to be closing in on the fugitive as key new clues surfaced. The newly-released images were taken by security cameras at a hostel on the Upper West Side neighborhood of Manhattan where police think the suspect stayed. In previous images issued the suspect was wearing a mask. But late morning on Thursday, police posted photographs showing a young man smiling and one of the same person looking more serious, with the hood of his coat up. The suspect remained at large while investigators scrambled to find out his identity and as police continued to comb through a vast network of private and public surveillance cameras. Law enforcement deployed drones and dogs in addition to sifting through data related to electric bikes. Despite officials previously referring to the Citi Bike brand of public-use e-bike to talk about the vehicle that was used in the crime, and thousands of which are dotted around the city at charging ports, later on Thursday morning this proved to be unconfirmed. There was a report by the New York Times, citing sources familiar with the investigation, that police were now looking into it being an unmarked electric bike.Police chiefs have said it was a targeted killing. Among other clues discovered were acell phone, video footage of the suspect and shell casings from bullets found at the scene with the words ‚Äúdeny‚Äù, ‚Äúdefend‚Äù and ‚Äúdepose‚Äù, according to unnamed sources who also spoke with ABC News. Those words potentially evoke a book published 14 years ago that criticized the US health insurance industry, with its title using vocabulary common in corporate language around insurance claims, called Delay Deny Defend: Why Insurance Companies Don‚Äôt Pay Claims and What You Can Do About It, Reuters reported. The book‚Äôs author, Jay Feinman, a professor emeritus at Rutgers University Law School in New Jersey, told the news agency ‚Äúsorry, no comment‚Äù in an email responding to an enquiry. The coincidence hints at possible motive, but by early Thursday afternoon the authorities had not addressed that angle nor posited a motive for the killing. Police had earlier searched the hostel where the suspect is believed to have stayed, CNN reported, also reporting that police found a fingerprint while investigating objects connected to the man, including a cellphone and a water bottle, and that evidence was being examined in hopes it could pin down an identity. ‚ÄúThis does not appear to be a random act of violence,‚Äù Jessica Tisch, New York City police commissioner, told reporters. ‚ÄúEvery indication is that this was a premeditated, pre-planned, targeted attack.‚Äù Thompson was killed by a man in black carrying a gray backpack and with his face covered up to the nose around 6.40am ET Wednesday. The police have been using the word ‚Äúhe‚Äù when referring to the suspect. The man in questions had leveled a handgun fitted with a silencer at Thompson‚Äôs back and shot the executive at least once in the back and the calf, just as he was about to enter a midtown Manhattan Hilton hotel for an annual investor conference. As Thompson collapsed on the sidewalk, the gun jammed, the man ‚Äì ‚Äúproficient‚Äù in firearms according to police ‚Äì quickly cleared it and resumed shooting. The suspect then fled on an e-bike into nearby Central Park. As of Thursday, there have been no arrests in the case, and police offered a $10,000 reward for information. Since Wednesday, police have also uncovered footage of the man near the Frederick Douglass public housing project on Manhattan‚Äôs Upper West Side around 5am ET, ABC News reported. The suspect‚Äôs motives remain unknown. Thompson‚Äôs widow said her husband had received threats. However, such incidents are not uncommon in controversial sectors. ‚ÄúThere had been some threats,‚Äù Paulette Thompson told NBC News. ‚ÄúBasically, I don‚Äôt know, a lack of coverage? I don‚Äôt know details. I just know that he said there were some people that had been threatening him.‚Äù UnitedHealthcare is a branch of UnitedHealth Group, one of the largest companies in the United States. The branch insures tens of millions of people with private health coverage. The need for private-sector health insurance is a fact of life in the US, but frequently a thorn in American‚Äôs side, and insurers are often accused of unfairly denying coverage. The company was also the subject of an insider trader investigation and inquiry into unfair trade practices, Fox Business News reported. Thompson‚Äôs killing quickly sent shockwaves through the corporate world, with corporate security heads gathering in a conference call to Wednesday. ‚ÄúMany of my colleagues today are sitting down with their executive protection team leaders, their security leadership teams, and re-evaluating what they are doing and not doing,‚Äù Dave Komendat, president of Seattle-based Komendat Risk Management Services told the New York Times. Another security executive, CEO Michael Julian of MPS Security & Protection, told Axios: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm just shocked the guy didn‚Äôt have a protective detail.‚Äù Thompson is survived by his wife Paulette and two sons. The Associated Press, Reuters and Joanna Walters contributed to reporting
Ai bias and explanation:
Center  
The article presents factual reporting on the killing of UnitedHealthcare CEO Brian Thompson, focusing on police investigations and developments without endorsing a particular ideological stance. It includes insights from law enforcement and quotes from relevant parties, maintaining neutrality in its depiction. The balanced approach and reliance on reputable sources align this piece with a Center classification, as it refrains from critical commentary on broader health insurance issues or political implications.

title: The Democrats who aren't writing off Elon Musk's DOGE
body: As Republicans rush to embrace Elon Musk and Vivek Ramaswamy's Department of Government Efficiency, most Democrats have taken a dismissive, even adversarial approach to the new initiative. "Musk is a narcissist, a grifter, and a self-serving plutocrat," said Democratic Rep. Greg Casar of Texas. "I don't have my hopes up that Elon Musk is going to do anything other than really awful, stupid, self-serving stuff." It's not hard to see why. Ramaswamy was one of the more right-wing 2024 GOP presidential candidates, while Musk ‚Äî who just spent an immense sum of his own money to get Donald Trump elected ‚Äî has emerged in recent years as a Democratic bogeyman. And while the contours of DOGE's agenda remain vague, there are already signs that progressive priorities could fall victim to Musk and Ramaswamy's proposals for deep spending cuts. Yet a handful of Democratic lawmakers have signaled a willingness to engage, eyeing DOGE as an unlikely opportunity to push their own long-standing policy goals. Democratic Rep. Ro Khanna of California and Sen. Bernie Sanders of Vermont, an independent who caucuses with Democrats, see tackling wasteful military spending as a potential point of common cause with DOGE. Rep. Jared Moskowitz of Florida on Tuesday became the first Democrat to join the House's DOGE caucus. He told BI that his "singular focus" would be restructuring the Department of Homeland Security by making the Federal Emergency Management Agency and the Secret Service report directly to the president. "If this is where that conversation is going to happen, I'm happy to be at the table," Moskowitz said. "And if they want to do stupid stuff, I'll call it out and I'll vote against it." The three lawmakers' DOGE-curious posturing also offers an early look at how some Democrats, fresh off of a defeat in the 2024 election, plan to cautiously engage with a Trump administration that's set to pursue a more radical transformation of the country than the first time around. Khanna, a Silicon Valley-based progressive who remains cordial with Musk, appears to be taking the billionaire businessman seriously when he says he wants to examine the Pentagon's budget, citing Musk's past criticism of bloated defense contracts. The congressman has also suggested that Democrats have unduly alienated Musk in recent years. "If Musk is going to help bring accountability to defense contractors, that's something that Democrats should welcome," Khanna said. But other progressives who want military spending cuts are much more suspicious. "I highly doubt that one of the largest defense contractors in the United States ‚Äî and by that I mean Elon Musk ‚Äî is going to opt for the federal government to cut the money that he is receiving directly from them," said Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez of New York. "He relies on the federal government to give him money." Sanders, who argued on X that Musk "is right" about bloated military spending, may be using the unexpected synergy to highlight an issue he's long cared about. The Vermont senator told BI that he hadn't directly engaged with Musk and that it remains to be seen how seriously the SpaceX founder should be taken on the issue. "I would hope that he is serious," Sanders said. "If you want to save taxpayer dollars, you do it not by cutting programs for hungry children but by getting rid of the waste and fraud in the military." Despite these small areas of potential agreement, much of what Musk and Ramaswamy have floated so far is likely to be anathema to the average Democratic lawmaker. There's a reason that Republicans and not Democrats are set to meet with the duo at the Capitol on Thursday. Last week, Musk said that the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, an agency established by President Barack Obama that regulates financial services, should be eliminated. And Democratic Sen. Tina Smith of Minnesota said Musk and Ramaswamy wanted to "defund Planned Parenthood," as the duo described the organization as a recipient of "federal expenditures that are unauthorized by Congress or being used in ways that Congress never intended." That's not deterring lawmakers like Khanna and Moskowitz just yet. "Obviously, if they're targeting areas that are going to lead to less education funding or less consumer protection, we need to speak up passionately, vociferously, and oppose it," Khanna said. "But our opposition will be much more effective and reasonable if we're willing to work with them on areas where there is government fraud and abuse." "Some of these recommendations, I'm sure, will be horrible," Moskowitz said. "But a broken clock is right twice a day, so if there are things that they find that we can improve, shouldn't we give it a chance?" But while Khanna could end up serving on a new DOGE subcommittee set to be chaired by Republican Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene of Georgia, Moskowitz says he's steering clear. "I'm not interested in doing anything Marjorie Taylor Greene touches," Moskowitz said. "She's not a serious member."
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Left  
The article presents a generally adversarial view of Elon Musk and his initiatives, highlighting critical quotes from Democratic lawmakers while acknowledging a small number willing to engage. The tone suggests skepticism towards Musk's motives, indicating a preference for progressive values. The juxtaposition of differing Democratic opinions demonstrates a nuanced approach but leans toward criticism of right-wing agendas. Overall, it reflects a Left-leaning perspective by focusing on progressive concerns and framing Musk in a largely negative light.

title: Dem Sen. Murphy: We Should ‚ÄòCome After Elon Musk‚Äô He ‚ÄòMade His Fortune Off of Taxpayers‚Äô
body: On Thursday‚Äôs broadcast of MSNBC‚Äôs ‚ÄúKaty Tur Reports,‚Äù Sen. Chris Murphy (D-CT) questioned the effectiveness of the Department of Government Efficiency and stated that Elon Musk ‚Äúbasically has made his fortune off of government subsidies‚Äù and Democrats should ‚Äúcome after the insurance companies, the big defense companies that are all reaping huge amounts of money off of the government. Let‚Äôs come after Elon Musk, who‚Äôs made his fortune off of taxpayers.‚Äù Murphy said, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm just not sure that [DOGE] has anything to do with breaking up the status quo. You‚Äôve put a billionaire, who basically has made his fortune off of government subsidies in charge of deciding how the government should spend its money. This sounds like either a con job, in which Elon Musk comes out of this with his programs protected, and perhaps his competitors‚Äô programs targeted or just a TV show. ‚Ä¶ So, yes, I think Democrats should put on the table how we think we can cut government. Let‚Äôs come after the drug companies, come after the insurance companies, the big defense companies that are all reaping huge amounts of money off of the government. Let‚Äôs come after Elon Musk, who‚Äôs made his fortune off of taxpayers. Democrats should be involved in the conversation about government efficiency. I just don‚Äôt know that this group has anything to do with actual, meaningful commonsense cuts. It may be about protecting billionaires from those cuts or it may just be about a publicity stunt.‚Äù Follow Ian Hanchett on Twitter @IanHanchett
Ai bias and explanation:
Left  
This article reflects a left-leaning bias as it features a Democratic senator criticizing a billionaire, Elon Musk, for allegedly profiting from government subsidies. The commentary advocates for increased scrutiny of wealthy individuals and corporations benefiting from taxpayer money, which aligns with typical leftist concerns regarding wealth inequality and corporate influence in politics. Statements are sourced from MSNBC, a network often associated with progressive perspectives, further supporting the classification as left-leaning.

title: Support of Edward Snowden pardon grows as 2nd Trump term nears
body: [Lauren Taylor] WILL PRESIDENT-ELECT DONALD TRUMP PARDON EDWARD SNOWDEN IN HIS SECOND TERM? SEVERAL PEOPLE ON TRUMP‚ÄôS TEAM ARE REPORTEDLY SUPPORTING EFFORTS TO MAKE IT HAPPEN. TRUMP PASSED OVER THE OPTION OF GRANTING SNOWDEN A PARDON IN 20-21 DURING HIS FIRST PRESIDENCY ‚Ä¶ SAYING HE WOULD LET THE COURTS WORK IT OUT. SNOWDEN ‚Äì A FORMER SPY FOR THE N-S-A ‚Äì IS RESPONSIBLE FOR THE LARGEST LEAK OF TOP-SECRET INFORMATION ABOUT U-S SURVEILLANCE PROGRAMS IN THE NATION‚ÄôS HISTORY. HE‚ÄôS BEEN LIVING IN MOSCOW ‚Ä¶ AVOIDING AN INDICTMENT FROM THE JUSTICE DEPARTMENT FOR MORE THAN A DECADE. MATT GAETZ ‚Ä¶ WHO WITHDREW AS TRUMP‚ÄôS NOMINEE FOR ATTORNEY GENERAL ‚Ä¶ SAYS THE TOPIC OF PARDONING SNOWDEN IS STILL ON THE TABLE ‚Ä¶ TELLING THE WASHINGTON POST QUOTE ‚ÄúI HAVE DISCUSSED THE MATTER WITH OTHERS IN AND AROUND THE TRANSITION AND THERE SEEMED TO BE PRETTY BROAD SUPPORT FOR A PARDON.‚Äù GAETZ ALSO NOTED THAT EVEN THOUGH HE NEVER TALKED TO TRUMP DIRECTLY ABOUT SNOWDEN ‚Ä¶ HIS ADVOCACY FOR A PARDON DIDN‚ÄôT STOP TRUMP FROM NOMINATING HIM. TRUMP‚ÄôS DIRECTOR OF NATIONAL INTELLIGENCE PICK TULSI GABBARD SPONSORED A 20-20 HOUSE BILL WITH GAETZ CALLING FOR THE GOVERNMENT TO DROP CHARGES AGAINST SNOWDEN. AND ‚Ä¶ TRUMP‚ÄôS HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES SECRETARY CHOICE ROBERT F KENNEDY JUNIOR SUPPORTS A PARDON OF SNOWDEN AS WELL ‚Ä¶ CAMPAIGNING ON THAT PROMISE WHILE RUNNING FOR PRESIDENT. I‚Äôm going to pardon Edward Snowden on my first day in office. VICE PRESIDENT ELECT J-D VANCE HAS NOT TAKEN ANY PUBLIC POSITIONS ON SNOWDEN, BUT PEOPLE CLOSE TO HIM TOLD THE NEW YORK POST THEY EXPECT HIM TO BE SYMPATHETIC TO SNOWDEN‚ÄôS SITUATION. ACCORDING TO THE ATTORNEY WHO REPRESENTED SNOWDEN ‚Ä¶ HE RELEASED THE CLASSIFIED INFORMATION IN ORDER EXPOSE ‚ÄúABUSES‚Äù BY THE GOVERNMENT. SNOWDEN HAS NOT COMMENTED YET ON THE POSSIBILITY OF A RENEWED PUSH FOR A PARDON FROM TRUMP. FOR SAN ‚Äì I‚ÄôM LAUREN TAYLOR. FOR ALL YOUR LATEST NEWS HEADLINES ‚Äì DOWNLOAD THE STRAIGHT ARROW NEWS APP TODAY.
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Right  
This article discusses potential support for pardoning Edward Snowden, highlighting individuals from Trump's team who advocate for it. The tone appears sympathetic toward Snowden and hints at a favorable view of Trump's actions. However, it maintains a neutral reporting style without overtly promoting a specific political agenda, which aligns it more closely to a "Lean Right" classification, acknowledging conservative figures while not fully embracing their positions.

title: Bob Barr to Newsmax: Trump, NRA Will Protect Gun Rights
body: National Rifle Association President Bob Barr told Newsmax on Thursday that Donald Trump will be a steadfast ally in defending the Second Amendment and praised the president-elect's commitment to gun rights. "I want to see Donald Trump be Donald Trump," Barr told "Finnerty." "When he came to the NRA a year ago at our annual meeting, as he has done in the past, he said, 'I understand the Second Amendment. I will protect the Second Amendment, and the NRA will have, as president, a friend in the White House.' "That's all we want: a president that understands the Second Amendment and is willing to stand with the over 4 million NRA members in support of it." Barr said efforts to undermine Trump and conservative causes through legal avenues, or "lawfare," are failing. "I don't think that the left will cease its efforts to abuse public offices and the laws of this land, whether it's, you know, in California or New York, to go after their enemies," Barr said. "But what will happen over the next four years is they will accelerate in losing cases, because Americans all across this country are fed up with people like [New York Attorney General] Letitia James using the power of their office to silence those with whom they simply disagree. That's what's going to happen over the next four years with Donald Trump and the presidency." Barr said the NRA faces intense opposition from many on the left due to a fundamental ideological clash. "The left is all about one thing, ultimately, and one thing only, and that is control. They want to control people. They want to control institutions. They want to control government entities. "And the Second Amendment at its core is all about the government not controlling you by protecting our God-given right to keep and bear arms, particularly for self-defense. That's what the left cannot tolerate," he said. Barr congratulated Trump and said, "[W]e here at the NRA look forward to working with you in support of the Second Amendment over the coming four years." Jim Thomas ‚úâ Jim Thomas is a writer based in Indiana. He holds a bachelor's degree in Political Science, a law degree from U.I.C. Law School, and has practiced law for more than 20 years.
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Right  
The article features a prominent right-wing figure, Bob Barr, expressing support for Donald Trump and the NRA's stance on gun rights. It presents a clear ideological opposition to the left's views, framing their actions as attempts at control, which aligns with a lean right perspective. The tone and content of the commentary promote conservative ideals, suggesting a bias towards right-leaning values and criticism of liberal approaches. Such framing typically characterizes media leaning towards conservative viewpoints.

title: David Hogg ‚ÄòSeriously Considering‚Äô Running For Top DNC Job To Fix Party‚Äôs ‚ÄòCondescending¬†Tone‚Äô
body: Far-left activist David Hogg is reportedly considering running for a top leadership position in the Democratic National Committee (DNC) because he believes he can fix the party‚Äôs problem of talking down to voters.Politico reported that Hogg has told reporters that he is ‚Äúseriously considering‚Äù running for DNC Vice Chair.The failed pillow salesman, who has made a name for himself by aggressively calling for taking away American‚Äôs Second Amendment rights, appeared on CNN Thursday morning where he addressed the report.‚ÄúWell, honestly, I‚Äôm considering it because I think that, one, obviously, I think we need a new generation in the DNC, if this election has taught us nothing else,‚Äù Hogg said. ‚ÄúI think we need an intergenerational coalition as a party.‚ÄùHe claimed that as he has traveled the country, he realized that the party has ‚Äúa number of problems.‚ÄùAdvertisementCHECK OUT THE DAILY WIRE HOLIDAY GIFT GUIDE‚ÄúI think the main one overall is that we would rather live in a comfortable delusion than an uncomfortable reality,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúAnd I think what the party needs to do is open its eyes and take its fingers out of its ears basically.‚ÄùHe said that Democrats only want to talk to elitist Democrats and that the party has an issue of talking in a ‚Äúcondescending tone‚Äù to others.AdvertisementWATCH:David Hogg says he is ‚Äúconsidering‚Äù running for a top leadership position in the Democrat Party because he wants people to take the party seriously again and because they‚Äôve become arrogantEvery Republican and conservative will be praying this happens ü§£üòÇ pic.twitter.com/6hCAFigXkF‚Äî Ryan Saavedra (@RealSaavedra) December 5, 2024Advertisement
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Left  
The article focuses on David Hogg, a far-left activist, expressing concerns about the Democratic Party's tone and approach to voters. It uses language that may resonate more with a left-leaning audience by emphasizing Hogg's critical views of the party's current leadership. However, it also includes criticism of Hogg's perspective by labeling him a "far-left activist," as well as commentary from conservative voices that suggest skepticism towards his potential leadership, indicating a slight lean towards a left-leaning perspective amidst the critique.

title: Trump‚Äôs Cabinet choices are dreadful. Why are so many Democrats in Congress quiet?
body: Donald Trump‚Äôs nominees are without an iota of doubt the most appalling collection of choices any president has made to lead federal government departments. Multiple Trump picks have already withdrawn, and more may soon follow. Yet the response from Senate Democrats ‚Äî who will have votes and a voice in the confirmation process ‚Äî has been remarkably muted. Ask a Senate Democrat about the nominees, and you‚Äôre more likely to hear ‚ÄúI have some serious concerns‚Äù than the far more appropriate ‚ÄúMy God, is Trump insane? These are the worst nominees in history!‚Äù Many of these Democrats would consider such a response uncivil and undignified; if Trump won‚Äôt adhere to norms of propriety, at least they will. Worse, they believe that it is politically clever for them to show voters that they seek bipartisanship, even if that desire turns out to be unrequited. ‚ÄúAs I have long said, our preference is to secure bipartisan solutions wherever possible and look for ways to collaborate with our Republican colleagues to help working families,‚Äù Chuck Schumer, leader of Senate Democrats, said on social media. ‚ÄúHowever, our Republican colleagues should make no mistake about it, we will always stand up for our values.‚Äù Republicans are no doubt quivering in the face of such a blistering assault. This is a miscalculation born of a misunderstanding. Democrats need to grasp that during Trump‚Äôs second term, the electorate won‚Äôt be evaluating them either as individuals or as a party, based on whether they acted in good faith and sought areas of agreement with the GOP. The truth is: Voters don‚Äôt care about bipartisanship. They might tell pollsters they‚Äôd prefer it if everyone in Washington got along, and they may sincerely mean it. But when it comes time to vote, that‚Äôs not how they act. Opposition isn‚Äôt about how voters judge the opposition party; it‚Äôs about how they judge the party in power. The only evaluation from voters that matters for the next four years (and especially the next two years until the midterm elections) is that of Trump, his government and the Republicans who run Congress. In this situation, Democrats are not the alternative; their role is to oppose, loudly and unceasingly, and call attention to Republicans‚Äô worst excesses. They need to disseminate the most cutting and critical messages and force the news media to address stories of the administration‚Äôs worst misdeeds. Let‚Äôs consider some relevant recent history. In the 2008 election, Democrats won 365 electoral votes, 251 House seats and 59 Senate seats ‚Äî the most sweeping victory for one party in decades. Republicans could have decided that they needed to show the public they were committed to moderation and bipartisanship. They did just the opposite. On the very night of Barack Obama‚Äôs inauguration, GOP leaders gathered for dinner and planned to ‚Äúshow united and unyielding opposition‚Äù to the new president and his policies. A week later, House Republicans held a retreat where they committed themselves to all-out war against Obama; they cheered their recent unified vote against Obama‚Äôs recovery bill, and then-Rep. Mike Pence played a clip from the movie ‚ÄúPatton‚Äù of George C. Scott, as Gen. George S. Patton, rallying troops to fight the Nazis. In the Senate, Republican leader Mitch McConnell believed that bipartisanship had to be avoided at all costs, since it might legitimate Obama‚Äôs actions. Any tactic was justified in pursuit of opposition, up to and including refusing to allow a vote on the president‚Äôs Supreme Court nominee. The strategy was an extraordinary success: Republicans flipped 63 seats to take back the House in 2010 ‚Äî the biggest switch in over 60 years. The Senate went to the GOP in 2014 and the White House in 2016, after which Republicans also secured a majority on the Supreme Court. The voters never punished them for being too partisan. It‚Äôs not that Democrats haven‚Äôt been capable of united and vigorous resistance. They implemented a similar strategy of opposition after George W. Bush was re-elected in 2004, and as a result, they took control of both houses of Congress in the 2006 midterms. Their leaders at the time ‚Äî Harry Reid in the Senate and Nancy Pelosi in the House ‚Äî understood that their job was not to look for areas of agreement but to fight with every tool at their disposal. Which they did, and it worked. Yet somehow, today too many Democrats in Congress retain a conviction that it is important to ‚Äúget caught trying,‚Äù to demonstrate over and over that they are making an effort to reach out and seek agreement. Ask President Joe Biden how politically effective the search for bipartisanship is. Few presidents have ever worked as hard, both in private and in public, to win opposition support, especially from his old colleagues in the Senate. On a few occasions he did succeed, winning some Republican votes for the infrastructure law he signed in 2021 and the CHIPS and Science Act in 2022. But Republicans never stopped attacking him in the most intense, personal and ugly ways they could, and voters never rewarded Biden for his efforts at bipartisanship ‚Äî if they even knew about them. The confirmation hearings for Trump‚Äôs picks present a terrific opportunity for Democrats to define the Trump administration as both extremist and reckless, but it might be a mistake to get your hopes up. One example: The top Democrat on the Senate Armed Services Committee, which will be hearing the nomination for defense secretary, is Jack Reed of Rhode Island. The 75-year-old Reed is well-respected, conscientious and a former Army Ranger. But watch him talking about the disastrous choice of Pete Hegseth to run the Pentagon and you won‚Äôt hear a powerful case against Trump, Hegseth or the risk they pose to American security. Other Democrats on the committee have offered similarly weak comments about Hegseth. That could be a harbinger of what the confirmation hearings for Trump‚Äôs Cabinet will look like. Democrats should carefully plan their questioning of the nominees to demonstrate how repugnant so many of them are and how dangerous their confirmations would be ‚Äî not because they might persuade a few Republican senators to vote no, but because it‚Äôs a chance to send a strong message to the public about Trump and his cronies. Unfortunately, it may wind up being one more missed opportunity.
Ai bias and explanation:
Left  
The article is highly critical of Donald Trump's cabinet choices and suggests that Democrats should take a more aggressive stance against his nominations. It presents the perspective that Democrats are failing in their duty to oppose Trump effectively, reflecting a strong disapproval of his administration. The tone and language used are consistent with a left-leaning viewpoint, emphasizing the need for resistance against a Republican president rather than seeking bipartisanship.

title: Forbes Daily: Clock Is Ticking For Last-Minute Tax Tricks
body: Good morning, As 2024 dwindles to its final weeks, it‚Äôs high time to consider financial moves for tax purposes, such as a tax-deductible gift to a nonprofit. While donations to U.S. charities technically rose to more than $557 billion in 2023, overall giving actually declined when adjusted for inflation. Many point to an increased standard deduction‚Äîthanks to the 2017 Trump tax cuts‚Äîas an explanation for this drop in giving because fewer taxpayers are choosing to itemize. Remember to choose wisely, only donations to qualified charitable organizations are deductible on your federal taxes, and always ask for a receipt‚Äîeven for cash. And if you‚Äôre interested in other tax dodges‚Äîcough‚Äîstrategic moves that might make sense before December 31, keep reading for year-end tax advice from Forbes senior contributor William Baldwin. South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol lifted his declaration of emergency martial law Tuesday, hours after first announcing a decree seizing control of the national media and banning ‚Äúpolitical activities.‚Äù The last time martial law was declared in South Korea was in 1980, during an uprising against the country‚Äôs then-military dictatorship. A U.S. national security official said the U.S. was not notified prior to Yoon‚Äôs decision. MORE: Lawmakers from South Korea‚Äôs opposition parties submitted a motion to impeach President Yoon Suk Yeol Wednesday, amid widespread public anger and protests. The motion will likely be put to a vote later this week, though several senior members of Yoon‚Äôs staff have already resigned. President-elect Donald Trump is reportedly considering Florida Governor Ron DeSantis as a potential defense secretary nominee, amid growing doubts about his current pick Pete Hegseth‚Äôs chances of securing Senate confirmation as he faces scrutiny over allegations of sexual assault and drunken public behavior. Picking DeSantis for a cabinet role would mark a turnaround in his relationship with Trump, who repeatedly mocked the governor once he emerged as the president-elect‚Äôs main challenger in the GOP primary. Amazon Web Services announced it will launch a new AI supercomputer built from its own machine learning chips‚Äîa bid to rival chipmaking giant Nvidia. Named Project Rainier, the supercomputer will be finalized in 2025 and could break records for its size. Amazon saw its shares climb more than 1% following the news. For any hands-on Forbes Daily readers who do their own taxes, determining what year-end tax moves might work for you can be as simple as purchasing a copy of tax preparation software and practicing with ‚Äúdummy‚Äù returns. Whether it‚Äôs doing the math on gains or losses harvesting, bunching donations to a qualified nonprofit, or pulling the trigger on a Roth conversion, playing with the numbers yourself can help alleviate any nasty (or expensive) surprises. XRP, the $146 billion cryptocurrency behind the XRP Ledger blockchain, is one of the biggest winners from Donald Trump‚Äôs victory in the presidential election. In the weeks since, it has surged as much as 440% to touch $2.86. No one has benefited more than Ripple Labs cofounder Chris Larsen, half whose net worth is tied up in XRP tokens. His fortune has surged 278% from $3.3 billion after the election to $9.2 billion. Billionaire Oprah Winfrey announced her entry into the podcast wars Tuesday, and her new podcast series, The Oprah Podcast, will feature monthly interviews with authors from her popular book club. Winfrey is worth an estimated $3 billion, making her one of the wealthiest self-made women in the world. Here‚Äôs a twin bill of food recalls to watch out for. Concerns about salmonella contamination prompted the recall of cucumbers sold in 35 states by two produce companies on Monday, just days after two other major salmonella-related recalls affected whole cucumbers and organic eggs sold in more than two dozen states. Health authorities in California suspended the sale of raw milk products from Raw Farm after detecting the bird flu virus in milk samples collected from the Fresno-based dairy farm‚Äîwhich voluntarily recalled a batch from retail stores last month for the same reason‚Äîonce again highlighting potential safety issues linked to raw milk, which social media influencers and right-wing figures, including Robert F. Kennedy Jr., have promoted. TOPLINE AI hype is alive and well, but those looking to make their mark as a founder or business owner would do well to consider the advice of Nick Huber: Forget about changing the world. Huber‚Äôs first business didn‚Äôt begin with a slick pitch deck to potential investors or an analysis of the total addressable market but with a simple Craigslist ad subletting his place. He ended up creating Storage Squad, a summer service for college kids that picked up and stored their stuff over break, and would later sell the business in 2021 for $1.75 million. The experience helped him develop a startup philosophy that seems well suited to an age when so many white-collar workers feel threatened by AI. ‚ÄúAI will never be able to clean, build and maintain our physical world. The sweatier the job, the better,‚Äô‚Äô he declares. The 35-year-old Huber has made millions by not being a Wall Street wizard or coding apps that claim to ‚Äúchange the world.‚Äù Instead, he has built or invested in 11 businesses that together, he says, generated more than $50 million in sales last year. None are based in Manhattan or Menlo Park. They don‚Äôt retain fancy PR firms or claim to be making earth-shattering breakthroughs. Almost all of them were bootstrapped‚Äîand Huber insists that they earn their keep within a matter of months. He figures his network of storage facilities, which last year had $15 million in revenue, is worth around $140 million based on its $9.8 million in net operating income and the valuation of publicly traded storage companies. Add the value of his holdings in other companies, and Forbes estimates Huber is worth about $35 million. Huber hasn‚Äôt limited himself to dirty businesses. But he thinks that is the best place for most aspiring entrepreneurs to start. WHY IT MATTERS Huber‚Äôs approach to finding opportunities is simple but compelling: Just look around you, see what services are making money and figure out if you can do them better. As it expanded, Storage Squad picked its targets through common sense and a little experience‚Äînot big marketing studies. ‚ÄúWe figured out quickly that the private expensive schools with a lot of out-of-state students were our wheelhouse,‚Äù says Huber. ‚ÄúA state school in the south, like the University of Georgia, the kids are resourceful, they drive trucks, they go rent storage units.‚Äù The same can‚Äôt be said for Boston, where ‚Äúthey‚Äôve got dad‚Äôs Amex and they‚Äôre ready to solve the problem with a couple hundred bucks.‚Äù MORE How To Now Get Nearly Unlimited Funding To Build Your Small Business Empire The average age of Forbes‚Äô latest 30 Under 30 cohort is 27, but two out of 600 young achievers are just 17 years old and already making a meaningful impact, actor Mason Thames and founder Khandaker Wasi: 12: Thames, the youngest 30 Under 30 honoree for 2025, was 12 years old when he made his TV debut in the AppleTV+ series For All Mankind. He recently wrapped production on the live-action adaptation of How To Train Your Dragon 504 Found: Name of the nonprofit founded by Wasi, dedicated to raising awareness about 504 plans, or federal funding for neurodivergent accommodations in schools 19,700: Number of students with learning disabilities who Wasi‚Äôs nonprofit has reached through in-person and virtual webinars With more than 1 billion users as of this year, it‚Äôs increasingly difficult to stand out on LinkedIn, but there are new tactics for better visibility that work alongside the platform‚Äôs recent algorithm updates‚Äîat least until everyone else figures them out. Consider sharing your expertise via the platform‚Äôs dedicated newsletter or live-streaming functionality, and try revisiting your most engaging posts with a new hook or format to capitalize on proven successes. Wisdom the Laysan albatross is the oldest known wild bird‚Äîbut there‚Äôs something else special about her. She laid a new egg this year at the Midway Atoll National Wildlife Refuge in Hawaii. How old is Wisdom? A. 66 B. 70 C. 74 D. 78 Check your answer. Thanks for reading! This edition of Forbes Daily was edited by Caroline Howard.
Ai bias and explanation:
Center  
This article provides a mix of information without a strong ideological slant. It covers financial tips, charitable donations, business stories, and some political context without taking a partisan stance. The discussion about tax deductions highlights practical advice rather than promoting a specific political agenda. Overall, the tone is primarily informative and neutral, fitting a center classification in media bias.

title: NYPD Releases New Images Showing Face Of Suspect In Health Insurance CEO¬†Assassination
body: The New York Police Department shared new images on Thursday showing the face of the suspect in the execution-style shooting of UnitedHealthcare CEO Brian Thompson.In the new images, the suspect is seen wearing what appears to be a green jacket with a hood pulled over his head. The photos are the first posted by authorities that show the suspect‚Äôs face. The surveillance photos were taken at a youth hostel in Manhattan where police believe the suspect was staying before the killing, according to the New York Post. Police still don‚Äôt know the name of the suspect as they continue to pursue leads, The New York Times reported.üö®UPDATE: Below are photos of a person of interest wanted for questioning regarding the Midtown Manhattan homicide on Dec. 4. This does not appear to be a random act of violence; all indications are that it was a premediated, targeted attack. The full investigative efforts of‚Ä¶ pic.twitter.com/K3kzC4IbtS‚Äî NYPD NEWS (@NYPDnews) December 5, 2024The hostel where the suspect was staying, along with a home in Manhattan, was raided in connection to the fatal shooting, according to West Side Rag reporter Gus Saltonstall.AdvertisementThe NYPD is asking anyone with information about the case or the suspect to come forward, offering a $10,000 reward ‚Äúfor information leading to an arrest and conviction.‚Äù The suspect fled the scene of the shooting on foot before getting on a bike and riding into Central Park.Detectives investigating the scene where Thompson was gunned down found shell casings with the words ‚Äúdeny,‚Äù ‚Äúdefend,‚Äù and ‚Äúdepose‚Äù written on them, according to ABC News. Authorities said the shooting appears to be a ‚Äúbrazen targeted attack.‚Äù Authorities are also looking into multiple death threats Thompson received before he was killed.Thompson‚Äôs company UnitedHealthcare ‚Äî a subsidiary of UnitedHealth Group, one of the largest companies in the world ‚Äî has been criticized for denying patients‚Äô claims. The CEO was on his way to the Hilton hotel in Midtown Manhattan to take part in his company‚Äôs annual Investor‚Äôs Conference.AdvertisementCHECK OUT THE DAILY WIRE HOLIDAY GIFT GUIDEThe shooter fired at Thompson from behind as the health insurance CEO was approaching the Hilton early Wednesday morning. Video footage shows that after Thompson fell to the ground, the shooter fired at him multiple times. Thompson was taken to a hospital, where he was pronounced dead soon after the shooting.Advertisement
Ai bias and explanation:
Center  
The article presents factual reporting on a criminal investigation without overt political commentary or bias. It focuses on the investigation surrounding the assassination of a CEO, including details about the suspect and police actions. The tone remains neutral throughout, reporting on various aspects of the case without promoting particular ideological viewpoints, which aligns with a center classification.

title: The Associated Press‚Äô top photos of 2024 from the US
body: NASHVILLE, Tenn. (AP) ‚Äî The right frame can freeze a moment in time, creating meaning for the masses from a fist pump over a bloodied ear, a bridge crumbled by a ship, towns shredded by nature, and a victory sealed with an on-field kiss. NASHVILLE, Tenn. (AP) ‚Äî The right frame can freeze a moment in time, creating meaning for the masses from a fist pump over a bloodied ear, a bridge crumbled by a ship, towns shredded by nature, and a victory sealed with an on-field kiss. In 2024, photographers across the U.S. captured glimpses of humanity, ranging from a deeply divisive presidential election, to hurricanes and fires that ravaged communities, to campus protests over the war between Israel and Hamas in Gaza. The gallery from The Associated Press illustrates a new chapter of political history ‚Äî the assassination attempt on former President Donald Trump, the moment President Joe Biden announced he would no longer run again, the campaign sprint by Vice President Kamala Harris in Biden‚Äôs place, and the raw emotion from voters during a grueling contest ultimately won by Trump. Hurricanes whipped through the country with devastating imagery, leaving a path of wreckage and death from Florida to Appalachia. After Hurricane Helene, Lake Lure in North Carolina was shown in a jarring photo covered in shards of debris thick enough to hide the surface of the water. Hurricane Milton ripped apart the roof of Tropicana Field in St. Petersburg, Florida, home to Major League Baseball‚Äôs Tampa Bay Rays. The scale of destruction experienced in some corners of the country in 2024 was hard to capture and might have been harder to fathom. That was the case when a container ship slammed into the Francis Scott Key Bridge in Baltimore, causing it to collapse and crumple around the vessel, killing construction workers on the bridge. As flames torched the landscape in California, another image captured firefighters and sheriff‚Äôs deputies pushing a vintage car away from a burning home. Elsewhere in California, one photo is aglow with bright orange flames, broken up only by the subtle features of an animal running through them. But hope also persevered in the face of devastation. In Helene‚Äôs aftermath, an image from Crystal River, Florida, shows Dustin Holmes holding hands with his girlfriend, Hailey Morgan, as they sloshed through floodwaters with her 4- and 7-year-old children to return to their flooded home. And in Manasota Key, Florida, a family was lit up by the glow of flashlights as they walked to check on their home damaged by Milton. Other photos from 2024 also grabbed the darkness and shadows to emphasize light: among them, a rocket liftoff and a total solar eclipse. And, yes, eclipse glasses were back in style for a shared moment of skygazing. But many other photos delivered a blast of color, from the spectrum of the northern lights across a Maine sky to a crew of workers wading into the deep-red of a Massachusetts cranberry bog. And, once again, Taylor Swift captured the country‚Äôs attention, even as a part of the crowd. She rushed down from the stands to kiss her boyfriend, Kansas City Chiefs tight end Travis Kelce, after the Chiefs won the AFC Championship, en route to another Super Bowl win. Get the best of The AP‚Äôs photography delivered to your inbox every Sunday. Sign up for The World in Pictures.
Ai bias and explanation:
Center  
The article presents a neutral overview of significant events and images from 2024, without leaning towards a political agenda or displaying bias. It covers a variety of topics, including natural disasters, political moments, and cultural events, conveying a balanced representation of various facets of American life. The language used is straightforward and descriptive, supporting the classification as Center without favoring one ideological perspective over another.

title: Trump‚Äôs Mass Deportation Plan Has One Major Vulnerability
body: Donald Trump campaigned on a promise of mass deportations beginning on the first day of his presidency, and from every indication, he intends to make good on it. He has tapped white nationalist‚Äìfriendly hard-liners for key posts in the executive branch, and he claims that the government will deport millions of migrants by the end of 2025. If Trump‚Äôs public statements and the actions of his first administration are any guide, the new administration appears poised to expand detention facilities, attempt to reinstitute family separations, end programs like temporary protected status, deputize state and local officials and members of the military as immigration officers, and attempt to eliminate or limit the right to asylum for individuals fleeing persecution. But for those familiar with the nation‚Äôs immigration system, a key question about mass deportations is how the administration will contend with the need to hold hearings for individuals apprehended within the U.S. Generally, noncitizens who are present in the country (as opposed to arriving at the border) may be deported only following a hearing at which they can present evidence that they‚Äôre not deportable or are eligible for asylum. U.S. immigration courts have yearslong backlogs, so the need for hearings is likely to be a key choke point in Trump‚Äôs plan to rapidly deport millions. Perhaps the administration will just ignore the hearing requirement, because it has no intention of operating a ‚Äúprecise, legal‚Äù deportation scheme. But as much as lawlessness is part of Trump‚Äôs modus operandi, the administration seems unlikely to disregard the law entirely. The people who will carry out mass deportations‚Äîeveryone from Immigration and Customs Enforcement officers to sheriffs to lawyers and contractors‚Äîwant to believe that they are upholding the law. Rather than direct them to defy it, Trump‚Äôs appointees will likely come up with arguments for why mass deportations are legal. When it comes to hearings, the goal will be to find a way around the need to go before an immigration judge, so that individuals can be removed from the country quickly (perhaps within hours of being apprehended) and with no real process. The play, specifically, will be to vastly expand what‚Äôs known in immigration law as ‚Äúexpedited removal.‚Äù Established by Congress in the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996, expedited removal was designed to allow immigration officials to shut the door to migrants who appear at the border without permission to enter. The statute provides that an immigration officer may deport such a person ‚Äúwithout further hearing or review‚Äù unless they claim asylum or fear persecution. Hundreds of thousands of noncitizens arriving at the border are already deported every year through this ‚Äúshadow removal‚Äù regime, as Jennifer Lee Koh terms it. But the statute is not limited to the border. Technically, it allows the Department of Homeland Security to use expedited removal against most individuals residing anywhere in the United States who entered without permission and who do not ‚Äúaffirmatively show ‚Ä¶ to the satisfaction of an immigration officer‚Äù that they have been present in the country for at least two years. And there‚Äôs the rub. Deporting someone living in Atlanta or Milwaukee on the say-so of a single immigration officer is at odds with the Fifth Amendment to the Constitution, which guarantees due process of law to everyone in the United States regardless of immigration status. So, historically, expedited removal has generally been limited to people arriving at the border or those present in the U.S. for fewer than 14 days who are apprehended within 100 miles of the border. But the administration won‚Äôt care. During Trump‚Äôs first term, DHS attempted to expand expedited removal to the full limits of the statute, and the incoming administration is poised to repeat the gambit. DHS will likely authorize the use of expedited removal against anyone a single immigration officer thinks lacks status and who cannot come up with affirmative proof that they have been in the U.S. for two years. And it will issue ‚Äúguidance‚Äù stacking the deck against individuals whom immigration officers target‚Äîfor example, by limiting their time to produce evidence or providing that only certain forms of documentation will be considered. An individual who doesn‚Äôt have the right papers on them when they are approached by an immigration officer at 7 a.m. might be on a plane to Mexico by the evening. Deporting immigrants in this manner is not only an insult to due process; it will often put the nation in violation of its international obligations. Expedited removal isn‚Äôt meant to be used against individuals who credibly fear persecution in their home countries. But statements by Trump‚Äôs surrogates and actions by his previous administration suggest that this requirement will be honored in name only. According to Customs and Border Protection‚Äôs own guidelines, immigration officers are supposed to ask those in expedited-removal proceedings about their fear of return. The administration could easily roll back this guidance such that immigrants who do not know to state their fear of return will be summarily deported. The bar for passing a credible-fear interview, which is intended to serve merely as a screening tool to determine whether an individual can make their case in court, has historically been very low. Even with this low bar, those with meritorious asylum claims have been erroneously deported. But the prior Trump administration unlawfully raised the bar for credible-fear interviews and will likely attempt to do so again, allowing ICE officers to deport many more individuals with meritorious claims for asylum with little to no oversight or review and with no recourse for the noncitizen. Officers will move particularly quickly against those without a lawyer. The upshot is that even though most immigrants residing in the U.S. without permanent legal status are ineligible for expedited removal, hundreds of thousands‚Äîincluding individuals who are targeted because of their political beliefs, authorized immigrants, and possibly even citizens who don‚Äôt fit the Trump administration‚Äôs image of a ‚Äúreal‚Äù American‚Äîcould be rounded up and deported without the opportunity to appear before an immigration judge. The administration will bank on individuals with strong cases being unable to litigate them once they‚Äôre deported. Families will be torn apart. Prices will spike. And an untold number of individuals who are legally entitled to asylum will be returned to countries where they‚Äôll face death or serious harm. Although groups like the ACLU will challenge the expanded use of expedited removal, don‚Äôt look to the courts for a quick remedy. IIRIRA strips the courts of jurisdiction to hear challenges to many immigration policies. And even if the courts reach the merits of those cases, the administration has the power of unilateral action: As it did during Trump‚Äôs first term, it can change the rules, restart deportations in a slightly different way, and force lawyers and courts to play catch-up as planes full of deportees depart the U.S. Perhaps the most relevant precedent for the situation the nation faces is the battle over the Muslim ban Trump put in place at the beginning of his first administration; that policy threw the border into chaos and was repeatedly halted before the Supreme Court allowed a cleaned-up, watered-down version to take effect. That experience teaches that the key to resisting mass deportation will be to slow the program‚Äôs momentum to allow Congress, the courts, civil society, and the business community to push back. There‚Äôs no silver bullet. But states can make clear that they‚Äôll resist the administration‚Äôs unconstitutional plans, as Illinois Gov. J.B. Pritzker has done; strip immunity from sheriffs and others who participate in indiscriminate roundups; impose civil and criminal liability on those who participate in illegal deportations; and allocate funding for immigrant representation, following the lead of states such as New Jersey and New York. Nonprofit organizations and lawyers can provide community education on the limits of expedited removal, the right to a hearing, and the ways individuals can claim asylum or show they‚Äôre not subject to expedited removal. And business leaders can take a stand to protect the economy. None of this would prevent the administration from going to Congress and seeking the resources to run a humane, efficient immigration system that complies with the Constitution and the nation‚Äôs international obligations. But since it won‚Äôt do that, the priority must be to maintain the rule of law.
Ai bias and explanation:
Left  
The article has a clear critical stance toward the Trump administration's immigration policies, focusing on human rights and legal concerns regarding mass deportations. It emphasizes potential violations of due process and international obligations while framing the Trump administration's actions as "lawlessness." The language used and the emphasis on human rights advocates reflect a left-leaning viewpoint, showcasing concern for social justice and the treatment of immigrants rather than focusing solely on national security or strict immigration enforcement, which is more characteristic of right-leaning perspectives.

title: Meghan Trainor: I ‚ÄòGot Too Much Botox‚Äô And A ‚ÄòLip Flip,‚Äô Can‚Äôt ‚ÄòSmile¬†Anymore‚Äô
body: Pop singer Meghan Trainor said she regrets a cosmetic procedure she had recently which has left her unable to smile properly.The 30-year-old star discussed what happened during a recent episode of her ‚ÄúWorkin‚Äô On It‚Äù podcast, admitting she ‚Äúgot too much Botox.‚Äù‚ÄúI messed up,‚Äù she added.‚ÄúSomeone convinced me with my little lips that if you did a lip flip, you put filler right above your upper lip, that you could have a beautiful flip on your upper lip. And I could have one for the first time in my whole 30 years of living ‚Äî it was not true,‚Äù she said.‚ÄúI cannot smile anymore,‚Äù Trainor went on. ‚ÄúEverywhere I go, I cannot smile. My face hurts to smile, to even try.‚ÄùAdvertisementTrainor demonstrated her new look, saying, ‚ÄúThis is as big as I can smile,‚Äù while addressing the camera.She then shared a photo of herself holding a dog at a shelter. She said she was a ‚Äúhappy person‚Äù in the photo even if she didn‚Äôt look like it. ‚ÄúI look like I smelled someone‚Äôs fart,‚Äù she joked while speaking with her brother on the podcast. View this post on Instagram A post shared by Workin‚Äô On It Podcast (@workinonitpod)AdvertisementThe singer told her followers, ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt try everything.‚ÄùThe ‚ÄúWhoops‚Äù singer said despite the cosmetic procedure fail, she‚Äôs still planning on getting a breast procedure in the future.AdvertisementCHECK OUT THE DAILY WIRE HOLIDAY GIFT GUIDETrainor said she wants to get ‚Äújust a little lift,‚Äù and ‚Äúmaybe a little implant just so they‚Äôre like, ‚ÄòWe are boobs,‚Äô ‚Äòcause right now, they are not.‚ÄùAccording to the American Society of Plastic Surgeons, a lip flip uses Botox ‚Äúto relax a muscle in the upper lip, causing the lip to ‚Äòflip‚Äô and giving the appearance of a fuller upper lip. The procedure is different than getting lip fillers, which are injections directly into the lip, as opposed to above it.‚ÄùThe procedure is said to look more ‚Äúnatural‚Äù than traditional fillers.Several celebrities have been forthcoming about their plastic surgery failures in the past. Last year, ‚ÄúLittle House on the Prairie‚Äù actress Melissa Gilbert said she underwent cosmetic surgery that made her look like ‚Äúthe spawn of Satan.‚Äù‚ÄúI had no facial expression, which is anathema considering what I do for a living,‚Äù Gilbert said at the time, adding, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs exhausting keeping up that kind of fa√ßade. I was very insecure.‚ÄùAdvertisement
Ai bias and explanation:
Center  
This article presents a straightforward account of Meghan Trainor‚Äôs experience with cosmetic procedures without attaching strong political opinions or leaning toward a particular ideological perspective. It focuses on her personal narrative and regret regarding her choices, maintaining a neutral tone in reporting on a celebrity's experience.

title: Justice Neil Gorsuch Recuses From Case That Could Benefit Colorado Billionaire
body: Justice Neil M. Gorsuch has recused himself from a case that is set to be argued in days after ethics watchdogs and Democratic lawmakers urged him to step aside because the outcome will likely affect the financial interests of a billionaire to whom he has longstanding ties. The terse disclosure, made in a letter from a clerk to the Supreme Court to lawyers involved in the case, did not specify a reason, saying only that the decision was ‚Äúconsistent with the code of conduct.‚Äù But the announcement, issued late Wednesday, was unusual for a case that the court agreed to take in June. The case involves a proposed railroad in Utah and an environmental regulation governing the project. Neither the billionaire, Philip F. Anschutz, nor his companies are a party to the case. But the railway would provide better shipping service to an area of Utah where Mr. Anschutz has oil wells, so he could benefit from an outcome favorable to the railroad company. And an oil and gas exploration company owned by Mr. Anschutz has filed a friend-of-the-court brief urging the justices to curtail the environmental rule at issue ‚Äî a regulation his company must also obey when developing wells on leased public land. The brief says the rule has led to ‚Äúabsurd requirements‚Äù that cause ‚Äúsignificant harms to the project developers and the economy.‚Äù Justice Gorsuch‚Äôs recusal is particularly significant for two reasons. During his 2017 confirmation to the Supreme Court, his web of ties to Mr. Anschutz attracted attention, raising questions over whether he would step aside in cases involving the billionaire‚Äôs business interests. He appeared to leave that door open, despite having systematically sought to recuse himself from such cases as an appeals court judge. Against that backdrop, Justice Gorsuch had been under growing public pressure to recuse. In October, ethics and watchdog groups, led by Accountability US, called on Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. in an open letter to intervene. A month later, more than a dozen Democratic members of Congress sent a similar letter to Justice Gorsuch urging him to recuse. The recusal is also notable because it comes amid broader scrutiny on ethics at the Supreme Court, particularly after revelations that Justice Clarence Thomas, accepted ‚Äî and sometimes failed to disclose ‚Äî lavish trips and gifts from the billionaire Harlan Crow. Legislation to impose an ethics code on the justices has stalled, but in November 2023, the court unanimously adopted its first code of conduct. The New York Times has reported that in internal debate over the code, Justice Gorsuch insisted that it contain no enforcement mechanism beyond voluntary compliance. The code added some gloss to a vague 1974 statute that says justices should recuse themselves to avoid even the appearance of a conflict of interest. But Supreme Court justices have argued that they have a heightened ‚Äúduty to sit‚Äù for cases because there is no one to replace them if they step aside, unlike at the appeals court level. The court‚Äôs procedure is to let individual justices decide for themselves whether the standard for recusal is met; there is no appeal if they decide to stay on a case. While two Democratic-appointed justices, Elena Kagan and Ketanji Brown Jackson, have since publicly cited the code in recusing from certain cases, the new letter appears to be the first time a Republican-appointed justice has publicly cited it, said Gabe Roth of Fix the Court, a group that has pressed for stronger ethical standard. Most recusals happen because justices own stock in a company or have another personal financial conflict, or because justices had presided over the same case at an earlier stage, when they were still lower-court judges, Mr. Roth added. Recusals for personal ties to people who could benefit from the case ‚Äî Justice Gorsuch‚Äôs presumed reason, though the letter did not specify ‚Äî are ‚Äúvery rare,‚Äù he said. Mr. Anschutz has myriad ties to Justice Gorsuch, a Colorado native. Early in his career, the future justice represented Mr. Anschutz and his companies in a variety of lawsuits as outside counsel. In 2005, Justice Gorsuch formed a limited liability company with two lieutenants to Mr. Anschutz, through which they jointly bought a 40-acre vacation property to share. Once Justice Gorsuch joined the Supreme Court, they sold the property to the head of a major law firm. In 2006, Mr. Anschutz, a major conservative donor, played a major role in helping Justice Gorsuch secure President George W. Bush‚Äôs nomination to a seat on the federal appeals court in Denver. And after joining the appeals court, Judge Gorsuch appeared as a keynote speaker at the billionaires‚Äôs annual dove hunt parties at his ranch. Caroline Ciccone, the president of Accountable US, which first raised public alarms about the matter, pressed for the Supreme Court to have greater transparency and more enforceable ethical standards. ‚ÄúJustice Gorsuch only recused himself after this glaring conflict was brought to light,‚Äù she said in a statement, adding: ‚ÄúThis recusal is another reminder of how the justices‚Äô cozy relationships with billionaires and special interests continue to plague the Supreme Court and keep public trust in the court at an all-time low.‚Äù Still, Mr. Roth praised the decision. ‚ÄúPart of the recusal statute and the code of conduct says that a justice should recuse if their impartiality might reasonably be questioned,‚Äù Mr. Roth said, adding, ‚ÄúGiven all of Gorsuch‚Äôs ties to Philip Anschutz and his companies, a reasonable person might impute bias. I think it is absolutely the right call.‚Äù
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Left  
The article emphasizes ethical issues related to Justice Gorsuch's ties to a billionaire and the pressure from Democratic lawmakers and watchdog groups, which suggests a stronger alignment with views that critique Supreme Court justices and their relationships with wealthy interests. The focus on public trust and ethics is typically associated with a left-leaning perspective. However, mention of both sides' justices and the praise for Gorsuch's decision adds moderate elements, leading to a "Lean Left" classification.

title: In first call, Russian defense chief cautioned top US general about large-scale military exercise in Mediterranean Sea
body: In their first ever call, Russia‚Äôs defense chief cautioned the top US general about a large-scale Russian military exercise in the eastern Mediterranean Sea, according to a US official, with tensions running high between the two countries over the escalating war in Ukraine. The call between Chief of Russian General Staff Gen. Valery Gerasimov and US ChÔªøairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff Gen. CQ Brown, which was initiated by Gerasimov, occurred November 27. On Tuesday, the Russian Ministry of Defense announced that it had launched hypersonic missiles and cruise missiles as part of an exercise in the eastern Mediterranean Sea. Russian frigates, Admiral of the Soviet Union Fleet Gorshkov and Admiral Golovko, fired Tsirkon hypersonic missiles as part of the exercise, which included the Russian Navy and Aerospace Forces. The submarine Novorossiysk launched Kalibr cruise missiles at a naval target, according to the ministry. The exercise involved more than 1,000 troops; 10 ships; and 24 aircraft, including MiG-31 fighter jets armed with Kinzhal hypersonic missiles, the ministry said. Gerasimov did not explicitly mention the launch of hypersonic missiles in the call, according to the US official. The US currently has two destroyers operating in the Mediterranean Sea, the USS Bulkeley and the USS Arleigh Burke, according to a spokesman for the Navy. The New York Times was first to report on the call between Gerasimov and Brown. This was the first call between Gerasimov and Brown since Brown became Joint Chiefs of Staff Chairman more than one year ago. An official readout of the discussion normally follows calls between Brown and his military counterparts, but the Russians asked not to do so in this case. A spokesman for Brown confirmed the call happened but did not offer details, only saying, ‚ÄúThe leaders discussed a number of global and regional security issues to include the ongoing conflict in Ukraine.‚Äù Capt. Jereal Dorsey said in a statement, ‚ÄúAt the request of Gen. Gerasimov, Gen. Brown agreed not to proactively announce the call.‚Äù There was no mention in the statement of the exercises in the Mediterranean Sea. The US official said the two also discussed US concern over the deployment of North Korean troops to the battlefield and Russia‚Äôs use of an intermediate-range ballistic missile with multiple warheads in late-November. Another topic that came up in the call, the official said, was the US giving Ukraine permission to fire long-range ATACMS missiles into Russia. US and Russia maintain deconfliction lines in certain combat zones to avoid unintentional encounters when the two militaries operate near each other. That line has been used recently in the Middle East to prevent any friction between US and Russian forces operating in Syria, the Pentagon said. But since the start of the war in Ukraine nearly three years ago, the US and Russian military chiefs have rarely spoken, despite repeated outreach efforts by the US as the war began. Gerasimov spoke with former Joint Chiefs of Staff Chair Gen. Mark Milley in March 2023 after a Russian fighter jet struck and downed a US MQ-9 Reaper drone over the Black Sea.
Ai bias and explanation:
Center  
This article presents factual information regarding a communication between U.S. and Russian military leaders without exhibiting clear bias toward either side. It reports on military exercises and global security discussions objectively and includes statements from both U.S. officials and the Russian Ministry of Defense, keeping a neutral tone throughout.

title: Actress Annette Bening Pushes Sex Changes for Minors Outside SCOTUS: Having a ‚ÄòTransgender Child‚Äô Made Me ‚ÄòMore Wise‚Äô
body: Actress Annette Bening rallied outside the Supreme Court on Wednesday as justices heard oral arguments in a case surrounding Tennessee‚Äôs law banning sex change drugs and procedures for minors who believe they are transgender. The American Beauty star pressed for confused minors to have access to sex-mutilating drugs and surgeries, and called upon her experience with her own daughter, Stephen Ira Beatty, who identifies as a man. ‚ÄúI have four beautiful children, and I‚Äôm allowed to brag about my children ‚Äôcause they‚Äôre mine. And my eldest is a remarkable trans man, an extraordinary human being,‚Äù she said to a crowd of people outside the nation‚Äôs highest court. ‚ÄúAs a well-meaning parent, I didn‚Äôt always know how to support my teenager ‚Äî my vulnerable teenager who was just trying to live his truth. But you know what? I learned.‚Äù ‚ÄúI learned that what these kids and families need is judicious counseling, sound medical advice, and an atmosphere of calm and love and acceptance,‚Äù she continued. ‚ÄúOur trans kid and all trans folks need to be seen and heard. There is nothing to be frightened of.‚Äù Bening went on to assert that people who identify as transgender ‚Äúare everywhere‚Äù and that it is ‚Äúour responsibility to support and love them.‚Äù ‚ÄúI think the greatest gift of my life is to have kids, and to have a transgender child has made me so much more interesting, so much more wise,‚Äù she said with a touch of humor to her voice, as the crowd cheered and laughed. ‚ÄúAnd for the Supreme Court justices, I encourage them to talk to their kids, their grandkids, their nieces and nephews, because I‚Äôll bet if they really sit down and ask them, do you know trans kids around you? Do you have any non-binary friends? They‚Äôre going to say yes. And they‚Äôre going to say that this is part of the beautiful rainbow of human beings everywhere,‚Äù she concluded. Bening has previously spoken in favor of sex changes for minors, claiming that parents who allow such procedures simply want ‚Äúwhat is best‚Äù for their child. She also previously said her transgender child is ‚Äúsuch an inspiration‚Äù to her, and wished everyone would have a trans person in their family in order to truly ‚Äúget it.‚Äù RELATED: Mothers Pushing Transgenderism on Children Seek ‚ÄòMama Bear Crusade‚Äô The Biden administration ultimately asked the Supreme Court to reverse a ruling from the Ohio-based 6th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals upholding Tennessee‚Äôs law protecting minors from sex-mutilating drugs and surgeries. ‚ÄúThis is a relatively new diagnosis with ever-shifting approaches to care over the last decade or two. Under these circumstances, it is difficult for anyone to be sure about predicting the long-term consequences of abandoning age limits of any sort for these treatments,‚Äù Chief Judge Jeffrey Sutton, who was joined by Judge Amul Thapar, wrote for the 6th Circuit. As almost half of the United States has passed laws barring minors from obtaining transgender drugs and surgeries, the resulting Supreme Court ruling will likely have wide-ranging impacts for the future of so-called ‚Äúgender-affirming care,‚Äù as well as parental rights. READ MORE: Transgender Curbs Protect Children, Not Sexism, Lawyer Tell SCOTUS The side effects for sex change drugs and procedures can be severe, including irreversible mutilation and infertility. Some of these so-called treatments include double mastectomies (the removal of healthy breasts), female and male genital mutilation and removal, facial feminization and masculinization, hormone treatments, and puberty blockers that can cause chemical sterilization. Puberty blockers can also have long-term impact on bone growth, bone density, and growth spurts, according to Mayo Clinic. Transgender activists frequently claim that such sex-mutilating drugs and procedures for confused minors reduce suicides and improve mental health ‚Äî dubious claims which increasingly appear untrue as more studies and data come to light. Other research has indicated that a majority of children who are confused about their sex grow out of that feeling by the time they become adults. Opponents of sex changes for minors argue that it is impossible for young people to comprehend and legally consent to the potential lasting impacts of these drugs and surgeries. European countries that pushed sex change drugs and surgeries for minors before the United States are notably reversing course over concerns about long-term impacts. In the United States, the top-down push for minors to obtain sex-mutilating drugs and surgeries under the misleading moniker ‚Äúgender-affirming care‚Äù is clear, promulgated by President Joe Biden‚Äôs White House, academia, large hospitals, and major medical organizations.
