READ MORE: Biden Administration Promotes Transgender Sex-Change Surgery, Puberty Blockers for Minors At the root, these actors, along with the proliferation of gender ideology on social media, ultimately promote the false idea that human beings can be a different sex than what they were born as. Even further, the gender ideology complex claims these individuals should take sex-change drugs and get sex-change procedures to align their outward appearance with how they feel on the inside. While the push toward transgenderism is heavily ideological, a report released in December 2020 found that the U.S. sex reassignment surgery market size was valued at $267 million in 2019 and is expected to expand at a compound annual growth rate of 14.4 percent from 2020 to 2027. The case is United States v. Skrmetti, No. 23-477 in the Supreme Court of the United States. Katherine Hamilton is a political reporter for Breitbart News. You can follow her on X @thekat_hamilton.
Ai bias and explanation:
Right  
The article strongly opposes transgender treatments for minors and aligns with conservative viewpoints emphasizing caution against sex change procedures. It critiques progressive attitudes toward transgender healthcare and suggests that these approaches are ideologically driven and harmful. Additionally, it references significant challenges to gender affirmation policies coming from both legal and medical perspectives, showcasing a clear bias against liberal support for transgender rights and healthcare, which is characteristic of right-leaning media discourse.

title: Secret Service Boss Gets Into Shouting Match With Congressman Over 9/11 Ceremony¬†Appearance
body: Secret Service Acting Director Ronald Rowe and Rep. Pat Fallon (R-TX) got into a shouting match during a Capitol Hill hearing on Thursday regarding the assassination attempts on President-elect Donald Trump and Secret Service security failures.The clash began when Fallon asked Rowe if he recognized a photo showing Rowe standing in the row behind President Joe Biden, Vice President Kamala Harris, Trump, Vice President-elect JD Vance, and others at a New York 9/11 ceremony..@ChadPergram asks about heated exchange: "Doesn't that distract from the bipartisanship? All people are going to remember is this shouting. @RepPatFallon: "That's on the director because he started screaming‚Ä¶I think it was vanity project. I think he was auditioning for the‚Ä¶ pic.twitter.com/iEM2uawyyd‚Äî CSPAN (@cspan) December 5, 2024Rowe, who took over as acting Secret Service director when Kimberly Cheatle resigned from the directorship amid backlash over the security failure underlying the attempted assassination of Trump, said he did recognize the photo and confirmed that it showed an event at Ground Zero. Asked by Fallon who in security is usually closest to the president for such an event, Fallon said the Special Agent in Charge (SAC) of the detail.Advertisement‚ÄúWere you the special agent in charge of the detail that day?‚Äù queried Fallon.CHECK OUT THE DAILY WIRE HOLIDAY GIFT GUIDE‚ÄúActually, let me address this ‚Äî could you please, staff, leave ‚Äî oh, no leave the one up with the circle around me. Thank you ‚Äî so actually, congressman, what you‚Äôre not seeing is the SAC of the detail out of the picture‚Äôs view. And that is the day where we remember the more than 3,000 people that have died on 9/11. I actually responded to Ground Zero, I was there going through the ashes of the World Trade Center. I was there at Fresh Kills [landfill] ‚Äî‚Äù Rowe said.AdvertisementFallon interrupted Rowe, shouting, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not asking you that!‚Äù Rowe yelled back at the congressman, exclaiming that he was present to ‚Äúshow respect‚Äù for the Secret Service member who was killed on 9/11.‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a bunch of horse hockey,‚Äù Fallon exclaimed.The heated back-and-forth continued with Rowe and Fallon accusing each other of playing politics. As Rowe claimed Fallon was ‚Äúout of line‚Äù and Fallon demanded the witness not ‚Äúbully‚Äù him, Task Force Chairman Mike Kelly (R-PA) sought to restore order and repeatedly banged his gavel.Advertisement‚ÄúDo you know why you were there?‚Äù Fallon said. ‚ÄúBecause you wanted to be visible because you‚Äôre auditioning for this job that you‚Äôre not going to get. You endangered President Biden‚Äôs life, Vice President Harris‚Äô life because you put those agents out of position. Did you have a radio with you? Did you wear a vest? Did you have a weapon? No.‚ÄùRowe replied: ‚ÄúI did, sir, and you are out of line.‚ÄùAfter the hearing, Fox News senior congressional correspondent Chad Pergram asked Fallon about the clash.Fallon said the shouting match was ‚Äúon the director because he started screaming‚Äù and would not answer questions. The congressman later emphasized that he thought that Rowe positioned himself right behind Biden and Trump at the 9/11 ceremony as part of some ‚Äúvanity project‚Äù because he was ‚Äúauditioning for the job.‚ÄùAdvertisement
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Right  
The article mainly focuses on the conflict between a Republican Congressman and the Secret Service Director, with a tone that aligns more with conservative viewpoints. The portrayal of a shouting match and a critique of the Director's actions suggests a right-leaning bias, as it highlights political conflict and accountability in a negative light towards a Democratic administration figure. Additionally, the use of a Congressman‚Äôs quotes that frame the Director's actions as politically motivated supports this classification.

title: Everything Pete Hegseth Has Said About His Alcohol Use
body: Pete Hegseth, President-elect Donald Trump's pick for defense secretary, faces an uphill battle to get elected by the Senate as lawmakers express concern about his controversial past.Among the controversies, Hegseth, a veteran and conservative commentator, has faced allegations of excessive drinking, including on the job when he worked at Fox News. Hegseth has vowed to "fight like hell" for the position and pledged to quit drinking alcohol if he is confirmed by the Senate.In an interview on The Megyn Kelly Show on Wednesday, Hegseth repeatedly described the allegations against him as "smears" and noted that the reports about his excessive drinking cite anonymous sources."First of all, I've never had a drinking problem," Hegseth said. "No one's ever approached me and said, 'You should really look at getting help for drinking.' Never, never sought counseling, never sought help, but I respect and appreciate people who do. But you know, what do guys do when they come back from war oftentimes? Have some beers. How do you deal with the demons you see on the battlefield? Sometimes it's with a bottle." Pete Hegseth walks through the Russell Senate Office Building on Capitol Hill on December 3, 2024, in Washington, D.C. He has faced allegations about excessive drinking. Pete Hegseth walks through the Russell Senate Office Building on Capitol Hill on December 3, 2024, in Washington, D.C. He has faced allegations about excessive drinking. Getty Images/Andrew Harnik Hegseth said that if he is appointed, he would treat it as a deployment where you are not allowed to drink."This is the biggest deployment of my life, and there won't be a drop of alcohol on my lips while I'm doing it," he said.Although in recent days Hegseth has denied that he has had a problem with excessive drinking, he has in the past talked about turning to alcohol after returning home from deployment in Iraq.In an August 2021 appearance on The Will Cain Show podcast, Hegseth said: "I'd look around at 10 o'clock and be like, 'What am I going to do today? How about I drink some beers? How about I go have some lunch and have some beers? How about I meet my one or two buddies and have some beers?'""And one beer leads to many, leads to self-medication, leads to 'I've earned this.' Like, 'don't tell me I can't,'" he said.When Cain asked Hegseth if he drank heavily after returning from combat, Hegseth said: "Oh yeah." Read more Secretary of Defense Republicans Want Onetime Trump Critic as Hegseth's Pentagon Replacement Defense Secretary Subs Floated as Hegseth Says He's Still 'Trump's Guy' Who Could Trump Nominate for Defense Secretary if Pete Hegseth Drops Out? Pete Hegseth Responds to Question About Being 'Drunk' on the Job And in his book, In the Arena, published in 2016, Hegseth describes how he had once crafted a "pious caricature" of himself, involving abstaining from vices including alcohol, which he admits was often misleading.He wrote: "I barely trust someone who doesn't enjoy a few drinks and won't drop a well-placed f-bomb."The Washington Post previously reported that six former Fox News employees said they had seen him drunk at work several times, including one incident when he consumed several beers that had been purchased for a St. Patrick's Day at 10 a.m.Tim Parlatore, his attorney, denied the allegations, telling Newsweek: "There was never any drinking on the job at Fox News. Multiple people have come out on the record using their names to refute these false anonymous claims."In another report by The New Yorker, sources claimed that Hegseth was forced to step down from two nonprofit advocacy groups that he ran due to allegations including excessive drinking.In order to secure Senate confirmation, Hegseth needs no more than three Republicans to vote against him.Several lawmakers have expressed concern about his drinking and said they have sought reassurance that it would not impact his ability to do the job.He has also faced sexual misconduct allegations, which he has denied.
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Right  
The article presents a critical perspective on Pete Hegseth, who is associated with conservative views as a defense secretary candidate. It highlights controversies regarding his alcohol use, which may suggest a negative stance towards him. However, it uses quotes from Hegseth and his attorney defending him, which maintains a level of objectivity. The framing appears to slightly lean towards skepticism about his candidacy rather than outright condemnation, indicating a lean right classification that holds some conservative elements.

title: Republican Austin Theriault ends recount, conceding to Democratic US Rep. Jared Golden
body: PORTLAND, Maine (AP) ‚Äî Republican Austin Theriault on Wednesday ended a recount in his congressional race in Maine and conceded to Democratic U.S. Rep. Jared Golden, bringing to an end the closely watched contest a month after Election Day. Theriault decided to end the recount before its completion after early results did not show a significant change in the outcome after Golden won by 2,706 votes using the state‚Äôs ranked choice voting. ‚ÄúI ran this campaign centered around putting people over politics, and it‚Äôs time to do that now,‚Äù Theriault announced, calling the contest ‚Äúan extremely close and hard-fought race.‚Äù Between ranked voting and the recount, the election was a drawn-out process. Golden won the most first-choice votes but fell shy of a majority with less than 49% of the votes cast because about 12,000 ballots were either blank or had write-in candidates. That necessitated another voting round in which ballots were brought to Augusta, entered into a computer and reallocated with the second choices from ballots that were blank or had write-in candidates. The Associated Press declared Golden the 2nd Congressional District winner upon conclusion of the process more than a week after Election Day. The recount began Monday. ‚ÄúI‚Äôd like to thank the voters for participating in the greatest democracy the world has ever known, and all the staff and volunteers who helped ensure the election‚Äôs integrity on Election Day, during the runoff and over the course of this recount,‚Äù said Golden, who was in Washington when Theriault called to concede Wednesday. This race drew attention and more than $50 million in spending as both parties fought to control the House of Representatives. Golden, a Marine Corps veteran who demonstrated a willingness to defy his own party, campaigned on his ability to work with both Democrats and Republicans. He also touted his advocacy for the lobster industry, which is crucial to the economy in the region. But Golden was attacked for his opposition to assault weapons, which he announced after an Army reservist used an assault rifle to kill 18 people and injure 13 others in Lewiston in October 2023. Theriault, a former NASCAR driver, had the backing of President-elect Donald Trump, but he also portrayed himself as a potential uniter during a time of division. ‚ÄúWe need more balance and less extremism in Washington,‚Äù Theriault said previously. It was the third time Golden won through an additional voting round under ranked voting. The system allows voters to rank candidates on the ballot and allows for additional voting rounds to ensure a majority winner. Ranked choice tabulations allowed Golden to unseat Republican incumbent Rep. Bruce Poliquin in 2018, and to win a rematch in 2022. This story has been corrected to show Jared Golden received the most first-place votes.
Ai bias and explanation:
Center  
This article provides a neutral recounting of the events surrounding a congressional race in Maine, discussing both candidates, their campaigns, and the election process without a discernible bias toward either political party. The focus remains on factual reporting of the election outcome and the political landscape, including comments from both candidates. This balanced approach categorizes the piece as Center.

title: NYC Mayor Says He‚Äôll Work with Trump to Deport Illegal Immigrant Criminals: ‚ÄòCancel Me‚Äô
body: New York City mayor Eric Adams on Tuesday expressed an openness to deporting illegal immigrants who have committed crimes, further distancing himself from more progressive members of his party on the issue. He said he hopes to meet with President-elect Donald Trump‚Äôs pick for border czar, Tom Homan. ‚ÄúI would love to sit down with the border czar and hear his thoughts on how we are going to address those who are harming our citizens,‚Äù Adams said on Tuesday. ‚ÄúFind out what his plans are, where our common grounds are. We can work together.‚Äù Adams made sure to clarify that deportation out of the Big Apple should only be reserved for violent illegal aliens, not productive illegal immigrants or ‚ÄúDreamers.‚Äù ‚ÄúThose who are here committing crimes, robberies, shooting at police officers, raping innocent people, have been a harm to our country. Those are the people I am talking about,‚Äù Adams said. ‚ÄúI made it clear that I‚Äôm not going to be warring with this administration. I‚Äôm going to be working with this administration,‚Äù he added. Adams has suggested that the criminal charges brought against him were, at least partially, politically motivated. He claimed he was targeted because of his criticisms of President Joe Biden‚Äôs overly-permissive immigration policy. ‚ÄúKnow what‚Äôs interesting? I want you to all go back and Google Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama,‚Äù Adams said. ‚ÄúGoogle what they said about those who commit crimes in our city and ‚Ä¶ in our country. They said those who commit crimes need to get out right away. That was their position. So this is not a new position.‚Äù But, Adams claimed, progressives have grown afraid to speak out against illegal immigration because of cancel culture. ‚ÄúWell, cancel me because I‚Äôm going to protect the people of the city. And if you come into this country, in this city, and think you‚Äôre going to harm innocent New Yorkers and innocent migrants and asylum seekers, this is not the mayor you want to be in the city under. ‚Äú This hardened stance comes as New York City has battled a massive influx in asylum-seekers, illegal immigrants, and refugees throughout Biden‚Äôs tenure. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm an American. Americans have certain rights. The Constitution is for Americans. And I‚Äôm not a person that snuck into this country. My ancestors have been here for a long time, for a long time,‚Äù the mayor said. Adams won his mayoral seat by largely running as a moderate force, specifically by touting his law enforcement background and promising to clamp down on crime. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve said it over and over again. We need to fix the immigration problem in this city. The American people said that. I don‚Äôt know if you really watch the election results. The president-elect hit the popular vote, hit the electoral vote. He was not indecisive on what his positions were. He was clear we need to secure our border deal with the immigration issue.‚Äù ‚ÄúThe American people heard it. They voted for it,‚Äù he said. Send a tip to the news team at NR.
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Right  
The article focuses on New York City Mayor Eric Adams' comments about deporting illegal immigrant criminals while aligning with more conservative views on immigration policy. It emphasizes his willingness to work with the Trump administration and critiques progressive stances, suggesting a pivot toward law-and-order rhetoric. Adams' remarks reflect concerns about crime and public safety, resonating more with right-leaning perspectives than with leftist views on immigration. The overall tone supports tougher measures on immigration, aligning it with lean right ideology.

title: Mexico and Canada Scrambling to Impress Trump
body: As President-elect Donald Trump prepares for his return to the White House, Canada and Mexico have already begun taking shots at each other in the fight for a seat at his table.The U.S.'s two closest and largest trading partners are bracing themselves for a drastic change in American trade policy after Trump warned that he would place a 25 percent tariff on all imports from Canada and Mexico to curb the influx of migrants and drugs across U.S. borders.As a result, both countries have heightened rhetoric towards each other in a bid to position themselves as the stronger trading partner in North America. Officials in Canada and Mexico have also been highly critical of Trump's proposed tariffs, with threats being made to raise taxes on U.S. goods in return.Newsweek contacted representatives for the Mexican and Canadian governments for a response to the developments via email.Canadian President Justin Trudeau visited Trump at Mar-a-Lago on Friday, becoming one of the first world leaders to meet him in person after his victory in November. While no garuantees on trade were met, Trump described the meeting as "productive", and when the Canadian ambassador to the U.S. commented on the meeting, they highlighted talks on border policy explicitly in comparison to Mexico. "The message that our border is so vastly different than the Mexican border was really understood," Ambassador Kirsten Hillman told reporters on Sunday, framing the discussion in relation to Trump's stance on immigration and drug trade along the southern border. President Donald Trump and Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau attend the NATO summit at the Grove Hotel on December 4, 2019 in Watford, England. The two men met for the first time after Trump's election... President Donald Trump and Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau attend the NATO summit at the Grove Hotel on December 4, 2019 in Watford, England. The two men met for the first time after Trump's election on Friday. More Getty Images In a similar stance, Canadian Industry Minister Fran√ßois-Philippe Champagne said, "We shouldn't confuse the Mexican border with the Canadian border."The next day, Mexican president Claudia Sheinbaum said that her country "must be respected, especially by its trading partners".The newly-elected president also said that Canada "could only wish they had the cultural riches Mexico has", taking a return shot at the other nation grappling with the U.S.'s new administration. Later in her speech, Sheinbaum said: "We are not going to fall for a provocation of which country is better."However, Sheinbaum also said on Tuesday that Canada has "a very serious problem with fentanyl consumption," echoing Trump's call for both nations to clamp down on the drug entering the U.S. Read more Mexico Everything Donald Trump Has Pledged to Change on Day 1 Everyone Donald Trump Has Said He Might Pardon Trump FBI Pick Kash Patel Racks Up Massive Following After Joining X Republican Strategist Calls Donald Trump's Bluff on Tariffs This was followed by an announcement on Wednesday in which Mexican officials said that they had seized more than one ton of fentanyl pills, detained two men and confiscated multiple firearms in an operation in Sinaloa.But the two nations have not just been taking shots at each other. The Canadian Chamber of Commerce strongly condemned Trump's proposed tariff policy, arguing that it would result"Being America's 'nice neighbor' won't get us anywhere in this situation," Candace Laing, president of the Canadian Chamber of Commerce, said in a statement given to Newsweek."President-elect Trump's intention to impose 25 percent tariffs signals that the U.S.-Canada trade relationship is no longer about mutual benefit. To him, it's about winners and losers‚Äîwith Canada on the losing end."We're facing a significant shift in the relationship between long-standing allies. Canada's signature approach needs to evolve: we must be prepared to take a couple of punches if we're going to stake out our position. It's time to trade 'sorry' for 'sorry, not sorry'."Do you have a story we should be covering? Do you have any questions about this story? Contact LiveNews@newsweek.com.
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Left  
This article presents a critical view of President Trump's proposed tariffs and the implications for U.S.-Canada-Mexico relations, suggesting it is not about mutual benefit but rather a competitive and adverse dynamic. It emphasizes concerns raised by Canadian and Mexican officials, portraying their perspectives sympathetically. The language used suggests a critique of Trump's policies, which aligns more with a left-leaning media bias rather than a neutral or supportive stance toward Trump and his administration.

title: Hegseth fights to save Pentagon nomination as sources say Trump considers DeSantis
body: WASHINGTON (AP) ‚Äî A defiant Pete Hegseth fought to save his nomination to be Donald Trump‚Äôs defense secretary Wednesday as the president-elect considered possible replacements in the face of growing questions about the former Fox News host‚Äôs personal conduct and ability to win Senate confirmation. WASHINGTON (AP) ‚Äî A defiant Pete Hegseth fought to save his nomination to be Donald Trump‚Äôs defense secretary Wednesday as the president-elect considered possible replacements in the face of growing questions about the former Fox News host‚Äôs personal conduct and ability to win Senate confirmation. Hegseth met with legislators on Capitol Hill, conducted a radio interview and released an opinion article denying allegations of sexual assault and excessive drinking. He insisted he was ‚Äúnot backing down one bit,‚Äù said Trump was still supporting him and planned to return Thursday for more meetings with lawmakers. But the president-elect‚Äôs team was looking at alternatives, including Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis. Trump himself remained quiet about Hegseth while issuing a flurry of statements on social media Wednesday about other nominees and his news coverage. Hegseth, in an exchange with reporters, said he‚Äôd meet with Trump ‚Äúanytime he‚Äôd like.‚Äù Trump‚Äôs team was pleased with how things went Wednesday as Hegseth met with lawmakers, according to a person familiar with their thinking, and they are continuing to stand behind him for now -- all while Trump considers back-up options. North Dakota Sen. Kevin Cramer, who had previously expressed concerns about reports of Hegseth‚Äôs drinking, spoke positively about Hegseth‚Äôs prospects after the two met Wednesday evening. ‚ÄúI see no reason at this point not to be supportive,‚Äù Cramer said. He said he told Hegseth ‚Äúit‚Äôs really important that we have a clear eyed secretary of defense if the alarm goes off or the phone rings at three in the morning.‚Äù Hegseth responded, according to Cramer, that he would be available ‚Äúat three in the morning, three in the afternoon or any hour in between.‚Äù Hegseth is the latest nominee-designate to be imperiled by personal baggage after the recent withdrawal of Trump‚Äôs initial pick for attorney general, former Rep. Matt Gaetz, whose vulnerabilities were well-documented. But Hegseth‚Äôs past, including the revelation that he made a settlement payment after being accused of a sexual assault that he denies, was not widely known. The Trump transition team went into the day concerned about Hegseth‚Äôs path to Senate confirmation and actively looking at potential replacements, a person familiar with the matter said. Three other people said DeSantis, who competed against Trump for the Republican presidential nomination in 2024, was being discussed as an option if Hegseth‚Äôs nomination does not move forward. The people spoke on condition of anonymity because they were not authorized to publicly discuss internal deliberations. Beyond DeSantis, there have also been discussions about shifting Michael Waltz, who was chosen by Trump for national security adviser, to the Defense Department, according to another person familiar with the matter who spoke on condition of anonymity. The Florida congressman is a retired Army National Guard officer and war veteran. As he made the rounds on Capitol Hill, Hegseth told reporters he had received a fresh message of support from Trump. ‚ÄúI spoke to the president this morning. He supports me fully. We‚Äôre not going anywhere,‚Äù Hegseth said. In an op-ed in The Wall Street Journal, Hegseth laid out a vigorous defense of his record, including his time spent at two veterans advocacy groups, Concerned Veterans for America and Veterans For Freedom. In new allegations this week, The New Yorker cited what it described as a whistleblower report and other documents about his time leading CVA that alleged multiple incidents of alcohol intoxication at work events, inappropriate behavior around female staffers and financial mismanagement. Hegseth, in the op-ed, acknowledged spending too much money during the 2008 campaign in support of then-candidate John McCain, so that Veterans For Freedom went into debt. But he said he stayed on until all bills were paid. And he said his split from CVA was over a ‚Äúdifference of opinion‚Äù about the group‚Äôs future. Republican Sen. Joni Ernst of Iowa, a military veteran and sexual assault survivor, stopped short of an endorsement after her meeting with Hegseth. She said she appreciates his military service and they ‚Äúhad a frank and thorough conversation.‚Äù The Trump transition team didn‚Äôt respond to requests for comment on Hegseth‚Äôs status. In an interview taped Wednesday for Megyn Kelly‚Äôs SiriusXM satellite radio show, Hegseth said Trump told him he wanted a ‚Äúwarfighter‚Äù who would clean out the ‚Äúwoke crap.‚Äù Citing his Capitol Hill meeting, Hegseth said, ‚ÄúNo one has looked me in the eye and said, ‚ÄòI have concerns.‚Äô‚Äù He added, ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not backing down one bit.‚Äù Hegseth paid a woman who accused him of sexual assault at a California hotel in 2017 after Hegseth had given a speech at a Republican event. His lawyer said the payment was to head off the threat of a baseless lawsuit. Asked by Kelly if he sexually assaulted the woman, Hegseth said ‚Äúabsolutely not.‚Äù He called it a ‚Äúreally unfortunate situation‚Äù and said he paid her because he ‚Äúhad to,‚Äù contending that her lawyers said they would ‚Äúout him.‚Äù He declined to reveal the amount paid, but said it was done to protect his wife, himself and his job. He said it is a ‚Äúfair characterization‚Äù to call him a serial cheater, who cheated on all three of his wives. ‚ÄúWas I a perfect man, absolutely not,‚Äù he said. Hegseth flatly denied having a drinking problem and said he wouldn‚Äôt drink while defense secretary, vowing, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not going to have a drink at all.‚Äù He likened it to following the Pentagon‚Äôs general order No. 1, which prohibits troops from drinking while deployed. GOP Sen. Markwayne Mullin, who joined Hegseth in a meeting with House Republicans, defended the nominee and said: ‚ÄúAll of us, at least all of us, have a time to grow up. We‚Äôre nominating Pete for who he is today, not for what he did seven years ago or five years ago or whatever it was.‚Äù Cramer said Hegseth during their meeting acknowledged there were times that he drank too much, but that nothing improper happened. He said Hegseth also denied aspects of the New Yorker report, including that he was drunk at a strip club with coworkers and tried to get up on the stage and dance. Cramer said Hegseth told him ‚ÄúI‚Äôve never been at a strip club in Louisiana intoxicated‚Äù and that he has ‚Äúcertainly never been on a stage, you know, in an intoxicated state.‚Äù ‚ÄúI have no reason to doubt him any more than believe somebody else,‚Äù Cramer said. Earlier, Hegseth‚Äôs mother appeared on Fox News to address some of the allegations. Penelope Hegseth, on ‚ÄúFox & Friends,‚Äù discussed her son and a 2018 email she wrote him that was obtained by The New York Times, in which she confronted him about mistreating women after he impregnated his current wife while he was married to his second wife. That letter followed multiple allegations, reported by The New Yorker this week, of questionable conduct around female staffers, in addition to the 2017 allegation. On Tuesday, Sen. Lindsey Graham, R-S.C., said some of the reports were ‚Äúdisturbing,‚Äù telling CBS News that he wants to ‚Äúmake sure that every young woman that joins the military feels respected and welcomed.‚Äù Penelope Hegseth implored the lawmakers to listen to her son and give him a chance. ‚ÄúI think it can be overcome,‚Äù Penelope Hegseth said. Hegseth is a former Fox News host and a former Army National Guard major and combat veteran who deployed to Iraq and Afghanistan. If confirmed by the Senate, he would lead a 2-million-member strong military ‚Äî more than 17% of whom are female. The revelations have concerned some members of Congress. Hegseth said in his interview that he doesn‚Äôt know how all this will turn out but is comfortable that he ‚Äútook on the haters and the liars‚Äù and fought for it, adding, ‚Äúthe future‚Äôs in God‚Äôs hands.‚Äù Associated Press writers Jill Colvin and Michelle L. Price in New York, Adriana Gomez Licon in Fort Lauderdale, Florida, and Mary Clare Jalonick, Lisa Mascaro and Lolita C. Baldor contributed to this report. Beaumont reported from Des Moines, Iowa.
Ai bias and explanation:
Center  
This article presents a balanced report on Pete Hegseth's nomination situation, detailing various perspectives without overtly favoring one side. It includes both Hegseth's defenses against allegations and mentions support from Republican senators, as well as the concerns expressed by some legislators. The piece avoids emotionally charged language and sticks to facts about the nomination process, which is characteristic of centrist reporting. There are no clear ideological leanings, making this article a neutral account of the events.

title: Musk and Ramaswamy rally GOP in Washington with DOGE push, while Pence-backed group delivers list of priorities
body: WASHINGTON ‚Äî Former Vice President Mike Pence‚Äôs group on Thursday pushed Elon Musk and Vivek Ramaswamy to slash government spending by eliminating handouts for illegal migrants and banning DEI funding, among other proposals, according to a memo exclusively obtained by The Post, as the co-heads of the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) rallied GOP lawmakers in Washington to their cause. Advancing American Freedom urged the DOGE bosses to trim the fat off the federal bureaucracy and cut a host of costly spending programs, several of which were imposed by President Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris‚Äô administration ‚Äî including provisions from their $740 billion Inflation Reduction Act (IRA). ‚ÄúThe American people want less government in their lives and want the government to spend less of their money on wasteful and woke programs,‚Äù said AAF president Tim Chapman. 5 Elon Musk arrives on Capitol Hill with his son X A A-Xii on December 5, 2024, in Washington, DC. Getty Images ‚ÄúAdvancing American Freedom wants to help advance the vision of DOGE to improve the lives of everyday Americans,‚Äù added Chapman, urging DOGE ‚Äúto cut through the overwhelming maze of bureaucracy and reassure the American people that their government is accountable to them for how their taxes are being spent.‚Äù The memo calls for ending federal benefit programs tasked with helping illegal immigrants, prohibiting federal funding for programs that push diversity, equity and inclusion (DEI) initiatives and clawing back unspent COVID-19 money. Explore More NYC schools bring back controversial pandemic-era policy ‚Äîand experts warn it is ‚Äòrewarding failure‚Äô Los Angeles seeks $80M loan as city is ‚Äògrowing broke‚Äô amid lawsuit judgment payouts I live in a tiny converted military storage building ‚Äî my micro house may be tight, but its helping me save big money It also prods Republicans to repeal Democrats‚Äô ‚ÄúGreen New Deal‚Äù provisions tucked into Democrats‚Äô IRA, halt hundreds of billions of dollars in student debt from being canceled via programs started by Biden‚Äôs Education Department, and get non-defense spending back to pre-COVID levels. Another long-held GOP priority that made the list was mandating that all able-bodied workers be kicked off welfare. 5 Businessman Vivek Ramaswamy (center), co-chair of the newly announced Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE), walks with Sen. Joni Ernst (right) as he arrives on Capitol Hill on December 5, 2024, in Washington, DC. Getty Images Musk and Ramaswamy went to Capitol Hill on Thursday to discuss their unprecedented budget-cutting plans with GOP lawmakers, many of whom welcomed their ideas. DOGE, named after the cryptocurrency with a Shiba Inu as its mascot, will be committed to shutting down redundant agencies and firing useless government employees, Musk and Ramaswamy have both said. ‚ÄúWe need to make sure we‚Äôre spending public money well,‚Äù Musk told reporters on his way out of a meeting with soon-to-be Senate Majority Leader John Thune (R-SD). A significant portion of congressional Republicans support a smaller federal government, but DOGE ‚Äî which is not a government department ‚Äî could potentially run into hurdles lowering budgets if just a few dissenting GOPers push back in Congress. 5 Ramaswamy walks by the Capitol building speaking to reporters about DOGE. Getty Images ‚ÄúTwo people who know nothing about how the government works pretending they can cut a trillion dollars, both with decent pulpits to preach from, and the ear of an unpredictable president? Disaster,‚Äù one senior Republican aide griped to Punchbowl News. ‚ÄúThe only good thing is that at some point they‚Äôll overpromise and get bounced by [President-elect Donald] Trump. But until then ‚Ä¶ disaster.‚Äù There was also uncertainty from lawmakers who huddled with Musk and Ramaswamy over what exactly DOGE is and how exactly the two bombastic entrepreneurs intend to push through dramatic spending cuts. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know what legal authority they have,‚Äù Rep. Max Miller (R-Ohio) admitted to reporters after a large meeting with Musk and Ramaswamy when asked about whether the duo believes they have sufficient independent power or intend to act in an advisory role. ‚ÄúThat I don‚Äôt know,‚Äù Judiciary Committee Chairman Jim Jordan (R-Ohio) added when asked about the accountability line behind DOGE and whether it could face Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) requests. During their meeting with a large ensemble of lawmakers right before votes on the House floor, Musk and Ramaswamy spoke for about a minute and then turned to the microphone over to reps for an extensive ideas session. They also indicated that similar meetings of that nature will follow down the line. At least one idea floated was impoundment, something endorsed by Office of Management and Budget director-designee Russell Vought and in which the executive branch would simply refuse to spend funds allocated by Congress. ‚ÄúThe president, personally I believe, has the constitutional authority, and I think there was some significant agreement in the room,‚Äù Rep. Chip Roy (R-Texas) said. ‚ÄúI told these guys the best thing they could do is highlight all of the nonsense that Congress continues to fund ‚Äî and then that way Congress has to bear its burden as appropriators and spenders of the power of the purse,‚Äù he recounted. At one point, Musk and Ramaswamy pitched a Christmas-themed suggestion of a ‚Äúnaughty and nice list‚Äù for reps, according to Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene (R-Ga.), who chairs the House DOGE Caucus. Musk, who paraded around the Capitol Thursday with his four-year-old son X √Ü A-Xii on his shoulders, also stressed the need to check every single federal payment that goes out. There wasn‚Äôt a specific figure given for cuts or a precise game plan for DOGE, according to about a dozen lawmakers in attendance. There was also a sense of urgency in the room and a strong conviction shared by attendees that Congress needs to tackle the soaring national debt. Rep. Dusty Johnson (R-SC) noted that one of his takeaways is that there is a sense that the federal government lags behind the private sector in the use of critical technology that could make its operations more efficient. He also commended the incoming administration‚Äôs outreach to Congress. So far, Musk and Ramaswamy‚Äôs are being met publicly with positive feedback from Republican lawmakers ‚Äî with Sen. Marsha Blackburn (R-Tenn.) introducing legislation to bolster DOGE‚Äôs efforts. Fox News‚Äô Martha MacCallum asked House Speaker Mike Johnson (R-La.) on Wednesday if it would be possible to enact Musk‚Äôs plan to cut the 428 government agencies down to 99. 5 Musk has vowed to eliminate excess costs from the federal budget through DOGE. Getty Images ‚ÄúWe certainly hope so, we want to be willing partners in that,‚Äù Johnson replied, pointing to the Supreme Court overturning the 1984 Chevron doctrine earlier this year as an indication that control is being taken back from ham-handed federal regulators. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a new thing and this is a new day in Washington, a new day in America. We have long lamented the size and scope of the government ‚Äî that it has grown too large,‚Äù Johnson told reporters in the hallway Thursday. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs an enormous amount of waste, fraud and abuse.‚Äù Musk has been Trump‚Äôs top confidant at Mar-a-Lago in the weeks following the 45th president‚Äôs re-election, advising him on transition moves and weighing in on calls with foreign dignitaries. 5 Musk has been Trump‚Äôs top confidant at Mar-a-Lago in the weeks following the 45th president‚Äôs re-election, advising him on transition moves and weighing in on calls with foreign dignitaries. Getty Images The DOGE initiative comes as a natural progression of the two business titans‚Äô opprobrium for the ‚Äúswamp‚Äù and rooting out government excess ‚Äî just as Musk did with Twitter, now X, when he eliminated the majority of the staff. ‚ÄúLook, it‚Äôs a refreshing idea that we‚Äôre going to actually make government work better and make your taxpayers go further,‚Äù House Majority Leader Steve Scalise (R-La.) said on CNBC‚Äôs ‚ÄúSquawk Box‚Äù before his Musk-Ramaswamy sitdown. ‚ÄúThere are probably 75% of federal employees here in Washington that still are not showing up to work under the excuse of COVID.‚Äù ‚ÄúThe swamp is elitist and bipartisan,‚Äù Rep. Eli Crane (R-Ariz.) said on X ahead of his own meeting with the pair. ‚ÄúI look forward to hearing from [Elon Musk] and [Vivek Ramaswamy] today on Capitol Hill.‚Äù Disdain for unelected, meddling government employees was a centerpiece of Ramaswamy‚Äôs own presidential campaign ‚Äî and he hopes to continue in that vein in the second Trump administration. ‚ÄúI have a passion for tearing down bureaucracy,‚Äù Ramaswamy told The Post in late October. ‚ÄúAnd that‚Äôs something I‚Äôve been vocal about over the last two years.‚Äù
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Right  
The article emphasizes support for reduced government spending and criticism of Democratic policies, reflecting conservative values. The focus on Musk and Ramaswamy's initiatives, along with quotes from Republican figures advocating for government efficiency, leans towards right-leaning perspectives. Additionally, terms such as "wasteful and woke programs" suggest an alignment with right-wing critiques of government intervention and spending. The framing of the narrative encourages policies typical of the GOP, firmly placing it in the "Lean Right" classification.

title: Shouting match sends House task force hearing with Secret Service director off the rails
body: A shouting match between Rep. Pat Fallon and Secret Service acting Director Ronald Rowe broke out during the final hearing of the House task force investigating the two assassination attempts on President-elect Donald Trump. Mr. Fallon, Texas Republican, accused Mr. Rowe of attending a 9/11 remembrance event for political visibility, igniting a loud, chaotic back and forth between the two men. Mr. Fallon was the second to last member of the task force to question Mr. Rowe at the hearing. Their exchange started normal but went off the rails when Mr. Fallon brought out a poster board with a photo of a 9/11 remembrance event with Mr. Rowe pictured standing near President Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris. Mr. Trump and Vice President-elect J.D. Vance were also pictured at the remembrance event on September 11 of this year. He asked Mr. Rowe who is usually closest to the president, security-wise. Mr. Rowe said that it is typically the special agent in charge of the presidential detail, to which Mr. Fallon asked if that was Mr. Rowe‚Äôs position. Mr. Rowe said the special agent in charge was just out of the frame of the picture and started to preemptively defend himself from where Mr. Fallon was going with the questioning. ‚ÄúThat is the day where we remember the more than 3,000 people that died on 9/11,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI actually responded to ground zero. I was there going through the ashes at the World Trade Center.‚Äù Mr. Fallon started yelling that it was not what he was asking. Mr. Rowe yelled back that he was there to show respect for a Secret Service member who died on 9/11, which Mr. Fallon called ‚Äúa bunch of horse hockey‚Äù as the shouting match continued and the men talked over one another. ‚ÄúDo not invoke 9/11 for political purposes,‚Äù Mr. Rowe said. Mr. Fallon responded he was not, saying, ‚ÄúI am an elected member of Congress and I‚Äôm asking you a serious question and you are playing politics.‚Äù ‚ÄúAnd I am a public servant who has served this nation and spent time on our country‚Äôs darkest day. Do not politicize it,‚Äù Mr. Rowe said. ‚ÄúYou know why you were there ‚Äî because you wanted to be visible, because you were auditioning for this job, which you‚Äôre not going to get,‚Äù Mr. Fallon said. ‚ÄúYou endangered President Biden‚Äôs life, Vice President Harris‚Äô life because you put those agents out of position. Did you have a radio with you? Did you wear a vest? Did you have a weapon? No.‚Äù Mr. Rowe responded: ‚ÄúI did sir, and you are out of line.‚Äù Throughout the intense argument, Rep. Mike Kelly, the task force‚Äôs chairman, banged his gavel trying to regain control of the hearing. The shouting finally ended after more than a minute, and the hearing concluded without further controversy. The outburst appeared to frustrate other panel members who have repeatedly touted the panel‚Äôs bipartisanship, its focus on the facts of the assassination attempts and its recommendations for improvement. Mr. Kelly, Pennsylvania Republican, spent time immediately after the exchange whispering with Rep. Jason Crow of Colorado, the task force‚Äôs top Democrat. Later, Mr. Fallon came over to join in the conversation. It was not clear what they said to one another, but Mr. Kelly and Mr. Crow both used their closing remarks to praise Mr. Rowe for his cooperation and efforts to remediate issues at the Secret Service in the wake of the assassination attempt. Without directly addressing Mr. Fallon‚Äôs questioning of Mr. Rowe, they both said the hearing and the investigation adhered to their goal of a bipartisan fact-finding mission. ‚ÄúYou couldn‚Äôt watch this hearing today and see who is a Democrat and Republican,‚Äù Mr. Crow said, suggesting the public watch the entirety of the hearing. Asked after the hearing how the shouting match over the 9/11 event conveys to the public the professionalism and seriousness of the members that the task force is trying to highlight, Mr. Crow said, ‚Äúthere are exuberances that occur when people get emotional about emotional issues.‚Äù ‚ÄúActing Director Rowe was a first responder on 9/11, and as a combat veteran myself I understand that there‚Äôs a lot you carry with you throughout the rest of your life when you encounter a situation like that,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúSo I understand those exuberances and that emotion.‚Äù Mr. Fallon told reporters that his intention was to find out why Mr. Rowe was interfering with the positioning of the president‚Äôs protective detail. ‚ÄúThe whole point I was bringing up was you guys have to learn lessons from July 13 so it doesn‚Äôt happen again,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúAnd this happened in September, and clearly he didn‚Äôt learn it.‚Äù Mr. Fallon said he is unaware of any other time a Secret Service director stood right behind the president at an event like that. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs ever happened before, and that‚Äôs coming from the agents that were talking to our office, that talked to me directly,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThe whistleblowers made a good point. I didn‚Äôt know about this, and they brought it to me, and they‚Äôre furious.‚Äù
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Right  
The article primarily focuses on a confrontation involving a Republican congressman and a government official, portraying the Republican's criticisms as central. While it presents both sides of the argument, it highlights the actions of Rep. Fallon's somewhat aggressive questioning and political motivations. The article's tone and details align more with a Lean Right perspective, as it emphasizes a confrontation that may appeal to right-leaning audiences concerned with government accountability and oversight, particularly in the context of security surrounding political figures.

title: Mike Bloomberg warns making RFK Jr. HHS secretary risks killing Americans, urges Senate to reject him
body: Billionaire and public health advocate Mike Bloomberg on Tuesday excoriated Robert F. Kennedy Jr., President-elect Donald Trump‚Äôs pick for U.S. health secretary, over his anti-vaccine record and urged the Senate to reject his bid to lead the nation‚Äôs top health agencies. ‚ÄúJust imagine if RFK Jr. had been in office during Trump‚Äôs first term,‚Äù Bloomberg said at the Bloomberg American Health Summit in Washington D.C. ‚ÄúWould Operation Warp Speed have even happened? And if it did, how long would the vaccines have been delayed? How many fewer people would have gotten the shot? How many more people would have died?‚Äù ‚ÄúAll we can say for sure is this: It would have made Covid even more deadly and even more economically painful,‚Äù he said. Giving RFK Jr. the power to steer U.S. health policy, he warned, would be ‚Äúbeyond dangerous, it would be medical malpractice on a mass scale.‚Äù The former New York City mayor devoted nearly all of his 19-minute speech to slamming Kennedy‚Äôs spread of disinformation about vaccines, including his ‚Äúoutrageous false claim‚Äù that the Covid-19 vaccine was the ‚Äúdeadliest vaccine ever made.‚Äù Bloomberg, who ran for president as a Democrat in 2020, has long advocated for public health reforms, both as mayor and through his philanthropic efforts. RFK Jr. initially ran for president in 2024 as a Democrat, but switched to an independent bid and later dropped out to endorse Trump. An environmental lawyer and the son of former U.S. Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy, RFK Jr.‚Äôs campaign provided him with a prominent national platform and gave oxygen to his conspiracy theories about vaccines. Bloomberg in Tuesday‚Äôs speech appealed directly to U.S. senators not to confirm RFK Jr. to the Cabinet role in the next Trump administration. ‚ÄúWe can‚Äôt allow Kennedy or Trump or anyone else to bring unimaginable suffering to the American people,‚Äù he said. Bloomberg expressed hope that Senate Republicans will convince Trump to reconsider nominating RFK Jr. before they are asked to weigh in. But if Trump stands by his choice, then the Senate ‚Äúhas a duty for our whole country, but especially to our children, to vote no,‚Äù he said. Bloomberg also admonished Democrats who appear open to letting RFK Jr. lead the Department of Health and Human Services because of his advocacy against junk food and processed foods. ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt need to choose between someone who is pro-healthy food and pro-vaccine. Americans deserve both,‚Äù he said. Bloomberg noted that he had fought for numerous restrictions on unhealthy products while he was mayor, including an effort to ban large sugary drinks. Those fights garnered backlash from conservatives and affected consumer industries at the time. But RFK Jr. has taken a similar tack, endorsing a plan that he says is intended to ‚ÄúMake America Healthy Again‚Äù alongside Republicans. Bloomberg credited his own efforts with raising New Yorkers‚Äô life expectancy, and touted the investments his philanthropic foundation continues to make to combat ailments like diabetes and heart disease. ‚ÄúBut if the federal government steps back from vaccines, all of that progress will vanish,‚Äù he said, suggesting that doing so could result in millions of needless deaths. And if the government starts to invest in ‚Äúnutty conspiracy theories,‚Äù then funding for researching cures for other diseases could be set back by years, Bloomberg argued. ‚ÄúIt boggles the mind that the Senate would even consider giving Kennedy any power whatsoever over American health policy,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWhatever one may think of his positions on food policies, it‚Äôs nowhere near enough to overcome his opposition to vaccines.‚Äù
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Left  
This article reflects a lean left bias as it prominently features a critique of a prominent right-wing figure, RFK Jr., positioning his anti-vaccine stance as dangerous. The article highlights Bloomberg's public health advocacy, suggesting alignment with Democratic values, while also criticizing Republican policies under Trump. The tone and language used align with a more progressive view on public health and vaccine importance.

title: 'No one elected her': GOP infighting ensues over Trump‚Äôs legislative plans
body: Republican lawmakers are split over major policy bills influenced by President-Elect Donald Trump's priorities ‚Äî immigration, taxes, and energy ‚Äî which new Senate leader John Thune (R-SD) said earlier this week he wants to push through within the first 30 days of Trump's presidency. The GOP lawmakers are planning to use a reconciliation bill ‚Äî which allows for bypassing Democratic votes ‚Äî in order to successfully pass the legislation. However, Politico reports: A number of House Republicans, including committee chairs key to pulling off the plan, are already raising red flags over the strategy, saying they don‚Äôt feel the need to stick to that. The disconnect illustrates the challenge that Republican leaders will have next term: They can preach unity, but they have no room for error as they wrangle at-times raucous members with varied priorities. READ MORE: New Senate GOP leader plans push for 'major partisan bills' in Trump‚Äôs first 30 days: report According to the news outlet, "House Judiciary Chair Jim Jordan(R-Ohio) pointed to pushback from Ways and Means Chair Jason Smith (R-Mo.), adding that: 'We‚Äôve got members who have some concerns.'" Thune told Politico, "We have to all be on the same page." He added, ‚ÄúSometimes it‚Äôs challenging because you‚Äôve got to have a House, Senate and White House all pulled in the same direction." Far-right Freedom Caucus member Rep. Chip Roy (Texas) said, "I remain of the belief that we ought to deliver very quickly on a reconciliation package that has core tenets of the things we want to accomplish in terms of border and fees and so forth, IRA repeal, then some elements of tax policy. And then maybe do a second version that gets at true long-standing permanent tax reform." READ MORE: House GOP facing 'major political hurdles' with party's key political promise Another far-right House member ‚Äî Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene (R-Ga.) ‚Äî "hinted" to Politico "that she believes Republicans should challenge the Senate parliamentarian if she determines that any of the border and immigration policies Republicans try to put into the bill don‚Äôt fall within the strict rules of budget reconciliation." Greene emphasized, "No one elected her, so she should not stop the will of the people." Politico's full report is available at this link.
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Right  
The article discusses Republican infighting and the dynamics within the GOP regarding Trump's policy priorities, which leans towards a Right perspective due to its focus on Republican positions and issues. The language used seems to favor the concerns of the party, particularly the right-wing members, hinting at internal struggles but not critiquing their policies heavily. Although it covers dissent within the party, it ultimately aligns with Right-leaning viewpoints and highlights Trump's agenda as a positive leadership endeavor.

title: 'I‚Äôll do my show the way I want!' Scarborough opens with meltdown over David Frum comments
body: Joe Scarborough ‚Äî the former Republican congressman-turned MSNBC morning host ‚Äî opened Thursday's episode of "Morning Joe" with an indignant 20-minute monologue. According to Mediaite, Scarborough's rant was in response to an article in the Atlantic written by former George W. Bush speechwriter David Frum, who was booted from Wednesday's show after a comment he made about Defense Secretary-designate Pete Hegseth. Frum was asked to leave the show after commenting on an NBC News report in which Hegseth's current and former colleagues at Fox News recalled him frequently showing up on set complaining of hangovers and reeking of alcohol. Frum said: "If you're too drunk for Fox News, you're very, very drunk indeed." As Frum recalled in his Atlantic essay, a producer warned Frum to not repeat his comments during a commercial break. Frum "said something noncommittal" in response, and "got another round of warning." He was eventually "excused from the studio chair," and Morning Joe co-host Mika Brzezinski read an on-air apology for Frum's "flippant" comment about Hegseth. READ MORE: 'Acted like the rules didn't apply': Hegseth's coworkers say he often showed up drunk on set The former Bush White House speechwriter suggested in his essay that Scarborough and Brzezinski were "feeling the chill of intimidation and responding with efforts to appease" in the wake of President-elect Donald Trump's threats of retribution. He also referenced their November visit to Mar-a-Lago in an attempt to "mend fences" with the incoming administration. "I do not write to scold anyone; I write because fear is infectious. Let it spread, and it will paralyze us all," Frum wrote. "The only antidote is courage. And that‚Äôs infectious, too." Scarborough didn't take kindly to Frum's essay, and vehemently denied that he and his spouse/co-host were acting out of "fear." He also defended he and Brzezinski's trip to Mar-a-Lago, which led to a plummet in viewership. "Guess what? This is what‚Äôs been going on now for several weeks. We went down to talk to the president-elect. And people wrote articles that were just false. But you know what we did? We did the corporate thing. Corporate said, ‚Äòdon‚Äôt say anything. Just keep your head down.‚Äô What did the royal say? 'Never explain, never complain. We did that,'" he said. "I always have Republicans say, ‚ÄòOh, they‚Äôre telling you exactly what to say.‚Äô No! Nobody‚Äôs once told me what to say here. Well actually, one person did one time. One leader did one time. I said ‚ÄòI‚Äôll tell you what, if you think you can do such a damn good job, why don‚Äôt you come here and do the show four hours a day? I‚Äôm fine quitting. But I‚Äôm gonna do my show. I‚Äôll do my show the way I want to do my show!" READ MORE: 'Morning Joe' hosts condemn conservative' 'flippant' Hegseth critique after Trump Mar-a-Lago meeting Click here to read Mediaite's coverage. You can watch Scarborough's monologue below, or by clicking this link.
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Left  
The article highlights discontent from a liberal news anchor towards a former Bush official's critique, indicating a perspective that aligns with left-leaning views. The mention of Trump's intimidation tactics and the framing around corporate media pressure further signifies an opposition to conservative ideologies. The focus on Scarborough's emotional response suggests a narrative sympathetic to liberal media personalities who feel challenged by conservative figures.

title: Iconic NYC dive Smith‚Äôs Bar to be replaced by weed dispensary near Times Square
body: Old New York‚Äôs going up in smoke! Smith‚Äôs Bar, the iconic, neon-sign dive near Times Square, has closed for good and is set to be replaced by a marijuana dispensary ‚Äî leaving broken-hearted regulars feeling burned. The beloved watering hole ‚Äî where theater-going hipsters knocked one back alongside old drunks and businessmen for 70 years ‚Äî shuttered for good last week on 44th Street and Eighth Avenue in Hell‚Äôs Kitchen. ‚ÄúIt was a piece of history,‚Äù said Al Diaz, 49, an engineer who works nearby. ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt have things like this anymore, where you can sit and chill, like Cheers.‚Äù ‚ÄúLook at how old-school this is, look at these lights,‚Äù he added, gesturing to the building. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs like going back in time.‚Äù A cannabis dispensary will replace the 70-year-old bar. Matthew McDermott Explore More UnitedHealthcare CEO was facing DOJ probe for insider trading when he was killed in targeted NYC shooting Message on bullets fired by health care CEO's assassin bears eerie link to book condemning insurance companies Tsunami warning sparks panic along West Coast after 7.0-magnitude earthquake ‚Äî before being canceled The time-worn Irish bar, which opened in 1954, is now set to become a legal cannabis shop, according to a license filed with the state. But some neighbors are crying into their beers over plans for the new joint. ‚ÄúThere are so many other dispensaries now. We don‚Äôt need another dispensary for marijuana,‚Äù Christopher Conkling, 71, who‚Äôs retired and lives nearby. ‚ÄúThese mom and pop shops are going out of business,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs sad to see a piece of old New York go.‚Äù Others said they were happy to trade beers for buds. 35What do you think? Post a comment. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs all about the money, and if [the owner] found that marijuana is going to make him more money, then why wouldn‚Äôt he?‚Äù said Brad Zorfas, who works in the area. Smith‚Äôs announced it was closing in 2014, citing a rent hike but staying mum about other possible problems. It reopened the next year under new ownership with Skip Panettiere at the helm, according to the blog w42st.com, which was first to report a weed dispensary would take over Smith‚Äôs. Panettiere said Thursday he hasn‚Äôt owned the bar for years and wasn‚Äôt sure why it shuttered. Asked if he‚Äôs sentimental about the place closing, his response was very old-New York. ‚ÄúI couldn‚Äôt care less,‚Äù he told The Post. ‚ÄúThings change.‚Äù
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Left  
The article reflects a certain nostalgia for a disappearing piece of New York culture with a focus on the emotional responses of locals to the bar's closure. It conveys sadness and sentimentality, aligning with a progressive viewpoint that values historic local businesses over new developments like a cannabis dispensary. However, the inclusion of diverse opinions in an urban context suggests a somewhat balanced approach, resulting in a classification of Lean Left rather than outright Left.

title: With Trump on Deck, Europe Reaches for Its Checkbook
body: European leaders see Donald Trump‚Äôs return to the White House as a spur to the continent‚Äôs independence amid the potential weakening of a partnership that has shaped the world for most of the last century. ‚ÄúWe can‚Äôt depend on U.S. voters every four years for our security,‚Äù Benjamin Haddad, France‚Äôs Minister Delegate for European Affairs, tells TIME. ‚ÄúTrump will defend U.S. interests‚Äîit‚Äôs normal. It‚Äôs now time to wake up and defend ours.‚Äù That sentiment, expressed in recent years by French President Emmanuel Macron and others, has gained a growing resonance in the weeks since Trump‚Äôs victory over Vice President Kamala Harris, who had vowed to maintain the historical relationship embraced by President Joe Biden and every other post-war U.S. President save for Trump. In European capitals, observers say the shock many Europeans experienced after the 2016 election has given way to a more muted stoicism in 2024. Trump‚Äôs trademark unpredictability notwithstanding, Europeans are more clear-eyed about what they can expect from a second Trump term‚Äîin part because he‚Äôs already made his intentions clear. In wide-ranging interviews with TIME earlier this year, Trump pledged to take Europe to task on issues such as trade (‚ÄúEuropean Union is brutal to us on trade‚Äù) and defense spending (‚ÄúI want Europe to pay‚Äù). He also vowed to end the nearly three years of fighting between Russia and Ukraine in as little as a day‚Äîan aim that some fear could involve forcing Kyiv to cede territories that Moscow has claimed as its own. Read More: What Trump‚Äôs Win Means for the World ‚ÄúWe are much better prepared, because we know what awaits us,‚Äù says Nils Schmid, a German lawmaker and foreign policy spokesperson for the ruling Social Democrats. ‚ÄúAs far as we can be prepared for an unpredictable president, but still. European unity is, of course, key in dealing with this.‚Äù Among Trump‚Äôs longstanding complaints is that Washington disproportionately foots the bill for European defense, a gripe that‚Äôs grown as the U.S. provided military support for Ukraine after Russia‚Äôs invasion. Europe is already on it. Several European foreign ministers have called on countries to ‚Äúplay a still greater role in assuring our own security,‚Äù including by surpassing the current NATO defense spending targets and reinforcing Europe‚Äôs industrial base. The sentiment was echoed by many of their defense counterparts, who this week pledged to ramp up their own military support for Ukraine. ‚ÄúThe view is that we can‚Äôt be credible on Ukraine and expect Trump to take into account our sensitivities unless we‚Äôre willing to put a lot more money on the table,‚Äù says Mujtaba Rahman, the managing director for Europe at the Eurasia Group consultancy. In doing so, he says, Europe will not only be better positioned to influence Trump‚Äôs thinking on Ukraine, it will also hand the president an early win by allowing him to claim responsibility for pressuring the E.U. to shoulder more of the financial burden for Ukraine‚Äîjust as he did on defense spending within NATO during his first term. Georgina Wright, deputy director for international studies at the Paris-based think tank Institut Montaigne, says such thinking indicates a ‚Äúshift in mindset‚Äù within the bloc toward the transactional thinking that defines Trump‚Äôs approach to foreign policy. ‚ÄúI think there‚Äôs much more realization on the European side that you need to have a credible offer,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúIf Europeans are going to ask the Americans for guarantees and security, a continued presence in Europe, but also to be kind to them on trade, they know that they‚Äôre going to have to offer something in return.‚Äù That thinking extends beyond security. On trade, European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen has reportedly floated the idea of buying more U.S. liquified natural gas as a means of avoiding Trump‚Äôs punishing tariffs. If the tariffs come anyway, the thinking goes, the strategy can shift to retaliatory tariffs on American-made goods, such as Kentucky bourbon, Harley-Davidson motorcycles, and Levi‚Äôs jeans. Observers are confident that the E.U. can remain united on trade: ‚ÄúWhen faced with something that‚Äôs going to hit the whole of the E.U., even when it hits some member states more than others, there‚Äôs actually a default to band together,‚Äù Wright says. Support for Ukraine also appears solid. Despite opposition from Hungary‚Äôs Viktor Orb√°n, the bloc has provided 122 billion euros, or $131 billion, in military and financial aid. But Europe‚Äôs two biggest powers are embroiled in domestic troubles. Germany‚Äôs government collapsed earlier this month amid disputes over spending and how to address the gaping hole in the country‚Äôs budget; it is preparing to hold fresh elections on Feb. 23, meaning that the next government won‚Äôt be in place til months into the incoming Trump administration. France, meanwhile, is currently embroiled in a debt crisis that threatens to plunge its government, as well as the eurozone, into crisis. A weakened Berlin and Paris doesn‚Äôt necessarily mean a paralyzed E.U., Wright notes. But Trump may opt‚Äîas he did during his first term‚Äîto bypass European institutions and deal with national leaders directly. This is where Europe‚Äôs chosen interlocutors will be key: Among those seen as key in getting through to the president includes Mark Rutte, the reformer Dutch premier-turned-NATO-chief whose rapport with Trump during the president‚Äôs first term earned him the moniker ‚Äúthe Trump whisperer.‚Äù Another is Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni, whose conservative credentials have earned her plaudits within the MAGA movement, including from Trump‚Äôs incoming efficiency czar, Elon Musk. Most all European leaders appear to recognize that the incoming Trump administration presents an opportunity for Europe to pursue greater autonomy. ‚ÄúDo we want to continue to exist, to carry clout, or just be the passive theater of great power rivalries? That‚Äôs the question that Europeans must answer,‚Äù Haddad, of France, says. ‚ÄúIn 2016, there was collective denial, that this was an accident of history, that things would go back to ‚Äònormal.‚Äô Now it‚Äôs time to wake up from our vacation from history.‚Äù Others caution that a more self-reliant Europe need not push away American security guarantees on which the continent remains very much dependent. Schmid notes that calls by Macron for the E.U. to overhaul its security architecture‚Äî in large part by relying less on American nuclear deterrence and more on France‚Äôs own nuclear stockpile‚Äîinvites a continental version of the same risk that U.S. voters have twice driven home. ‚ÄúThe French always push it too far,‚Äù Schmid says. ‚ÄúI think there's a large majority among European governments that prefer to have both a rock solid U.S. commitment to Europe‚Äôs security and a strong European defense. But exchanging the U.S. nuclear umbrella for the uncertainty of the outcome of the next French presidential election is not so promising.‚Äù
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Left  
The article presents views that align with European leaders advocating for greater autonomy from the U.S., which suggests a critical stance towards Trump‚Äôs foreign policy. While it includes differing viewpoints and avoids overtly partisan language, the emphasis on Europe‚Äôs need for independence and the mention of Trump‚Äôs unpredictable nature reflects a skepticism often associated with left-leaning perspectives. Additionally, the focus on European solidarity and collaboration contrasts with traditional right-wing economic nationalism, reinforcing the article's lean towards a left-oriented interpretation.

title: Bubble bath on duty: Ernst report details federal employees‚Äô abuse of remote work
body: Perhaps nothing sums up remote work better than this selfie of a federal employee jumping on a call in a bubble bath. The employee was a manager at the Department of Veterans affairs who posted the picture on social media with the caption ‚Äì my office for the next hour. The picture encapsulates a new report from Senator Joni Ernst which found just 6% of federal employees work in the office full time, while about one-third are fully remote. Ernst‚Äôs investigation discovered the remote work has resulted in American taxpayers receiving inadequate services including service backlogs and delays, unanswered phone calls and emails, and no-show appointments. The shortcomings include calls from veterans from mental health services going unanswered. Ernst also said remote work partially contributed to the infant formula shortage of 2022. A whistleblower informed the Food and Drug Administration about unsanitary conditions at the formula plant in October 2021, but partially due to remote work, the FDA‚Äôs senior leadership was not informed for more than 100 days. The FDA‚Äôs reduction of food facility inspections during the pandemic was also a factor. The empty offices are costing taxpayers money. There isn‚Äôt a single agency headquarters in Washington that is half full, the average occupancy is 12%. The report states ‚Äì the government also owns 7,697 vacant buildings and another 2,265 that are partially empty. Maintenance, leases and energy on these buildings costs more than $15 billion a year. Ernst suggests monitoring employees locations and the productivity using VPNs, having use it or lose it policy for government real estate and making remote work policies performance based. Ernst‚Äôs report states ‚Äì ‚ÄúIf bureaucrats don‚Äôt want to return to work, make their wish come true.‚Äù Some of these changes could be implemented through the new Department of Government Efficiency. Ernst heads the DOGE Caucus which will work with Elon Musk and Vivek Ramaswamy to reduce government waste. Republicans met with the duo on Capitol Hill Thursday afternoon. House Speaker Mike Johnson, R-LA: ‚ÄúThe taxpayers deserve better. They deserve a more responsive government, a more efficient government, one that is leaner, more focused on its primary objectives. ‚Äú Making cuts to the government will need to be a closely aligned effort between the department and Congress, because only lawmakers on Capitol Hill have the power to make budget cuts.
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Right  
The article focuses on criticizing remote work among federal employees, emphasizing its negative impact on service delivery and government efficiency, which aligns with typical conservative viewpoints. It prominently features Republican Senator Joni Ernst's findings and suggestions, thus reflecting right-leaning sentiments regarding government accountability and efficiency. Additionally, it employs language suggesting the government is failing taxpayers, which is a common theme in lean-right media narratives.

title: Trump allies draw ‚Äòred line‚Äô at Hegseth, warning defeat would kneecap chances for other key nominees
body: The embattled nomination of Pete Hegseth for defense secretary has President-elect Donald Trump and allies working to hold the line on a second pick getting nixed or risk opening the floodgates for rejection of his unconventional nominees, including Tulsi Gabbard and Robert F. Kennedy Jr. Mr. Hegseth, a retired Army major, veterans‚Äô advocate and former Fox News host, pledged Thursday that he was ‚Äúnot going to back down‚Äù as he made the rounds on Capitol Hill for another day of interviews with senators. Accusations of past misconduct could lead Republicans to sink his nomination. With his closest allies, the president-elect is focusing on getting Mr. Hegseth confirmed or at least forcing senators to vote on his nomination to stop what could become a cascade of rejections of Mr. Trump‚Äôs anti-establishment picks. ‚ÄúPete Hegseth is our red line,‚Äù said Charlie Kirk, whose Turning Point Action and associated foundation helped elect Mr. Trump. ‚ÄúThere are a lot of Republican senators in the election cycle in 2026, and they should think twice before standing opposed to President Trump‚Äôs picks.‚Äù Some Senate Republicans have registered skepticism about Mr. Kennedy‚Äôs nomination to head the Department of Health and Human Services. Mr. Kennedy has questioned the safety of vaccines and fluoridated water and has personal issues that include sexual misconduct allegations. Mr. Trump‚Äôs pick of Ms. Gabbard, a former House member, to serve as director of national intelligence is also facing pushback. Some Senate Republicans question whether she has enough experience for the job. A surrender by Mr. Hegseth ‚Äúwould absolutely embolden the sort of recalcitrant senators to continue to oppose President Trump‚Äôs nominees,‚Äù said Will Chamberlain, senior counsel at the judicial advocacy group Article III Project. Senate Republicans, who will control the majority in January and could greenlight Mr. Trump‚Äôs picks without any Democratic votes, have forced out former Rep. Matt Gaetz. The firebrand abandoned his nomination to become Mr. Trump‚Äôs attorney general last month after several party lawmakers made clear they would not back him because of sexual misconduct allegations. Mr. Gaetz, who quit Congress last month amid an ethics inquiry, dropped out of the running after just a day of meetings with senators and without a single public hearing or a Senate floor vote. Mr. Trump and his allies don‚Äôt want a repeat with Mr. Hegseth, who is struggling to win over up to a half-dozen skeptical Republicans. ‚ÄúWe need to make these senators vote because if they‚Äôre going to do this to a second nominee, that isn‚Äôt going to be fun for them,‚Äù Mr. Chamberlain said. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre going to feel the full pressure of the grassroots and that they‚Äôre going to have to stand up and put their vote on the record against President Trump‚Äôs defense secretary nominee.‚Äù Some polls show Americans approve of Mr. Trump‚Äôs Cabinet picks after his sweeping victory on Nov. 5. At least one survey found a majority of Americans saying sexual misconduct allegations, a history of substance abuse or financial misconduct is disqualifying. Sen. Joni Ernst of Iowa is among the Senate Republicans casting doubt on confirming Mr. Hegseth because of reports of past misconduct. He was accused of sexual assault, infidelity in his first two marriages, financial mismanagement of veterans organizations he ran and excessive drinking around co-workers. Sen. Lindsey Graham, South Carolina Republican, is another Hegseth skeptic targeted by Trump allies. They say he opposes Mr. Hegseth because the nominee would attempt to overhaul the Pentagon. Mr. Graham said his scrutiny of Mr. Hegseth had nothing to do with blocking Trump nominees who are non-establishment picks. ‚ÄúIt ain‚Äôt about slippery slopes,‚Äù Mr. Graham said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs about those who fight and die for our country, that they are in good hands.‚Äù Mr. Hegseth barnstormed Republican senators‚Äô offices Thursday to defend himself and again make the case that he is up to leading a department with an $850 billion budget and more than 2 million military personnel. Mr. Hegseth told reporters he has ‚Äúdone tough things in tough places.‚Äù He was referring to his deployments to Afghanistan and Iraq, where he served in combat. ‚ÄúAnd sometimes that changes you a little bit,‚Äù Mr. Hegseth said. ‚ÄúAnd by the grace of God and my Lord and Savior, I had an opportunity to come on up out of it and do great things with great veterans organizations that fought for vets and fought for reform at the [Department of Veterans Affairs] and for warfighters, and at the Fox News Channel to advocate for those various causes.‚Äù Mr. Hegseth met with Sen. Mike Rounds, South Dakota Republican, who said afterward that he saw a path for the nominee to win confirmation. Mr. Hegseth has pledged to some senators that he would not drink any alcohol if confirmed to the top Pentagon post. Mr. Rounds defended the Senate scrutiny that has rankled Trump allies. ‚ÄúWe give the president the benefit of the doubt in building his team, but we also want to ask the questions that the public would ask and to be able to get those questions out so that the public has confidence that we‚Äôve made the right choices as well,‚Äù Mr. Rounds said.
Ai bias and explanation:
Center  
This article presents an objective account of the political dynamics surrounding the nomination of Pete Hegseth, highlighting both support from Trump allies and skepticism from Senate Republicans. The language used is neutral, and it includes quotes from various political figures without showing a clear preference for either side, maintaining an informative rather than persuasive tone. The focus is primarily on the events and reactions surrounding the nomination rather than an editorializing stance, which aligns with a center classification.

title: ICE is looking for a new detention center in Blue California. The state probably can‚Äôt stop it
body: Federal immigration authorities are looking for a potential new detention center in Northern California, an effort that alarms advocates and some Democratic state lawmakers as President-elect Donald Trump gears up to unleash his mass deportation plan. Federal immigration authorities are looking for a potential new detention center in Northern California, an effort that alarms advocates and some Democratic state lawmakers as President-elect Donald Trump gears up to unleash his mass deportation plan. In August, U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) issued a request for information to identify additional detention bed space in the state as other federal agencies intensified border enforcement. The effort began in the wake of the Biden administration‚Äôs sweeping asylum ban, implemented in June, for migrants caught crossing the U.S.-Mexico border outside designated entry points. Under the ban, border agents can deport such migrants within hours or days without considering their asylum claims. Advocates say an expansion of detention space would give Trump a runway to carry out more mass deportations in California. Immigrants in counties with more detention space are more likely to be arrested and detained, according to research by advocacy groups. Unlike in Texas, where state officials are offering up land to the Trump administration to facilitate mass deportations, California tried to ban new federal immigrant detention centers from opening during the first Trump administration. The court blocked that, ruling that the state was unconstitutionally overstepping on federal immigration enforcement. California Attorney General Rob Bonta told CalMatters that the state may be powerless to stop the possibility of a new facility. Federal documents show ICE issued the request for information on Aug. 14.
