Such requests can pave the way for federal contracts, in this case to obtain ‚Äúavailable detention facilities for single adult populations (male and female)‚Äù in Arizona, New Mexico, Washington, Oregon, and California. Its request says the facilities should each have from 850 to 950 detention beds and ‚Äúmay be publicly or privately owned and publicly or privately operated.‚Äù One of the facilities should be within a two-hour drive of the San Francisco field office, the documents state. The request also seeks facilities near field offices in Phoenix, El Paso, and Seattle. ‚ÄúICE has identified a need for immigration detention services within the Western U.S. area of responsibility,‚Äù ICE spokesman Richard Beam wrote in an email to CalMatters. ‚ÄúThe proposed services are part of ICE‚Äôs effort to continually review its detention requirements and explore options that will afford ICE the operational flexibility needed to house the full range of detainees in the agency‚Äôs custody.‚Äù Currently, ICE detains roughly 38,000 people every day in about 120 immigration jails across the country. In California, that number is just under 3,000 detainees each day, held in six facilities, according to the most recently available immigration data maintained by the Transactional Records Access Clearinghouse at Syracuse University. That‚Äôs the third-largest population of detained immigrants in the country. While ICE, the federal agency responsible for immigration enforcement, owns and operates a very small number of facilities nationwide, it mostly contracts with private prison operators such as CoreCivic, GEO Group, and Management and Training Corp. Their detention facilities house 80% of ICE‚Äôs detainees. Stock for CoreCivic and GEO Group soared upon Trump‚Äôs win last month. In California, private, for-profit prison companies run all six ICE detention facilities ‚Äì the Golden State Annex and Mesa Verde detention facilities in Kern County; the Adelanto Detention Facility and Desert View Annex, both in San Bernardino County; the Otay Mesa Detention Center in San Diego County; and the Imperial Regional Detention Facility in Imperial County. Across all six, the federal government has the capacity to detain up to 7,188 people statewide. State Sen. Mar√≠a Elena Durazo, a Democrat from Los Angeles, said she was concerned about the potential economic impacts of ICE having an increased capacity for detention and, therefore, deportations. ‚ÄúThe expansion of detention in California concerns everyone in our state. Expanding detention correlates with increased ICE raids and family separation, all of which has devastating social and economic impacts for California,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIn addition, these facilities are run by private for-profit companies that consistently place their bottom-line profit above the health and safety of those who work in or are detained in these facilities.‚Äù Advocates argue that detention expansions lead to human rights abuses and undermine community safety. ‚ÄúAn expansion of ICE detention operations within the Bay Area and Northern California is going to be part of a reign of terror on our communities the Trump administration is threatening,‚Äù said Bree Bernwanger, a senior staff attorney on the Immigrants‚Äô Rights team at the American Civil Liberties Union of Northern California. ‚ÄúWe already know from existing facilities within California that ICE does not and cannot maintain safe and or healthy standards of confinement for people inside.‚Äù The ACLU is suing to learn more about the federal agency‚Äôs expanded detention plans. Bernwanger was referring to issues like complaints of sexually abusive patdowns. Also, in 2023, ICE allegedly retaliated against hunger strikers by storming into their cells, violently dragging them, threatening them with forced feedings, and then providing food that was not appropriate for breaking a 21-day fast, prompting a medical condition in at least one inmate, according to a claim filed by the inmate, who was represented by two advocacy groups. In August, the civil liberties organization released a 34-page report detailing 485 grievances filed by detainees across six immigration detention facilities in California between 2023 and June 2024. Those grievances included allegations of hazardous facilities, inhumane treatment, medical neglect, and retaliation. ICE declined to comment on the report. In December 2019, California passed a law that would have banned private immigration detention centers. It was part of a wave of resistance by California Democrats to the first Trump administration. It also prohibited the state from using for-profit prisons for any inmates starting in 2028. The for-profit facilities ‚Äúcontribute to over-incarceration‚Äù and ‚Äúdo not reflect our values,‚Äù Gov. Gavin Newsom said in a statement when signing the bill. Days before the law was set to go into effect, ICE signed new contracts for its facilities in California. The federal 9th Circuit Court of Appeals later overturned the state‚Äôs ban on private prisons. Bonta, who wrote the unsuccessful ban as an Oakland assemblymember, told CalMatters in November that the state might not be able to stop ICE from opening another detention facility outside of San Francisco. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a matter of federal jurisdiction,‚Äù Bonta said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs federal. I disagree, but my office‚Äôs disagreement was considered, and the court determined that it was a federal issue.‚Äù This story was originally published by CalMatters and distributed through a partnership with The Associated Press.
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Left  
The article expresses concern over ICE‚Äôs potential expansion of detention centers and mass deportations, reflecting sentiments of alarm from advocates and California Democrats. It highlights issues of human rights abuses and the for-profit nature of private detention facilities, which aligns with progressive perspectives emphasizing the protection of immigrants‚Äô rights. The framing of ICE's actions and federal policies tends to resonate more with a left-leaning audience, reflecting skepticism of the federal government's approach to immigration under the Trump administration.

title: Democrats Tell Biden to Get as Many Migrants Possible into U.S. Before Leaving Office
body: A few Senate Democrats are lobbying President Joe Biden to get as many migrants into the United States as possible and ensure they stay indefinitely before he leaves office and President-elect Donald Trump enters the White House. This week, Sens. Catherine Cortez Masto (D-NV), Ben Ray Luj√°n (D-NM), and Alex Padilla (D-CA) sent a letter to Biden asking him to reward large groups of illegal aliens and other migrants in the U.S. with immigration benefits before he exits office next month. ‚ÄúIn addition to supporting strong border security, we are eager to ensure that DACA recipients, TPS holders, and other immigrants who are critical members of our communities and economies are not forgotten during this busy time,‚Äù the Senators write. In particular, the Senators want Biden to allow hundreds of thousands of illegal aliens enrolled in the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program to extend their status for the maximum length of time that is allowed by the Department of Homeland Security (DHS). Similarly, the Senators are asking Biden to extend and redesignate several countries for Temporary Protected Status (TPS) so that newly arrived migrants from such countries can stay in the U.S. while those already in the U.S. can stay even longer than currently granted. ‚ÄúWhat I take is what I hear from this incoming administration, they‚Äôre going to engage in mass deportation and nobody is safe,‚Äù Cortez Masto told MSNBC this week. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs why I‚Äôm asking the administration to come in now to protect some of the immigrant communities ‚Äî TPS recipients, DACA recipients.‚Äù Already, the Biden administration has grown the foreign-born population by nearly seven million since January 2021 ‚Äî ballooning the number of foreign nationals living in the U.S. to an unprecedented nearly 52 million. John Binder is a reporter for Breitbart News. Email him at jbinder@breitbart.com. Follow him on Twitter here.
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Right  
The article reflects a right-leaning bias as it emphasizes the perspectives of Senate Democrats advocating for the easing of immigration controls, framing them as politically motivated actions before a transition to a Republican administration. Furthermore, the use of phrases like "mass deportation" and highlighting an increase in foreign-born population suggest a critical stance towards immigration policies associated with the Biden administration, characteristic of a conservative viewpoint.

title: New York judge refuses to marry same-sex couple 'because of her religious beliefs': report
body: A civil judge in Syracuse, New York recently refused to officiate a wedding between two women, in an apparent violation of anti-discrimination laws. That's according to a Wednesday article in the Syracuse Post-Standard, which reported that Judge Felicia Pitts Davis walked out of her chambers on November 16 as soon as a same-sex couple walked in. The couple ‚Äî 33 year-old Shawntay Davis and 29 year-old Niccora Davis ‚Äî were left alone in the chambers until another city court judge, Mary Anne Doherty, came in and officiated their wedding. "The way [Pitts Davis] got up and left the courtroom was rude, then all of a sudden another judge came in, and that‚Äôs when we got married,‚Äù Shawntay Davis told the Post-Standard. ‚ÄúIt was real weird.‚Äù READ MORE: This Michigan lawmaker wants to 'make gay marriage illegal again' Pitts Davis had officiated a wedding of a heterosexual couple just prior to the Davises, and reportedly even cried during the ceremony. The Post-Standard cited two unnamed sources who said Pitts Davis told Doherty that she didn't want to marry the two women due to her "religious beliefs." Syracuse city court spokesperson Al Baker told the paper that the court was "aware of the allegation and have referred the matter to the State Commission on Judicial Conduct." Pitts Davis was elected to her 10-year term in 2020, in the wake of the Black Lives Matter uprising that swept the nation after former Minneapolis Police Department officer Derek Chauvin murdered George Floyd. She told the paper at the time that she recalled watching her mother work until she was almost 90 years old, and grew uo hearing stories about racial discrimination and lynchings. "As a Black woman, what I‚Äôve always been taught ‚Äì what I‚Äôve fought for ‚Äì has relied on the protections of the Constitution, and I had to learn how to make those real," she said. AlterNet has reached out to Pitts Davis' office for comment, and will update this article in the event of a response. READ MORE: (Opinion) How the Supreme Court could make same-sex marriage into second-class marriage Click here to red the Post-Standard's article in its entirety.
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Left  
The article focuses on the refusal of a judge to officiate a same-sex marriage, citing religious beliefs, which highlights issues of discrimination and civil rights. The framing emphasizes the struggles and experiences of the same-sex couple while also mentioning the broader social context of discrimination faced by marginalized communities. This perspective aligns more closely with a left-leaning viewpoint that advocates for LGBTQ+ rights and criticisms of discrimination, rather than aiming for neutrality or supporting traditional views on marriage.

title: President-Elect Trump Fills Top Roles as Republicans Set to Win Senate and House
body: Just three days after Election Day, the transition is already underway for President-elect Donald Trump's second term. The new administration is moving swiftly to fill top roles, while Republicans are on track to take control of both chambers of Congress. After securing his historic second White House term as the 47th president, Trump's team is looking ahead to day-one priorities, including carrying out his campaign promise to deport an estimated 12 million undocumented immigrants and rescind any of the Biden's administration policies that expanded opportunities for migrants to live and work in the U.S. The President-elect is also already starting to fill out his administration. New York Congresswoman Elise Stefanik is said to be the administration's top candidate for U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations. However, no official decision has been made. Women are among the first names to fill administration roles including the appointment of Susie Wiles. Trump's campaign manager will serve as the White House Chief of Staff. Wiles, the daughter of football legend Pat Summerall, is the first woman to hold the influential role. There's quite the shake-up in Washington D.C., from the Oval Office to Capitol Hill. The latest election results appear to put House and Senate Republicans on track to control both chambers of Congress next year. The GOP carrying the Senate with 53 seats following a major upset out of Pennsylvania. Republican David McCormick flipped Democratic incumbent Bob Casey's seat. Like Trump and Republicans across the map, McCormick significantly erased Democratic support. Meanwhile, lawmakers in other states are prepared to challenge the new Trump administration. "As attorney general, I will continue to use the full force of the law, the full authority of my office to address injustice, to stand up for all people, especially those who have been long overlooked and undervalued, to safeguard reproductive rights," said Rob Banta, California's Attorney General. California Governor Gavin Newsom echoed the Attorney General calling for a special session of the state legislature to help fund potential legal challenges to Trump policies affecting women's rights, immigration, and climate. The governors of Illinois and New York are making similar pledges to defend their states against Trump's second-term policies they deem harmful. The president-elect's new mass deportation plan, according to some estimates, could cost upwards of $88 billion a year. Mr. Trump dismissed those price concerns in an interview with NBC News saying, "There is no price tag to safety."
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Right  
The article mainly focuses on President-elect Trump's administration and Republican dominance, presenting information in a factual manner that highlights GOP successes and Trump's plans. However, it includes critical perspectives from Democratic figures, particularly regarding those who challenge Trump's policies. The tone leans towards positivity about Republican initiatives while framing opposition as reactive and defensive, which aligns with a lean-right bias. Overall, it emphasizes a pro-Republican narrative while acknowledging dissent from Democrats.

title: This Administration Doesn‚Äôt Care About the Cool Girls
body: GOP senators are already laying the groundwork with which to blow off the new, harrowing reporting from Jane Mayer in the New Yorker about Trump‚Äôs putative new defense secretary, Pete Hegseth. They dismiss the allegations of a serial abuser as the kind of sweetly innocent ‚Äúwild child‚Äù activity that is somehow de rigueur in the military. Which means that many American women will yet again confront a tough choice: Are they going to be ‚Äúparty girls‚Äù or ‚Äúnot party girls,‚Äù as Hegseth himself allegedly classified the female staffers of the nonprofit veterans group he once ran? Do they wish to be the invisible, fungible women destined to be groped, assaulted, and humiliated, or will they be the ‚Äúnot party girls,‚Äù who, as we are only just beginning to discover, are invisible and fungible as well? This is hardly a new or unfamiliar taxonomy, just as the taxonomy of which women will die this year as a result of a miscarriage is not new or unfamiliar. No matter what we choose‚Äîto want to be mothers or not, to go along with it or not‚Äîit can still be any of us. As Nick Fuentes put it, women‚Äôs bodies are now his choice. So it can be any of us. The Republican senators who met with Hegseth this week brushed aside reports of drunkenness, sexual abuse, rape, and financial self-dealing as trivial, NBC reports, just as they threaten to do away with the very FBI background checks that would determine as much. So the victims will be any of us. We are finally collapsing the ancient social scaffolding of ‚Äúgood girls‚Äù versus ‚Äúgirls who had it coming‚Äù in the interest of ensuring that there are only girls who had it coming. It‚Äôs almost as if 2024 became the year in which maybe all women were not really ‚Ä¶ real. Jessica Reed Kraus, who writes the hugely popular House Inhabit Substack, affirmed after the election that she remains certain that Donald Trump, Elon Musk, and RFK Jr. were her leaders of choice. But she also noted that she is realizing that what women think of them doesn‚Äôt much matter to them. Reflecting on that photo of the bros pounding McDonald‚Äôs on Trump‚Äôs plane after a UFC match was, ‚Äúeven for me‚Äîsomeone who unapologetically champions the return of brazen masculinity‚Äî ‚Ä¶ a bit too ‚Äòbro-ish‚Äô for my liking.‚Äù Kraus couldn‚Äôt fathom why‚Äîhaving just wrapped up a ‚Äúyear‚Äôs worth of flattering coverage‚Äù of Trump‚Äîfemale Trump boosters, like herself and Danica Patrick, were again being shunted aside for the ‚Äúpodcast bros‚Äù her girlfriends weren‚Äôt tuned in to. Why, Kraus mused, in all this chest-thumping coverage of the UFC fight and the subsequent friends-with-that flight, had ‚Äúno one honed in on the moment when Trump sidestepped a crowd to kiss Marla Maples on the cheek‚Äù? Kraus didn‚Äôt understand why women Trump fans had not been offered evidence of that kiss, like a chocolate-dipped Hallmark Christmas movie shot. As E.J. Dickson of the Cut noted, Kraus‚Äô primary objection wasn‚Äôt so much the actual bro-y-ness of the postelection worldview as the bro-y ‚Äúaesthetic.‚Äù Why, asked Kraus, is it that ‚Äúthe UFC scene was overwhelmingly directed to impress dudes‚Äù? Why, one must ponder, have all these public-facing men who pretended to care about their women and their families in 2016 opted to erase the media coverage of Trump‚Äôs sweet and loving kiss bestowed on the second wife with whom he cheated on the first wife, before he cheated on her by taking up with his third wife? What the hell, we are forced to ask, has happened to family values? It is certainly possible that the right-wing media simply forgot to cover the tender moments of fatherhood and love and heroic chivalry and sensitivity in this election cycle. But it is far more likely that the flagrant election of‚Äîand the subsequent offering of Cabinet positions to‚Äîa host of men variously accused of sexual assault, sexual trafficking of minors, assaulting babysitters, and serial adultery is no longer disqualifying for the position but essential and maybe even mandatory prior work experience. And so the performance of family values is a drag. Sherrilyn Ifill has been asking why discussions of gender and race have been almost totally erased from the postelection punditry, and embedded in that question is a more chilling one: Why have a host of men who manifestly hate women, who abuse and demean and then attempt to erase them, been offered leadership roles without a searching analysis of why that happened? Why did the patina of respect for, and the false promise of protection of, vulnerable women simply drop out of the Trump transition efforts? Is anyone experiencing the dawning realization that for men like Pete Hegseth‚Äîwhose own mother has described him as a profoundly damaged abuser of women‚Äîthe women who are grabbed and attacked and discredited are staunch Republican activists, not the other sorts of women, not the cat ladies, not the ‚Äúnon‚Äìparty girls‚Äù? Is it possible, as Dickson describes it, that what ‚Äúthe growing reservations of female Trump voters indicate is that within the patriarchy, there are no exceptions, no chill girls to whom the rules do not apply‚Äù? The reason you are not seeing soft-filter narratives about Donald Trump‚Äôs Cabinet picks and their love for women is because there‚Äôs no need for filtration. Hating women is OK now. Any man who has been accused of wrongdoing is presumptively a gladiator, and any woman who levels an accusation is presumptively a liar. Jane Mayer‚Äôs stunning portrait of Hegseth‚Äôs life of abuse and assault, which includes paying off a victim of a 2017 assault in Monterey, ends with twin revelations that would be shocking in any other age: The Trump transition team didn‚Äôt bother to learn of and were in fact ‚Äúblindsided‚Äù by these allegations. (Indeed, the group expected Hegseth to share them.) And Hegseth‚Äôs attorney told Mayer that the police report about the alleged sexual assault had surfaced prior false allegations of sexual assault by the alleged victim that had discredited her account. That was a lie, immediately debunked by the Monterey County district attorney‚Äôs office. No need to muddy the waters, no need to create alternative facts. Just call women liars and move along to the confirmation. For a very long time, we preferred to have public officials vetted before they assumed office‚Äîin part because of the fear that they could be subject to blackmail. Overnight and perhaps imperceptibly, we have moved into an era in which there is evidently no reason to fear such blackmail. The conduct shocks nobody. Abusing women for sport, or because you‚Äôre not a ‚Äúchurch boy,‚Äù or because to be a ‚Äúwild child‚Äù is to embody manliness: that need not be power-washed or kept secret anymore. There need be no investigation, FBI or ersatz, because whatever is unearthed is allowed. And the women who will be paid off and fired and shunned and rape kitted and lied about? They will be knowingly and deliberately devalued, whether they wanted to ‚Äúparty‚Äù or not.
Ai bias and explanation:
Left  
This article presents a critical view of the Republican Party and its treatment of women, specifically referencing allegations of abuse and the perceived dismissal of women's voices. The language used suggests a strong disdain for the GOP's handling of gender issues and paints a picture of systemic misogyny. The focus on the implications of male-dominated leadership and the negative portrayal of Trump's Cabinet choices further aligns with left-leaning perspectives that advocate for women's rights and equality.

title: The Syrian Civil War Has Come Alive After Years of Being Dormant. What‚Äôs Happening?
body: The resumption of large-scale fighting in Syria‚Äôs civil war affirms, once more, the wisdom of the Irish poet William Butler Yeats, who wrote that when ‚ÄúThings fall apart; the centre cannot hold; / Mere anarchy is loosed upon the world, / The blood-dimmed tide is loosed.‚Äù In Syria‚Äôs case, the region‚Äôs security arrangements fell apart, the delicate balance of power could not hold, and so the strongest of the country‚Äôs armed militias rushed into the resulting void, unleashing a blood-dimmed tide along the way. Which is to say: Russia, Iran, and Hezbollah‚ÄîSyrian President Bashar al-Assad‚Äôs main allies, which have kept him in power for the past decade by helping him bomb, strafe, and otherwise crush a variety of rebel groups (along with much of the general population)‚Äîare now gravely weakened or preoccupied elsewhere. Last week, the strongest of these rebel groups, Hayat Tahrir al-Sham (known as HTS), exploited Assad‚Äôs isolation by going on the offensive, taking control of Aleppo, Syria‚Äôs second-largest city, and is now on the verge of capturing Hama, a crucial point on the route by which Assad has received arms from Hezbollah and Iran. For the moment, Assad is still safe. Damascus, the capital, is 115 miles from Hama. But the Syrian army collapsed with surprising ease, with many troops deserting the battlefield, in the face of the HTS rebels‚Äô onslaught. Russia sent a few planes to bomb the rebel positions, but not many and, so far, to little effect; the Russian deployments in Syria were also overrun (the commanding officer has since reportedly been fired). Iran‚Äôs ministry of foreign affairs condemned the assault as ‚Äúterrorism,‚Äù but it has done little to help. Their predicaments are clear. Russia‚Äôs military is stretched thin by the war in Ukraine. (It is now reliant on former underlings, importing drones from Iran and rockets‚Äîas well as 10,000 troops‚Äîfrom North Korea.) Iran is weakened in two ways. First, Hezbollah, which has acted as its main agent in helping Syria, has been decimated in recent battles with Israel. Second, Iran itself is nearing economic collapse, which has compelled Tehran‚Äôs leaders to seek renewed contact with the West. The collapse of Syria‚Äôs network isn‚Äôt the only cause of the rebels‚Äô surge. In the 13 years of the country‚Äôs civil war, Assad, his army, and his allies have killed more than 500,000 of his own citizens, many of them peaceful pro-democracy activists. He has little support among the civilian population. Assad‚Äôs policies, combined with Western sanctions, have impoverished the country. Even his soldiers, 100,000 of whom have been killed or wounded in the fighting, are short on supplies, which could explain why they so quickly ran from fighting. So, who are the rebels of Hayat Tahrir al-Sham? Should we be rooting for them? Reports are mixed and at times contradictory, perhaps in part because with all the wars going on in the Middle East, the Syrian civil war‚Äîwhich has been relatively dormant in the past few years‚Äîhas escaped the attention of many journalists and analysts in the region. The group was once affiliated with al-Qaida. Its leader, Abu Mohammed al-Golani, cut ties with the terrorist group some years ago, saying he wanted to attain international legitimacy, in part so that he could step up as leader of Syria‚Äôs myriad rebel groups‚Äîsome of them Kurds, some Sunni Arabs, most of them having little in common ideologically. Still, HTS remains a Salafi Jihadist group, and the United States and U.K. still consider it a ‚Äúterrorist organization,‚Äù meaning it cannot be given assistance. President Biden‚Äôs national security adviser, Jake Sullivan, told CNN on Sunday that he won‚Äôt ‚Äúcry over the fact that the Assad government‚Äîbacked by Russia, Iran, and Hezbollah‚Äîare facing certain kinds of pressure,‚Äù though he added that there are ‚Äú
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Left  
The article presents a critical view of Bashar al-Assad's regime, highlighting the human toll of the Syrian civil war and framing the actions of Russia, Iran, and Hezbollah negatively. It emphasizes Western involvement and perspectives, particularly through the lens of U.S. officials. While it doesn't exhibit extreme bias, the focus on the plight of civilians and the portrayal of Assad's government as oppressive suggest a lean toward left-leaning perspectives that often prioritize human rights and condemn authoritarian regimes.

title: Democrat Senator Shocks ‚ÄòThe View‚Äô: Pardon Is Warranted In Trump‚Äôs NY¬†Case
body: Senator John Fetterman (D-PA) told the liberal hosts of ABC‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe View‚Äù that he believed a pardon was called for in ‚Äúthe trial in New York‚Äù for President-elect Donald Trump, saying that it was a clear example of a politically motivated prosecution.Fetterman joined the cohosts of the midday talk show on Thursday, and the discussion turned to President Joe Biden‚Äôs Thanksgiving weekend pardon of his embattled son, Hunter Biden. Fetterman also claimed that the case against Hunter Biden ‚Äî which was brought by a special prosecutor and President Biden‚Äôs Justice Department ‚Äî was politically motivated, arguing that pardons would be reasonable in both cases.‚ÄúSo, Senator, President Biden‚Äôs decision to pardon his son Hunter is facing bipartisan backlash. Even the Democrats are all over it. But what do you think?‚Äù host Joy Behar asked, attempting to downplay the pardon. ‚ÄúIs this much ado about nothing? It is his son, after all, and people do have sympathy for that, but a lot of people are angry with him about that. What do you say?‚Äù‚ÄúI think it‚Äôs undeniable that the case against Hunter Biden was really politically motivated but I also think it‚Äôs true that the trial in New York for Trump, that was political as well too,‚Äù Fetterman replied. ‚ÄúIn both cases, I think a pardon is appropriate. And I really think collectively America‚Äôs confidence in these kinds of institutions have been damaged by these kinds of cases.‚ÄùWATCH:AdvertisementFetterman calls out Democratic Party hypocrisy on criminal justice reform and second chances while saying Trump shouldn't be president because he's a convicted felon. Adding: "‚Ä¶charges would have never been brought unless one side could realize they could weaponize that." pic.twitter.com/hnECB6Qg6a‚Äî Nicholas Fondacaro (@NickFondacaro) December 5, 2024Behar jumped back into the conversation, fretting that the same argument could be made about the people facing charges and prison time for crimes related to January 6th.AdvertisementCHECK OUT THE DAILY WIRE HOLIDAY GIFT GUIDE‚ÄúThey‚Äôll say that about the J-6 people too though, right? That‚Äôs what they‚Äôre going to say on the other side,‚Äù she complained. ‚ÄúThat that is weaponized also.‚ÄùFetterman pushed back, saying he wasn‚Äôt going that far with the argument: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not referring to that. I‚Äôm talking about the New York trial and now ‚Äî the Democrats, on our side, there were some that were gleeful calling it ‚Äî well, ‚Äònow he‚Äôs a convicted felon,'‚Äù Fetterman continued, arguing that it made Democrats look dishonest when they claimed to be in favor of things like criminal justice reform and second chances while celebrating Trump‚Äôs conviction and arguing that he did not deserve a moment‚Äôs grace for anything.AdvertisementThe cohosts of ‚ÄúThe View,‚Äù whether Fetterman realized it or not, were among those Democrats who gleefully crowed about the fact that Trump had been convicted in the New York case, and went out of their way to refer to him as a ‚Äúconvicted felon‚Äù as often as possible.‚ÄúI felt like America won! I felt like I won!‚Äù cohost Sunny Hostin said after the verdict was announced.Advertisement
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Left  
The article presents a narrative that aligns with left-leaning perspectives, focusing on a Democratic senator's comments about political motivations behind legal actions against Trump and Hunter Biden. It includes quotes from the senator that critique both sides of politics and highlights an inherent hypocrisy in the Democratic response to Trump's conviction. However, the overall tone and subject matter reflect a liberal viewpoint, especially by framing the discussion around perceived political injustices in legal proceedings.

title: Bernie Sanders says Elon Musk is 'a very smart guy' and RFK Jr. 'is right' about our unhealthy society
body: Sen. Bernie Sanders is extending an olive branch to President-elect Donald Trump and his incoming administration. In an interview with Business Insider on Tuesday, the Vermont senator listed areas of common ground with Elon Musk, a cochair of a new extragovernmental body aiming to cut costs, as well as with Robert F. Kennedy Jr. on health and Trump on credit debt. "If somebody on the other side has a good idea, sure, I'll work with them," Sanders, who at 83 is the longest-serving independent in Congress, told BI. Sanders made headlines on Sunday when he posted on X his support for Musk's pitch to curb defense spending. Musk, whom Sanders has previously criticized as a threat to democracy, responded with a laughing emoji and said, "Maybe we can find some common ground." Sanders told BI he had no qualms about working with Musk on the Department of Defense's spending, or on any other good ideas he has as cochair of DOGE, the new Department of Government Efficiency announced by Trump. "Many of the things he did during the campaign were really ugly. On the other hand, he's a very smart guy," Sanders said, adding that "he is absolutely right" to call for the first independent audit of the Pentagon in over seven years. "We need a strong military, but we don't need all the waste and the profiteering and the fraud that exists in the Pentagon right now," he said. While Musk has yet to outline specific plans to curb defense spending, he has criticized the Department of Defense's F-35 program and cited its $841 billion budget in a Wall Street Journal op-ed about his mission to cut costs. In April, Sanders pushed to cut $88.6 billion, or 10%, from the military budget. The amendment was outvoted, and Sanders slammed lawmakers, saying they're pouring money into an unaudited department. In 2021, the Pentagon said that it was trying to learn from each failed audit but that it would take until 2028 to make all the logistical changes necessary to meet standards. The Department of Defense did not immediately respond to a request for comment. Sanders, a cochair of the Senate health committee, told BI he also saw common ground with Kennedy, particularly when it comes to ultraprocessed food. Kennedy, Trump's pick to lead the Department of Health and Human Services, faces a tough confirmation hearing, given his opposition to vaccines and plans to take on food giants and industry lobbyists. If confirmed, he has pledged to "make America healthy again" by tackling chronic disease. He promises to ban processed foods from school meals and remove food dyes from the US food system, among other measures. Sanders is game for a shake-up of our nutrition system. This week, he's leading a Senate hearing on ultraprocessed foods, interrogating how processed products are regulated and how they affect health. "When Kennedy talks about an unhealthy society, he's right. The amount of chronic illness that we have is just extraordinary," Sanders told BI. He cited the millions of people living with obesity and diabetes and the ripple effects across all sectors. Diabetes care now costs the US an estimated $400 billion a year, a GlobalData analysis found. And a recent report said the military was struggling to recruit young people who meet the physical requirements to be enlisted. "Our kids are not healthy enough. In the long run, you want a healthy society as an end in itself," Sanders said. "We want our people to have long lives, productive lives, happy lives. That's what we want. And if the industry is giving our kids food that's making them overweight, leading to diabetes and other illnesses, clearly that's an issue that we've got to deal with." Sanders, who has previously criticized Kennedy's views on vaccines, added: "I think a lot of what RFK is saying is kind of crazy and driven by conspiracy theory. Some of what he's saying is not crazy. "Anybody with a brain in his or her head wants to deal with this issue, to get to the cause of the problem. I think processed food and the kind of sugar and salt that we have in products that our kids and adults are ingesting is an important part of addressing that crisis." Kennedy did not immediately respond to a request for comment. While Trump and Sanders are on opposite sides of the political spectrum, they may have common ground on credit-card interest rates. Credit-card debt held by American consumers hit $1.17 trillion in 2023, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. "Donald Trump came out with an idea during this campaign. He said, you know what, credit-card interest rates, which in some cases right now are 20, 25%, should not be higher than 10%. Well, you know what? I agree with that," Sanders said. While Trump said a cap would be "temporary" to help Americans "catch up" with payments, the suggestion made a splash. Mark Cuban, a longtime critic of Trump, mocked him for going even further than "self-described socialist Bernie Sanders." It would be tough to drive through Congress, as Sanders knows. He and Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez tabled an interest-rate cap of 15% in 2019, which went nowhere. Now Sanders is challenging Trump to wield his strong mandate to make this a key issue. "We'll see if Mr. Trump is prepared to keep his word. We're looking forward, and we will work with some Republicans on that issue," Sanders said. Trump did not immediately respond to a request for comment. "Where Trump and Republicans make sense, happy to work with them," Sanders said. "And we will be in vigorous opposition to many of their policies, which to me are extremely distasteful."
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Left  
The article primarily features Bernie Sanders' perspectives and cooperation with various figures, including those from opposing political views, showcasing an inclination towards progressive ideas. However, by portraying Sanders' willingness to engage with those like Trump and Kennedy, it leans slightly left while not heavily skewing towards partisan criticism, allowing for a more balanced view of political dialogue. The inclusion of Sanders‚Äô critiques of unhealthy societal conditions and processed food reflects a focus on left-leaning socio-economic concerns.

title: After years of legal fights, North Carolina's voter ID law gets its first major test
body: CHARLOTTE, N.C. ‚Äî For more than a decade, North Carolina has been home to a bitter back-and-forth over whether voters must show identification to cast a ballot in the swing state. The requirement finally got its first major test in last month's presidential election. Overall, just a tiny fraction of people had their ballots rejected. But critics say voter ID is still a solution in search of a problem, and they note that Black voters were more likely to have their ballots rejected than white voters. Kelle Pressley of Charlotte was one of the voters nearly affected. Pressley is a consistent voter, having cast a ballot 29 times since 2008, counting primaries and general elections. But when she came to vote on Election Day last month, she realized she didn't have her ID. "I change bags often, and I was thinking I had it on me, but I didn't," she said. "I still haven't found it." Pressley said there was confusion at her precinct about her options. She said poll workers urged her to go home and find her ID, instead of having her cast a provisional ballot and fill out an ID exception form, which allows voters to list a reason why they don't have an ID. The reasons range from a voter lacking transportation to them losing their ID. Pressley went home and called a voter protection hotline. She then came back to her precinct an hour before polls closed. She said this time poll workers allowed her to fill out the exception form and cast a provisional ballot. Her vote ultimately counted. "Someone else would have ‚Ä¶ been like, 'Forget about it, I'm not voting,' " she said. "'Que sera sera, whatever will be will be.' " Pressley was one of nearly 6,900 North Carolinians who came to vote without photo ID. Out of more than 5.7 million voters, that's about one in every 830 voters who cast ballots. Most of those people were able to cast a provisional ballot. County elections boards counted most of them and, in the end, just 1,670 people had their ballots rejected because they didn't have ID. The rejection rate was one in every 3,400 voters. But attorney Kathleen Roblez with the group Forward Justice, which has a pending lawsuit over the voter ID law, said that's still too many people, considering in-person voter fraud has been found to be almost nonexistent. And she said more people were probably impacted this year than show up in state data. "So you really have no idea how many people saw all of the information about ID and said, 'I can't vote,' " Roblez said. Voter ID is required in 36 states, including the swing states of Georgia, Arizona and Wisconsin. North Carolina's fight over ID rules has lasted more than a decade. Two years after Republicans gained control of the state legislature in 2011, GOP lawmakers passed a strict photo ID law. The 4th Circuit Court of Appeals in 2016 overturned the law, ruling that Republican legislators targeted Black voters with "almost surgical precision." In 2018, lawmakers tried again. They placed a constitutional amendment on the ballot requiring photo ID. It was approved with 55% of the vote. It also had support from some Black lawmakers. The legislature then passed a law to implement the amendment. The second photo ID law was more lenient than the 2013 version, allowing voters to use multiple IDs and to get a free ID from their county elections board. It also allowed people to cast provisional ballots so long as they list a reason for not having identification. Six voters sued over the new law, along with the NAACP. In 2021, North Carolina judges struck down the law, saying it again discriminated against Black voters. Allison Riggs, who is now on the state Supreme Court, was an attorney for the plaintiffs. She said that ruling shows "how the state's Republican-controlled legislature undeniably implemented this legislation to maintain its power by targeting voters of color." But in 2023, the state Supreme Court ‚Äî with a new Republican majority ‚Äî said that photo ID could proceed. The requirement was in place for municipal elections that fall, and in the March 2024 primary. The November general election was photo ID's first major test. A small fraction of people had ballots rejected. But there was a racial disparity. Black voters had 30% of the rejected ballots, despite being about 20% of the electorate. "Black North Carolinians statistically lack the kind of IDs that would be approved," Roblez said. "And they are also statistically more likely to have a hard time getting the other ID." Andy Jackson, with the conservative John Locke Foundation, said it's important to note that the number of rejected ballots for each racial group was small. For Black voters, 502 people had their ballots rejected, compared with 622 white voters. He said there will always be disparities among groups in any requirement. "I don't know if anyone ever expects any statistic to be exactly the same," he said. Some North Carolina Republicans have questioned whether the state's voter ID exception form undermines the purpose of the law. But Jackson said he believes most Republicans want to move on. "I don't know how strict they want to go because I don't know if they have an appetite for another lawsuit," he said. On Monday, GOP lawmakers advanced a new measure that would codify in the state constitution that photo ID is needed for voting by mail as well. Photo ID wouldn't have materially affected the state's presidential race this year, which Donald Trump won by 183,000 votes. But some contests were much closer, like a state Supreme Court race, where Riggs, a Democrat, went into a recount against her Republican opponent up by just 722 votes.
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Left  
The article presents a critical perspective on North Carolina's voter ID law, emphasizing its potential discriminatory impact on Black voters while citing legal challenges and expert opinions that question its necessity. The inclusion of voices from activists and critiques of the Republican-controlled legislature suggests a bias towards highlighting social justice issues associated with voting rights, aligning more closely with a lean left viewpoint.

title: Legislators propose 15% to 25% tax rate for new states adopting internet gambling
body: ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. (AP) ‚Äî Lawmakers from states where gambling is legal are proposing standards for additional states that are considering allowing internet gambling, including a tax rate of 15% to 25%, and a ban on credit card deposits. The National Council of Legislators from Gaming States issued model legislation last week for states that are weighing whether to permit internet gambling. The proposal will be discussed at the group‚Äôs winter meeting in New Orleans next week. It is designed to give them a framework around which to build their own legislation while incorporating things that have been working well in other states. Seven U.S. states currently offer legal online casino games: Connecticut, Delaware, Michigan, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island and West Virginia. Nevada offers internet poker but not online casino games. ‚ÄúMany states have been discussing this, but were having a hard time getting it across the finish line,‚Äù said Shaun Fluharty, a West Virginia Democratic state delegate who serves as president of the national legislators group. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre trying to put together some best practices for them.‚Äù The proposed legislation is modeled closely on laws that have been operating in states including New Jersey, which has been a leader in approving and regulating internet gambling since 2013. David Rebuck, the retired head of New Jersey‚Äôs Division of Gaming Enforcement, advised the lawmakers‚Äô group on the proposed legislation. ‚ÄúNinety-five percent of this mirrors what we‚Äôre already doing in New Jersey, which is good,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a great start that builds on what is already in place and operational elsewhere.‚Äù It calls for strict oversight of internet gambling to protect consumers and weed out unsavory individuals and companies. The proposal also calls for the establishment of a government agency to regulate online wagering if one does not already exist. It would limit deposits to $20,000 in any 24-hour period and prohibit the use of credit cards to fund gambling accounts. A suggested tax rate of 15% to 25% is a starting point for discussions, Fluharty said. That range is above what some states charge, but far less than others, such as Pennsylvania, which taxes online sports betting at 36% and online slot machine games at 54%. Fluharty said the national average for online gambling tax rates is 19%. West Virginia taxes them at 15%. ‚ÄúThe thinking was we didn‚Äôt want to form a barrier to entry into the market with a high tax rate that only the biggest companies could afford,‚Äù he said. Fluharty said Maryland has been trying to enact internet gambling, which made it through the House but not the Senate in April. He also said other states including Ohio and Louisiana have been considering their own online gambling measures. New York lawmakers have been trying to enact online casino gambling with a 31.5% tax rate without success but did allow online sports betting. Rebuck predicted that more states will give internet gambling a serious look in the new year as budget pressures mount. ‚ÄúA number of states are being cautious about their budgets, and if they‚Äôre looking at this as a potential revenue driver, it‚Äôs pretty significant,‚Äù he said. New Jersey‚Äôs 13% tax on online sports betting and 15% tax on online casino games brought in over $414 million in tax revenue last year. It has nearly matched that figure through just the first 10 months of this year. The group‚Äôs proposal does not attempt to set national standards. Gambling is largely regulated by states, and sporadic attempts to enact nationwide laws on it have gone nowhere in recent years. President-elect Donald Trump has repeatedly said he favors letting states decide important questions. During his first term as president, Trump did not act to impose nationwide regulations on the gambling industry of which he once was a member, with three casinos in Atlantic City. Follow Wayne Parry on X at www.twitter.com/WayneParryAC
Ai bias and explanation:
Center  
The article presents a neutral report on lawmakers proposing a tax framework for internet gambling. It includes various perspectives without showing bias towards a political ideology or direction. The article focuses on factual information about legislation and statistics related to state governance around internet gambling, allowing readers to draw their own conclusions without favoring one political standpoint over another. This balanced reporting aligns with a center classification.

title: House GOP twice blocks release of potentially damning Gaetz ethics report
body: House Republicans twice blocked the release of a potentially damning report from the House Committee on Ethics about former Rep. Matt Gaetz on Thursday, burying sexual misconduct and drug abuse allegations that had in part derailed his push to be confirmed as President-elect Donald Trump‚Äôs attorney general. In rapid fire deliberations, the House in near party-line votes of 206-198 and 204-198 moved the matter back to the purview of the Ethics panel. Rep. Tom McClintock of California was the lone Republican to cross the aisle and double down in voting with Democrats to open the scandal to the public. Reps. Sean Casten (D-Ill.) and Steve Cohen (D-Tenn.) introduced the dueling measures Tuesday as privileged resolutions, which require a vote within two legislative days. Casten‚Äôs demanded the release of the report, while Cohen‚Äôs required both the release and preservation of documents. ‚ÄúResigning from Congress should not allow Members to avoid accountability for allegations as serious as those faced by Matt Gaetz. The Ethics Committee has often released reports on former Members,‚Äù Casten argued in defense of his resolution. 3 Matt Gaetz resigned form Congress and has denied wrongdoing. Los Angeles Times via Getty Images Explore More UnitedHealthcare CEO was facing DOJ probe for insider trading when he was killed in targeted NYC shooting UnitedHealthcare CEO Brian Thompson's suspected shooter used fake NJ ID to check into hostel: sources Message on bullets fired by health care CEO's assassin bears eerie link to book condemning insurance companies Interest in the House Committee on Ethics‚Äô long-rumored investigation into sex trafficking accusations against the Sunshine State firebrand reached a fever pitch last month after Trump, 78, tapped him to serve as his next US attorney general. Ultimately, Gaetz dropped out of the running not long after it became clear he faced an uphill Senate confirmation process. Trump then announced former Florida Attorney General Pam Bondi (R) as his pick for the role. Prior to Congress‚Äô break for Thanksgiving, the Ethics Committee met for a vote but opted against releasing the report despite the complaints of Democratic members of the bipartisan panel. While the panel did not confirm what they were voting on, its Chairman Michael Guest (R-Miss.) and ranking member Susan Wild (D-Pa.) dropped strong hints they were mulling the potential release of the report. The House Committee on Ethics met again prior to the vote on Casten‚Äôs resolution Thursday but did not release the report or disclose specific details of the meeting. 3 Sean Casten had introduced the resolution prior to Thanksgiving but opted to reintroduce it Tuesday to force the vote. Bloomberg via Getty Images House Speaker Mike Johnson (R-La.) had publicly opposed the release of the report and after Gaetz dropped out of consideration for the AG post, momentum to do so seemingly lost steam. Witnesses had allegedly come forward to the committee with accusations that Gaetz paid for sex with two women and had sex with a then-17-year-old over seven years ago, according to multiple attorneys. Gaetz has strenuously denied wrongdoing. He had roiled many of his Republican and Democratic colleagues in Congress alike last year by spearheading the effort to oust former House Speaker Kevin McCarthy (R-Calif.) Accusers had alleged that Gaetz sent Venmo payments in exchange for sex. The intercourse with the then-minor allegedly took place at a party in July 2017. One of the accusers claimed to have witnessed Gaetz in flagrante delicto with the minor, according to Orlando-based attorney Joel Leppard, who represents the two accusers who weren‚Äôt minors at the time. Leppard indicated that the witness said ‚Äúher understanding was that Matt Gaetz did not know that [the 17-year-old] was a minor, and that when he learned that she was a minor, that he broke off things and did not continue a sexual relationship until she turned 18,‚Äù ABC News reported. The Justice Department had investigated the claims against Gaetz but ultimately declined to press charges against him. 3 Steve Cohen argued there needs to be more transparency on former Rep. Matt Gaetz. AP 46What do you think? Post a comment. Typically, the ethics panel does not release reports on former members, but Cohen and Casten both cited exceptions in their resolutions and were adamant that the situation warranted it. Gaetz had said that he doesn‚Äôt plan on returning to the lower chamber when the 119th Congress begins in January ‚Äî despite winning his reelection last month.
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Left  
This article presents a critical view of House Republicans concerning their handling of allegations against Matt Gaetz, focusing on transparency and accountability. It emphasizes the partisan divide in the voting process, frames Gaetz's actions negatively, and highlights the Democrats‚Äô push for releasing the ethics report, which suggests a lean towards left-leaning perspectives on accountability in governance and ethics. The language used appears to align more with a progressive viewpoint.

title: Bill Clinton Says He Wishes Joe Biden Didn't Do This Thing Before Pardoning His Son
body: Bill Clinton said Wednesday that you ‚Äúcan‚Äôt take the politics out of‚Äù presidential pardoning decisions as he weighed in on Joe Biden‚Äôs recent pardon of his son Hunter Biden. ‚ÄúI wish he hadn‚Äôt said he wasn‚Äôt going to do it. I think it does weaken his case,‚Äù Clinton said of Joe Biden, who had vowed he wouldn‚Äôt pardon his son, who was found guilty in June of illegally owning a gun in 2018 and pleaded guilty in a tax case in September. Clinton, in remarks to Andrew Ross Sorkin at The New York Times‚Äô DealBook Summit, said the president had ‚Äúreason to believe‚Äù his son would likely face ‚Äúfar stronger, adverse consequences‚Äù than the average person. On Sunday, Joe Biden said in a statement that his son was ‚Äúunfairly‚Äù and selectively prosecuted, adding that he was ‚Äúsingled out‚Äù due to his ties to his father. The move by the president has led to bipartisan condemnation in the days since. Clinton dismissed comparisons of Biden‚Äôs pardon to his own 2001 pardon of his half-brother Roger Clinton Jr., who was convicted of cocaine possession and drug trafficking in 1985. ‚ÄúThe real question was, would he ever be able to vote again? Would he ever be able to have normal citizenship responsibilities?‚Äù said the former president, who noted that his half-brother had already served a 14-month sentence in federal prison at the time. He continued, ‚ÄúAnd I‚Äôve been sort of upset that there‚Äôs been almost no discussion about the larger problem, which is, does the pardon system we have work?‚Äù Bill Clinton, who urged Americans to see Biden‚Äôs move in a ‚Äúlarger context,‚Äù then turned to House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries‚Äô (D-N.Y.) call for the president to also pardon those ‚Äúin the federal prison system whose lives have been ruined by unjustly aggressive prosecutions for nonviolent offenses.‚Äù He said that Biden is ‚Äúalmost certainly right‚Äù that his son received ‚Äúcompletely different treatments‚Äù than he would have otherwise. But the issue over the pardon, he said, isn‚Äôt ‚Äúway high‚Äù on his ‚Äúhierarchy of things‚Äù he‚Äôs supposed to be upset about. Sorkin later asked Clinton if Biden should pardon President-elect Donald Trump in what could be seen as a ‚Äúbalanced‚Äù move prior to the change in administrations. ‚ÄúWell, I do think we should stop trying to criminalize politics,‚Äù Clinton said. He later continued, ‚ÄúBoth of them. ... And the people like it when they are not going along with it from right to left. On the other hand, you have to ask yourself, if you do this as a blanket thing, is there anything a president could do that he or she someday would get in trouble for?‚Äù
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Left  
This article primarily focuses on comments made by Bill Clinton regarding Joe Biden's handling of his son's pardon. While it provides a critical view toward Biden's decision, it also highlights aspects of fairness in the judicial process, suggesting a concern for justice that aligns with progressive values. The presence of Democratic figures and the overall tone indicate a preference for policies that may resonate more with a left-leaning audience. Additionally, addressing systemic issues rather than solely critiquing Biden further leans the article left.

title: Biden Faces Mounting Criticism from Dem Senators over Pardoning Hunter
body: The trickle of intraparty criticism over President Joe Biden‚Äôs decision to pardon his son Hunter increased throughout the day on Monday, as a growing chorus of congressional Democrats returned to Washington and laid into the president for going back on his word after spending more than a year insisting that the pardon was not on the table. ‚ÄúHe said he wouldn‚Äôt do it. He shouldn‚Äôt have broken his promise,‚Äù Senator Tim Kaine (D., Va) told National Review Monday evening a few hours after he issued a statement criticizing Biden‚Äôs decision. Most Democrats who are frustrated by the president‚Äôs pardon ‚Äî which came days before his son‚Äôs sentencing for a federal gun conviction and a tax-evasion guilty plea ‚Äî acknowledged the difficulty and pain that came with Hunter‚Äôs addiction to crack cocaine. ‚ÄúAnybody who‚Äôs got kids knows what a tragedy it is to have a child that‚Äôs addicted for year after year on drugs,‚Äù Senator John Hickenlooper (D., Colo.) told NR Monday evening. ‚ÄúThey literally lose their ability to make responsible decisions, and I recognize that President Biden felt that his son was prosecuted unfairly, way beyond what would have normally been justified.‚Äù ‚ÄúBut,‚Äù Hickenlooper added, ‚Äúwe are a country of law, and he was tried by his peers.‚Äù There‚Äôs no shortage of congressional Democrats who have continued to stay mum on the matter since Biden‚Äôs announcement Sunday evening, and a number of Senate Democrats on Capitol Hill Monday evening staunchly defended the president‚Äôs decision. And yet with Biden‚Äôs presidency coming to an end, a significant number of congressional Democrats clearly feel that they have little political capital to lose when criticizing the lame-duck octogenarian during his final days atop the party hierarchy. The outgoing president‚Äôs sweeping pardon immunizes the younger Biden for any offenses he ‚Äúmay have committed or taken part in‚Äù over an eleven-year period. And it comes less than two months before his predecessor, Donald Trump, returns to the White House with plans to potentially pardon those imprisoned for participating in the January 6th Capitol riot. The pardon‚Äôs time period of January 1, 2014, to December 1, 2024, includes the entirety of Hunter Biden‚Äôs foreign business dealings as well as the tax and gun charges that special counsel David Weiss prosecuted him for. The scope of the pardon has some Democrats worried about the precedent that will be set for future commanders in chief ‚Äî namely the president-elect. Elaborating on his Monday-morning statement that Biden‚Äôs pardon puts ‚Äúpersonal interest ahead of duty‚Äù and undermines Americans‚Äô faith in the justice system, Senator Michael Bennet (D., Colo.) said that Biden‚Äôs decision sets a ‚Äúlousy precedent‚Äù for future presidents, especially as Trump is ‚Äúon his way to town.‚Äù Some Senate Democrats defended Joe Biden‚Äôs move to pardon his son, with Senator Ron Wyden (D., Ore.) accusing Trump of politicizing the FBI. ‚ÄúGiven the extent to which Donald Trump is politicizing the FBI, I think it‚Äôs understandable,‚Äù Wyden told reporters. Trump announced Saturday that he has chosen MAGA hardliner Kash Patel to run the FBI and clean house at the bureau. ‚ÄúThis decision must have been a deeply personal one,‚Äù Senator Richard Blumenthal told National Review, calling the move ‚Äúan exercise of discretion that is accorded to the president under the Constitution.‚Äù He added that it‚Äôs ‚Äúhis alone to make to his son.‚Äù Senator Raphael Warnock (D., Ga.) told NR that ‚Äúit‚Äôs within the realm of the president‚Äôs authority, and that‚Äôs been the case for a very long time.‚Äù Right after the pardon, numerous Republican lawmakers were quick to lambast Joe Biden for reversing his promise and said it was part of a larger pattern of behavior from the Biden family. According to NBC News, it was Joe Biden‚Äôs plan to publicly state he would not pardon his son, while keeping the option on the table privately. White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre insisted Monday that Joe Biden ‚Äúcame to the decision this weekend.‚Äù She subsequently took to X to deny NBC‚Äôs reporting and reiterate her statements. Send a tip to the news team at NR.
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Left  
The article focuses on criticism from Democratic senators regarding President Biden's decision to pardon his son, indicating a potential divide within the party. While it highlights dissent among Democrats, it also includes their empathetic comments about Hunter‚Äôs struggles, which reflects a sympathetic portrayal of the Biden family. The mentions of Republican reactions serve to contextualize the criticism but do not dominate the narrative. Overall, the emphasis on intra-party criticism and the mix of perspectives suggest a "lean left" bias rather than outright left or center.

title: Ex-officials call for closed-door Senate hearings on Tulsi Gabbard, Trump‚Äôs pick for intel chief
body: WASHINGTON ‚Äî Nearly 100 former senior U.S. diplomats and intelligence and national security officials have urged Senate leaders to schedule closed-door hearings to allow for a full review of the government‚Äôs files on former Rep. Tulsi Gabbard, Donald Trump‚Äôs pick to be national intelligence director. The former officials, who served in both Democratic and Republican administrations, said they were ‚Äúalarmed‚Äù by the choice of Gabbard to oversee all 18 U.S. intelligence agencies. They said her past actions ‚Äúcall into question her ability to deliver unbiased intelligence briefings to the President, Congress, and to the entire national security apparatus.‚Äù A spokesperson for Gabbard on the Trump transition team on Thursday denounced the appeal as an ‚Äúunfounded‚Äù and ‚Äúpartisan‚Äù attack. Avril Haines, the current director of national intelligence, when asked Thursday whether intelligence sharing with allies could be in jeopardy under the next administration, cited the importance of those relationships and noted the strong bipartisan support for them in Congress. The question, at a Council on Foreign Relations talk, focused on the especially close intelligence sharing among the Five Eyes - the U.S., Britain, Canada, Australia and New Zealand. It did not mention Gabbard by name. ‚ÄúIt is hard for me to believe that anybody coming in wouldn‚Äôt want to maintain those relationships,‚Äù Haines said. ‚ÄúSo I wouldn‚Äôt think of them as being in a significant risk,‚Äù she added. ‚ÄúI certainly hope that will continue.‚Äù Among those who signed the letter were former Deputy Secretary of State Wendy Sherman, former NATO Deputy Secretary General Rose Gottemoeller, former national security adviser Anthony Lake, and numerous retired ambassadors and high-ranking military officers. They wrote to current Democratic Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer and incoming Republican Majority Leader John Thune on Wednesday to urge the closed briefings as part of the Senate‚Äôs review of Trump‚Äôs top appointments. They requested that Senate committees ‚Äúconsider in closed sessions all information available to the U.S. government when considering Ms. Gabbard‚Äôs qualifications to manage our country‚Äôs intelligence agencies, and more importantly, the protection of our intelligence sources and methods.‚Äù The letter singles out Gabbard‚Äôs 2017 meetings in Syria with President Bashar Assad, who is supported by Russian, Iranian and Iranian-allied forces in a now 13-year war against Syrian opposition forces seeking his overthrow. The U.S., which cut relations with Assad‚Äôs government and imposed sanctions over his conduct of the war, maintains about 900 troops in opposition-controlled northeast Syria, saying they are needed to block a resurgence of extremist groups. Gabbard, a Democratic member of Congress from Hawaii at the time of her Syria trip, drew heavy criticism for her meetings with a U.S. adversary and brutal leader. As the letter notes, her statements on the wars in the Middle East and Ukraine have aligned with Russian talking points, diverging from U.S. positions and policy. Gabbard throughout her political career has urged the U.S. to limit military engagement abroad other than combatting Islamic extremist groups. She has defended the Syria trip by saying it is necessary to engage with U.S. enemies. In postings on social media earlier this year she confirmed that the U.S. had for a time placed her ‚Äúon a secret terror watch list‚Äù as a ‚Äúpotential domestic terror threat.‚Äù She blamed political retaliation. Neither she nor U.S. authorities have publicly detailed the circumstances involved. Alexa Henning, a spokesperson for Gabbard with the Trump team, called the letter sent to the Senate leaders ‚Äúa perfect example‚Äù of why Trump chose Gabbard for this position. ‚ÄúThese unfounded attacks are from the same geniuses who have blood on their hands from decades of faulty ‚Äòintelligence,‚Äô‚Äù and use classified government information as a ‚Äúpartisan weapon to smear and imply things about their political enemy,‚Äù Henning said. A spokesperson for Thune did not immediately respond to questions about the request. ‚Ä¢ Associated Press writer Didi Tang contributed.
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Right  
The article presents concerns from former officials about Tulsi Gabbard's suitability for a key intelligence position under Donald Trump, highlighting bipartisan criticism. While it notes these officials come from various administrations, the framing of her meetings with Assad and alignment with Russian positions reflects scrutiny often seen in conservative perspectives. Additionally, Gabbard's spokesperson's claims of partisan attacks align with narratives typically supported in right-leaning media, indicating a tendency to protect Trump's choices against criticism.

title: How Tulsi Gabbard Likely Bought Her Way Onto The Best-Seller List
body: A political action committee tied to Tulsi Gabbard, Donald Trump‚Äôs nominee for Director of National Intelligence, spent $33,000 in 2024 on her then newly released book, For Love of Country: Leave the Democrat [Sic] Party Behind. The bulk purchases appear to have helped secure Gabbard a spot on the New York Times best-seller list. Gabbard launched Defend Freedom, Inc., a leadership PAC, in March 2024. The PAC reported no cash on hand until April 15, two weeks before the April 30 release of Gabbard‚Äôs book. Published by conservative imprint Regnery, the book blends memoir and political manifesto (‚ÄúThe Democrat [sic] elite deny the existence of objective truth and the biological differences between men and women,‚Äù she wrote. ‚ÄúIn the ultimate expression of hatred and hostility toward women, and our Creator, they are trying to ‚Äòerase‚Äô our existence altogether.‚Äù). It debuted at No. 4 on the New York Times hardcover nonfiction bestseller list for the week ending May 4 but was flagged for bulk purchases (with a dagger icon), indicating that large orders may have influenced its ranking. For Love of Country remained on the list for one more week. At least some of those bulk purchases came from Gabbard‚Äôs PAC. On July 11, Defend Freedom made the first of four disbursements for ‚Äúprinting‚Äù to BulkBooks, a book wholesaler based in Franklin, Tennessee that specializes in large orders. The PAC would go on to direct $33,000 in donors‚Äô funds to BulkBooks. A spokesperson for Gabbard confirmed that the PAC‚Äôs payments to BulkBooks were purchases of For Love of Country. ‚ÄúFor a limited time, Defend Freedom PAC supporters who gave $100 or more received Tulsi Gabbard's NYT bestselling book For Love of Country,‚Äù said Erika Tsuji. An advertisement on Anedot, an online fundraising platform, shows that the PAC also packaged the book with tickets to a Tulsa, Oklahoma event headlined by ‚Äúbestselling author‚Äù Tulsi Gabbard. As for why the PAC made the purchases from a wholesaler rather than directly from the publisher, which ostensibly would have been a cheaper option, Tsuji said that BulkBooks was able to fulfill and expedite the orders more efficiently. Purchases from BulkBooks were also able to help get Gabbard on that best-seller list: BulkBooks‚Äô website says that its sales get reported to the New York Times. Authors typically receive royalties from books purchased wholesale, according to the Authors Guild, meaning Gabbard may have personally profited from the transactions. When asked via email if she did, her spokesperson didn‚Äôt comment. It wouldn‚Äôt be illegal, according to an attorney specializing in campaign finance. ‚ÄúShe is not a federal candidate or an officeholder, so she is allowed to personally profit when her PAC buys her book with donors‚Äô funds,‚Äù said Brett Kappel. Gabbard‚Äôs spokesperson also pointed out that her boss was not a candidate for elected office. ‚ÄúAll FEC laws were followed in this process,‚Äù said Tsuji. Of course, just because a politician can profit off of donors‚Äô funds, it doesn‚Äôt mean they have to. Former Vice President Mike Pence‚Äôs PAC, Great America Committee, spent $91,000 in 2022 to purchase copies of his memoir, So Help Me God. While Pence too could have legally profited from the deal, he did not do so, a spokesperson told Forbes at the time. For Love of Country sold 46,000 copies as of Nov. 23, according to Circana BookScan, an industry data service. It only tracks retailers though, so purchases from BulkBooks are not included in that figure. Through mid-October, Gabbard‚Äôs Defend Freedom, Inc. raised $1.9 million and spent $1.4 million, according to FEC records. In addition to books, most of its money went to credit card fees incurred when processing donations, direct mail and digital consultants.
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Right  
The article critiques Tulsi Gabbard's actions related to her book sales, pointing out the financial maneuvers of her PAC and the implications of bulk purchases that may mislead the best-seller list rankings. The emphasis on the legality of her actions and the mention of her "conservative imprint" aligns with a right-leaning perspective, particularly in how it frames her connection to Trump and critiques the Democratic Party, suggesting a bias towards a conservative viewpoint while maintaining factual reporting.

title: The History Lesson Democrats Can‚Äôt Afford to Forget
body: Well, that was a thumping, wasn‚Äôt it? Even optimistic MAGA fans didn‚Äôt see Donald Trump winning the popular vote, taking control of the Senate and the House, and sweeping all seven swing states. He came within five points of taking New Jersey! Exit polls showed more than half of Latino men voting for him! The results are devastating for Kamala Harris, Joe Biden, Elizabeth Warren, Chuck Schumer, and the rest of the Democrats: They lost the nation. So what on earth do they do next? One approach would be to repeat what they‚Äôve been doing. Resist! It‚Äôs what they chose the last time Trump won. In the aftermath of Trump‚Äôs 2016 victory, America was stunned. There had never been a president so immune to normal analysis, and, as such, so unpredictable. Each time he opened his mouth, Trump exploded political norms‚Äîand Democrats responded in kind. Being an opposition party was not enough, they believed. Instead, they would fight his very legitimacy. They built this idea of resistance into their very fabric, and it infected every aspect of progressive society‚Äîfrom raging late-night talk show hosts to left-wing prosecutors determined to put Trump in prison.But while the Democrats won in 2020, the resistance ultimately failed. Democrats spent nearly a decade telling Americans that Trump was an existential threat to the republic. And what happened? Americans from all walks of life voted for him in overwhelming numbers. The Democrats wanted to erase Trump from the political scene; instead he now controls it. Perpetual outrage was not the path to power. Let‚Äôs be honest, it was a total disaster: The resistance pulled on pink hats, and hollered about fascism‚Äîand then gasped with shock when the nation chose Trump again. Democrats Have Recovered from Worse DefeatsSo the party is in a pickle. If the Democrats want a shot at winning in 2028, then they need a new direction. Losing parties survive by figuring out why they lost and trying something different next time. In the meantime, they take incremental wins when they can. They act like an opposition, not a resistance. The good news for Democrats is that they‚Äôve been here before. Forty years ago, a few centrist renegades mapped out a course that eventually saved the party from oblivion. If you are devastated over last week‚Äôs electoral blowout, well, Trump‚Äôs victory was a squeaker compared to Ronald Reagan‚Äôs landslide over Walter Mondale in 1984. The Democrats were not just in disarray, they were on life support. It‚Äôs hard to overstate the scope of that Reagan victory. Mondale, who was vice president during Jimmy Carter‚Äôs one-term presidency, lost everywhere except his home state of Minnesota and the District of Columbia. Reagan swept up everything else. A conservative Republican won Massachusetts, New York, and Hawaii, for God‚Äôs sake. And yet only eight years later, the Democrats found their savior, a young governor from Arkansas named Bill Clinton. Democrats Were Backed by Special Interest Groups, Not VotersMondale‚Äôs loyalty to interest groups inside the Democratic party was his Achilles‚Äô heel. Gary Hart, a senator from Colorado and his chief rival in the primary that year, summed up the problem as follows: ‚ÄúYou have to reach [those voters] who don‚Äôt feel represented by the AFL[AFL-CIO], the NAACP, NOW [National Organization for Women], or the Sierra Club.‚ÄùBut Mondale could not see beyond the demands of the noisiest factions in his coalition. His campaign attacked one of Reagan‚Äôs most innovative initiatives‚Äîresearch into space-based missile defense‚Äîclaiming ‚Äúkiller weapons‚Äù would send the arms race with the Soviets spinning out of control.And Reagan countered with one of the most effective ads in American political history. Some people say the bear is tame. Others say it‚Äôs vicious and dangerous. Since no one can really be sure who‚Äôs right, isn‚Äôt it smart to be as strong as the bear?Al From, one of the men who would eventually remake the Democratic Party, watched all this with dismay. In one sense, Mondale was an effective candidate. He unified all the special interest groups in the party. Except for one thing. This post is for paying subscribers only Subscribe now Already have an account? Sign in
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Right  
The article presents a critical analysis of the Democratic Party's strategies in contrast to Trump‚Äôs electoral success. It implies that the Democrats' resistance to Trump has been ineffective, suggesting a need for significant reevaluation and change in their approach. This tone, focusing on Republican victories and implying a failures of the left, reflects a bias that leans right, favoring a more conservative perspective on political dynamics and party strategies.

title: Putin‚Äôs nuclear-capable ballistic missile launch was long-planned, not response to US allowing Ukraine deeper strikes into Russia: Kremlin officer
body: WASHINGTON ‚Äî President Vladimir Putin‚Äôs launch of a nuclear-capable ballistic missile into Ukraine two weeks ago was not in response to the recent US decision to allow Kyiv to strike deeper into Russia, a top Kremlin military officer told the chief of the Joint Staff in a secret call last week. Chief of the Russian Armed Forces‚Äô General Staff Gen. Valery V. Gerasimov held a classified call with Chief of the Joint Staff Air Force Gen. CQ Brown last week, just six days after Moscow launched a new missile dubbed Oreshnik ‚Äî Russian for hazelnut tree ‚Äî to strike a facility in Dnipro, Ukraine, the Pentagon confirmed to The Post on Thursday. 3 Russian President Vladimir Putin and Russian Chief of General Staff Valery Gerasimov walk to meet top military brass at the headquarters of Russia‚Äôs Southern Military District in Rostov-on-Don, Russia, on Aug. 19, 2023. AP While Putin claimed the blast came as a reaction to the US policy shift last month to allow Ukraine to launch longer-range ATACMS missiles into Russia, unnamed officials told the New York Times that Gerasimov in the conversation said that the missile launch had been planned long before the US agreed to let Ukraine strike deeper into Russia. The call happened Nov. 27 ‚Äúfollowing a request by the Russian Ministry of Defense,‚Äù Joint Staff spokesperson Navy Capt. Jereal Dorsey said in a statement. 1/1 Skip Ad Continue watchingafter the adVisit Advertiser websiteGO TO PAGE‚ÄúThis was the first time the leaders spoke since Gen. Brown became Chairman,‚Äù Dorsey said. ‚ÄúThe leaders discussed a number of global and regional security issues to include the ongoing conflict in Ukraine.‚Äù 3 The missile was dubbed Oreshnik, which is Russian for hazelnut tree. COME BACK ALIVE/AFP via Getty Images Explore More UnitedHealthcare CEO was facing DOJ probe for insider trading when he was killed in targeted NYC shooting Message on bullets fired by health care CEO's assassin bears eerie link to book condemning insurance companies UnitedHealthcare CEO Brian Thompson's suspected shooter used fake NJ ID to check into hostel: sources While it‚Äôs not unusual for Russia and the US to hold deconfliction talks, such conversations are typically announced shortly after they occur. They also commonly occur before major ballistic missile launches to avoid miscalculations that could lead to nuclear war. ‚ÄúAt the request of Gen. Gerasimov, Gen. Brown agreed to not proactively announce the call,‚Äù Dorsey said. 3 A screengrab taken from handout footage released by the Russian Defense Ministry on March 1, 2024, purporting to show the test firing of an ICBM belonging to the Moscow‚Äôs nuclear deterrence forces. Russian Defence Ministry/AFP via Getty Images The Pentagon did not disclose why Gerasimov did not want Brown to announce their conversation earlier. Though the Oreshnik was carrying conventional weapons, it has the capacity to hold nuclear warheads and concerned NATO members, including the US, when it was launched. ‚ÄúThis was new type of lethal capability that was deployed on the battlefield, so that was certainly of concern,‚Äù Pentagon deputy spokeswoman Sabrina Singh said at the time.
Ai bias and explanation:
Center  
The article presents a factual account of military communications and events without emotional language or clear bias towards either side of the conflict. It reports on statements made by officials from both Russia and the United States, maintaining a neutral tone. There are no expressions of strong political opinions or angles that would indicate a significant lean towards left or right ideologies, thus placing it in the center.

title: Acting Secret Service director says changes have been made since Trump assassination attempt
