body: The acting director of the Secret Service Director told a House panel investigating the assassination attempt against President-elect Donald Trump said the agency has already made changes to ensure the assassination attempt doesn't happen again amid a heightened threat environment. "We are operating in a heightened threat environment with expanding protection requirements, and this requires a shift in the Secret Service's levels of protection, readiness and sustainability," acting Director Ronald Rowe told Congress. "A paradigm shift focuses on elevating protection, prioritizing training, strengthening our workforce and increasing accountability." Rowe said he is creating the Office of Field Operations "to reset our thinking, thinking and perspective about the role field offices play in protection and to enhance our operational effectiveness by better leveraging field offices to support, enable and inform protection and protective activities." "The world is a dangerous place. Responsibilities of the Secret Service are critical to the national security of the United States, it is important that decision makers fully recognize and appreciate the vital role and significance of the Secret Service in our nation's security,‚Äù he said. The hearing was disrupted when Rowe got into a screaming match with Republican Rep. Pat Fallon of Texas over Rowe's attendance at the 9/11 memorial. Fallon accused Rowe of putting the president's Secret Service detail out of position so he could sit behind him during the ceremony. Before the exchange, Rowe said that the agency will use GPS blue force trackers -- a military asset that uses GPS to show where friendly and hostile assets are. He also asked Congress for more money to make sure the agency will have the preventive resources it needs and that it has already put the supplemental money to good use. "We've also started moving money out to acquire more materials that we needed as we started to put more assets out on the road, classified assets, ballistic assets, now the wear and tear on that is going to increase," Rowe said. "So now we have to make sure that we can acquire more and put more money down on contracts so that, as we are going to now go through the service life of these materials, we have to be able to replenish them and replenish them quickly. So some of these are long, lean items, so that money has been very, very helpful to us in making sure that we can address our immediate needs." He said the agency has about 500 agents in "various statutes of training between now and March." The agency "is on pace" to hire 650 special agents and 350 uniformed division agents. Rowe said he is standing up an "auditing capacity" to regularly send feedback to agents to ensure they are doing the best job possible. "We're not here to take punitive action against people, just to, you know, just to get you for something," he said. "No, we want to make the mission better." Rowe also said that he stood up a drone unit that is actively hiring, and that if there had been a counter-drone mechanism on the ground in Butler, the attempt might have been stopped. "My goal is to get more drone operators and people with this expertise downrange in the field, so that they can go out and do this and are there on the ground, and that's going to help us fly drones and identify line of sight vulnerabilities, get that ‚Äòeye in the sky‚Äô perspective as we're doing our advance," he said. He also said he made changes like getting state and local partners on the same radio frequencies.
Ai bias and explanation:
Center  
The article provides a factual report on the statements made by the acting Secret Service director regarding changes implemented after an assassination attempt on Trump. It presents information without evident bias towards any political ideology. The tone is neutral, focusing on security measures and organizational changes rather than expressing any opinion or critique related to the political context. The use of direct quotes adds to the objective nature of the reporting.

title: Dr. Fauci, Schiff, Cheney: Biden weighs preemptive pardons ahead of Trump term
body: THE BIDEN WHITE HOUSE IS DEBATING WHETHER TO ISSUE **PREEMPTIVE PARDONS FOR SEVERAL PUBLIC OFFICIALS. THE PARDONS WOULD BE FOR PEOPLE BIDEN‚ÄôS SENIOR AIDES BELIEVE COULD BE TARGETED BY PRESIDENT-ELECT TRUMP. SOURCES CLOSE TO THE DISCUSSIONS TOLD POLITICO THE PARDONS COULD GO TO HIGH-PROFILE PEOPLE WHO HAVE BEEN OUTSPOKEN AGAINST TRUMP ‚Äì LIKE SENATOR-ELECT ADAM SCHIFF OF CALIFORNIA, REPUBLICAN FORMER CONGRESSWOMAN LIZ CHENEY WHO JOINED KAMALA HARRIS ON THE CAMPAIGN TRAIL, AND DOCTOR ANTHONY FAUCI ‚Äì A KEY FIGURE IN HOW THE U.S. SHAPED ITS HEALTH POLICY DURING THE PANDEMIC. THE WHITE HOUSE IS WEIGHING THE LEGAL AND POLITICAL RISKS OF OFFERING PREEMPTIVE PARDONS TO PEOPLE WHO AREN‚ÄôT CHARGED WITH ANY CRIMES TODAY ‚Äì BUT WOULD BE PROTECTED FROM FUTURE PROSECUTION ‚Äì IN CASE CHARGES WERE TO LATER BE BROUGHT. SOME OF THOSE WHO ARE REPORTEDLY BEING CONSIDERED FOR PARDONS ‚Äì HAVE ALREADY QUESTIONED THE IDEA OF ACCEPTING ONE. SCHIFF SAYS HE WOULD ‚ÄúURGE THE PRESIDENT NOT TO DO THAT‚Äù BECAUSE HE SAYS ‚ÄúIT WOULD SEEM DEFENSIVE AND UNNECESSARY.‚Äù TRUMP POSTED ON TRUTH SOCIAL IN JUNE THAT THE JANUARY SIXTH SELECT COMMITTEE SHOULD BE INDICTED ‚Äì ASSERTING THEY DELETED AND DESTROYED EVIDENCE. BUT HAS ALSO SAID HE WILL NOT GO AFTER POLITICAL OPPONENTS ‚Äì INSTEAD SAYING QUOTE ‚ÄúHIS REVENGE WILL BE HIS SUCCESS.‚Äù THE TALKS OF POTENTIAL PARDONS COME AFTER BIDEN PARDONED HIS SON HUNTER ‚Äì AND THE REACTION TO THE PARDON ‚Äì HAS BEEN MIXED. SOME DEMOCRATS THEN CALLED ON BIDEN TO ISSUE MORE PARDONS AS A MEANS TO MAKE THINGS RIGHT. HOUSE MINORITY LEADER HAKEEM JEFFRIES SAYING IN A STATEMENT ‚Äì ‚ÄúDuring his final weeks in office, President Biden should exercise the high level of compassion he has consistently demonstrated throughout his life, including toward his son, and pardon on a case-by-case basis the working-class Americans in the federal prison system whose lives have been ruined by unjustly aggressive prosecutions for nonviolent offenses.‚Äù THANKS FOR WATCHING OUR NEWS UPDATE. FOR MORE STORIES THAT MATTER TO YOU ‚Äì DOWNLOAD THE STRAIGHT ARROW NEWS MOBILE APP TODAY.
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Left  
The article primarily discusses potential preemptive pardons by President Biden, which aligns with the Democratic Party's more lenient approach on issues of justice and incarceration. It quotes prominent Democratic figures expressing a need for compassion and reinforcing the idea of pardons related to social justice, which suggests a favorable view toward the Biden administration's actions. While there is mention of Trump and his comments, the overall tone and focus on Democratic perspectives indicate a lean towards left.

title: 'I've seen tougher guys at Starbucks': MAGA country star turns on Republican senator
body: One-half of the country duo Big & Rich laid into Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-SC) on Wednesday evening over the senator's comments about Pete Hegseth, President-elect Donald Trump's embattled pick for Pentagon chief. John Rich, a vocal supporter of Trump ‚Äî and vehement opponent of Joe Biden who once mocked the president as "Sniffy" over his sniffles ‚Äî took to the social media site X to voice his displeasure with Republicans waffling on Hegseth's nomination. "The pro-war RINO's are all against @PeteHegseth and that tells you all you need to know," wrote Rich. "Pete is a threat to the war machine. Recess appointments?" He added in a separate post, "Don't Kavanaugh our Hegseth," referring to the tough confirmation hearing of Supreme Court Justice Brett Kavanaugh, whose nomination was dogged by a sexual assault allegation and protests. Rich then set his sights on Graham, who has called the allegations against Hegseth "disturbing." "I think some of these articles are very disturbing. He obviously has a chance to defend himself here, but some of this stuff is it's going to be difficult..." Graham told CBS News. Rich unleashed a series of posts on X targeting Graham, including at least two that used a homophobic reference. "Who do you trust more? (repost for maximum results and hilarious responses:)" Rich asked his followers, providing just two responses: Santa Claus and Lindsey Graham. "I sat across from Lindsey Graham at dinner with DJT a while back. As I was answering a direct question from POTUS, Lindsey twirled his Chardonnay (pinkies up) and told Trump I was a raging conspiracy theorist. I gave him a look that would hairlip the devil, then dismantled him," Rich later posted. He added: "I've seen tougher guys at Starbucks." Rich didn't stop there. He shared Graham's office number to his followers and urged them to let him know their feelings about confirming Hegseth. "This better have 5k reposts before I go to bed," he challenged his followers. Within an hour, the post had thousands of reposts. "Welp, that didn't take long," he followed up.
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Right  
This article reflects a lean right bias due to its focus on a right-leaning celebrity attacking a Republican senator for perceived lack of loyalty to Trump's agenda. The strong language used by John Rich against Sen. Graham highlights a faction within the Republican Party that is becoming increasingly critical of moderate Republicans. This framing aligns more with right-wing sentiment, showcasing division over support for Trump rather than presenting a balanced overview of political discourse.

title: Ron DeSantis, Joni Ernst potential Trump defense secretary nominees if Hegseth drops out: Sources
body: A growing number of senators have privately signaled that they are not inclined to vote to confirm Pete Hegseth as President-elect Donald Trump's next defense secretary, leading Trump's advisers to begin discussing who may be a viable replacement, sources familiar with the matter told ABC News. Sources tell ABC News that at least six senators have privately indicated that they don't intend to vote for Hegseth amid the growing allegations about his mistreatment of women. While Trump and his advisers have privately said the president-elect backs Hegseth and wants him to "keep fighting," sources familiar with private discussions tell ABC News that a growing list of replacements is emerging to replace him. Those include Iowa Sen. Joni Ernst, Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis, Tennessee Sen. Bill Hagerty and Florida Rep. Mike Waltz, whom Trump has already tapped to be national security adviser. Sources close to DeSantis say he has expressed interest in the role. He was seen today with Trump attending a memorial service for three Palm Beach County sheriff's deputies in West Palm Beach, who were killed in a crash last month. Reached by ABC News, a spokesperson for the Trump transition team declined to comment. Hegseth was back on Capitol Hill Tuesday looking to shore up support as he fends off the allegations of misconduct and sexual impropriety. The visit came after a report in The New Yorker that Hegseth was forced to step down from two veteran nonprofit groups -- Veterans for Freedom and Concerned Veterans for America -- amid accusations of financial mismanagement, sexist behavior and other disqualifying behavior.
Ai bias and explanation:
Center  
The article presents factual information regarding potential nominees for a cabinet position under President-elect Donald Trump, including the context of opposition to Pete Hegseth. It mentions sources and reactions from various political figures without expressing any overt bias or opinion. The language is neutral, focusing solely on reporting the developments without indicating a political lean toward either the left or the right.

title: Vivek Ramaswamy Plots His Next Move, With or Without Trump
body: Vivek Ramaswamy wants to be clear, or clear-ish: He says he doesn‚Äôt really know if anyone‚Äôs eating cats and dogs over in Springfield, Ohio, 45 minutes from his home in Columbus. But the hyperkinetic-MAGA loyalist is going to head to the town that became a political flash point after the outlandish Internet theory about Haitian migrants there went viral. Never mind that the bizarre claim ‚Äî amplified by Donald Trump during the presidential debate ‚Äî is false. As a divided America slouches toward Election Day, Ramaswamy is the same man the nation remembers: the preeningly ambitious, do-and-say-what-it-takes overachiever hungering for his shot at history. On this mid-September afternoon, he‚Äôs gulping down a bottle of Mountain Valley Spring Water ‚Äî the same brand, not incidentally, that‚Äôs been served at the White House ‚Äî after a round of tennis and a workout with battle ropes, and barefooting around his mansion. Propped on the mantle in the basement, beneath an American flag, is an image of Trump after his attempted assassination in July. Indian hand drums are nestled on the floor nearby. If he looks and sounds like a guy in a hurry, well, that‚Äôs because he is. Ramaswamy pads down to his basement studio for an interview about his latest book. Then up to his office for a conference call with John Bolton, Trump‚Äôs former national security adviser. Then back down to the basement for another interview. He talks so fast that Ramaswamy said Trump once joked he made his head hurt. Before long, he‚Äôs heading downtown to give a talk to the Ohio Chamber of Commerce. At age 39, and with a national profile few might have foreseen, Ramaswamy is on the cusp of ‚Äî something. It was only nine months ago that he ended his long-shot campaign for the Republican nomination, where he prayed with Evangelicals and rapped to Eminem. Now, if Trump wins on Nov. 5, Ramaswamy might very well follow the former president back to Washington. There‚Äôs talk of a cabinet position, perhaps the Department of Homeland Security. Trump has vowed to deport millions of people living in the US illegally and has said that one the places he‚Äôd start would be Springfield. Ramaswamy declines to discuss his potential role in a Trump administration. And if Kamala Harris wins? Ramaswamy says he would accept the result of ‚Äúa free and fair election,‚Äù even as Trump keeps claiming, with zero evidence, that the last election was ‚Äúrigged‚Äù and this one might be too. ‚ÄúWhoever wins the election, wins the election,‚Äù Ramaswamy says. ‚ÄúI would commit to leading the Republican party to move past allegations of stolen elections.‚Äù But Ramaswamy is Ramaswamy: He‚Äôs also strongly considering running for governor right here in Ohio. As his SUV heads toward the colonnaded statehouse, the former biotech entrepreneur says he‚Äôd transform his home state, synonymous with Rust Belt despair, into the next low-tax Florida or Texas. ‚ÄúIf other states have pulled it off and managed to get a boom of economic growth as a consequence, Ohio can too,‚Äù he says. Read more: The Anti-ESG Crusader Who Wants to Pick a Fight With BlackRock Another option, Ramaswamy says, would be to fill the Senate seat currently occupied by JD Vance, his former classmate at Yale Law, who Trump chose as his running mate rather than Ramaswamy. Whether it‚Äôs Plan A, B or C, Ramaswamy seems poised to reap dividends for pledging allegiance to Trump. Since bowing out of the presidential race, he‚Äôs bought a stake in media company Buzzfeed Inc. and cemented valuable connections in the MAGA-verse. The Trump campaign dispatched him to the ‚Äúspin room‚Äù in Philadelphia to talk up Trump‚Äôs performance following the September debate with Vice President Harris. He‚Äôs also been stumping for Trump in swing states, helped to galvanize him on crypto currencies and visited Trump‚Äôs Mar-a-Lago estate in Florida, where he said he helped the former president and his team craft a statement on abortion earlier this year. Today, Ramaswamy says he counts among his friends Elon Musk, Trump‚Äôs richest fan, whom he met last year at the home of venture capitalist Chamath Palihapitiya. Backers of Ramaswamy‚Äôs young investment firm, Strive Asset Management, include Peter Thiel, the tech billionaire who was an early patron of Vance, and Howard Lutnick, the Wall Street financier who happens to be helping to vet potential cabinet members for Trump. No one goes into politics without some measure of self-regard. But to say Ramaswamy projects assurance would be to understate the matter. He‚Äôs ticked the boxes: Harvard, Yale Law, business success and wealth. His first book, ‚ÄúWoke, Inc.‚Äù brought him to national attention. So did his role as an early instigator of conservative attacks against environmental, social and governance investing on Wall Street, as well as against diversity, equity and inclusion. Ramaswamy now argues that corporate diversity efforts have only fueled racial animus. Black Americans who get jobs on merit are often viewed as diversity hires, he says. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs an injustice of a different kind,‚Äù he says. Looking back, Ramaswamy says he was ‚Äúchastened‚Äù that the announcement of his presidential run fell flat. But, like Trump, he‚Äôs developed a reputation as a political counterpuncher. Nicknamed ‚ÄúV-Dog‚Äù in high school because of his bulldog tenacity, he hits back hard when challenged ‚Äî and keeps on coming. He says personal attacks against him during his run triggered his ‚Äúgladiatorial instincts.‚Äù Now, just maybe, Ramaswamy has a second shot at power in Washington. None of this seems to surprise him. This, he says, was the plan all along. ‚ÄúIt feels natural for me,‚Äù Ramaswamy says. ‚ÄúI feel like I am pursuing my calling.‚Äù Ramaswamy says his ambition and drive probably reflect insecurities that can come with being part of an immigrant family. He peers out the window of his SUV at the quiet streets of downtown Columbus and goes on: ‚ÄúThey probably have roots in some sort of deep-seated experiences of inadequacy that make you want to make sure that you‚Äôre able to fight your way.‚Äù Ramaswamy brushes off the suggestion that he and Harris, whose late mother is from India and father is from Jamaica, might share something in common in that regard. Among other things, they speak the Indian language Tamil. Ramaswamy‚Äôs brusque retort: ‚ÄúBut I‚Äôm very open about my heritage.‚Äù The comment echoes Trump, who‚Äôs falsely suggested that Harris ‚Äúhappened to turn Black.‚Äù When Ramaswamy got to Springfield last week, he spoke at a town hall-style event. The place was packed. He said he doesn‚Äôt blame migrants nor locals for the uproar (most Haitians in Springfield are in the US legally). Instead, he blamed the Biden administration‚Äôs immigration policies. Ramaswamy said in an interview afterward that he didn‚Äôt go there to talk about cats and dogs. This much is sure: Vivek Ramaswamy has a plan ‚Äî several, in fact. Whichever one plays out, he says he wants to bring about ‚Äúlasting change‚Äù in the US. And by ‚Äúlasting,‚Äù the hyper-ambitious Ramaswamy doesn‚Äôt mean for the next four years. He means ‚Äúover decades or centuries.‚Äù Nov. 5 will determine his next move.
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Left  
The article contains a critical tone toward Vivek Ramaswamy and his political affiliations, particularly his ties to Trump and MAGA rhetoric. It highlights his ambitious nature but frames it with skepticism about his motives and the reliability of his political claims. The mention of falsehoods associated with Trump and critical perspectives on Ramaswamy's views suggests a left-leaning bias, as it promotes an implicit narrative that is less favorable toward right-wing politics and figures compared to left-leaning perspectives.

title: Alarm raised over Trump plot to install nominees without Senate approval
body: Republican U.S. Senator John Thune (R-SD), who was elected to become the next Senate Majority Leader, gestures as he speaks to the media after a U.S. Senate Republicans meeting to vote on leadership positions for the 119th Congress, on Capitol Hill in Washington, U.S., November 13, 2024. REUTERS/Leah Millis Dozens of civil rights and pro-democracy organizations teamed up Wednesday to express opposition to President-elect Donald Trump's push to use recess appointments to evade the Senate confirmation process for his political nominees, many of which have glaring conflicts of interest. The 70 groups‚Äîincluding People For the American Way, Public Citizen, the Constitutional Accountability Center, and the NAACP‚Äîsent a letter to U.S. senators arguing that Senate confirmation procedures provide "crucial data" that helps lawmakers and the public "evaluate nominees' fitness for the important positions to which they are nominated." "The framers of the Constitution included the requirement of Senate 'Advice and Consent' for high-ranking officers for a reason: The requirement can protect our freedom, just as the Bill of Rights does, by providing an indispensable check on presidential power," reads the new letter. "None of that would happen with recess appointments. The American people would be kept in the dark." Since his victory in last month's election, Trump has publicly expressed his desire to bypass the often time-consuming Senate confirmation process via recess appointments, which are allowed under the Constitution and have been used in the past by presidents of both parties. The need for Senate confirmation is already proving to be a significant obstacle for the incoming administration: Trump's first attorney general nominee, Matt Gaetz, withdrew amid seemingly insurmountable Senate opposition, and Pentagon nominee Pete Hegseth appears to be on the ropes. "Giving in to the president-elect's demand for recess appointments under the current circumstances would dramatically depart from how important positions have always been filled at the start of an administration," the groups wrote in their letter. "The confirmation process gathers important information that helps ensure that nominees who will be dangerous or ineffective for the American people are not confirmed and given great power, and that those who are confirmed meet at least a minimum standard of acceptability." "The American people deserve full vetting of every person selected to serve in our nation's highest offices, and Trump's nominees are no exception." Scholars argue recess appointments were intended as a way for presidents to appoint officials to key posts under unusual circumstances, not as an exploit for presidents whose nominees run up against significant opposition. The Senate could prevent recess appointments by refusing to officially go on recess and making use of pro forma sessions, but incoming Senate Majority Leader John Thune (R-S.D.) has said that "we have to have all the options on the table" to push through Trump's nominees. "We are not going to allow the Democrats to thwart the will of the American people in giving President Trump the people that he wants in those positions to implement his agenda," Thune said last month. Trump has also previously threatened to invoke a never-before-used provision of the Constitution that he claims would allow him to force both chambers of Congress to adjourn, paving the way for recess appointments. Conservative scholar Edward Whelan, a distinguished senior fellow of the Ethics and Public Policy Center, denounced that proposed route as a "cockamamie scheme" that would mean "eviscerating the Senate's advice-and-consent role." Svante Myrick, president of People For the American Way, said in a statement Wednesday that "if you're trying to ram through nominees without Senate and public scrutiny, it's a pretty good guess that you have something to hide." "The American people deserve full vetting of every person selected to serve in our nation's highest offices," said Myrick, "and Trump's nominees are no exception."
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Left  
This article primarily showcases the concerns of civil rights and pro-democracy groups about Trump's potential use of recess appointments to bypass the Senate confirmation process. It emphasizes the importance of transparency and scrutiny in nominations, which aligns with a more liberal viewpoint that values checks on presidential power. Additionally, the use of direct quotes from critics and an emphasis on the potential dangers of Trump's approach indicates a leaning toward a left-leaning perspective while maintaining some acknowledgment of conservative viewpoints.

title: Agency Allows Tens Of Thousands Of Bureaucrats To Work Remotely For Years As Trump Return Looms
body: A Biden administration appointee agreed to a new contract with a government employee union that will allow tens of thousands of bureaucrats to work remotely for years ahead of President-elect Donald Trump‚Äôs return to the White House, according to Bloomberg News. Recently-departed Social Security Administration (SSA) Commissioner Martin O‚ÄôMalley signed off on a new deal last week with the American Federation of Government Employees (AFGE) ‚Äî which represents about 42,000 SSA employees ‚Äî that will extend remote work availability into 2029, according to Bloomberg News. The incoming Trump administration and the newly-minted Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE), are poised to target work-from-home policies for government employees as part of a broader push to rein in the federal government and eliminate bureaucratic bloat. The agreement will effectively allow SSA employees to maintain their current levels of remote work through Trump‚Äôs term, according to Bloomberg News, which learned of the deal before its public announcement. Currently, SSA employees are required to be in the office between two and five days each week depending on what their specific job is. (RELATED: Most EPA Employees Really Don‚Äôt Want To Show Back Up To The Office, Survey Finds) Social Security Commissioner Martin O‚ÄôMalley testifies before the Senate Committee on the Budget at the U.S. Capitol on September 11, 2024 in Washington, D.C. (Photo by Anna Rose Layden/Getty Images) ‚ÄúThis deal will secure not just telework for SSA employees, but will secure staffing levels through prevention of higher attrition, which in turn will secure the ability of the Agency to serve the public,‚Äù AFGE chapter president Rich Couture wrote in a message to his members reviewed by Bloomberg News. Labor unions have lobbied the lame duck Biden administration to reach agreements with federal employees before Trump officially takes office in January 2025, according to Bloomberg News. ‚ÄúUnder President Trump‚Äôs leadership, the Government Efficiency effort led by Vivek and Elon will target waste and fraud throughout our massive federal bureaucracy,‚Äù Trump transition team spokesman Brian Hughes said in a statement shared with the Daily Caller News Foundation. ‚ÄúThey will work together slashing excess regulations, cutting wasteful expenditures, and restructuring Federal Agencies.‚Äù Billionaire businessmen Vivek Ramaswamy and Elon Musk, Trump‚Äôs two picks to run DOGE, recently wrote in a Wall Street Journal op-ed that a mandatory return-to-office policy across the federal government could induce some federal employees to voluntarily find other work in what would be a welcome development. It is unclear what the Trump administration may try to do about the new contract upon taking office next month, but moving to unilaterally nix it could initiate a lengthy legal battle, according to Bloomberg News. Elsewhere in the federal government, the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and the AFGE locked in a new contract in May, which contains protections meant to allow employees to report scientific misconduct or discuss their work with the press without retribution, according to Bloomberg News. Employees at the Justice Department are also organizing with the National Treasury Employees Union in an effort to be recognized before President Joe Biden leaves the White House. The SSA and AFGE did not respond immediately to requests for comment. All content created by the Daily Caller News Foundation, an independent and nonpartisan newswire service, is available without charge to any legitimate news publisher that can provide a large audience. All republished articles must include our logo, our reporter‚Äôs byline and their DCNF affiliation. For any questions about our guidelines or partnering with us, please contact licensing@dailycallernewsfoundation.org.
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Right  
The article expresses a critical perspective on the Biden administration's agreement with a government employee union, framing it as a move that could be undermined by the incoming Trump administration. This leads to a portrayal of the Biden admin in a somewhat negative light while favorably quoting Trump-affiliated sources, which indicates a slight rightward lean in bias.

title: The International Criminal Court is facing doubts as its member states meet
body: THE HAGUE, Netherlands ‚Äî The International Criminal Court's member states open their annual meeting Monday while the court faces pushback over arrest warrants for Israeli officials, sexual harassment allegations against the court's chief prosecutor and a very empty docket. The Assembly of States Parties, which represents the ICC's 124 member countries, will convene its 23rd conference to elect committee members and approve the court's budget against a backdrop of unfavorable headlines. Last month, judges granted a request from the court's chief prosecutor Karim Khan to issue arrest warrants for Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, his former defense minister and Hamas' military chief, accusing them of crimes against humanity in connection with the nearly 14-month war in Gaza. It marks the first time that a sitting leader of a major Western ally has been accused by the global court of justice. The decision has been denounced by critics of the court and given only milquetoast approval by many of its supporters, a stark contrast to the robust backing of an arrest warrant for Russian President Vladimir Putin last year over war crimes in Ukraine. U.S. President Joe Biden called the warrants for Netanyahu and the former defense minister "outrageous" and vowed to stand with Israel. A year ago, Biden called the warrant for Putin "justified" and said the Russian president had committed war crimes. The U.S. is not an ICC member country. France said it would "respect its obligations" but would need to consider Netanyahu's possible immunities. When the warrant for Putin was announced, France said it would "lend its support to the essential work" of the court. Hungary's Prime Minister Viktor Orb√°n, who currently holds the European Union's rotating presidency, accused the court of "interfering in an ongoing conflict for political purposes" and said his country wouldn't arrest Netanyahu. Hungary is an ICC member country. The ICC was established in 2002 as the world's permanent court of last resort to prosecute individuals responsible for the most heinous atrocities ‚Äî war crimes, crimes against humanity, genocide and the crime of aggression. The court only becomes involved when nations are unable or unwilling to prosecute those crimes on their territory. To date, 124 countries have signed on to the Rome Statute, which created the institution. Those who have not include Israel, Russia and China. The ICC has no police force and relies on member states to execute arrest warrants. Member country Austria begrudgingly acknowledged it would arrest Netanyahu but called the warrants "utterly incomprehensible," Italy called them "wrong" but said it would be obliged to arrest him. Germany said it would study the decision. Global security expert Janina Dill worried that such responses could undermine global justice efforts. "It really has the potential to damage not just the court, but international law," she told The Associated Press. U.S. Sen. Lindsey Graham, whose Republican party will control both branches of Congress in January, called the court a "dangerous joke" and urged Congress to sanction its prosecutor. "To any ally, Canada, Britain, Germany, France, if you try to help the ICC, we're going to sanction you," Graham said on Fox News. President-elect Donald Trump sanctioned the court's previous prosecutor, Fatou Bensouda, with a travel ban and asset freeze for investigating American troops and intelligence officials in Afghanistan. Milena Sterio, an expert in international law at Cleveland State University, told the AP that sanctions could affect a number of people who contribute to the court's work, such as international human rights lawyer Amal Clooney. Clooney advised the current prosecutor on his request for the warrants for Netanyahu and others. "Sanctions are a huge burden," Sterio said. Clooney did not respond to a request for comment. Khan is up against internal pressures as well. In October, the AP reported the 54-year old British lawyer is facing allegations he tried to coerce a female aide into a sexual relationship and groped her. Two co-workers in whom the woman confided reported the alleged misconduct in May to the court's independent watchdog, which says it interviewed the woman and ended its inquiry after five days when she opted against filing a formal complaint. Khan was never questioned. He has denied the claims. The Assembly of States Parties has announced it will launch an external probe into the allegations. It's not clear if the investigation will be addressed during the meeting. The court, which has long faced accusations of ineffectiveness, will have no trials pending after two conclude in December. While it has issued a number of arrest warrants in recent months, many high-profile suspects remain at large. Member states don't always act. Mongolia refused to arrest Putin when he visited in September. Sudan's former President Omar al-Bashir is wanted by the ICC over accusations related to the conflict in Darfur, but his country has refused to hand him over. Last week, Khan requested a warrant for the head of Myanmar's military regime, Senior Gen. Min Aung Hlaing, for attacks against the country's Rohingya Muslim minority. Judges have yet to decide on that request. "It becomes very difficult to justify the court's existence," Sterio said.
Ai bias and explanation:
Center  
The article presents a neutral overview of the International Criminal Court's challenges, including responses from various countries regarding arrest warrants, criticism of the court's effectiveness, and internal allegations against its chief prosecutor. It reports on multiple perspectives without showing clear favoritism toward any political viewpoint, maintaining a balanced and informative tone. The piece incorporates quotes from officials and experts that reflect a range of opinions, ensuring a comprehensive representation of the topic.

title: Takeaways from the Supreme Court arguments on transgender health care ban: Conservatives skeptical
body: WASHINGTON (AP) ‚Äî The Supreme Court heard the most high-profile case of its term on Wednesday, weighing Tennessee‚Äôs ban on gender-affirming health care for transgender minors. Similar laws have been passed by other conservative-leaning states. Challengers say they deprive kids of treatment they need, while the states defend them as protecting minors from life-changing decisions. The conservative-majority court appeared ready to uphold Tennessee‚Äôs law. It comes against the backdrop of escalating pushback to transgender rights, notably from President-elect Donald Trump. Here are some takeaways from the arguments: In the arguments on Wednesday, five of the court‚Äôs six conservatives seemed skeptical of the argument that the ban on gender-affirming care for minors is discriminatory. Two key conservatives, Chief Justice John Roberts and Justice Amy Coney Barrett, repeatedly challenged the arguments from lawyers challenging the ban. Roberts questioned whether judges should be weighing in on a question of regulating medical procedures, an area usually left to state lawmakers. Barrett sounded skeptical of the administration‚Äôs argument that the law discriminates because of sex. Conservative Justice Neil Gorsuch was notably silent, asking no questions. The court‚Äôs other three conservatives seemed to favor Tennessee. The three liberals largely backed the challengers, with Justice Sonia Sotomayor highlighting the risks of suicide among kids with gender dysphoria. The litigation marked only the second time the high court has heard a case that represented a fundamental test of transgender rights. In a case involving LGBTQ+ rights four years ago, two conservative justices, Roberts and Gorsuch, joined with its liberals to expand protections for transgender workers. Barrett wasn‚Äôt on the bench at the time and had no record on transgender rights. Gorsuch wrote the opinion, which left open claims of discrimination in other situations. The court isn‚Äôt expected to rule for several months. The decision could have direct effects in the 26 states that have passed versions of the bans, and might have ripple effects on other measures that restrict sports participation and bathroom use by transgender people. Supporters of the health care laws argue the gender-affirming treatments are risky, and the laws protect kids from making decisions before they‚Äôre ready. Challengers say many medical interventions come with some degree of risk, and families should be able to weigh those against the benefits. The arguments in favor of Tennessee‚Äôs ban could also be used to back federal restrictions, said Chase Strangio, the ACLU attorney who represented three families challenging the law. Tennessee Attorney General Jonathan Skrmetti said that his state‚Äôs arguments would still let each state set its own policy.
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Left  
The article presents a nuanced discussion of a Supreme Court case involving a transgender health care ban while highlighting the skepticism of conservative justices towards arguments against the law. The focus on challenges to the ban and quotes from liberal justices suggests a sympathetic stance towards transgender rights. Additionally, references to the risks of the legislation for transgender minors underscore a critical viewpoint of conservative policies, indicating a lean towards left-leaning perspectives.

title: Trump Assassination Hearing Devolves Into Chaos: 'You Are Out of Line!'
body: Representative Pat Fallon, a Texas Republican, and acting director of the Secret Service Ronald Rowe Jr. got into a yelling match during the final meeting of the Task Force on the Attempted Assassination of Donald Trump.Fallon was given the floor to question Rowe about the Secret Service's conduct on July 13 when then-Republican presidential candidate Trump faced an attempted assassination in Butler, Pennsylvania. He asked Rowe about the 9/11 memorial ceremony three months ago, when the acting director was pictured behind politicians rather than in position or scanning the area. Rowe was positioned behind President Joe Biden, Vice President Kamala Harris and President-elect Donald Trump. The two yelled at each other for over two minutes."I am a public servant who has served this nation and spent time on our country's darkest day. Do not politicize it," Rowe yelled. "You are out of line."Fallon had shown a photo of Rowe behind Trump and other politicians during the 9/11 memorial service in New York three months ago."I've got another question for you," Fallon said, showing an image with Rowe circled in it at Ground Zero for the September ceremony. "Do you recognize this photo?"Rowe confirmed that he recognized the image, noting that the special agent in charge of the detail is often close to the president during events like the memorial.Fallon then asked if Rowe was the special agent in charge of the detail that day."Let me address this," Fallon said. "Actually Congressman, what you're not seeing is the SAC of the detail off out of the picture's view. And that is the day where we remember the more than 3,000 people that have died on 9/11. I actually responded to Ground Zero. I was there going through the ashes of the World Trade Center." Secret Service Acting Director Ronald L. Rowe Jr. responds to questions from Rep. Pat Fallon, R-Texas, during a hearing by the House Task Force on the Attempted Assassination of Donald J. Trump on the Secret... Secret Service Acting Director Ronald L. Rowe Jr. responds to questions from Rep. Pat Fallon, R-Texas, during a hearing by the House Task Force on the Attempted Assassination of Donald J. Trump on the Secret Service's security failures regarding the assassination attempts on President-elect Trump, in Butler, Pa. on July 13, 2024, and West Palm Beach, Fla. on Sept. 15, 2024, on Capitol Hill, Thursday, Dec. 5, 2024, in Washington. The two got into a yelling match More AP Photo/Rod Lamkey, Jr. Fallon then yelled that he was "not asking" Rowe about that."I'm asking you were you the special agent in charge?" Fallon yelled, as Rowe continued to respond over him."I was there to show respect for a Secret Service member that died on 9/11," Rowe yelled, pointing his finger at Fallon. "Do not invoke 9/11 for political purposes."Fallon said he was not, while Chairman Mike Kelly, a Pennsylvania Republican, repeatedly hit his gavel and said "order." Read more Secret service As Hegseth Falters, Ron DeSantis May Get to Take 'War on Woke' to Military Gas Prices Lowest in More Than Three Years Net Worths of Donald Trump's Billionaire Appointments Former Staff Says Tulsi Gabbard 'Fraud' Politics Supported by Alleged Cult "Don't try to bully me," Fallon said, pointing his finger back at Rowe. "I am an elected member of Congress and I'm asking you a serious question. You won't answer the question." Rep. Pat Fallon, R-Texas, questions Secret Service Acting Director Ronald L. Rowe Jr. during a hearing by the House Task Force on the Attempted Assassination of Donald J. Trump on the Secret Service's security failures... Rep. Pat Fallon, R-Texas, questions Secret Service Acting Director Ronald L. Rowe Jr. during a hearing by the House Task Force on the Attempted Assassination of Donald J. Trump on the Secret Service's security failures regarding the assassination attempts on President-elect Trump, in Butler, Pa. on July 13, 2024, and West Palm Beach, Fla. on Sept. 15, 2024, on Capitol Hill, Thursday, Dec. 5, 2024, in Washington. The two got into an arguing match. More AP Photo/Rod Lamkey, Jr. Rowe finally answered that he was not there as the secret agent in charge and that he was there "representing the United States Secret Service.""It did not effect protective operations," Rowe said.Fallon, however, continued to say that Rowe "put those agents out of position" so that he could be seen in the photo at the memorial service. Fallon then started asking if Rowe had a radio, was wearing a vest, or had a weapon, while Kelly repeated that Fallon was out of time."I did sir, and you are out of line," Rowe said, ending the argument.Another representative on the committee, who was not shown on the televised hearing feed, called Fallon a bully.The rest of the hearing so far has been about the Secret Services' "failure" on July 13 at Trump's rally, as Rowe called it."That abject failure underscored critical gaps in Secret Service operations and I recognize that we did not meet the expectations of the American public, Congress and our protected and they rightly have that idea based on how we performed," Rowe said.Rowe called out the "glaring" failure of the lack to secure the American Glass Research building, where gunman Thomas Matthew Crooks later shot at Trump."When I traveled there, the day after I was named the acting director, and as I'm walking around and I'm up on the roof and I'm looking at the proximity of it to the site, I was taken aback that it was not secured," Rowe said.Since taking on the role as acting director, Rowe said he has been refocusing the Secret Service on trainings as well as the importance of communications. He told the representatives that the Secret Service is currently training 500 agents and is set to onboard an additional 400 as well as 200 division uniformed officers by June.He also announced during the hearing that the agency will shift the Office of Investigations to the Office of Field Operations."This is not simply a semantic change," Rowe said. "Establishing the office of field operations is an opportunity to reset our thinking and perspective about the role field offices play in protection and to enhance our operational effectiveness by better leveraging field offices to support, enable and inform protection and protected activities."
Ai bias and explanation:
Center  
The article reports on a contentious hearing involving a Texas Republican representative and the acting director of the Secret Service regarding security failures during an attempted assassination of Donald Trump. The tone remains factual and neutral, presenting both sides of the argument without overt bias. It aims to inform the audience about the developments in the hearing without promoting a particular political agenda, which qualifies it as a ‚ÄúCenter‚Äù classification.

title: Biden Admits His DOJ Is Corrupt
body: President Joe Biden admitted on Sunday that his Department of Justice (DOJ) is ‚Äúinfected‚Äù by politics. It‚Äôs an admission that‚Äôs entirely true ‚Äî but not for the reasons Biden thinks. Biden issued a blanket pardon for his son Hunter for ‚Äúoffenses against the United States which he has committed or may have committed or taken part in during the period from January 1, 2014 through December 1, 2024.‚Äù That means Hunter is off the hook for the federal gun and tax charges he was being prosecuted for, as well as other potential crimes he committed like FARA violations and money laundering. In explaining the unprecedented, decade-long pardon, Biden said he had no choice since the DOJ was corrupted by politics. ‚ÄúI believe in the justice system, but as I have wrestled with this, I also believe raw politics has infected this process and it led to a miscarriage of justice ‚Äî and once I made this decision this weekend, there was no sense in delaying it further,‚Äù Biden said. ‚ÄúI hope Americans will understand why a father and a President would come to this decision.‚Äù Biden‚Äôs right, his DOJ is corrupt. Under his DOJ, U.S. Attorney David Weiss delayed bringing charges against Hunter despite ample evidence that Hunter failed to pay more than $1.4 million in taxes and lied about drug use on his federal form to purchase a firearm. Biden‚Äôs DOJ hand-crafted a sweetheart plea deal for Hunter that eventually derailed after a judge scrutinized the broad immunity it afforded Hunter. The DOJ, as explained by my colleague Jordan Boyd, ‚Äúspecifically choked an IRS investigation and subsequent charging recommendations for Hunter because they feared it would hurt Joe‚Äôs chances in the 2020 election.‚Äù All of that is corruption ‚Äî corruption that only stood to benefit Hunter. But as far as victims of the Biden DOJ‚Äôs corruption goes, Hunter isn‚Äôt one of them. The DOJ‚Äôs Jack Smith indicted President-elect Donald Trump twice. One indictment centered around Trump‚Äôs questioning of the administration of the 2020 election. (The other was related to Trump‚Äôs alleged mishandling of classified documents.) After Smith dragged Trump through the mud and made a mockery of the so-called ‚Äújustice‚Äù system, the Supreme Court torpedoed Smith‚Äôs lawfare efforts in July when it ruled that a U.S. president has ‚Äúabsolute immunity‚Äù for ‚Äúactions within his conclusive and preclusive constitutional authority‚Äù and ‚Äúat least presumptive immunity‚Äù for all ‚Äúofficial acts.‚Äù Smith later filed a superseding indictment against Trump, refusing to let the case go because he thought it would hurt Trump‚Äôs chances of winning the election. Smith has since dropped the case after Trump‚Äôs victory. Biden‚Äôs politicized DOJ has also prosecuted nearly 1,500 Americans for protesting the 2020 election, with Attorney General Merrick Garland telling Americans in August to take the prosecutions as a warning about what would happen to them should they raise questions about an election. The DOJ also targeted a group of praying pro-lifers who decided to pray outside of an abortion clinic in the hope that their silent pleas would help save the life of an innocent child. Seven pro-lifers were found guilty of violating the Freedom of Access to Clinic Entrances (FACE) Act and engaging in a civil rights conspiracy for, as explained by The Federalist‚Äôs Beth Brelje, ‚Äústanding and sitting in front of the door of the Northland Family Planning Clinic‚Äù in Michigan in 2020. The DOJ is corrupt and politicized, as Biden correctly pointed out. But the real victims of the DOJ‚Äôs perversion of justice are Trump and the American people, not Hunter Biden.
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Right  
This article presents a critical view of President Biden and his administration's Department of Justice (DOJ), indicating a bias against him. The framing of the DOJ as corrupt and politicized implies a stance more aligned with conservative viewpoints. Additionally, the emphasis on Biden's son Hunter's legal troubles and a perceived miscarriage of justice aligns with common criticisms found in leaning right or right-leaning media, which often highlight alleged corruption within liberal administrations. The overall tone supports a conservative interpretation of the events discussed.

title: South Korean president reverses martial law declaration after immediate opposition from parliament
body: South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol backed down early Wednesday after tossing his country into turmoil by suddenly declaring martial law and mobilizing the army. Yoon did so in the face of nationwide defiance that erupted some 155 minutes after he announced in a late-night TV address on Tuesday that he was taking over. Members of South Korea‚Äôs parliament raced to the National Assembly building and, with 190 of its 300 members present, they quickly passed a resolution demanding that Yoon lift his order while protesters opposed to martial law gathered outside the building. ‚ÄúI have accepted the decision made by the National Assembly to dissolve and lift the martial law,‚Äù Yoon said in an address to the nation via television broadcast nationwide. It was an abrupt end to a standoff that began when parliament publicly defied Yoon and passed a resolution that martial law was officially nullified. After the vote, National Assembly Chairman Woo Won-sik demanded that the special forces leave the building and grounds of parliament. Shortly afterward, the soldiers began filing out through one of the gates. ‚ÄúI regret what happened today,‚Äù said Han Dong Hoon, leader of the ruling People Power Party to which Yoon belongs. ‚ÄúExercise of military police and other government authority is illegal now that the resolution for the nullification of the martial law has passed.‚Äù But the country‚Äôs Defense Ministry said that martial law would remain in place until Yoon lifted the order. For several hours, there was no immediate response from Yoon, whose conservative government took office in 2022 and who, as justification for declaring martial law, accused opposition parties of sympathizing with North Korea and controlling parliament. ‚ÄúI am declaring a state of emergency in order to protect the constitutional order based on freedom and eradicate shameful pro-North Korea anti-state groups, that are stealing freedom and happiness of our people,‚Äù Yoon said on the country‚Äôs YTN news channel. He added that this would protect the country ‚Äúfrom the threats of North Korea‚Äôs communist forces.‚Äù ‚ÄúWhile the imposition of martial law may cause significant inconvenience to the law-abiding citizens who uphold the constitutional values of the Republic of Korea, I will strive to minimize these disruptions,‚Äù he added. Yoon‚Äôs address was quickly followed by a proclamation from Martial Law Commander, Gen. Park Ahn-soo. It said that ‚Äúall political activities‚Äù would be banned, and that ‚Äúall media and publications will be subject to the control of the Martial Law Command.‚Äù ‚ÄúStrikes, work slowdowns, and gatherings that incite social disorder are forbidden,‚Äù it added. It also ordered ‚Äúall medical professionals‚Äù to return to work within 48 hours. ‚ÄúViolators of this proclamation will be subject to arrest, detention, and search and seizure without a warrant under Article 9 of the Martial Law Act,‚Äù it said. At the U.S. State Department, Deputy Spokesperson Vedant Patel said it had received no advance warning that Yoon was about to declare martial law. Earlier, the White House National Security Council confirmed that the Biden administration had been in contact with the South Korean government and that it was ‚Äúmonitoring the situation closely.‚Äù ‚ÄúThe situation is fluid,‚Äù Philip Goldberg , the U.S. ambassador to South Korea posted on X before Yoon announced the end of martial law. South Korean Democratic Party leader Lee Jae-myung, who had to climb over a fence to get into the National Assembly building, called Yoon‚Äôs martial law declaration ‚Äúillegal and unconstitutional.‚Äù It was the first time since 1980 that martial law has been declared in South Korea. There were no reports of tanks or soldiers on the streets in the capital, Seoul, or elsewhere in South Korea, which is a key U.S. ally in the region and home to around 28,500 American troops. More from NBC News: ‚ÄúRight now there has been essentially no impact on U.S. forces,‚Äù Pentagon Press Secretary Major General Pat Ryder said before Yoon backed down. But South Korea‚Äôs Yonhap News Agency reported that dozens of people had gathered in front of the National Assembly in the early hours of the morning local time, leading to scuffles with police. The Korean won fell sharply against the U.S. dollar after Yoon declared martial law. Yoon has struggled to push through his agenda against an opposition-controlled parliament, and his approval rating has nosedived in recent months due to various controversies. His People Power Party has clashed with the liberal opposition Democratic Party, which has a majority in parliament, over next year‚Äôs budget. The Democratic Party has also pushed to impeach some of the country‚Äôs top officials. Still, experts on South Korean politics said Yoon‚Äôs dramatic power grab was unexpected. ‚ÄúIt really is quite an extraordinary situation and a genuine surprise,‚Äù said Edward Howell, the Korean Foundation Fellow at Chatham House, a British think tank that focuses on international affairs. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs almost as if President Yoon went straight for the most extreme option first.‚Äù Stella Kim reported from Seoul, and Freddie Clayton from London.
Ai bias and explanation:
Center  
This article describes a complex political event in South Korea with a focus on facts and quotes from multiple stakeholders, including government officials and opposition leaders. It maintains neutrality by presenting various viewpoints without overt bias for or against any political faction, thus placing it in a "Center" classification.

title: The Left Seethes At Trump‚Äôs Triumph As A Cultural Icon
body: President-elect Donald Trump went from a former commander-in-chief with a polarizing exit to a cultural icon whose re-election over a mugshot and two assassination attempts defined one of the greatest American comebacks of all time. Enter the ‚ÄúTrump dance‚Äù as a nationwide celebration of the ex-president‚Äôs triumph over four years of dystopian rule by a condescending administration. Trump‚Äôs signature moves to his popular campaign anthem, the Village People‚Äôs ‚ÄúY.M.C.A.,‚Äù have taken the internet by storm after being performed by online influencers and athletes all across the sports world. This is what you call Respect. There‚Äôs a new dance craze and it‚Äôs called the Donald Trump pic.twitter.com/bnGG5N0OMc The left, which suddenly exempted themselves from their own lockdowns to parade in crowded streets because their candidate won four years ago, is now having a hard time watching Americans relish in Trump‚Äôs massive victory. [RELATED: Donald Trump Made The GOP Cool Again] ‚ÄúAthletes will come to regret their ‚ÄòTrump dance‚Äô celebrations,‚Äù headlined an op-ed in USA Today by an author named Nancy Armour. ‚ÄúAs anyone over the age of, oh, 12 can tell you, what seems cool today will make you cringe in the future,‚Äù Armour wrote. ‚ÄúSo it will be with athletes and their ‚ÄòTrump dance‚Äô celebrations.‚Äù ‚ÄúActually, mimicking president-elect Donald Trump‚Äôs dance moves looks dumb in the moment,‚Äù Armour added. She sounds fun. A few paragraphs later, Armour actually wrote, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs all fun and games until people start getting deported.‚Äù Well ok, if we‚Äôre going to go there, someone might ask the family of murdered 22-year-old Laken Riley how much they‚Äôve enjoyed the ‚Äúfun and games‚Äù of an illegal immigrant from Venezuela slaughtering her. The killer, Jose Ibarra, was handed a life sentence Wednesday, wherein he‚Äôll live on the government payroll the rest of their life. On Sunday, a panel on CNN featured pundits who characterized Trump as a ‚ÄúRepublican Caesar‚Äù following the president-elect‚Äôs appearance at Saturday night‚Äôs UFC event in New York City‚Äôs Madison Square Garden. Trump walked into the legacy venue with an entourage of some of the most recognizable personalities from his campaign now preparing to staff the new administration, such as Elon Musk, Vivek Ramaswamy, Tulsi Gabbard, and Robert F. Kennedy Jr. Also present at the fight where Trump held one of the most significant rallies of his latest campaign included UFC President Dana White, Republican House Speaker Mike Johnson of Louisiana, and the president-elect‚Äôs two sons, Donald Trump Jr., and Eric Trump. ‚ÄúIt really looks like ancient Rome here,‚Äù said Bulwark reporter Marc Caputo. ‚ÄúThis is sort of the conquering Republican Caesar who‚Äôs going into The Colosseum and everyone‚Äôs cheering, and he‚Äôs got his political gladiators with him.‚Äù Was that supposed to be an insult? Normal Americans (and normal gays) who aren‚Äôt allergic to testosterone yet might call it remarkable. Indeed, Heavyweight Champion Jon Jones celebrated his victory in the headline event with the ‚ÄúTrump dance‚Äù and thanked the president-elect for being there as the fighter defended the UFC title. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm proud to be a great American champion,‚Äù Jones said in the cage with the display of high-octane patriotism that used to unite the country. Patriotism is cool again four years after the Democrat Party denigrated Mount Rushmore out of self-hatred. Jones even went on to shake hands with the president-elect after handing Trump the championship belt. Incredible moment of respect when Jon Jones handed his UFC championship belt to President Trump. The culture is changing. I love this. üá∫üá≤üá∫üá≤üá∫üá≤üá∫üá≤üá∫üá≤üá∫üá≤üî•üî•üî•üî•üî•üî• pic.twitter.com/qgb3BjgLOK ‚ÄúThat appearance isn‚Äôt just about him enjoying the applause,‚Äù Caputo said on CNN. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs sending a message to the Senate. Like, not only, ‚Äòare you entertained?‚Äô But, ‚Äòthese are my people, and are you willing to fight? Because here‚Äôs who I have.'‚Äù Trump did, after all, vow on election night usher in the ‚Äúgolden age of America‚Äù with echoes of the ‚ÄúPax Romana,‚Äù which refers to the roughly 200-year era of unprecedented prosperity for the Roman Empire between 27 BC to 180 AD. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre going to fix everything about our country, and we‚Äôve made history for a reason tonight,‚Äù Trump said. ‚ÄúThis will truly be the golden age of America.‚Äù The ‚ÄúPax Romana‚Äù also happens to translate to ‚ÄúRoman peace.‚Äù While Trump detractors are constantly out to characterize him as an unhinged authoritarian, American voters spoke clearly when they elected their ‚ÄúRepublican Caesar‚Äù and tossed the incumbent regime, which has pushed the world closer to nuclear conflict and zealously prosecuted its top political opponent. In other words, democracy was kept safe as Americans welcomed the candidate who promised world peace.
Ai bias and explanation:
Right  
The article exhibits strong right-wing bias, focusing on positive portrayals of Donald Trump and his supporters while depicting critics, particularly those from the left, as condescending and out of touch. It frames Trump‚Äôs actions as a cultural comeback and celebrates nationalism and patriotism, which are pivotal themes in right-leaning politics. The references to critics‚Äô opinions are largely dismissive, which further indicates a slant favoring Trump and his administration. The language used throughout emphasizes admiration for Trump, reinforcing its conservative viewpoint.

title: Here‚Äôs How Much Cash Donald Trump Spends Each Year
body: What does it cost to live like a king? Ask Donald Trump. Bank records released in the former president‚Äôs fraud trial, which he lost earlier this year and is now appealing, suggest that the real estate mogul spends about $1 million a month on personal expenses. But that‚Äôs just the start of it. Trump also has an empire to protect‚Äîproperties to buy, developments to create, debt to service and litigation to settle. Add everything up, and Trump burned through more than $130 million a year on average, or $11 million a month, from 2010 through the first half of 2019, according to bank records. His expenses varied wildly by year, exceeding $200 million before he ran for president the first time, then dropping to about $60 million once he settled into the White House. Now one month away from reclaiming his throne, Trump is at a crossroads, with little clarity on how much cash he will need over the next four years. To understand how Trump arrived at this moment, it helps to go back to the Great Recession, when cash was tight for almost everyone. The crisis hit Trump hard at projects in Chicago and Las Vegas. But he had an advantage that other developers did not. The Apprentice, which started in 2004, provided both entertainment income and licensing opportunities. By 2010, Trump earned nearly $50 million a year from those sources, even more than he took in from his buildings. So while other developers pinched pennies, Trump spent big. He shelled out $37 million to upgrade his aircraft in 2010, purchasing a Boeing 757 and customizing it to his liking. It was his biggest cash outlay of the year, accounting for more than one-third of his total $101 million in spending. Shortly thereafter, Trump doled out another $25 million for a helicopter, with the idea that it could ferry people a few miles between Miami‚Äôs airport and his new golf resort, Trump National Doral. He used some cash more responsibly, purchasing a $130 million note against his tower in Chicago for $48 million, then paying down another loan in Las Vegas. Cleaning up his balance sheet required $75 million of liquidity over the 12-month period ending June 30, 2012, his biggest cash expense in a year when he burned $203 million. Then he went on a building binge. From mid-2012 to mid-2016, Trump blew through $600 million of cash on acquisitions and property development, about 80% of the money flying out his door. He redeveloped the Miami golf resort and purchased two others in Europe. He also transformed Washington D.C.‚Äôs Old Post Office into the Trump International Hotel. To top it off, he spent about $65 million on his presidential campaign. Building a political movement turned out to be cheaper than building a real estate empire. In the White House, Trump‚Äôs development expenses decreased by more than $100 million a year. But politics came with other costs. In 2016, shortly after winning the election, Trump agreed to a $25 million settlement to resolve litigation surrounding Trump University, a blow that led him to take out a secret loan around the time of his first inauguration. Trump‚Äôs cash expenses fell to $83 million in the year ending June 30, 2018, their lowest level since at least 2012, then dropped another 30% to about $60 million the following year, according to the records. Eventually, most of his cash outlays went toward propping up various ventures, as both the D.C. hotel and the European courses strained to turn a profit. Losses multiplied when Covid-19 landed in 2020. ‚ÄúI wouldn‚Äôt say you‚Äôre thriving when you decide to close down your hotels and your businesses,‚Äù Trump told a crowd of reporters inside the White House briefing room. But the problems went away almost as suddenly as they appeared. Trump sold his money-losing hotel for a reported $375 million in 2022, handing the headache to other investors (who failed to meet their debt obligations and ended up losing control of the property). Trump‚Äôs golf business, meanwhile, thrived as the world healed from the pandemic. Donors kept pouring money into Trump‚Äôs political groups, saving him from having to put more of his own cash into his 2024 presidential run. He even got other people to finance his new social-media business. A spokesperson for the president-elect, Steven Cheung, ignored a set of specific inquiries related to this story and instead issued a statement touting his boss. "President Trump is one of the most successful businessmen in history and then became president of the United States,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúHe has built historic and widely recognized properties that redefined the New York skyline and has created award-winning golf courses around the world." On the cusp of returning to the White House, Trump‚Äôs finds himself facing an unpredictable financial position. The operations of the Trump Organization are in good shape, leaner and more profitable than during his first term. With fewer weaknesses in his empire, Trump might be able to deploy less than $50 million of cash in 2025, which would make the coming year one of his cheapest in recent memory. But that‚Äôs assuming everything goes his way, which it might not. On July 6, 2025, a $117 million loan comes due against one of Trump‚Äôs New York City properties. The president-elect, who still has not refinanced the debt, might have to dip into his own pocket to pay back his lender. Legal troubles are also looming‚ÄîTrump owes a total of $578 million, including interest, stemming from three court cases, all currently under appeal. Losses could leave Trump‚Äôs underlings scrambling to sell or refinance assets while he serves as president.
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Right  
The article examines Donald Trump's financial dealings in a largely neutral tone, presenting facts about his spending habits while running a prominent business and political career. However, it carries a slight bias leaning towards a more favorable perspective on Trump, as it refers to him as a "successful businessman" and emphasizes his achievements. While the analysis of his expenses includes some critical points about his legal troubles and financial challenges, the overall framing does not exhibit an overtly negative stance, thus placing it in the "Lean Right" category.

title: Trump's SEC pick Atkins marks victory for establishment expertise
body: WASHINGTON, Dec 5 (Reuters) - While Wall Street breathed a sigh of relief at President-elect Donald Trump's pick of respected Washington lawyer Paul Atkins to lead the Securities and Exchange Commission, critics worry his light-touch philosophy and crypto-friendly stance will hurt investors. After a string of controversial cabinet picks considered by critics to be lacking in qualifications, financial executives had wondered whether populist Trump loyalists were headed for the financial agencies too. But the choice of Atkins, a former top SEC official and well-liked veteran of financial and Republican circles, marked a victory for establishment expertise, said industry executives. Several people who have worked with Atkins also described him as highly professional, principled and fun. "Paul is a quality pick who will have credibility on both sides of the aisle," said Stephen Crimmins, who worked as an enforcement attorney at the SEC for 14 years, overlapping with Atkins for some of that time. "He knows securities regulation cold and has the people skills to get things done." Atkins, 66, is familiar with both the complex plumbing of the markets and the inner workings of the 5,000-strong SEC, which oversees roughly 40,000 companies, as well as how Wall Street companies and other firms operate, the people said. After leaving the SEC, Atkins in 2009 founded consultancy Patomak Global Partners, located just around the corner from the White House. The firm has represented banks, financial technology firms and crypto companies in their dealings with the SEC and other regulators, according to its website. A self-avowed free marketeer, Atkins will be a marked change from the current SEC Chair Gary Gensler, who was appointed by Democratic President Joe Biden. Gensler cracked down on Wall Street and crypto firms with a hard-nosed style that upset industry executives and even some congressional Democrats. Atkins' SEC knowledge and expertise will put him in a strong position to unpick some of Gensler's rules, especially short-sale regulations and climate disclosure rules already facing lawsuits, as well as cryptocurrency accounting restrictions. Still, Atkins is considered unlikely to fundamentally weaken the agency, a fear stoked by Elon Musk's role as co-head of a newly created government efficiency watchdog. The Tesla and SpaceX CEO has clashed with the agency and repeatedly attacked it. "He (Atkins) grew up with the SEC and recognizes the important purposes of the agency," Richard Hong, a partner with Morrison Cohen law firm who joined the SEC as a lawyer while Atkins was a commissioner there. Atkins and his representatives did not immediately respond to an email on Thursday seeking comment. But not everyone is cheering Atkins on. Pro-regulation progressive groups, as well as top Democratic Senator Elizabeth Warren, were quick to flag concerns over his industry ties and record championing light-touch enforcement while at the SEC. Atkins said at the time that big corporate penalties unduly punished shareholders who had already been hurt by the original misconduct. Speaking in February 2008 just months before the subprime mortgage crisis kicked into full swing, Atkins said the SEC should offer companies more transparency and predictability over enforcement probes and penalties. "Atkins ... is smart, experienced, and capable. Unfortunately, he is also a deregulation zealot and industry cheerleader," said Dennis Kelleher, the CEO of Washington-based advocacy group Better Markets, who also noted that Atkins served in the Republican majority at the SEC in the years leading up to the 2008 crisis and the Bernard Madoff Ponzi scandal, opens new tab. Others warned that Atkins may give free reign to the crypto industry, which donated heavily to support Trump's 2024 presidential campaign and has pushed for a new industry-friendly SEC leader who will end Gensler's crackdown. Gensler is scheduled to step down on Jan. 20, 2025. Atkins has helped create best practices for crypto issuances and trading as co-chair of the Token Alliance, and is a member of the Chamber of Digital Commerce's advisory board. Bitcoin breached $100,000 for the first time on Wednesday on excitement over a SEC crypto policy overhaul under Atkins. "Crypto companies' unprecedented political spending apparently just bought them control of the nation's investor protection police," said Bartlett Naylor, financial policy advocate at Public Citizen, a progressive consumer rights group.
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Right  
This article leans towards a Center-Right bias. It primarily focuses on the selection of Paul Atkins by President-elect Trump for the SEC and highlights his establishment credentials, emphasizing a positive response from Wall Street and financial executives. While the piece acknowledges concerns from critics, including progressive groups, it ultimately presents Atkins as an experienced and credible choice, aligning more with pro-business and financial perspectives, consistent with lean Right media bias.

title: Jurors In Daniel Penny Case Review Crucial Video Evidence In Ongoing¬†Deliberations
body: No matter what side people were on regarding Daniel Penny‚Äôs guilt in the death of Jordan Neely, many believed a verdict would come quickly.That hasn‚Äôt happened, and jurors are entering their second full day of deliberations on Thursday. Since deliberations began, the jurors have asked to review key pieces of evidence, including three videos tied to the case, Fox 5 New York reported.Penny is charged with second-degree manslaughter and a lesser charge of criminally negligent homicide. Jurors can find him guilty of one of the charges, or acquit him of all charges.On Wednesday, jurors asked to review body cam footage from police taken as they arrived at the scene after Penny placed Neely in a chokehold. Penny said he took action because Neely was threatening passengers on the New York City subway. They also asked to review the original video of the incident taken by another passenger, and the footage from Penny‚Äôs interrogation with police, where they didn‚Äôt tell him Neely had died.Jurors also asked to review the cross-examination of New York medical examiner Dr. Cynthia Harris, who testified that she made the determination Neely died due to asphyxiation based on video alone ‚Äì before the toxicology report came back.AdvertisementIn November, Penny‚Äôs defense attorneys questioned Harris why Neely‚Äôs death certificate originally listed the cause of death as pending further study. Harris said this was due to a misunderstanding from a police report that said Neely had been screaming while police were present. But, after viewing video of Penny restraining Neely in a chokehold and appearing unresponsive, Harris made her determination about the cause of death.CHECK OUT THE DAILY WIRE HOLIDAY GIFT GUIDEHarris told the defense that even if Neely had enough fentanyl in his system to take out an elephant, she still would have ruled that he died from asphyxiation. The defense, however, was able to get her to agree that medical examiners can disagree on the cause of death and that it‚Äôs not a perfect science.AdvertisementOn Tuesday afternoon, less than an hour after deliberations began, jurors asked about the specifics of justification defenses from the judge‚Äôs instructions. To convict Penny, jurors need to agree that Penny‚Äôs chokehold on Neely was unjustifiable and that he acted recklessly.The jurors were read that section of the judge‚Äôs instructions, deliberated for another hour and a half, and then went home for the day, The Daily Wire reported.Also on Wednesday, Neely‚Äôs father filed a lawsuit against Penny for the death of his son, the New York Post reported, demanding ‚Äújudgment awarding damages in a sum which exceeds the jurisdictional limits of all lower Courts which would otherwise have jurisdiction.‚ÄùAdvertisement
Ai bias and explanation:
Center  
The article provides an objective account of the ongoing legal proceedings surrounding Daniel Penny, presenting the facts of the case without apparent bias. It outlines the jury's actions, the evidence reviewed, and statements from both the prosecution and defense, maintaining a neutral tone. While references to sources like Fox 5 New York and The Daily Wire may imply certain leanings, the overall reporting focuses strictly on the legal context rather than taking a definitive stance on the matter.

title: Head of Democratic Caucus says thin House margins make attendance vital next year
body: The head of the House Democratic Caucus is sending an early message to his troops heading into the 119th Congress: Attendance will be crucial given the razor-tight margins in the lower chamber. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs important for every member to come to work and to do their job. That‚Äôs what we‚Äôre telling our caucus,‚Äù Rep. Pete Aguilar (D-Calif.) said during a press briefing in the Capitol. ‚ÄúTheir attendance is incredibly important, and the work that we do here is important, and pushing back against Republican overreach is potentially something that we have to do next year,‚Äù he continued. ‚ÄúAnd in order to do that, we‚Äôre going to need them coming‚Äù to Washington. While Democrats generally fared poorly in this year‚Äôs elections ‚Äî losing the Senate and White House while failing to flip the House ‚Äî the party outperformed the top of the ticket in the lower chamber, where GOP leaders will have just a spare 220 to 215 advantage in the next Congress. That thin advantage will get even thinner in the early part of next year, as Reps. Elise Stefanik (R-N.Y.) and Michael Waltz (R-Fla.) are set to join the Trump administration, while former Rep. Matt Gaetz (R-Fla.) ‚Äî who won reelection last month ‚Äî has already resigned ahead of his failed bid to lead the Justice Department in Trump‚Äôs second term. Those shifts will leave Speaker Mike Johnson (R-La.), who‚Äôs expected to keep the gavel in the next Congress, with a hairline 217 to 215 majority for several months of 2025, when President-elect Trump is hoping to use the GOP majorities in Congress to move an ambitious 100-day agenda that includes a sweeping extension of his 2017 tax cuts. The tiny cushion means GOP leaders will have to achieve perfect unity among Republican lawmakers in order to pass their partisan agenda, since even a single defection would lead to a tie ‚Äî 216 to 216 ‚Äî which spells failure under House rules. The math changes, however, if there are Democratic absences, which would lower the threshold Republicans would need to pass their bills, thereby padding their cushion to allow more GOP defections. It‚Äôs that scenario that Aguilar and other Democratic leaders are already fighting to avoid by encouraging every member to be in the chamber when hot-button legislation hits the floor. The Democratic Caucus chairman said he‚Äôs sympathetic to lawmakers who are suffering from serious illnesses, including several with cancer, but quickly emphasized that those members volunteered to seek reelection, even knowing of their health troubles. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs life, but members also ran for these jobs,‚Äù Aguilar said. ‚ÄúMembers ran for these jobs and were reelected knowing that that was what they were experiencing. And if they asked their voters to send them to D.C. to do work, my expectation is that they‚Äôre going to come to D.C. to do work. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs how I approach it.‚Äù
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Left  
The article focuses on challenges faced by the Democratic Party and emphasizes the importance of member attendance to oppose Republican initiatives. Though it provides factual information about party dynamics and upcoming congressional decisions, the framing of the narrative demonstrates a bias that aligns with Democratic perspectives, particularly in discussing 'Republican overreach' and the urging of Democratic members to fulfill their duties despite personal hardships. This aligns with a Lean Left classification due to the emphasis on party solidarity and challenges posed by an opposing party.

title: Hegseth fights to keep Defense nomination. And, police search for gunman who shot CEO
body: Good morning. You're reading the Up First newsletter. Subscribe here to get it delivered to your inbox, and listen to the Up First podcast for all the news you need to start your day. Pete Hegseth, President-elect Donald Trump's pick for defense secretary, is fighting to save his nomination by defending himself against allegations of drinking and womanizing.
