Jamie Raskin announced his bid for the job and quickly amassed support from colleagues. ‚ÄúI am also proud that, under my leadership, some of our caucus‚Äôs most talented rising stars have been given a platform to demonstrate their leadership and their abilities,‚Äù Nadler wrote in the letter to Democrats that was obtained by The Associated Press. ‚ÄúThat includes Jamie Raskin, who in just a few terms in Congress has already proven himself to be an exceptional leader and spokesperson for our party‚Äôs values.‚Äù The 77-year-old chose to step aside as the Democratic party undergoes an internal reckoning over their losses in the election, which swept Republicans into a trifecta of power in Washington. Many Democrats are eager for generational change and a new approach as President-elect Donald Trump returns to the White House. The decision by Nadler, who is serving his 17th term in Congress, reflects that generational shift. Before he made his decision Wednesday morning, Nadler spent time speaking with staff about what his next step should be. He also made a call to Raskin, which was described as cordial by a person familiar with the conversation who was not authorized to discuss it publicly. ‚ÄúJerry Nadler is an extraordinary lawyer, patriot and public servant,‚Äù Raskin posted on X. ‚ÄúHis dogged defense of civil rights and civil liberties is a great inspiration to our people.‚Äù He added, ‚ÄúI am honored and humbled to have his support in the battles ahead.‚Äù Democratic Leader Rep. Hakeem Jeffries also reached out to Nadler, according to the same person, and offered him an emeritus status on the Judiciary committee, an honorary title that recognizes a member‚Äôs seniority and service to the chamber. Nadler said he plans to stay on the committee as a senior member and will likely take up a ranking member role on one of the various subcommittees. But despite the cordial back-and-forth, the timeline of events that led to Raskin‚Äôs surprise bid and Nadler‚Äôs swift decision to step down damaged a close friendship between the two men. Nadler‚Äôs staff had expected that there would likely be a challenger for the ranking member spot. And a week before Thanksgiving, they heard that Raskin, a former constitutional law professor, was making the rounds, talking to Democratic colleagues about a potential run. Nadler, who ran the vote counting operation to successfully land Raskin the top spot on the House Oversight Committee, confronted the Maryland lawmaker, who denied he was making a play for the job, according to the same person. Raskin told him that he would soon put out a letter announcing that he would run for the Oversight post again. Raskin‚Äôs office did not respond to a request for comment. That letter never came and when Nadler inquired again about it days later, Raskin softened his stance, according to the person, saying that he was hearing from a lot of people that he should run. On Saturday, reports came out of Raskin pursuing the post before he made it official with a letter to colleagues on Monday. He wrote that the Judiciary Committee under his leadership would become ‚Äúthe headquarters of Congressional opposition to authoritarianism‚Äù as well as other efforts by Trump and his allies to thwart the Constitution. It was a stunning turn of events given that over the years Democrats have rarely broken from the seniority system for committee assignments, no matter how long someone has held a position, making the outcome of the race uncertain. But being the face of the resistance against Trump is not new territory for Raskin who spent the last two years on the House Oversight committee as the most vocal defender of President Joe Biden and his family as they faced a sprawling Republican investigation ‚Äî encouraged by Trump ‚Äî into their various business affairs. He also helped draft articles of impeachment against the incoming president for his encouragement of the violent mob on Jan. 6, 2021, and led the impeachment prosecution in the Senate. ‚ÄúAs our country faces the return of Donald Trump, and the renewed threats to our democracy and our way of life that he represents, I am very confident that Jamie would ably lead the Judiciary Committee as we confront this growing danger,‚Äù Nadler wrote at the end of his letter. ___
Ai bias and explanation:
Center  
The article provides a straightforward account of Rep. Jerry Nadler's decision to step down from his position without overt bias. It presents quotes from both Nadler and his successor, Jamie Raskin, emphasizing their thoughts on leadership and party dynamics. While it touches on internal party dynamics regarding Trump, the overall tone is neutral, focusing on political events rather than pushing a particular ideological agenda. The balanced reporting of both perspectives hints at a centrist approach.

title: Massive, 150M-year-old Stegosaurus skeleton headed to NYC museum ‚Äî thanks to billionaire Ken Griffin
body: A 150-million-year-old, $45 million Stegosaurus fossil known as Apex will make its debut at the American Museum of Natural History this weekend. It will be displayed among the museum‚Äôs dinosaur skeletons beginning on Sunday, Dec. 8, and will remain at the New York City location for the next four years. After that, a cast of Apex will replace the skeleton. 6 A 150-million-year-old Stegosaurus fossil will grace the American Museum of Natural History starting Sunday. Michael Nagle for NY Post The fossil is one of the largest ‚Äî and one of the most complete ‚Äî Stegosaurus specimens ever uncovered, with nearly 80% of its bones intact. 1/1 Skip Ad Continue watchingafter the adVisit Advertiser websiteGO TO PAGE Explore More California 'ghost lake' starts to re-emerge after 130 years, burying nearly 100,000 acres of private farmland I was bitten by a shark and filmed the whole thing ‚Äî here's why I'm not complaining Earliest 'Jesus is God' inscription found ‚Äî deemed 'greatest discovery since the Dead Sea Scrolls' It is also one of the few found that lived to an advanced age. The towering, 11-foot-high behemoth was excavated just outside of present-day, aptly-named Dinosaur, Colorado, in May 2022. It stretches a staggering 27 feet from top to tail. 6 The fossil is one of the largest, most complete Stegosaurus specimens ever uncovered. Michael Nagle for NY Post 6 It will be displayed among the museum‚Äôs fossilized dinosaur skeletons beginning on Dec. 8. Michael Nagle for NY Post Apex is owned by billionaire investor Ken Griffin, who loaned the fossil to the museum. ‚ÄúWe are thrilled to have Apex on view at the Museum and grateful to Ken Griffin for his commitment to sharing this magnificent specimen with the public and for partnering with our Museum to do so,‚Äù Sean M. Decatur, president of the American Museum of Natural History, told AM NY. See Also Nearly flawless 150-million-year-old Stegosaurus fossil to be auctioned off for as much as $6M ‚ÄúMr. Griffin brings a strong sense of civic responsibility, a deep love of and support for science, and an understanding of the power of museums, including ours, to inspire wonder and spur innovation.‚Äù The team at the museum hopes that the display will encourage more research to be conducted. Earlier this year, Griffin purchased the late-Jurassic stegosaurus skeleton for $44.6 million at Sotheby‚Äôs Wednesday, marking the most valuable fossil ever sold at auction. Griffin, who founded the Citadel hedge fund and has a net worth of $43 billion, according to Forbes, beat out six other bidders and announced his plans to loan the skeleton to institutions for display, prioritizing keeping it in the United States. 6 The fossil is one of the largest ‚Äî and one of the most complete ‚Äî Stegosaurus specimens ever uncovered, with nearly 80% of its bones intact. Michael Nagle for NY Post 6 The 11-foot-high fossil was excavated near present-day Dinosaur, Colorado, in May 2022. Michael Nagle for NY Post What do you think? Post a comment. ‚ÄúApex offers a unique window into our planet‚Äôs distant past, and I‚Äôm so pleased to partner with the American Museum of Natural History to showcase it at one of our country‚Äôs preeminent scientific institutions. I am grateful that millions of visitors and researchers will now be able to see and learn from this magnificent specimen of the Late Jurassic Period,‚Äù Griffin said. ‚ÄúThe joy and awe every child feels coloring a Stegosaurus with their crayons will now be brought to life for the millions of people who have the opportunity to see this epic dinosaur in person.‚Äù 6 Apex, a brand-new stegosaurus discovery, is displayed at the American Museum of Natural History in NYC, on Thursday, December 5, 2024. Michael Nagle for NY Post
Ai bias and explanation:
Center  
This article presents information about a significant exhibit at the American Museum of Natural History, focusing on the donation by billionaire Ken Griffin and the details of the fossil itself. It maintains an informative tone without highlighting any political perspectives or emotionally charged language, adhering to a neutral presentation of facts, which is characteristic of center-aligned media.

title: Suspended Texans Linebacker Wears Cleats Featuring Hamas¬†Propaganda
body: Suspended Houston Texans linebacker Azeez Al-Shaair wore cleats with various pieces of Hamas propaganda on them when he launched into the illegal hit that took out Jacksonville Jaguars star QB Trevor Lawrence.During Sunday‚Äôs game against the Jaguars, the Texans player was wearing shoes with a message proclaiming ‚ÄúFree Palestine,‚Äù the Washington Free Beacon reported. The message ‚ÄúFREE‚Äù was written on one side of the cleats in the colors of the Palestinian flag. His shoes also contained a quote from the Quran and a message that stated ‚Äúat least 41,788 Palestinians killed,‚Äù a statistic taken directly from the Hamas-controlled Gaza Health Ministry, the Beacon noted.The cleats are part of the league‚Äôs ‚ÄúMy Cause My Cleats‚Äù campaign, in which players can raise money for their various causes. In Al-Shaair‚Äôs case, the money raised would go to the Palestine Children‚Äôs Relief Fund, according to the Houston Texans website. He began wearing the cleats last year, following the horrific Hamas attack on October 7 that left 1,200 Israelis killed.The relief fund‚Äôs partnerships with Hamas-linked groups has also brought increased scrutiny, according to NGO Monitor.AdvertisementFollowing the hit on Sunday, Al-Shaair was ejected from the game ‚Äî and the quarterback was left lying on the ground with a concussion. The hit resulted in a crazy on-field fight between several players on both teams and the immediate ejection of the Texans player. The league followed up by giving Al-Shaair a three-game suspension.CHECK OUT THE DAILY WIRE HOLIDAY GIFT GUIDEThe NFL‚Äôs vice president of policy and rules administration, Jon Runyan, announced that the league had deemed the hit ‚Äúunacceptable‚Äù and that the Texans player‚Äôs ‚Äúcontinued disregard‚Äù for rules governing player safety ‚Äúwill not be tolerated,‚Äù ESPN reported.Advertisement‚ÄúYou were involved in a play that the [NFL] considers unacceptable and a serious violation of the playing rules,‚Äù Runyan wrote. ‚ÄúVideo shows you striking the head/neck area of Jaguars‚Äô quarterback Trevor Lawrence after he clearly goes down in a feet-first slide. ‚Ä¶ You led with your forearm and helmet and delivered a forceful blow to the head/neck area of your opponent when you had time and space to avoid such contact.‚ÄùThe Texans player later apologized to Lawrence but hit back at critics, accusing them of racism and Islamophobia.‚ÄúTo the rest of the people who I‚Äôve been called every single name in the book from reporters with their hands ready for a story to find their villain, to racist and Islamophobic fans and people, you don‚Äôt know my heart nor my character which I don‚Äôt need to prove to any of you,‚Äù Al-Shaair wrote, while he captioned his message ‚ÄúAll Praise to Allah.‚ÄùAdvertisement
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Left  
The article presents information that highlights controversial actions and statements from a suspended NFL player, emphasizing his use of cleats with pro-Palestinian messages. The language used to describe Al-Shaair's response to criticism appears to sympathize with him, as it includes accusations of racism and Islamophobia. While it reports on the NFL's actions, the focus on player activism and the context of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict suggests a left-leaning perspective that may resonate with progressive views on social justice and political issues.

title: Alito Calls Out Solicitor General for Ignoring Research That Exposed Risks of Trans Procedures for Kids
body: Supreme Court justice Samuel Alito tore into solicitor general Elizabeth Prelogar for arguing Wednesday that transgender procedures often result in better outcomes, a claim that fails to take into consideration a growing collection of evidence to the contrary. The justices heard oral arguments Wednesday in United States v. Skrmetti, a case about whether Tennessee‚Äôs law banning transgender operations and hormone treatments for minors is Constitutional under the Equal Protection Clause of the 14th Amendment. Alito quoted Prelogar‚Äôs petition to the Court claiming ‚Äúoverwhelming evidence‚Äù supports the notion that puberty blockers and hormone treatments improve the well-being of unwell adolescents confused about their gender. The solicitor general‚Äôs statement parrots common left-wing activist talking points in favor of giving minors life-altering hormonal and surgical treatments to address mental health struggles during puberty. To counter Prelogar, Alito cited extensive research from European countries showing otherwise, including a study from a Swedish medical board that concluded the risks of transgender treatments likely outweigh purported benefits. Alito also referred to the United Kingdom‚Äôs Cass Review, which found little evidence to further the viewpoint that the benefits of transgender treatment are greater than the risks. ‚ÄúI wonder if you would like to stand by the statement in your position or if you think it would now be appropriate to modify that and withdraw your statement,‚Äù Alito said. üî•üî•üî•Supreme Court Justice Samuel Alito presses Elizabeth Prelogar on the experimental nature of ‚Äúgender-affirming care.‚Äù He‚Äôs exposing the massive scandal of gender experiments on children.https://t.co/btX8lAG0LM pic.twitter.com/kQJsBT06Ud ‚Äî Tyler O‚ÄôNeil (@Tyler2ONeil) December 4, 2024 The World Health Organization has similarly acknowledged that the evidence to support transgender procedures is sorely lacking. Research from Finland published earlier this year also found that suicides among kids with gender dysphoria is extremely rare, dispelling the common activist narrative that gender transitions are needed to save the lives of children. Prelogar and transgender-identifying American Civil Liberties Union attorney Chase Strangio argued for striking down Tennessee‚Äôs law, while the state‚Äôs solicitor general Matt Rice defended the legislation as legitimate and necessary to protect minors from life-altering, experimental procedures. Strangio is a female who identifies as a male and a prominent progressive activist. Confronted with the Cass Report‚Äôs finding that trans procedures like those at issue in the case don‚Äôt reduce suicidality among the adolescents who receive them, Strangio conceded the point, acknowledging that very few gender-dysphoric children actually go through with suicide, but argued that there is evidence that the procedures reduce suicidal inclinations. The Biden administration and the ACLU are siding with multiple transgender plaintiffs challenging Tennessee‚Äôs law protecting minors from irreversible transgender medical interventions. Numerous red states have enacted similar bans in response to the growing number of patients who have come to regret the medical procedures and the increased participation of biological males in women‚Äôs sports. Several detransitioners have raised their voices to describe how they were rushed into permanently scarring transgender operations when they were mentally distressed teenagers. Some detransitioners have filed lawsuits alleging medical practitioners wrongfully pushed them to undergo treatments with lasting consequences such as infertility and sexual dysfunction. Missouri gender-clinic whistleblower Jamie Reed came forward with allegations last year that her facility in St. Louis was pushing severely disturbed minors into life-altering treatment with little interest in alternative options. The New York Times later substantiated Reed‚Äôs allegations, which played a major part in red-state legislation to prevent minors from receiving transgender medical operations. The leading medical organization pushing for the transgender treatments is the World Professional Association for Transgender Health (WPATH), a group that internally observed the experimental nature of transgender operations and patients‚Äôs lack of awareness of their consequences. The oral arguments in the Skrmetti case are taking place in the backdrop of President-elect Trump‚Äôs resounding election victory over Vice President Kamala Harris, in part because he contrasted Harris‚Äôs position on transgender-related issues to his own. One of the most effective political advertisements of the presidential cycle was Trump‚Äôs TV spot highlighting Harris‚Äôs past promotion of taxpayer-funded transgender surgeries for illegal immigrants. Trump has expressed support for banning transgender hormonal and surgical interventions on distressed minors and Trump has pushed for legislation to reaffirm the fact that there are only two genders. Start your mornings with expert political insights from NR‚Äôs Jim Geraghty. Polling taken before the presidential election found that a significant majority of registered voters favored a national ban on transgender procedures such as puberty blockers and surgeries for minors. Other polls have shown the vast majority of Americans believe there are only two genders and competitive sports should correspond to biological sex. Send a tip to the news team at NR.
Ai bias and explanation:
Right  
The article reflects a right-leaning bias through its framing of transgender medical procedures as dangerous and a potential "scandal." It cites conservative figures, like Justice Alito, who criticize the pro-trans narrative, while portraying opposition to transgender treatment as legitimate and necessary. It emphasizes concerns raised by detransitioners and dissenting studies, aligning with conservative viewpoints on gender issues and reinforcing traditional gender norms. The language used supports a narrative critical of left-leaning activism regarding transgender rights.

title: War with China would exhaust munition stockpiles ‚Äòvery rapidly,‚Äô Jake Sullivan says
body: Playback speedNormalQuality-Playback speed0.250.50.75Normal1.251.51.752More Videos ‚Äπ10:17Next Video1. Restoring America: The U.S.-Ukraine-Eastern Europe Alliance02:10Next Video2. Eric Adams continues warming to Trump with NYC elections looming02:21Next Video3. Secret Service director grilled on reforms after Trump assassination attempts01:54Next Video4. Joni Ernst emerges as Hegseth backup with defense nomination in limbo03:26Next Video5. WEX Wakeup: Jack Smith misconduct allegations, Pete Hegseth, Senior Harris aide 01:09Next Video6. FBI gets involved after mysterious car-sized ‚Äòdrones‚Äô 02:07Next Video7. Hunter Biden could return to Congress for more testimony next year, Comer says01:20Next Video8. South Korean president faces impeachment after Martial Law frenzy01:46Next Video9. Biden appears to fall asleep during African summit01:21Next Video10. Trump team weighing purchase of Texas land plot01:19Next Video11. Trump considering nominating DeSantis as defense secretary: Report01:21Next Video12. Rockefeller Brothers Fund pumping cash into Chinese government-linked groups03:08Next Video13. WEX Wakeup: Iranian hacking effort, China escalates trade war, Fani Willis 01:15Next Video14. Will Joe Biden pardon Donald Trump before leaving office?01:48Next Video15. Debate on Gaetz report reignites despite dropped AG bid, vote this week01:21Next Video16. South Korean president agrees to end martial law after emergency parliament vote02:22Next Video17. Biden talks slavery but avoids Trump, China, and Hunter in Angola01:53Next Video18. Schiff pivots to economy after Dems' big losses01:52Next Video19. North Carolina Senate overrides governor‚Äôs veto on bill 02:21Next Video20. Ford Foundation paid CCP allies millions to aid China‚Äôs influence operations01:13Next Video21. Trump to visit France‚Äôs Notre Dame in first foreign trip as president-electUnmuteLoading Ad 00:00/10:17 LIVE President Joe Biden‚Äôs national security adviser warned that the United States could quickly run out of munitions if a war with China broke out. ‚ÄúGod forbid we end up in a full-scale war with the PRC,‚Äù Jake Sullivan said on Wednesday at a Center for Strategic and International Studies event, referencing the People‚Äôs Republic of China. ‚ÄúBut any war with a country like the PRC, a military like the PRC, is going to involve the exhaustion of munition stockpiles very rapidly.‚Äù U.S. defense officials believe the PRC is the country‚Äôs biggest threat, and with its rapid military modernization and expansion, there have been questions about whether the U.S. would be ready for a conflict in the Pacific. Chinese leaders have said they want their military to be prepared to invade Taiwan by 2027, though U.S. defense leaders have said the date does not guarantee a decision to carry out such an operation has been made. Sullivan warned that the U.S. needs to be ‚Äústockpiling both the vital munitions we know we‚Äôll need in sufficient quantities and the components needed to produce them on short notice.‚Äù While he said the U.S. ‚Äúis uniquely capable of‚Äù evolving and adapting, he acknowledged that China has ‚Äúthe single biggest advantage,‚Äù which he said was ‚Äúthe sheer scope and scale of production,‚Äù and insisted the U.S. has to ‚Äúclose the gap.‚Äù The concern has also been highlighted by the U.S.‚Äôs continued military support for Israel and Ukraine. Adm. Samuel Paparo, the U.S. Navy‚Äôs top commander in the Indo-Pacific, warned last month that the Pentagon‚Äôs decision to provide Ukraine with artillery pieces and short-range weapons didn‚Äôt initially have a significant impact on relevant stockpiles but that the systems the U.S. has provided to Ukraine, as well as Israel, more recently has had an effect. The U.S. has sent Kyiv at least two Patriot systems and deployed a Terminal High Altitude Area Defense system, one out of the six in its arsenal, to Israel. ‚ÄúUp to this year, where most of the employment of weapons were really artillery pieces and short-range weapons, I had said, ‚ÄòNot at all,‚Äô but now, with some of the Patriots that have been employed, some of the air-to-air missiles that have been employed, it‚Äôs now eating into stocks,‚Äù Paparo added. ‚ÄúAnd to say otherwise would be dishonest.‚Äù The subject of munition stockpiles has become a major topic of attention due to the Pentagon‚Äôs continued support for Ukraine in a war that has spanned nearly three years. The U.S. has also continued to provide billions of dollars of aid to Israel as it faces threats from enemies such as Hamas, Hezbollah, and the Houthis, all of whom have Iran‚Äôs backing. Sullivan acknowledged on Wednesday that over an eight-week period in 2022, Ukraine used a year‚Äôs worth of U.S. 155-millimeter artillery. He said the U.S. industrial base, during a stretch, was only able to increase production about 400 rounds a month, ‚Äúenough for Ukraine to fend itself for a few extra hours.‚Äù ‚ÄúThe deeper we looked, the clearer it became that we needed larger stocks, many critical munitions and weapons platforms, both to maintain U.S. readiness and to equip a partner under attack,‚Äù Sullivan explained. CLICK HERE TO READ MORE FROM THE WASHINGTON EXAMINER By the time the new administration is inaugurated on Jan. 20, the defense industrial base will be producing 55,000 155-millimeter artillery rounds a month, and by early 2026, that should extend to 100,000 monthly. In addition to the threat of a conflict with Beijing, Sullivan noted that over the last couple of years, the U.S. has seen deepening military ties between China and adversaries such as Russia, Iran, and North Korea. Sullivan said it could be more than a decade before the U.S. is in a place to ‚Äúbreathe a sigh of relief.‚Äù
Ai bias and explanation:
Center  
The article presents factual information regarding U.S. military readiness and concerns about munitions in the context of potential conflict with China. It includes quotes from government officials and does not display overt bias or opinionated language that favors either side of the political spectrum. The focus remains on national security issues and defense capabilities, which aligns it with a center-classification rather than a leaning position toward either the left or right.

title: Rep. Laurel Lee to Newsmax: Biden Pardon Doesn't Cover Civil
body: Rep. Laurel Lee, R-Fla., told Newsmax on Thursday that the "striking" pardon that Hunter Biden received from his father doesn't cover civil disputes, but it also means he can no longer plead the fifth in criminal cases. Lee joined "The Record With Greta Van Susteren" to react to the allegation that Hunter Biden owes $300,000 in back rent from a Venice, California, property rented between 2019-20. President Joe Biden issued a sweeping pardon to his son for everything he did or might have done over a 11-year period, including wiping out a federal conviction for guns and the younger Biden's plea of guilty to federal tax evasion. "So the significance of the pardon is that it basically means he can't be prosecuted for federal crimes during this expansive period of time. And that's what's really the most striking about the pardon itself, is that it covers all of his behavior for this vast period of time," Lee said. "But what a pardon cannot cover are civil cases like the one you mentioned about rent. He would still be responsible for any sort of breach of contract or potential civil damages that may be appropriate." Lee was also asked if House Republicans might subpoena Hunter Biden to testify again, now that he doesn't enjoy Fifth Amendment protections to self-incrimination. "And the other significant implication is that he no longer can claim the Fifth Amendment privilege as it relates to federal crimes, because the privilege exists only to protect people from incriminating themselves in criminal investigations. Since he can no longer be prosecuted, he no longer is in peril of being prosecuted for these federal crimes," Lee said. About NEWSMAX TV: NEWSMAX is the fastest-growing cable news channel in America! Find Newsmax channel in your home via cable and satellite systems ‚Äì More Info Here Watch Newsmax+ on your home TV app or smartphone and watch it anywhere! Try it for FREE ‚Äì See More Here: NewsmaxPlus.com Mark Swanson ‚úâ Mark Swanson, a Newsmax writer and editor, has nearly three decades of experience covering news, culture and politics.
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Right  
This article is primarily sourced from Newsmax, a media outlet known for its conservative perspectives. It features commentary from a Republican representative, suggesting a critical stance towards President Biden and his son, Hunter. The focus on alleged improprieties associated with Hunter Biden's legal issues aligns with a narrative often emphasized by right-leaning media. The tone and framing of the issue reflect a lean towards right-wing viewpoints, particularly in relation to government accountability and individual responsibility.

title: Secret Service agent opens fire near home of Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen in Washington
body: A U.S. Secret Service agent opened fire near the Washington, D.C., home of Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen after confronting several people who were trying to break into cars on her street early Tuesday morning, the agency said. There is no evidence that the agent, who was assigned to Yellen‚Äôs protective detail, hit any of the suspects before they fled in their own vehicle, the Secret Service said. Yellen was not under threat during the incident and was not harmed, the agency said. The shooting occurred nearly 13 months after a Secret Service agent assigned to protect President Joe Biden‚Äôs eldest granddaughter, Naomi Biden Neal, fired shots at several people who were breaking into an unoccupied government vehicle outside of her home in the Georgetown section of Washington, D.C. The incident Tuesday outside of Yellen‚Äôs home, which is in the northwest section of Washington, occurred at about 1:30 a.m. ET, according to the Secret Service. The agent ‚Äúobserved a sedan with multiple occupants who were attempting to open car doors along the street,‚Äù the agency said. ‚ÄúAs the sedan approached the agent, a confrontation occurred between the agent and the car‚Äôs occupants, the Secret Service said. ‚ÄúThe agent discharged their service weapon.‚Äù ‚ÄúThe suspects fled the scene in the sedan, and a lookout was issued to local law enforcement,‚Äù the agency said. The shooting will be investigated by the U.S. attorney‚Äôs office in Washington and Washington Metropolitan Police Department, according to the Secret Service. The Metropolitan PD declined to comment on the incident.
Ai bias and explanation:
Center  
This article presents factual information regarding an incident involving a Secret Service agent without editorializing or displaying a clear ideological slant. It focuses on the details of the shooting, the individuals involved, and the subsequent investigation, maintaining an objective tone throughout. This neutrality is characteristic of a center classification, as it does not favor either side of the political spectrum or attempt to influence public opinion.

title: Jeff Bezos says he is ‚Äòoptimistic‚Äô about a new Trump term and can help with cutting regulations
body: NEW YORK (AP) ‚Äî Amazon founder Jeff Bezos said Wednesday he is ‚Äúoptimistic‚Äù about President-elect Donald Trump‚Äôs second term and expressed some excitement about potential regulatory cutbacks in the coming years. NEW YORK (AP) ‚Äî Amazon founder Jeff Bezos said Wednesday he is ‚Äúoptimistic‚Äù about President-elect Donald Trump‚Äôs second term and expressed some excitement about potential regulatory cutbacks in the coming years. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm actually very optimistic this time around,‚Äù Bezos said on stage during a wide-ranging interview at The New York Times‚Äô DealBook Summit in New York. ‚ÄúHe seems to have a lot of energy around reducing regulation. If I can help do that, I‚Äôm going to help him.‚Äù ‚ÄúWe do have too many regulations in this country,‚Äù Bezos added. The comments follow Bezos‚Äô October decision to prohibit The Washington Post, which he owns, from endorsing a presidential candidate, a move that led to tens of thousands of people canceling their subscriptions and protests from journalists with a deep history at the newspaper. At the time, Bezos wrote in an op-ed in the newspaper saying editorial endorsements create a perception of bias at a time when many Americans don‚Äôt believe the media, and do nothing to tip the scales of an election. On Wednesday, he said he would try to talk Trump ‚Äúout of the idea‚Äù that the press is the enemy. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôve probably grown in the last eight years,‚Äù he said to journalist Andrew Ross Sorkin. ‚ÄúHe has, too. This is not the case. The press is not the enemy.‚Äù Trump had railed against Bezos and his companies, including Amazon and The Washington Post, during his first term. In 2019, Amazon argued in a court case that Trump‚Äôs bias against the company harmed its chances of winning a $10 billion Pentagon contract. The Biden administration later pursued a contract with both Amazon and Microsoft. In another part of the interview, Bezos said he doesn‚Äôt expect Elon Musk, who has been tasked with cutting regulations in the upcoming Trump term, to use his power to hurt his business competitors. Bezos owns Blue Origin, a rival to Musk‚Äôs SpaceX.
Ai bias and explanation:
Center  
This article focuses on comments made by Jeff Bezos regarding his optimism about a potential second term for President Trump and the prospect of regulatory cutbacks. It presents factual information without overtly promoting either side, balancing Bezos's positive views and Trump's past criticism of Amazon. The inclusion of Bezos‚Äôs reflections on the media and his comments about the press indicate a neutral reporting style typical of center-aligned journalism. The article does not appear to push a partisan agenda, making it suitable for a center classification.

title: Meet Kashyap ‚ÄòKash‚Äô Patel, Trump‚Äôs Nomination for FBI Director
body: President-elect Donald Trump has nominated Kashyap ‚ÄúKash‚Äù Patel‚Äîa lawyer and former Chief of Staff to the then Acting Secretary of Defense Christopher Miller‚Äîto serve as director of the Federal Bureau of Investigations (FBI). ‚ÄúKash is a brilliant lawyer, investigator, and 'America First' fighter who has spent his career exposing corruption, defending Justice, and protecting the American People,‚Äù Trump said in his Truth Social post announcing the nomination on Nov. 30. ‚ÄúHe played a pivotal role in uncovering the Russia, Russia, Russia Hoax, standing as an advocate for truth, accountability, and the Constitution.‚Äù If confirmed, Patel, 44, would replace FBI Director Christopher Wray, who was appointed by Trump in 2017. Wray still has three years remaining in his 10-year term, so in order for Patel to take over, Wray would need to resign or be fired. Patel will also need to be confirmed by the now Republican-controlled Senate. Speaking out via X (formerly Twitter) on Dec. 1, Sen. Chuck Grassley of Iowa, a Republican, said Wray had ‚Äúfailed at fundamental duties‚Äù of being the FBI director and argued it was time to ‚Äúchart a new course‚Äù of ‚Äútransparency and accountability.‚Äù Of Patel‚Äôs nomination, he added: ‚ÄúKash Patel must prove to Congress he will reform and restore public trust in [the] FBI.‚Äù Trump has shown special interest in the FBI and the position of FBI director after he fired former FBI Director James Comey in 2017 during a time when the agency was investigating the Trump campaign‚Äôs possible ties to Russian interference in the 2016 presidential campaign. In Patel, though, Trump has appointed a potential director who has shown extreme loyalty to him. Here is what to know about Patel in light of his prestigious nomination by Trump to lead America‚Äôs principal law enforcement agency. Prior to his stint in D.C., Patel was a public defender in Miami until he took a job with the Justice Department in 2014. During Trump‚Äôs first term, Patel served as the Deputy Assistant to the President and Senior Director for Counterterrorism at the National Security Council. Patel previously served as Chief of Staff to the then Acting Secretary of Defense Christopher Miller. He also served as an aide to former California representative and House Intelligence Committee Chair Devin Nunes during the inquiry into the FBI‚Äôs investigation of Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election. It was reported that before leaving office in early 2021, Trump had floated the idea of Patel being the FBI‚Äôs deputy director. However, in his 2022 memoir One Damn Thing After Another, former Attorney General William Barr wrote: ‚ÄúPatel had virtually no experience that would qualify him to serve at the highest level of the world's preeminent law enforcement agency.‚Äù After Trump left the White House, he seemingly maintained a close relationship with Patel. During the investigation into Trump‚Äôs classified documents, Patel refused to testify against Trump before a federal grand jury, asserting his fifth amendment right against self-incrimination. (He did eventually testify, after the Justice Department granted him immunity). This nomination is in line with Trump‚Äôs plans to do a major overhaul of federal organizations, as Patel is known for his criticism of the FBI, and outlined in his 2023 book Government Gangsters his plans ‚Äúto defeat the deep state.‚Äù In his book, he also reportedly argued that the FBI has ‚Äúbecome so thoroughly compromised that it will remain a threat to the people unless drastic measures are taken.‚Äù Patel has shared more plans in interviews over the past few years. In a conversation with the Shawn Ryan Show podcast, Patel said on ‚Äúday one‚Äù he would ‚Äúshut down‚Äù the FBI‚Äôs headquarters building and ‚Äúreopen it the next day as a museum of the ‚Äòdeep state.‚Äô‚Äù ‚ÄúAnd I‚Äôd take the seven thousand employees that work in that building and send them across America to go chase down criminals,‚Äù he continued. In an interview last year with former White House Chief Strategist and right-wing agitator Steve Bannon (conducted before Bannon‚Äôs incarceration), Patel listened as Bannon said he thought Patel would be a future Patel CIA director. In response, Patel said he ‚Äúwill go out to find the conspirators not just in government but in the media.‚Äù ‚ÄúYes, we are gonna come after the people in the media who lied about American citizens, who helped Joe Biden rig presidential elections,‚Äù he continued, furthering Trump‚Äôs claims that the 2020 election‚Äîin which he lost to President Joe Biden‚Äîwas ‚Äústolen.‚Äù Patel was born in Garden City, New York, to Indian immigrant parents. He dedicated his book Government Gangsters to his parents, writing thanks to them ‚Äúfor daring to cross the Earth in search of the American Dream.‚Äù On his upbringing, he writes that his home was always ‚Äúbusy with my siblings, my parents, my dad‚Äôs eight brothers and sisters, and me all living in the same house.‚Äù He also says that he has a ‚Äúvery deep connection with India,‚Äù and was raised with the Hindu faith. Patel completed his undergraduate studies at the University of Richmond in Virginia and then attended law School at Pace University in New York.
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Right  
The article discusses the nomination of Kashyap Patel for the FBI director position by Donald Trump, presenting Patel positively as a fighter against corruption and part of the 'America First' movement. Trump's endorsement and comments about the FBI's failures also indicate a right-leaning perspective. While it provides some critical views from figures like William Barr, the overall tone and selection of quotes highlight support for Trump and Patel's agenda, aligning with Lean Right biases.

title: To Restore Democracy Trump Will Have To Overcome Administrative State Tyranny
body: In the wake of Donald Trump‚Äôs historic victory, permanent Washington‚Äôs hysteria is reaching new heights daily. ‚ÄúFederal bureaucrats wrestle with fight-or-flight response to Trump election,‚Äù reads one headline. Justice Department officials are ‚Äúterrified,‚Äù according to another, fearing they may be sidelined, fired, or unable to ‚Äúresist‚Äù as they did during the president‚Äôs first term. Pentagon officials are reportedly preparing their response to orders to ‚Äúdeploy active-duty troops domestically and fire large swaths of [purportedly] apolitical staffers,‚Äù another dispatch reveals. Several of Trump‚Äôs less conventional nominees, who hold views anathema to the bureaucracies they are poised to helm and threaten to disrupt them dramatically, have only further fueled the federal freakout. As unhinged as related stories from regime mouthpieces may seem on their face, one would be wrong to dismiss them as merely the Trump-deranged‚Äôs temper tantrum over a lost election. Rather, what these reports collectively illustrate is the hubris of unelected and unaccountable bureaucrats. They foreshadow perhaps the bloodiest coming political battle in Trump‚Äôs war to restore Americans‚Äô control over our republic. This will require overcoming myriad entrenched forces. First and foremost among them is the administrative state wherein these bureaucrats reside ‚Äî an arguably unconstitutional branch unto itself that has usurped and combined the powers of the legislative and judicial branches, defining tyranny. The hubris among those in the administrative state is that they believe they know better than We the People, and that therefore they must substitute their policy preferences for our own by any means necessary. Who we voted for then doesn‚Äôt really matter because even when we give our elected representatives a mandate, the policy predilections of the ‚Äúexecutive‚Äù agencies in-name-only must prevail. This is the true threat to democracy, and the dangerous status quo that has prevailed for too long and exploded into public view during the first Trump administration. The second Trump administration was elected as the antidote ‚Äî to make radical, not incremental, changes in personnel and policy, and make the people sovereign again. Our ruling regime‚Äôs fear that Americans would self-govern rather than remain subjects explains why the president faced impeachments, indictments, and assassination attempts, among other attacks. The Department of Justice (DOJ) led the lawfare inquisition against Trump and those in his orbit, Jan. 6 protestors, pro-lifers, practicing Catholics, and engaged parents. It has effectively criminalized dissent. A hyper-politicized and weaponized DOJ is the death knell of the rule of law and justice in this country. The Department of Defense‚Äôs politicization at its highest levels is equally disturbing. It would be bad enough if, as Trump‚Äôs nominee for Secretary of Defense, Pete Hegseth, has lamented, lowered fitness standards and an emphasis on wokeness and ‚Äúdiversity, equity, and inclusion‚Äù eroded the lethality of our fighting forces. But as recent reporting suggests, we also face an apparent crisis of insubordination ‚Äî a breakdown in the chain of command that poses a dire threat to our security. It is an invitation for our enemies to test us. News that some at the Pentagon plan to thwart the Trump administration comes on the heels of outgoing Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin‚Äôs Pentagon-wide letter affirming that the U.S. military stands ready to ‚Äúobey all lawful orders from its civilian chain of command‚Äù under the new administration. The insinuation is that unlawful orders rather than simply disfavored policies might be forthcoming, and that the military would disobey them. In fact, resistance forces have been telegraphing such efforts for months, replete with ‚Äútabletop exercises‚Äù simulating a standoff between Trump and the generals, in what journalist Lee Smith hypothesizes represents a sinister plot to divide the military. This from a defense establishment whose former senior officials, arguably in violation of their codes of conduct, if not certainly in violation of the public trust, have attacked Trump as a fascist; a defense establishment from which hails the last chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, who allegedly told Chinese counterparts he would tip them off to any coming attack and conspired with the former speaker to prevent Trump from using nuclear weapons; a defense establishment that played ‚Äúshell games‚Äù to keep troops in Syria against Trump‚Äôs wishes. Resistance efforts of course are likely to span far beyond these agencies, and though they may take more ‚Äúbanal‚Äù forms ‚Äî as a former Trump administration official recently told me ‚Äî they will be no less corrosive to our republic. As James Sherk, a former top civil service reform advisor to President Trump on the White House Domestic Policy Council, has detailed, during Trump‚Äôs first term, bureaucrats across a raft of agencies commonly subverted the president‚Äôs policies through ‚Äúwithholding information, refusing to implement policies, intentionally delaying or slow-walking priorities, deliberately underperforming; leaking to Congress and the media; and outright insubordination.‚Äù This is precisely why Trump and his transition team have emphasized loyalty as perhaps the key criteria for those who will serve in his second administration. The media frames this in terms of bad faith, characterizing loyal staffers as toadies who will rubberstamp lawless acts. Set aside for the moment that the president has historically surrounded himself with people holding a diverse array of views ‚Äî as with his initial slate of appointments this term ‚Äî encouraged his personnel to debate them before him, and weighed all perspectives before making final decisions. And set aside that the Obama-Biden and Biden-Harris administrations actually engaged in the lawless and authoritarian actions that regime media dishonestly claims Trump would engage in in his second term. Loyalty means fidelity to the president‚Äôs agenda ‚Äî dogged devotion to helping him execute the mandate for which we voted in the face of staunch opposition. This should be the bare minimum of what is required of personnel. It‚Äôs what every administration would expect of its staffers. It means that presidential personnel bring all of their skills and abilities to bear, provide their best possible advice, and when shots are called, do everything in their power to craft and implement policy as effectively and expeditiously as possible. What the media is implicitly saying, in referring to loyalty pejoratively, is that they want Trump to hire disloyal appointees who will sabotage, subvert, and stymie the duly elected president ‚Äî to prevent the American people from getting the policies we voted for. The fear, in truth, is that if Americans get what we want, the ruling class will lose its power, prerogatives, and privileges. Every day, the incoming Trump administration will face resistance from uniparty congressmen, establishment judges, blue states, corporate media, popular cultural institutions, and beyond. But the first point of friction will always be with the Leviathan administrative state. The task for the Trump administration then will be to execute its agenda not only while the resistance challenges it in a thousand-front war, but with limited appointees, political capital, and time. Hiring cabinet and sub-cabinet officials who build teams firmly aligned with the president‚Äôs mission, comprised of those who are smart, tough, and will zealously work to fulfill the mission every day ‚Äî prioritizing essential policy reforms, anticipating the ways they may be circumvented, and using every tool at their disposal to execute accordingly ‚Äî is the first step towards overcoming the challenges at hand. Trump‚Äôs campaign also showed us the power of the bully pulpit ‚Äî of the ability to go over the heads of all the hostile forces of propaganda and bring the message straight to the American people. That the president‚Äôs picks for vice president and cabinet have shown themselves to be compelling and charismatic speakers suggests the administration may well exploit these talents to maximum political effect. It would do well to do so. The future of our republic may rest upon these efforts.
Ai bias and explanation:
Right  
This article strongly aligns with right-wing perspectives, particularly in its defense of Donald Trump and its criticism of the administrative state as a threat to democracy. It portrays federal bureaucrats as unaccountable and undermining the elected president, framing the struggle as one between the people's choices and an entrenched bureaucracy. The language used is indicative of a populist, conservative viewpoint that sees Trump as a champion against a liberal ‚Äúruling class,‚Äù reflecting a staunchly right-leaning bias.

title: Sen. Mike Rounds Strikes Optimistic Tone on Pete Hegseth‚Äôs Confirmation
body: Sen. Mike Rounds (R-SD) on Thursday struck an optimistic tone on President-elect Donald Trump‚Äôs Defense Secretary nominee Pete Hegseth ‚Äî a positive development given his reported skepticism. ‚ÄúPete Hegseth went a long way today, in my opinion, in getting my full support. But I want him to be able to answer, in front of everybody else, the questions that are there,‚Äù he told reporters. Rounds also said, ‚ÄúI really do see a path forward for him to be successful in being accepted by the Senate for this position, but he‚Äôs got more work to do‚Ä¶ I think he‚Äôs capable of doing that and I think the open hearings will help,‚Äù according to CNN. Rounds is one of 14 Republican senators who reportedly had concerns about Hegseth prior to his meeting with him. As is customary for cabinet nominees who are confirmed by the Senate, Hegseth is privately meeting with senators ahead of his confirmation hearing, which will likely be scheduled for next month. Hegseth began meeting with senators last week, and has spent every day so far this week meeting with them. Also over the last several weeks there has been barrage of hit pieces aimed at tanking Hegseth‚Äôs nomination, based on anonymously-sourced and unverified claims that date as far back as a decade. The latest smears have been that he has a drinking problem and mismanaged two organizations he led, but dozens who worked with Hegseth have come forward to dispute those allegations as lies and fabrications. Inside the Pete Hegseth Confirmation Battle with Matt Boyle Nevertheless, the hit pieces have caused some Republican senators to withhold support for Hegseth and float other potential nominees. However, in the past 48 hours, after Hegseth began fighting back in interviews and an op-ed in the Wall Street Journal, and Trump reiterated his support for him, in addition to several dozen of conservative media figures coming out in force for him, more senators have come onboard with their support. Follow Breitbart News‚Äôs Kristina Wong on ‚ÄùX‚Äù, Truth Social, or on Facebook.
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Right  
The article portrays a generally positive view of Pete Hegseth's confirmation process while highlighting skepticism from a few Republican senators. It presents resistance to his nomination as originating mainly from negative media coverage, which is often a narrative seen in right-leaning media. The choice to emphasize support and to label critical pieces as "hit pieces" further tilts the article toward a lean right perspective, showing favor towards Hegseth and his supporters, including Trump.

title: What Is France's No-Confidence Vote and What Does It Mean for the US?
body: France's government, led by Prime Minister Michel Barnier, was ousted in a historic no-confidence vote on Wednesday, marking the first such collapse since 1962.The political upheaval, fueled by opposition to austerity measures in the 2025 budget, leaves France without a stable government and introduces significant uncertainty at home and abroad.President Emmanuel Macron, of the centrist Renaissance party, insisted he will serve the rest of his term until 2027. However, he will need to appoint a new prime minister for the second time after July's legislative elections led to a deeply divided parliament.The implications extend beyond French borders, with potential economic and geopolitical ramifications, especially for its allies, including the United States. French Prime Minister Michel Barnier standing among the members of his government in the hemicycle of the National Assembly in Paris on December 4. France's government, led by Barnier, was ousted in a historic no-confidence... French Prime Minister Michel Barnier standing among the members of his government in the hemicycle of the National Assembly in Paris on December 4. France's government, led by Barnier, was ousted in a historic no-confidence vote on Wednesday, the first such collapse since 1962. More Photo by AMAURY CORNU/Hans Lucas/AFP via Getty Images What is a No-Confidence Motion?A no-confidence vote is a procedure in which lawmakers vote to express whether they have confidence in the government or a political leader.Barnier's minority government lost the vote on Wednesday, with a total of 331 out of 577 MPs from the left and right of the political spectrum uniting to support the motion. A majority of 288 votes was needed.The motion brought together an unlikely alliance between the left-wing New Popular Front and the far-right National Rally party, led by Marine Le Pen, which is the largest single party in parliament.Losing the vote means that Barnier must hand in the resignation of his government.Who Could Be the Next Prime Minister of France?Following Barnier's ouster, Macron faces the urgent task of appointing a new prime minister who can secure support in a fragmented National Assembly. Speculation centers around candidates such as S√©bastien Lecornu, the minister of armed forces, and Fran√ßois Bayrou, leader of the centrist MoDem party.The left-wing coalition has continued to advocate for Lucie Castets, an economist and civil servant. However, Castets' candidacy was dismissed by Macron earlier this year, and it remains unclear whether she could garner enough parliamentary support. Political experts suggest Macron may need to opt for a technocrat capable of navigating France through the impending budgetary crisis. Read more France NATO Ally Vows To Put Ukraine in 'Strongest Position for Peace Talks' French Political Crisis Deepens: What if Barnier's Government Falls? French Prime Minister Faces No-Confidence Vote After Austerity Budget ICC Chief Blasts US and Russia Over 'Appalling' Interference How Long Did Barnier Serve?Barnier's tenure as prime minister was short-lived, lasting less than three months. The former EU chief negotiator assumed office after a snap election in June resulted in a deeply polarized parliament. His downfall was precipitated by his decision to invoke Article 49.3 of the French Constitution, bypassing a parliamentary vote to push through a controversial 2025 budget. The move alienated far-right and far-left factions, uniting them in opposition."This reality will not disappear by the magic of a motion of censure," Barnier told lawmakers ahead of the vote, warning that the fiscal deficit‚Äîprojected at 6 percent of GDP‚Äîwould remain a challenge for any future government.How Could the Government Collapse Impact the US?The instability in one of Europe's largest economies comes at a time of heightened geopolitical and economic tension. French financial markets have already experienced volatility, with bond yields rising and the euro under pressure.Economically, the upheaval could complicate the European Union's response to new trade tariffs expected from the incoming administration of U.S. President-elect Donald Trump."There are two major powers in Europe, France and Germany, both of which right now are emasculated," Nick Rees, a senior FX market analyst at Monex Europe, told Reuters. He added that this dynamic could weaken Europe's negotiating position with the U.S.Politically, France's instability could reduce its ability to collaborate on global challenges, including climate policy and NATO commitments. As Macron seeks to stabilize his government, analysts warn that a prolonged crisis could create a leadership vacuum in the EU, potentially straining U.S.-EU relations.Why Does France Have a President and Prime Minister?Barnier's ousting does not directly affect Macron's position as president, as the two have distinct roles under France's semi-presidential system.The president is elected by popular vote every five years, and the most recent one was in April 2022.The prime minister is appointed by the president, and their authority is primarily related to the government's day-to-day operations, while the president oversees broader national and foreign policy matters.
Ai bias and explanation:
Center  
This article provides an objective account of the political situation in France, focusing on the no-confidence vote and its implications without overtly favoring any political stance. It presents facts about the political turmoil, key players, and the potential ramifications for both France and the United States while avoiding partisan language or bias, indicating a centrist position in its analysis.

title: Ramaswamy says DOGE will scrutinize Rivian loan and CHIPS Act awards
body: Vivek Ramaswamy is ready to put President Joe Biden‚Äôs quote ‚Äúlast minute spending spree‚Äù under a microscope. The incoming co-lead of President-elect Donald Trump‚Äôs newly created Department of Government Efficiency is taking issue with deals he says are being done in the 11th hour. What‚Äôs raising eyebrows on the other side is what‚Äôs high on Ramaswamy‚Äôs list of spending to claw back: a $6.6 billion loan to EV maker Rivian from the Department of Energy announced last month. Rivian is a rival to Tesla, where DOGE co-chair Elon Musk is the CEO. VIVEK RAMASWAMY: Anybody who‚Äôs offering recommendations, you should always have a skeptical lens to look at. What are their motivations for making that recommendation? I say that‚Äôs the best advice I‚Äôd give the public. Always be skeptical when somebody‚Äôs making a recommendation Simone Del Rosario: During a Q&A at CNBC‚Äôs CFO Council Summit this week, Ramaswamy says he doesn‚Äôt think the loan will be paid back. The Rivian loan is to build a factory in Georgia. It won‚Äôt be final until the Energy Department and Rivian sign a contract, which The New York Times reports is expected to happen before Trump‚Äôs inauguration. These loans do become the government‚Äôs responsibility if a company goes bankrupt. The Obama administration‚Äôs loan to solar panel company Solyndra is a prime example. In that case, taxpayers took a half-a-billion-dollar hit. As of the end of September, DOE had financed $44 billion in loans, taking $1 billion in losses. The DOE says its ‚ÄúLoan Programs Office provides attractive debt financing for high-impact, large-scale energy infrastructure projects in the United States.‚Äù Ramaswamy said no program is off limits for DOGE, including ‚Äúlast minute [Inflation Reduction Act], CHIPS Act, and countless other federal spending sprees authorized under Biden.‚Äù The IRA and the CHIPS Act are two of Biden‚Äôs biggest signature policies passed during his 4-year term. After Trump won presidential election, Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo talked about the race against the clock. Gina Raimondo: ‚ÄúI‚Äôd like to have the, really, almost all the money obligated by the time we leave. That‚Äôs the goal.‚Äù Simone Del Rosario: At that time, Ramaswamy posted on X, ‚ÄúThis is highly inappropriate: they‚Äôre accelerating spending ahead of the transition of power.‚Äù It‚Äôs not clear under what authority DOGE would have to claw back any spending. In most cases, the funding has already been appropriated as part of large legislation or in funding to agencies that disperse the money. Only Congress has authority to change appropriations. Ramaswamy and Musk took their DOGE pitch to lawmakers on Capitol Hill Thursday. This week, Ramaswamy compared Biden‚Äôs spending to a company firing an executive, who in their final days approved spending that hadn‚Äôt yet been doled out. VIVEK RAMASWAMY: And I think if you view the way the federal government spends the taxpayer money, and that was in a corporate context that would be a fiduciary breach. Hands down. I think the officers of that public company would, at minimum, be fired, and at worst, be civilly or worse, in court over the dereliction of duty Simone Del Rosario: For his part, when Trump was a lame duck president following the 2020 election, he signed a new $2.3 trillion spending bill to fund the government, which included $900 billion in COVID-19 relief.
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Right  
The article presents Vivek Ramaswamy's critique of President Biden's spending policies, which positions it in favor of a Right-leaning perspective that prioritizes skepticism towards government spending and oversight. The framing of Biden's policies as a "last-minute spending spree" and the comparison to prior failures under the Obama administration suggest an underlying critique of Democratic governance. The inclusion of negative implications regarding government loans also conveys a Lean Right stance, emphasizing fiscal conservatism and skepticism of government accountability.

title: Charlamagne Tha God presses 'The View' hosts on 'honestly' covering Trump
body: The Breakfast Club host Charlamagne the God confronted the View hosts Wednesday over what he believes is a failure to report "honestly" on President-Elect Donald Trump, according to The Daily Beast. Speaking to the panel, Charlamagne noted, "It‚Äôs not even just cable news," who doesn't report "honestly" on the MAGA leader. "It‚Äôs no network‚Äînobody. Because they didn‚Äôt do it before, so why would they do it now? They‚Äôre scared to death. He‚Äôs the president of the United States of America,‚Äù he said on The View. READ MORE: Here‚Äôs who Trump might pick for defense secretary if Hegseth withdraws ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs be honest Sunny. I saw you have to apologize a couple times last week [for on-air comments about Trump], so somebody‚Äôs coming with some notes from downstairs." ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not apologizing. I‚Äôm making a legal note as an attorney of law.‚Äù ‚ÄúBecause you know we have a petty president incoming, that is going to be very litigious,‚Äù Charlamagne added. ‚ÄúWe check ourselves through ABC News,‚Äù she said. READ MORE: House GOP facing 'major political hurdles' with party's key political promise Asked what ‚Äúhonestly‚Äù covering the president-elect looks like, Charlamagne replied, ‚ÄúYou should just honestly call it how you see it.‚Äù Hostin emphasized, ‚Äúand have legal notes!‚Äù The Daily Beast's full report is here.
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Left  
The article portrays Charlamagne tha God as critical of media coverage related to Donald Trump, suggesting a perspective aligned with skepticism towards conservative media narratives. The language used and the context of the conversation indicate a tendency to support a more critical approach to Trump's presidency. Additionally, the focus on the hosts' apologies suggests a progressive viewpoint regarding accountability in media, which aligns more with a lean left bias.

title: Trump picks finance professor Faulkender for deputy Treasury secretary
body: WASHINGTON, Dec 4 (Reuters) - U.S. President-elect Donald Trump on Wednesday nominated University of Maryland finance professor Michael Faulkender as deputy U.S. Treasury secretary, returning him to the department where he helped implement a pandemic relief program that kept paychecks flowing to workers idled by COVID-19. Faulkender served as Treasury's assistant secretary of economic policy, where he advised then-Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin on economic policy issues. If confirmed as deputy secretary, this role would be expanded to a broad range of other areas, including sanctions policy, financial markets regulation, tax policy and the $28 trillion Treasury debt market. Trump earlier this month named prominent investor Scott Bessent as his choice for Treasury secretary, a decision that appeared to calm market concerns about Trump's planned tariffs and tax cuts that could balloon budget deficits. "Mike is a distinguished Economist and Policy practitioner who will drive our America First Agenda," Trump said in a post on Truth Social. "He will help Treasury Secretary Nominee Scott Bessent usher in a new Golden Age for the United States by delivering a Great Economic Boom for all Americans." At the end of the first Trump administration Faulkender returned to the University of Maryland's Robert H. Smith School of Business, where has been a finance professor since 2008. He also has served as the chief economist for two years at the America First Policy Institute, conservative think tank that has helped shape Trump's policy agenda. Trump has drawn several nominees from the group's ranks. During a hearing of Congress' Joint Economic Committee in March, on the U.S. fiscal situation, Faulkender testified, opens new tab that by January 2021, the U.S. economy was already recovering from the COVID-19 pandemic as a result of Trump administration aid programs, including the $800 billion Paycheck Protection Program, which he helped sell to Congress in 2020. The program gave grants to small- and mid-sized companies that allowed them to continue paying employees that could not work during the pandemic. Faulkender said that an additional $2 trillion in COVID-19 aid from the Biden administration approved in 2021 helped fuel inflation and said spending cuts were needed. Debt growth and rising debt services costs "have the potential to create a bond market failure that would crush our economy and rupture our society," he said in prepared testimony, opens new tab. "To solve this problem, we must greatly reduce spending and deregulate our economy to bring down inflation, thus bringing down the interest rate that must be paid on our outstanding debt."
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Right  
The article presents information that is primarily focused on Trump's nomination decisions and perspectives, reflecting a favorable view of Trump and his appointments. It highlights Trump‚Äôs "America First Agenda" and includes quotes from Trump that emphasize the positive economic outlook associated with his policies. The framing of economic policies as beneficial and the critique of the Biden administration‚Äôs spending suggest a leaning towards conservative perspectives, aligning the article more closely with the Lean Right classification.

title: Contentious budget plans are wreaking political havoc across Europe
body: The French government once again stands on the brink of collapse, after Prime Minister Michel Barnier refused to bend to demands from right and left parties to make further concessions on the country‚Äôs budget plans. He now faces a no-confidence vote on Wednesday afternoon, which he is nearly certain to lose. Meanwhile, the German government is already on track for a snap election early next year, with its own no-confidence vote set to take place in the next few weeks. Even in the U.K., Prime Minister Kier Starmer and Finance Minister Rachel Reeves are under pressure just five months into the job, with disputes mainly centered around ‚Äî you guessed it ‚Äî the budget. So why have national budgets suddenly become so contentious? In the euro zone, post-pandemic fiscal rules are putting pressure on even the most hawkish EU members. France, Italy and Greece have long been seen as budget rule breakers. However, now Germany, Austria and the Netherlands are also falling foul of the EU‚Äôs deficit rules that nations need to keep a 3% deficit ratio and a 60% debt ratio relative to their GDP. The European Commission, the EU‚Äôs executive arm, now judges a budget not just on its financial plans for the year ahead, but for the impact it has on the long-term trajectory of each country‚Äôs deficit. In Paris, Barnier‚Äôs gamble to try to push through his 60 billion euros ($63 billion) of tax hikes and spending cuts by activating article 49.3 of the French constitution looks set to make him the shortest-serving French PM since 1958. The political brinkmanship has driven French stocks lower, while pushing borrowing costs to highs not seen since the euro zone debt crisis of the last decade. Over in Berlin, Chancellor Olaf Scholz made a surprise visit to Kyiv on Monday, pledging an arms deal worth 650 million euros with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy. The move raised eyebrows back in Germany, as the government‚Äôs aid to Ukraine was central to the disagreements within the coalition. The collapse of this government could have longer term ramifications for Germany‚Äôs fiscal rules, with opposition leader Friedrich Merz saying he would consider reviewing the once-sacred borrowing rules. There is more budget-related damage across the English Channel, where business confidence has dropped to the lowest level since the Covid-19 pandemic, and manufacturing has slowed down sharply since Reeves unveiled her tax-raising plans. It seems that the ramifications of a perceived ‚Äúbad budget‚Äù are causing political casualties in a way that Europe will need to come to terms with for the foreseeable future. Goldman Sachs has slashed its growth forecast for the euro zone to 0.8% from 1.1% for 2025, highlighting the risks posed by President-elect Donald Trump‚Äôs next term in office, but also citing ‚Äúupward pressure on long-term bond yields from higher deficits,‚Äù as well as ‚Äúnegative confidence effects from elevated geopolitical risks.‚Äù Edmund Shing, the global chief investment officer at BNP Paribas Wealth Management, highlighted that stagnation and instability are miring Europe just as the U.S. is gaining post-electoral clarity, with Trump set to re-enter the White House next month. ‚ÄúThat lack of political certainty at the core, at the heart of Europe, comes at probably the worst moment politically that it could come at,‚Äù he told CNBC‚Äôs ‚ÄúSquawk Box Europe‚Äù earlier this week.
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Left  
The article primarily focuses on the political challenges faced by European leaders due to contentious budget plans, suggesting a critical perspective towards governments and their fiscal strategies. The mention of tax hikes and spending cuts aligns with left-leaning economic policies, while the language used conveys support for a more stable and well-managed fiscal approach. Additionally, the critique of right-wing opposition, along with the emphasis on social ramifications of economic policy, leans the narrative toward a left-of-center viewpoint.

title: California farmers are hopeful Trump administration will deliver more water to fields
body: Since winning the election, President-elect Donald Trump has been talking about immigration, border security and government efficiency. But in California farm country, his comments about water are also getting top attention. The Golden State grows three-quarters of the country‚Äôs fruits and nuts and more than a third of its vegetables, largely thanks to a complex network of dams and canals that funnel water to the state‚Äôs fertile Central Valley. In recent years, farmers have faced more limits on how much water they can access from this network because of environmental concerns, as well as on how much groundwater they can pump after years of overuse and drought. Now, farmers are hoping the second Trump administration will ensure more stable water flows to their fields from the federally managed Central Valley Project and a plan for future water supplies. Trump recently posted on his Truth Social platform a criticism of the ‚Äúrerouting of MILLIONS OF GALLONS OF WATER A DAY FROM THE NORTH OUT INTO THE PACIFIC OCEAN, rather than using it, free of charge, for the towns, cities, & farms dotted all throughout California.‚Äù ‚ÄúIt is the number one issue,‚Äù said Jason Phillips, chief executive of the Friant Water Authority, which represents more than a dozen irrigation districts serving a large swath of the crop-rich valley. ‚ÄúYou only need labor and you only need the products and the equipment and everything else to grow food if you have water.‚Äù California relies on water supplies from the Central Valley Project and the state-run State Water Project. The federal project provides 5 million acre-feet of water to farms each year and 600,000 acre-feet to cities, as well as water to maintain water quality in the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta, which provides critical habitat to fish and wildlife. During the prior Trump administration, government officials issued rules to allow for a greater flow of water to California farms. The move was blasted by environmental groups. The Biden administration pushed back on those decisions and has been working on new rules aimed at balancing farming with protections for endangered wildlife such as the delta smelt, a tiny fish that is an indicator of the health of California‚Äôs waterways, and Chinook salmon. In recent years, California farmers said federal water allocations have been more limited than they feel is necessary after two years of ample rain boosted the state‚Äôs reservoirs. The state previously grappled with a yearslong drought that in 2022 saw the driest January-to-March period in at least a century, with scientists saying weather whiplash will likely become more common as the planet warms. That is a big concern of environmentalists and commercial fishermen, who want to see less water diverted to agriculture and more flowing to the delta. Salmon fishing has been banned off the California coast for the past two years because of dwindling stocks, and critics say Trump‚Äôs prior decisions moving water away from salmon-spawning areas are to blame. ‚ÄúThey delivered all the cold water behind Shasta Dam. It literally cooked the baby salmon before they were hatched,‚Äù said Barry Nelson, policy advisor to the Golden State Salmon Association, a nonprofit focused on restoring California salmon. ‚ÄúMath is a brutal master, and we‚Äôve hit physical limits on the amount of water we can take from the Bay delta, and the sign of that is the collapse of the ecosystem.‚Äù Democratic California Gov. Gavin Newsom, a long-time Trump critic, recently called on California lawmakers to gear up ahead of another Trump presidency to safeguard the state‚Äôs progressive policies. Environmental advocates, however, contend Newsom has not done enough to improve the situation in the delta for fish and wildlife. During Trump‚Äôs prior administration, Newsom opposed his rules for water flows, filing a legal challenge, but since then put forth his own rules, which Jon Rosenfield, San Francisco Baykeeper‚Äôs science director, said ‚Äúwere never that much different.‚Äù Competing demands on California‚Äôs water have led to numerous battles over who gets how much. Advocates for fishermen, environmental interests and farmers all say more must be done to shore up future water supplies. But what that looks like depends on who is asked, with proposed solutions spanning from more conservation to expanding water storage to technological upgrades. Aubrey Bettencourt, who oversaw Department of Interior water policy during the prior Trump administration, said she would like to see the system updated to respond to swings in climate rather than setting water releases based on the calendar. One of the issues, she said, is not how much water you get but knowing how much water you will get. ‚ÄúIt makes it very hard to plan not just as a farmer but as a city manager,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI would expect an emphasis on restoring operational certainty.‚Äù The incoming Trump administration has discussed a series of economic policies that could also affect agriculture, including tariffs that could wind up affecting some exports and push up input costs for growers, according to a recent Rabobank report. But when it comes to water, many farmers in California are hopeful. Daniel Errotabere, a third-generation farmer and previous Westlands Water District president whose family grows tomatoes, garlic and almonds, is among them. As California ramps up limits on groundwater pumping, it is even more important to ensure a stable flow of surface water to grow the food the country is counting on, he said. Farmers have had to fallow fields and often don‚Äôt plant as much as they could because of water uncertainty, he said. ‚ÄúIf electricity was delivered this way there‚Äôd be a revolt,‚Äù Errotabere said. ‚ÄúThis is not any way to operate resources.‚Äù
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Right  
This article presents a perspective that leans toward supporting agricultural interests and the policies of the previous Trump administration. It emphasizes the challenges farmers face regarding water supply and portrays them as hopeful for future improvements under Trump. While it acknowledges environmental concerns and opposition from various groups, the tone suggests alignment with pro-farming viewpoints, thus aligning more with a Lean Right classification. The focus on farmer quotes and experiences further supports this classification.

title: University Of Michigan Drops DEI Statements In Faculty¬†Hiring
body: The University of Michigan announced on Thursday that it has eliminated diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) statements from its faculty hiring, promotion, and tenure processes.Some university community members celebrated the decision to scrap the DEI statements, which individuals were asked to provide to demonstrate what they‚Äôve done and plan to do to advance such policies. They said the statements were used as ideological litmus tests and enforced intellectual conformity.‚ÄúI applaud the provost for ending the practice of requiring diversity statements,‚Äù said Sarah Hubbard, one of the regents on the eight-person board overseeing the university. ‚ÄúThis policy change removes a barrier to diversity of thought on campus by eliminating the ideological litmus test.‚ÄùProvost Laurie McCauley announced the decision on Thursday after forming a faculty committee to review the use of diversity statements.‚ÄúCritics of diversity statements perceive them as expressions of personal identity traits, support of specific ideology or opinions on socially-relevant issues, and serve as a ‚Äòlitmus test‚Äô of whether a faculty member‚Äôs views are politically acceptable,‚Äù the committee stated in a report. ‚ÄúThus, as currently enacted, diversity statements have the potential to limit viewpoints and reduce diversity of thought among faculty members.‚ÄùAdvertisementWhile the University of Michigan Board of Regents is set to meet on Thursday, Hubbard says she doesn‚Äôt expect it to address any other DEI issues at this time.CHECK OUT THE DAILY WIRE HOLIDAY GIFT GUIDEThe University of Michigan‚Äôs decision follows the Massachusetts Institute of Technology‚Äôs announcement over the summer that it would discontinue using DEI statements in the hiring process.Advertisement‚ÄúRequests for a statement on diversity will no longer be part of applications for any faculty positions at MIT,‚Äù one MIT representative said at the time.‚ÄúMy goals are to tap into the full scope of human talent, to bring the very best to MIT, and to make sure they thrive once here,‚Äù MIT President Sally Kornbluth said. ‚ÄúWe can build an inclusive environment in many ways, but compelled statements impinge on freedom of expression, and they don‚Äôt work.‚ÄùHarvard University‚Äôs Faculty of Arts and Sciences also announced this summer that it would discontinue the use of diversity statements in its hiring process.Advertisement
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Right  
The article focuses on the removal of DEI statements, framing it as a positive step towards enhancing diversity of thought and freedom of expression. It highlights support from conservative figures and presents the abandonment of these policies favorably, reflecting a perspective that aligns with right-leaning views against perceived ideological conformity in academia. The emphasis on the negative aspects of DEI statements suggests a critique of progressive policies, common in media with a lean right bias.

title: Sen. Joni Ernst says vetting process will continue for defense secretary nominee Pete Hegseth
body: Sen. Joni Ernst declined Thursday to give her full support to former Fox News host Pete Hegseth, President-elect Donald Trump‚Äôs pick for defense secretary, and said the vetting process needs to continue.
