Some Republican senators have already announced their support for Mr. Hegseth, but others have expressed concerns about multiple allegations he faces regarding sexual assault, infidelity and alcoholism, among others. ‚ÄúI think for a number of our senators, they want to make sure that any allegations have been cleared and that‚Äôs why we have to have a very thorough vetting,‚Äù Ms. Ernst, Iowa Republican, told Fox News host Bill Hemmer during an interview Thursday. ‚ÄúAnd that‚Äôs why I was very happy to sit down with Pete and have that conversation with him.‚Äù Ms. Ernst met with Mr. Hegseth on Capitol Hill Wednesday. In an X post after the meeting, she said the two had a ‚Äúfrank and thorough conversation.‚Äù On Fox she said they talked about ‚Äúa number of those issues.‚Äù ‚ÄúThe vetting will continue, I am certain, through the next month or so until we approach that hearing date,‚Äù she said. Mr. Hegseth has been meeting with senators since before Thanksgiving and will continue to have meetings with them. On Wednesday he said he wouldn‚Äôt be backing down from the position. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm doing this for the warfighters, not the warmongers,‚Äù he posted Wednesday on X with a picture of himself and others in military attire. ‚ÄúThe Left is afraid of disrupters and change agents. They are afraid of @realDonaldTrump‚Äîand me. So they smear w/ fake, anonymous sources & BS stories. They don‚Äôt want truth,‚Äù he wrote. ‚ÄúOur warriors never back down, & neither will I.‚Äù
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Right  
The article primarily focuses on Republican Sen. Joni Ernst and her cautious approach towards President-elect Trump's nominee Pete Hegseth, characterized by quotes supporting Hegseth's continued vetting amid concerns about allegations against him. The framing, along with the inclusion of Hegseth's sentiments about the "Left," showcases a slight bias towards right-wing perspectives while also addressing accountability within the party, indicating a "Lean Right" classification.

title: A growing chorus of Democrats calling on Biden to pardon Trump
body: In the wake of President Biden‚Äôs pardon of his son Hunter Biden an increasing number of Democrats are calling upon him to extend executive clemency to President-elect Donald Trump. Sen. John Fetterman of Pennsylvania on Thursday became the latest Democrat to say a Trump pardon would be good for the country. During an appearance on ABC‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe View,‚Äù Mr. Fetterman said he agreed with Mr. Biden that the legal cases against Hunter Biden were ‚Äúpolitically motivated‚Äù ‚Äî adding that was all the more reason to pardon Mr. Trump, too. He said that the same argument about politically motivated prosecution could be said about Mr. Trump‚Äôs conviction in New York, in which the president was found guilty on 34 counts of business fraud. ‚ÄúAnd in both cases, I think a pardon is appropriate, and I really think, collectively, America‚Äôs confidence in these kinds of institutions has been damaged by these kinds of cases, and we cannot allow these kinds of institutions to be weaponized against our political opponents,‚Äù Mr. Fetterman said. He added that it‚Äôs ‚Äúvery clear‚Äù that both the Trump and Hunter Biden trials were ‚Äúpolitically motivated and weaponized‚Äù by the other side. The idea of pardoning Mr. Trump has gained increased popularity among Democrats following Mr. Biden‚Äôs broad and sweeping pardon of his son. Mr. Biden‚Äôs pardon absolved Hunter Biden of the consequences following his conviction on federal gun charges and pleading guilty to tax evasion. It also blocks prosecutors from bringing charges against Hunter Biden for any crimes he may have committed since January 2014. If Mr. Biden were to pardon Mr. Trump, it would be largely symbolic. Although Mr. Trump faced criminal charges for his handling of classified documents and his role in the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the U.S. Capitol, neither case made it to trial before his election. Late last month, special counsel Jack Smith, who brought the charges against Mr. Trump, moved to drop both cases, citing a Justice Department policy that forbids criminally charging a sitting president. Mr. Trump‚Äôs New York conviction was on state charges, and presidential pardons only apply to federal cases. Mr. Biden would be unable to grant clemency in that case. Still, other Democrats have said the move, even symbolically, would be good for the nation. Rep. James E. Clyburn, South Carolina Democrat, told CNN this week that he‚Äôd support the pardon of Mr. Trump, saying others who called for it ‚Äúmay be on to something.‚Äù Outgoing Sen. Joe Manchin III of West Virginia, a Democrat who recently switched to independent, also told the network that Mr. Biden should use his pardon power on the president-elect. ‚ÄúWhat I would have done differently and my recommendation as a counsel would‚Äôve been, ‚ÄôWhy don‚Äôt you go ahead and pardon Donald Trump for his charges,‚Äô‚Äù Mr. Manchin said when asked about the Hunter Biden pardon. He said things would have ‚Äúgone down a lot more balanced‚Äù if Mr. Biden had pardoned the president-elect alongside Hunter Biden. In addition, Douglas Schoen, a longtime adviser to President Clinton and a Democrat pollster and Robert Green, a Democratic strategist, authored an op-ed for Fox News saying Mr. Trump should receive a pardon. ‚ÄúEnding the cases involving the former and past president would put the country in a position to go forward and address more significant challenges such as the increasingly aggressive Russia-China-Iran axis, the Middle East, inflation here at home and more,‚Äù they wrote. ‚ÄúThis would also display a level of equality and parallelism that would suggest to the American people that our elected leaders are capable of cooperation and working in the country‚Äôs best interests, two qualities Americans deserve,‚Äù they wrote. The White House and the Trump campaign did not respond to requests for comment.
Ai bias and explanation:
Center  
The article presents a balanced view by reporting on calls from various Democrats for President Biden to pardon Trump without showing strong support or opposition. It details the arguments made by both politically motivated trials and maintains a neutral tone throughout, incorporating perspectives from multiple political figures. There is no apparent agenda to push a particular ideological standpoint, making it a centrist presentation of a contentious political issue.

title: Republicans Look To Reshape State Governments After Major 2024 Victories
body: While the political world‚Äôs eyes are focused on Republicans winning trifecta control of the federal government for the first time since 2017, the GOP had many other major victories last week that deserve attention as well. Throughout the country, Republicans scored significant wins in state legislative races imperative to implementing a conservative agenda moving forward. In Arizona, Republicans are on track to maintain their majorities in the state House and Senate, preliminary election results from the New York Times suggest. Republicans could potentially expand their majorities in both chambers as well. The outcome marks a huge defeat for leftists, who spent millions of dollars to flip or ‚Äúreach ties‚Äù in state legislatures including in Arizona, as The Federalist previously reported, where a slim GOP legislative majority separates the state from a Democrat trifecta takeover. In South Carolina, unofficial results indicate Republicans won a veto-proof supermajority in the state Senate and held onto their supermajority in the state House of Representatives. Similar trends are also reflected in Iowa‚Äôs preliminary results, which show the state GOP is already projected to expand its majority in the state House. In New Hampshire, Republicans are on track to maintain trifecta control of state government, according to early results. The GOP is projected to win the governor‚Äôs mansion and a supermajority in the Senate and could also expand its majority in the House compared to 2022 results. Despite efforts by Kansas Democrat Gov. Laura Kelly and Democrats to take down Republican legislative candidates this cycle, the Kansas GOP is not only projected to maintain its House and Senate supermajorities but is on track to grow them, preliminary results suggest. State Republicans have previously used their supermajorities to override Kelly‚Äôs vetoes on critical bills approved by the legislature, including one making it a felony for individuals to coerce pregnant women into getting abortions, as The Kansas City Star reported earlier this year. In Michigan, Republicans are projected to take back the state House of Representatives after losing the chamber during the 2022 midterms. The GOP‚Äôs victories disintegrate Gov. Gretchen Whitmer and Democrats‚Äô trifecta control, providing the party with a buffer to prevent Michigan leftists from enshrining their radical policies into law. Michigan Democrats‚Äô defeats haven‚Äôt stopped them from attempting to use their final weeks in power to further their agenda, however. As my colleague Logan Washburn recently reported, the leftist party is seeking to pass legislation that would bind Michigan‚Äôs electoral votes to the winner of the popular vote in presidential elections. Republicans‚Äô positive gains were also noticeable in Minnesota, the home state of Democrat Gov. Tim Walz ‚Äî Vice President Harris‚Äô running mate this cycle. According to local media, preliminary results show the state GOP breaking Democrats‚Äô trifecta by splitting control of the state House, 67-67. Two of the races are headed for recounts, according to the local outlet, meaning a change in the outcome of one of the contests could tip the chamber to one party or the other. In Pennsylvania, the Keystone State GOP is projected to hold its majority in the Senate. Republicans did, however, come up short in their effort to reclaim the House of Representatives, where Democrats seemingly held onto their one-seat majority, according to preliminary results. Republicans also experienced success in states in which Democrats maintained their legislative majorities. As previously noted in the Las Vegas Sun, Nevada Republicans appear to be ‚Äúon track to stave off a Democratic voting supermajority in the Nevada Assembly to protect Gov. Joe Lombardo‚Äôs veto power.‚Äù The outlet noted how the Republican governor vetoed 75 bills during last year‚Äôs legislative session. Vermont Republicans apparently gained enough seats to break Democrats‚Äô supermajorities in the state House and Senate, as a local NBC affiliate reported last week. Democrats previously used these supermajorities to override vetoes by liberal Republican Gov. Phil Scott. Last year, for example, the Democrat-controlled legislature approved an amendment adopted by the City of Burlington allowing illegal aliens to vote in local elections. Scott vetoed the measure but was subsequently overridden by the legislature. Last week‚Äôs elections did come with some setbacks for conservatives, however. While Republicans are projected to hold majorities in the Wisconsin Legislature, they are on track to lose their supermajority in the state Senate. The expected results come after the state instituted Democrat-friendly redistricted maps for state races earlier this year. The state‚Äôs leftist-controlled supreme court shot down maps submitted by the GOP-led legislature last year. A similar trend also occurred in North Carolina, where Republicans are on track to maintain their legislative majorities but lose their supermajority in the state House by one seat, according to reports. The loss could prove consequential given Democrat Josh Stein‚Äôs victory in the state‚Äôs gubernatorial race against Republican Mark Robinson.
Ai bias and explanation:
Right  
The article predominantly discusses the electoral victories of the Republican Party across various states, presenting these outcomes in a positive light while framing Democrats and their actions negatively. The use of terms like "huge defeat for leftists" and emphasis on conservative agendas suggests a strong bias toward Republican viewpoints, thus aligning the article with right-wing perspectives.

title: Canadian Prime Minister Trudeau Meets With Trump in Florida Amid Tariffs Threat
body: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. ‚Äî Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau flew to Florida on Friday to have dinner with President-elect Donald Trump at his Mar-a-Lago club after Trump threatened to impose sweeping tariffs on Canadian products. Trump threatened to impose tariffs on products from Canada and Mexico if they don‚Äôt stop what he called the flow of drugs and migrants across their borders. He said he would impose a 25% tax on all products entering the U.S. from Canada and Mexico as one of his first executive orders. A person familiar with the details called it a "positive wide-ranging dinner that lasted three hours.‚Äù The official, who was not authorized to speak publicly and spoke to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity, said topics included trade, border security, fentanyl, defense, Ukraine, NATO, China and pipelines, as well as the the Group of Seven meeting in Canada next year. Although Trump once called Trudeau ‚Äúweak‚Äù and ‚Äúdishonest‚Äù during his first term, ties between the two countries have remained among the closest in the world. Trudeau is the first leader from the G7 countries to visit Trump since the Nov. 5 election. Joining Trump and Trudeau at dinner were Howard Lutnick, Trump's nominee for commerce secretary, North Dakota Gov. Doug Burgum, Trump's pick to lead the Interior Department, Mike Waltz, Trump's choice to be his national security adviser, and the three men's wives. Also at the dinner were David McCormick, just elected U.S. senator from Pennsylvania, and his wife, Dina Powell, a former deputy national security adviser under Trump, as well as Canadian Public Safety Minister Dominic LeBlanc, whose responsibilities include border security, and Katie Telford, Trudeau's chief of staff. McCormick posted a photo on X of the group seated at a round table on the patio of Mar-a-Lago. At the table behind the president-elect a boy can be seen mugging for the camera. Trump‚Äôs transition did not respond to questions about what they had discussed or whether the conversation alleviated Trump‚Äôs concerns about the border. A smiling Trudeau declined comment upon returning to his West Palm Beach hotel late Friday. Trudeau said earlier Friday that he would resolve the tariffs issue by talking to Trump. Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum said Thursday after speaking with Trump that she is confident a tariff war with the United States will be averted. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre going to work together to meet some of the concerns,‚Äù Trudeau told reporters in Prince Edward Island in Atlantic Canada. ‚ÄúBut ultimately it is through lots of real constructive conversations with President Trump that I am going to have, that will keep us moving forward on the right track for all Canadians.‚Äù Trudeau said Trump got elected because he promised to bring down the cost of groceries but now he's talking about adding 25% to the cost of all kinds of products including potatoes from Prince Edward Island. ‚ÄúIt is important to understand that Donald Trump, when he makes statements like that, he plans on carrying them out. There‚Äôs no question about it,‚Äù Trudeau said. ‚ÄúOur responsibility is to point out that he would not just be harming Canadians, who work so well with the United States, but he would actually be raising prices for Americans citizens as well and hurting American industry and business,‚Äù he added. Those tariffs could essentially blow up the North American trade pact that Trump‚Äôs team negotiated during his initial term. Trudeau noted they were able to successfully re-negotiate the deal, which he calls a ‚Äúwin win‚Äù for both countries. ‚ÄúWe can work together as we did previously,‚Äù Trudeau said. Trump made the tariff threat Monday while railing against an influx of illegal migrants, even though the numbers at the Canadian border pale in comparison to the southern border. The U.S. Border Patrol made 56,530 arrests at the Mexican border in October alone ‚Äî and 23,721 arrests at the Canadian one between October 2023 and September 2024. Trump also railed about fentanyl from Mexico and Canada, even though seizures from the Canadian border are few in comparison to the Mexican border. U.S. customs agents seized 43 pounds of fentanyl at the Canadian border last fiscal year, compared with 21,100 pounds at the Mexican border. Canadian officials say lumping Canada in with Mexico is unfair but say they are ready to make new investments in border security. Trudeau called Trump after he made his social media posts on the border. When Trump imposed higher tariffs during his first term in office, other countries responded with retaliatory tariffs of their own. Canada, for instance, announced billions of new duties in 2018 against the U.S. in a tit-for-tat response to new taxes on Canadian steel and aluminum. Canada is already examining possible retaliatory tariffs on certain items from the U.S. should Trump follow through on his threat to impose sweeping tariffs on Canadian products, a senior official told The Associated Press this week. A government official said Canada is preparing for every eventuality and has started thinking about what items to target with tariffs in retaliation. The official stressed no decision has been made. The person spoke on condition of anonymity as they were not authorized to speak publicly. Canada is the top export destination for 36 U.S. states. Nearly $3.6 billion Canadian (US$2.7 billion) worth of goods and services cross the border each day. About 60% of U.S. crude oil imports are from Canada, and 85% of U.S. electricity imports are from Canada. Canada is also the largest foreign supplier of steel, aluminum and uranium to the U.S. and has 34 critical minerals and metals that the Pentagon is eager for and investing in for national security. Canada is one of the most trade-dependent countries in the world, and 77% of Canada‚Äôs exports go to the U.S. ‚ÄúCanada has reason to fear because Trump is impulsive, often influenced by the last thing he sees on Fox News,‚Äù said Nelson Wiseman, professor emeritus at the University of Toronto. ‚ÄúHe can leverage that by catering to what he thinks will sound and look good to the public rather than to what happens or will happen.‚Äù
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Left  
The article presents a critical perspective on Trump's tariff threats, emphasizing their potential negative impact on both Canadians and Americans. It incorporates insights from Trudeau and experts, suggesting concerns about Trump's impulsive nature. The framing of Trump's actions and the inclusion of quotes highlighting risks and criticism indicates a leaning towards a left-leaning viewpoint, while still presenting factual information about the meeting and topics discussed, which maintains some balance.

title: President Joe Biden Pardons His Son Hunter After Previously Saying He Wouldn‚Äôt
body: WASHINGTON ‚Äî President Joe Biden pardoned his son, Hunter, sparing the younger Biden a possible prison sentence for federal felony gun and tax convictions and reversing his past promises not to use the extraordinary powers of the presidency for the benefit of his family. The Democratic President had previously said he would not pardon his son or commute his sentence after convictions in the two cases in Delaware and California. The move on Sunday night comes weeks before Hunter Biden was set to receive his punishment after his trial conviction in the gun case and guilty plea on tax charges, and less than two months before President-elect Donald Trump is set to return to the White House. It caps a long-running legal saga for the younger Biden, who publicly disclosed he was under federal investigation in December 2020‚Äîa month after his father‚Äôs 2020 victory‚Äîand casts a pall over the elder Biden‚Äôs legacy. Biden, who time and again pledged to Americans that he would restore norms and respect for the rule of law after Trump‚Äôs first term in office, ultimately used his position to help his son, breaking his public pledge to Americans that he would do no such thing. Read More: 6 Reasons Why Joe Biden Pardoned Hunter Biden In a statement released Sunday evening, Biden said, ‚ÄúI believe in the justice system, but as I have wrestled with this, I also believe raw politics has infected this process and it led to a miscarriage of justice.‚Äù The President‚Äôs sweeping pardon covers not just the gun and tax offenses against the younger Biden, but also any other ‚Äúoffenses against the United States which he has committed or may have committed or taken part in during the period from January 1, 2014 through December 1, 2024.‚Äù In June, Biden categorically ruled out a pardon or commutation for his son, telling reporters as his son faced trial in the Delaware gun case, ‚ÄúI abide by the jury decision. I will do that and I will not pardon him.‚Äù As recently as Nov. 8, days after Trump‚Äôs victory, White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre ruled out a pardon or clemency for the younger Biden, saying, ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve been asked that question multiple times. Our answer stands, which is no.‚Äù The elder Biden has publicly stood by his only living son as Hunter descended into serious drug addiction and threw his family life into turmoil before getting back on track in recent years. The President‚Äôs political rivals have long used Hunter Biden‚Äôs myriad mistakes as a political cudgel against his father: In one hearing, lawmakers displayed photos of the drug-addled President‚Äôs son half-naked in a seedy hotel. House Republicans also sought to use the younger Biden‚Äôs years of questionable overseas business ventures in a since-abandoned attempt to impeach his father, who has long denied involvement in his son‚Äôs dealings or benefiting from them in any way. ‚ÄúThe charges in his cases came about only after several of my political opponents in Congress instigated them to attack me and oppose my election,‚Äù Biden said in his statement. ‚ÄúNo reasonable person who looks at the facts of Hunter‚Äôs cases can reach any other conclusion than Hunter was singled out only because he is my son.‚Äù ‚ÄúI hope Americans will understand why a father and a President would come to this decision,‚Äù Biden added, claiming he made the decision this weekend. The President had spent the Thanksgiving holiday in Nantucket, Massachusetts, with Hunter and his family, and departed for Angola later Sunday on what may be his last foreign trip as President before leaving office on Jan. 20, 2025. Hunter Biden was convicted in June in Delaware federal court of three felonies for purchasing a gun in 2018 when, prosecutors said, he lied on a federal form by claiming he was not illegally using or addicted to drugs. He had been set to stand trial in September in the California case accusing him of failing to pay at least $1.4 million in taxes. But he agreed to plead guilty to misdemeanor and felony charges in a surprise move hours after jury selection was set to begin. David Weiss, the Trump-appointed U.S. attorney in Delaware who negotiated the plea deal, was subsequently named a special counsel by Attorney General Merrick Garland to have more autonomy over the prosecution of the President‚Äôs son. Hunter Biden said he was pleading guilty in that case to spare his family more pain and embarrassment after the gun trial aired salacious details about his struggles with a crack cocaine addiction. The tax charges carry up to 17 years behind bars and the gun charges are punishable by up to 25 years in prison, though federal sentencing guidelines were expected to call for far less time and it was possible he would have avoided prison time entirely. Hunter Biden was supposed to be sentenced this month in the two federal cases, which the special counsel brought after a plea deal with prosecutors that likely would have spared him prison time fell apart under scrutiny by a judge. Under the original deal, Hunter was supposed to plead guilty to misdemeanor tax offenses and and would have avoided prosecution in the gun case as long as he stayed out of trouble for two years. But the plea hearing quickly unraveled last year when the judge raised concerns about unusual aspects of the deal. The younger Biden was subsequently indicted in the two cases. Hunter Biden‚Äôs legal team this weekend released a 52-page white paper titled ‚ÄúThe political prosecutions of Hunter Biden,‚Äù describing the President‚Äôs son as a ‚Äúsurrogate to attack and injure his father, both as a candidate in 2020 and later as President.‚Äù The younger Biden‚Äôs lawyers have long argued that prosecutors bowed to political pressure to indict the President‚Äôs son amid heavy criticism by Trump and other Republicans of what they called the ‚Äúsweetheart‚Äù plea deal. Rep. James Comer, one of the Republican chairmen leading congressional investigations into Biden‚Äôs family, blasted the President‚Äôs pardon, saying that the evidence against Hunter was ‚Äújust the tip of the iceberg.‚Äù ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs unfortunate that, rather than come clean about their decades of wrongdoing, President Biden and his family continue to do everything they can to avoid accountability,‚Äù Comer said on X, the website formerly known as Twitter. Biden is hardly the first President to deploy his pardon powers to benefit those close to him. In his final weeks in office, Trump pardoned Charles Kushner, the father of his son-in law, Jared Kushner, as well as multiple allies convicted in special counsel Robert Mueller‚Äôs Russia investigation. Trump over the weekend announced plans to nominate the elder Kushner to be the U.S. envoy to France in his next administration. Read More: Here Are the New Members of Trump‚Äôs Administration So Far Trump, who has pledged to dramatically overhaul and install loyalists across the Justice Department after he was prosecuted for his role in trying to subvert the 2020 presidential election, said in a social media post on Sunday that Hunter Biden‚Äôs pardon was ‚Äúsuch an abuse and miscarriage of Justice.‚Äù ‚ÄúDoes the Pardon given by Joe to Hunter include the J-6 Hostages, who have now been imprisoned for years?‚Äù Trump asked, referring to those convicted in the violent Jan. 6, 2021 riot at the U.S. Capitol by his supporters. Hunter Biden said in an emailed statement that he will never take for granted the relief granted to him and vowed to devote the life he has rebuilt ‚Äúto helping those who are still sick and suffering.‚Äù ‚ÄúI have admitted and taken responsibility for my mistakes during the darkest days of my addiction‚Äîmistakes that have been exploited to publicly humiliate and shame me and my family for political sport,‚Äù the younger Biden said. Hunter Biden‚Äôs legal team filed Sunday night in both Los Angeles and Delaware asking the judges handling his gun and tax cases to immediately dismiss them, citing the pardon. A spokesperson for Weiss did not respond to messages seeking comment Sunday night. NBC News was first to report Biden was expected to pardon his son Sunday. ‚ÄîAssociated Press writer Josh Boak in Nantucket, Massachusetts, contributed to this report.
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Left  
This article tends to focus on President Biden's actions regarding his son Hunter, providing detailed explanations of the circumstances surrounding the pardon while highlighting criticisms from political rivals. The framing of Biden's decision depicts a struggle between familial loyalty and political accountability, which aligns with a more sympathetic view of Democratic leadership. However, it acknowledges issues of bipartisanship by referencing Trump's similar actions, while emphasizing the potential implications of Biden's decision on his legacy, suggesting a slight left-leaning bias in its presentation.

title: Resurfaced letter from veterans group defending Hegseth offers him lifeline
body: Playback speedNormalQuality-Playback speed0.250.50.75Normal1.251.51.752More Videos ‚Äπ01:19Next Video1. Trump considering nominating DeSantis as defense secretary: Report02:10Next Video2. Eric Adams continues warming to Trump with NYC elections looming01:37Next Video3. White House weighing preemptive pardons: Report01:54Next Video4. Joni Ernst emerges as Hegseth backup with defense nomination in limbo03:26Next Video5. WEX Wakeup: Jack Smith misconduct allegations, Pete Hegseth, Senior Harris aide 02:07Next Video6. Hunter Biden could return to Congress for more testimony next year, Comer says01:20Next Video7. South Korean president faces impeachment after Martial Law frenzy01:46Next Video8. Biden appears to fall asleep during African summit01:21Next Video9. Trump team weighing purchase of Texas land plot03:08Next Video10. WEX Wakeup: Iranian hacking effort, China escalates trade war, Fani Willis 01:15Next Video11. Will Joe Biden pardon Donald Trump before leaving office?01:48Next Video12. Debate on Gaetz report reignites despite dropped AG bid, vote this week02:22Next Video13. Biden talks slavery but avoids Trump, China, and Hunter in Angola01:53Next Video14. Schiff pivots to economy after Dems' big losses01:52Next Video15. North Carolina Senate overrides governor‚Äôs veto on bill 01:13Next Video16. Trump to visit France‚Äôs Notre Dame in first foreign trip as president-elect01:18Next Video17. Senate Democrats elevate Klobuchar to No. 3 leadership spot, succeeding Stabenow01:54Next Video18. What Trump‚Äôs economic picks could foretell for second administration03:03Next Video19. WEX Wakeup: NYC Criminal migrants, Johnson on pardon, Trump cabinet01:42Next Video20. Whoopi Goldberg rips pardon ‚Äòpearl clutching‚Äô: It‚Äôs ‚Äòpresident‚Äôs prerogative‚Äô01:38Next Video21. Obama steps back into spotlight after election warnings about Trump ignoredUnmuteLoading Ad 00:00/01:19 LIVE A veterans group‚Äôs letter stating that Pete Hegseth resigned from the organization ‚Äúvoluntarily‚Äù as opposed to being fired has resurfaced. Randy Lair, trustee for Concerned Veterans for America, wrote a letter in January 2016 to Fox News, where Hegseth was a contributor, seeking to ‚Äúset the record straight‚Äù about Hegseth‚Äôs departure. ‚ÄúThe truth is Pete resigned his position as CEO of Concerned Veterans for America as a result of a difference of opinion as to the future of the organization and so that he could focus on other endeavors, including his relationship with Fox News,‚Äù Lair wrote in the letter. ‚ÄúPete was not terminated by the organization and, in fact, we at CVA worked with him through this difficult decision and mutually agreed the end of 2015 was the best timing for both parties.‚Äù Lair went on to commend Hegseth for his ‚Äústrong leadership‚Äù as head of the organization from 2013 to 2016. The letter‚Äôs resurfacing comes following a New Yorker article that outlined allegations laid out by a whistleblower within Concerned Veterans for America. The allegations, laid out in a seven-page document, accused Hegseth of engaging in drunken behavior at organization events and sexual impropriety with female employees. The report was first sent to senior CVA management in February 2015 and was later forwarded to Jae Pak, Hegseth‚Äôs successor, on Jan. 15, 2016, in an email with the subject line: ‚ÄúCongratulations on Removing Pete Hegseth.‚Äù The email outlined how Hegseth ‚Äútreated the organization funds like they were a personal expense account ‚Äî for partying, drinking, and using CVA events as little more than opportunities to ‚Äòhook up‚Äô with women on the road.‚Äù Hegseth has denied these allegations, and he wrote an op-ed in the Wall Street Journal, published on Wednesday, that the media is peddling a ‚Äúsmear‚Äù campaign on him. ‚ÄúThey provide no evidence, no names, and they ignore the legions of people who speak on my behalf,‚Äù Hegseth wrote. ‚ÄúThey need to create a bogeyman because they believe I threaten their institutional insanity. That is the only thing they are right about.‚Äù CLICK HERE TO READ MORE FROM THE WASHINGTON EXAMINER Hegseth was set to meet with several senators on Wednesday, including Sen. Joni Ernst (R-IA), which was expected to be one of the most crucial of his meetings as he needs Senate confirmation to become the next defense secretary. With Republicans holding a 53-majority in the Senate, Hegseth can only afford to lose three Republican votes to confirm his nomination, assuming Senate Democrats are staunchly opposed.
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Right  
This article reflects a Lean Right bias as it discusses Pete Hegseth in a positive light, emphasizing his leadership qualities and presenting his allegations as a "smear campaign" against him. The framing suggests support for Hegseth's candidacy and highlights Republican viewpoints, indicating a more favorable approach to right-leaning individuals. The mention of a veterans group's defense further bolsters Hegseth's reputation while downplaying the serious allegations against him, which aligns with Lean Right media tendencies to defend conservative figures.

title: Trump taps billionaire private astronaut Jared Isaacman as next NASA administrator
body: Billionaire entrepreneur Jared Isaacman, a veteran private astronaut with strong ties to Elon Musk and his rocket company SpaceX, has been picked to serve as NASA's next administrator, President-elect Donald Trump announced Wednesday. If confirmed, Isaacman, 41, would be the fifth NASA administrator with spaceflight experience, replacing former Democratic Sen. Bill Nelson, who flew into orbit aboard the space shuttle Columbia in early 1986. "I am delighted to nominate Jared Isaacman, an accomplished business leader, philanthropist, pilot, and astronaut, as Administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration," Trump said on his social media platform Truth Social. "... Jared's passion for Space, astronaut experience, and dedication to pushing the boundaries of exploration, unlocking the mysteries of the universe, and advancing the new Space economy, make him ideally suited to lead NASA into a bold new Era." Isaacman founded the payment processing company later named Shift4 Payments while he was a high school student. He chartered the first purely commercial, all-civilian American "space tourist" mission ‚Äî Inspiration4 ‚Äî in February 2021, paying SpaceX an undisclosed amount to launch him and three other civilian flyers on a two-day, 23-hour flight. He flew to space again this past September, commanding the first of three planned SpaceX Polaris missions, logging nearly five days in space on a flight that took the crew farther from Earth than any astronauts have gone since the Apollo moon program. Isaacman also became the first private citizen to carry out a spacewalk. He is scheduled to lead another Polaris mission aboard a SpaceX capsule before leading the first crew to space aboard the California rocket builder's gargantuan Super Heavy-Starship rocket. Dates have not been announced for either of those missions, and it's not yet clear what impact Isaacman's selection to lead NASA will have on those flights, whether Isaacman still intends to fly aboard one or both or what sort of influence his friendship with Musk might have on NASA's future direction. But Isaacman, a skilled pilot who flies his own MiG-29 fighter jet, made it clear in a post following Trump's announcement that NASA can expect him to be a vocal space advocate who will help "usher in an era where humanity becomes a true spacefaring civilization." "With the support of President Trump, I can promise you this: We will never again lose our ability to journey to the stars and never settle for second place," Isaacman said. "We will inspire children, yours and mine, to look up and dream of what is possible. Americans will walk on the moon and Mars and in doing so, we will make life better here on Earth." He said it would be the "honor of a lifetime to serve in this role and to work alongside NASA's extraordinary team to realize our shared dreams of exploration and discovery." Jim Bridenstine, Nelson's predecessor at the helm of NASA, helped kickstart the agency's Artemis moon program during the first Trump administration. He said in a statement Wednesday that "Jared's vision for pushing boundaries, paired with his proven track record of success in private industry, positions him as an ideal candidate to lead NASA into a bold new era of exploration and discovery. I urge the Senate to swiftly confirm him." The Isaacman announcement comes as NASA struggles to keep the Artemis program on track amid tight budgets and what the agency's own inspector general calls the "unsustainable" costs of NASA's Space Launch System, or SLS, moon rocket. SpaceX supporters argue the company's more powerful, fully reusable Super Heavy-Starship rocket is the obvious choice for deep space exploration, but the huge rocket is far from operational with just a half-dozen suborbital test flights to its credit. The SLS, on the other hand, is considered operational in that it completed an initial test flight in November 2022, sending an unpiloted Orion capsule around the moon and back. But unlike the Super Heavy-Starship, the SLS is a throwaway, expendable booster expected to cost some $1.4 billion for each of its first four moon missions. NASA is currently gearing up to launch three NASA astronauts and a Canadian flyer on an SLS-Orion mission ‚Äî Artemis 2 ‚Äî late next year. But problems with the first Orion's heat shield and other issues threaten to push the Artemis 2 flight into 2026, years past initial expectations. It's not yet clear when the Artemis 3 mission, the first to carry astronauts to a landing near the moon's south pole, might be feasible. But that flight will feature a lunar lander built by SpaceX, a variant of the company's Starship upper stage. SpaceX has carried out six test flights of the fully reusable Super Heavy-Starship to date, but has not yet put the Starship upper stage into orbit or brought it down for an intact landing. Given the company's rapid-fire test schedule, most observers believe SpaceX will get the Super Heavy-Starship working as planned in the near future, but scores of test flights will be required to demonstrate the safety and reliability required by NASA to put astronauts aboard. And the moon mission poses unique challenges. For the initial landing mission, multiple Super Heavy "tanker" flights will be required to refuel the moon lander in low-Earth orbit before it can be sent to the moon. Once in lunar orbit, it will await the arrival of the Artemis 3 crew, launched aboard an Orion capsule by an SLS rocket. After boarding the Starship lander, two astronauts would descend to the surface, carry out the mission's planned exploration, and then head back up to the orbiting Orion for the trip back to Earth.
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Right  
This article predominantly reflects a positive portrayal of Jared Isaacman and aligns with the policies and sentiments of the Trump administration. The language used by Trump and Isaacman emphasizes innovation and American exceptionalism in space exploration, echoing a pro-business and pro-private enterprise perspective commonly associated with right-leaning media. Additionally, it contrasts Isaacman with his predecessor, a former Democratic senator, suggesting a favorable view towards the current administration's choices and direction for NASA.

title: Proud Boys Leader Testifies In Trial Of Accused Corrupt Cop
body: WASHINGTON ‚Äî After being transferred from prison where he is serving out a 22-year sentence for seditious conspiracy, Henry ‚ÄúEnrique‚Äù Tarrio, the former leader of extremist group the Proud Boys, took the witness stand Thursday in the trial of a former D.C. police officer accused of disclosing insider information to him and then lying about it to investigators. Shane Lamond, once the head of the D.C. Metropolitan Police Department‚Äôs intelligence division, is charged with obstruction of justice and making multiple false statements. Prosecutors say he tipped Tarrio off about a police probe into the Proud Boys and the burning of a Black Lives Matter banner on Dec. 12, 2020. Tarrio, wearing a dark green prison-issued jumpsuit and black-rimmed glasses, denied ever having a friendship with Lamond and repeatedly denied ever receiving information in advance from police about a warrant for his arrest. Instead, the former Proud Boys leader testified he was a ‚ÄúTwitter head,‚Äù constantly perusing social media. He claimed it was a social media post from the D.C. MPD about the banner burning that alerted him he could soon be arrested. Tarrio admitted Thursday that on Dec. 15, just days after the incident, he spoke to Lamond. But he said he never confessed to Lamond directly that he burned the banner. He wanted to do it himself and create a ‚Äúcircus,‚Äù in the process, he testified. ‚ÄúI was dead set on getting arrested ... that was my plan. I wanted to be arrested for burning the banner,‚Äù Tarrio testified. He continued: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm a dedicated person ... Here. I‚Äôll be honest. I wanted to put up the circus tent. The only way to do that was to push the message out that I was about to be arrested for burning a BLM banner when so many American flags are being burned in D.C.‚Äù People needed to see the arrest was ‚Äúreal,‚Äù Tarrio told Lamond‚Äôs defense lawyer Mark Schamel. ‚ÄúAnd I was going to show what the Department of Justice was and I was dedicated to that cause with everything in me,‚Äù Tarrio said. Prosecutors say Lamond told Tarrio about the probe into the banner burning roughly a week after it happened and disclosed that police were weighing whether it should be charged as a hate crime. Lamond allegedly told Tarrio he would check to see if criminal investigators had footage of him burning the banner and allegedly warned Tarrio that the FBI and U.S. Secret Service were ‚Äúall spun up‚Äù after the Proud Boys leader went on InfoWars. When Tarrio was on trial for seditious conspiracy, prosecutors argued the arrest, facilitated by his relationship with Lamond, ultimately ended up giving the Proud Boys leader a tidy alibi for his whereabouts on Jan. 6, 2021. When Tarrio‚Äôs cross examination started and it appeared prosecutors would ask him about Jan. 6, Tarrio refused. He wouldn‚Äôt discuss that on the stand today, he said, threatening to invoke his Fifth Amendment right. This prompted the judge to stop proceedings and call lawyers over for a private discussion at the bench. This is a developing story. Please check back for updates.
Ai bias and explanation:
Center  
The article presents a straightforward account of legal proceedings involving Enrique Tarrio, the former leader of the Proud Boys, and a D.C. police officer. It reports on the trial facts, quotes, and statements made by the involved parties without overt bias or emotionally charged language. The focus remains on the legal context, allowing readers to form their own opinions without persuasive or ideological framing, which aligns it with a centrist perspective.

title: Mexico warns Trump tariffs would kill 400,000 U.S. jobs, threatens retaliation
body: Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum said on Wednesday Mexico would retaliate if U.S. President-elect Donald Trump followed through with his proposed 25% across-the-board tariff, a move her government warned could kill 400,000 U.S. jobs and drive up prices for U.S. consumers. ‚ÄúIf there are U.S. tariffs, Mexico would also raise tariffs,‚Äù Sheinbaum said during a press conference, in her clearest statement yet that the country was preparing possible retaliatory trade measures against its top trade partner. Mexican Economy Minister Marcelo Ebrard, speaking alongside Sheinbaum, called for more regional cooperation and integration instead of a war of retaliatory import taxes. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a shot in the foot,‚Äù Ebrard said of Trump‚Äôs proposed tariffs, which appear to violate the USMCA trade deal between Mexico, Canada and the U.S. Ebrard warned the tariffs would lead to massive U.S. job losses, lower growth and hit U.S. companies producing in Mexico by effectively doubling the taxes they paid. ‚ÄúThe impact on companies is huge,‚Äù he said. The proposed tariffs would hit the automotive sector‚Äôs top cross-border exporters especially hard, Ebrard added, namely Ford, General Motors and Stellantis. Ebrard noted that 88% of pickup trucks sold in the U.S. are made in Mexico and would see a price increase. These vehicles are popular in rural areas that overwhelmingly voted for Trump. ‚ÄúOur estimate is that the average price of these vehicles will increase by $3,000,‚Äù Ebrard said. Sheinbaum and Trump spoke by phone later on Wednesday, with the two discussing topics at the top of Trump‚Äôs agenda. Trump had said the tariffs would remain in effect until the flow of drugs ‚Äì particularly fentanyl ‚Äì and migrants into the U.S. was controlled. In a post on his Truth Social platform, Trump said Sheinbaum ‚Äúagreed to stop migration through Mexico, and into the United States, effectively closing our Southern Border.‚Äù He described the conversation as ‚Äúvery productive.‚Äù Sheinbaum later responded on X that she had laid out Mexico‚Äôs migration strategy, which ‚Äúattended to‚Äù migrants before they arrived at the U.S.-Mexico border, in her call with Trump. ‚ÄúMexico‚Äôs stance is not to close borders, but to build bridges between governments and their peoples,‚Äù she added. In after-hours trading on Wednesday, Mexico‚Äôs peso strengthened by as much as nearly 1% against the dollar, reversing losses logged in previous days. Many analysts regard Trump‚Äôs tariff threats as more of a negotiating tactic than trade policy. ‚ÄúThe lack of a clear link between this threat and questions related to trade suggests the new president plans to use tariffs as a negotiating strategy to achieve goals largely unrelated to trade,‚Äù said David Kohl, chief economist at Julius Baer. Mexico‚Äôs automotive industry is the country‚Äôs most important manufacturing sector, exporting predominantly to the United States. It represents nearly 25% of all North American vehicle production. Analysts at Barclays said they estimate the proposed tariffs ‚Äúcould wipe out effectively all profits‚Äù from the Detroit Three automakers. ‚ÄúWhile it‚Äôs generally understood that a blanket 25% tariff on any vehicles or content from Mexico or Canada could be disruptive, investors under-appreciate how disruptive this could be,‚Äù they wrote in a note on Tuesday. Brian Hughes, a spokesperson for Trump‚Äôs transition team, said the tariffs would protect U.S. manufacturers and workers from ‚Äúunfair practices of foreign companies and foreign markets.‚Äù Hughes said Trump would implement policies to make life affordable and more prosperous for his country. GM and Stellantis declined to comment. Ford did not comment on how the threatened tariffs would affect its business but said it manufactures more vehicles in the United States than most major automakers. Mexico‚Äôs automotive industry group AMIA said it would prepare for any possibility and wait to see what formal actions are taken. The Institute of International Finance, a trade group for the global financial services industry, warned Mexico-U.S. relations would be challenging going forward. ‚ÄúThe imposition of tariffs, eventually leading to increased protectionism, and other policies affecting exchange rates and commodity prices could have significant implications for the region,‚Äù it said in a note. The USMCA is up for review in 2026. Katia Goya, director of international economics at Grupo Financiero Banorte, said it was likely the three USMCA countries would seek wholesale renegotiation of the pact rather than just rubber-stamp it to continue in its current form. ‚ÄúThe effect of a trade-conflict situation is that it will mean lower economic growth in the United States, higher unemployment and higher inflation,‚Äù Goya said. Ebrard said USMCA trade amounted to $1.78 trillion in the first nine months of this year. ‚ÄúWe can fragment and divide with tariffs,‚Äù Ebrard said. ‚ÄúMexico does not want conflicts and divisions, but to build a stronger region.‚Äù
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Left  
This article presents a critical view of Trump's proposed tariffs, highlighting potential job losses and economic disruption. The Mexican officials cited suggest a preference for cooperation rather than confrontation in trade policy, which aligns with more progressive economic views. Additionally, the tone and focus on negative consequences of protectionist policies suggest a critique that leans towards leftist economic principles prioritizing regional integration and minimizing conflicts. The framing and emphasis indicate a bias that favors collaboration and concern for the broader economic impact, common in left-leaning narratives.

title: California Governor Newsom Requests $25 Million from Legislature for Anti-Trump Litigation Fund
body: California governor Gavin Newsom is calling for lawmakers to approve a $25 million litigation fund to defend the state from federal overreach and ‚Äúpotential harm‚Äù during President-elect Donald Trump‚Äôs second administration. The Democrat made the request on Monday to kick off a special session aimed at Trump-proofing the progressive state ahead of Trump‚Äôs inauguration in January. The proposed $25 million fund would be available to the California Department of Justice and other state agencies to ‚Äúdefend California from unconstitutional federal overreach, challenge illegal federal actions in court, and take administrative actions to reduce potential harm,‚Äù according to a press release from Newsom‚Äôs office. Newsom vowed to work with the new administration, adding that ‚Äúwe want President Trump to succeed in serving all Americans.‚Äù ‚ÄúBut when there is overreach, when lives are threatened, when rights and freedoms are targeted, we will take action,‚Äù he said in a prepared statement. Newsom‚Äôs office said the $25 million would be used to protect billions of dollars in state funding, including disaster relief and health care. It would also be used to protect abortion access, ‚Äúaccess to clean air and water, and fundamental civil rights.‚Äù During Trump‚Äôs first term, California‚Äôs spent about $42 million to support 122 lawsuits against his administration, Newsom‚Äôs office reported. That money resulted in tens of millions of dollars more in federal reimbursements, billions of dollars in savings for California consumers, and protected billions of dollars in federal funding, the office said. California attorney general Rob Bonta said in a prepared statement that the $25 million litigation fund would ensure this office has ‚Äúthe resources we need to meet the demands of the moment and robustly defend California‚Äôs people, progress and values.‚Äù ‚ÄúWith potentially billions of dollars in federal funding on the line if the President-elect follows through on his promises, we must be ‚Äî and we are ‚Äî ready to act on day one,‚Äù Bonta said. According to the Sacramento Bee, Newsom told reporters on Monday that it is important for California to ‚Äúprepare for Trump 2.0, where his rhetoric is not only heightened, but his call for retribution, revenge is pretty clear. Anyone who‚Äôs not paying attention, I think is doing so at their own peril.‚Äù. State assemblyman James Gallagher, the Republican leader, told the paper that the special session was a ‚Äútotal posture‚Äù from Newsom who wants to be a ‚Äúprogressive darling.‚Äù ‚ÄúI mean, Gavin Newsom wants to run for president,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs what this is about.‚Äù In addition to the $25 million litigation fund requested by Newsom, Democratic state senator Scott Wiener, filed a bill Monday to provide another $25 million for legal services, including for defending illegal immigrants from deportation, and $10 million ‚Äúto ensure cities & counties can defend against Trump.‚Äù Today, as Chair of the Senate Budget Committee, I introduced SB1X 1 in our Special Session. It provides: $25M to Dept of Justice to enforce the law when Trump violates it $25M for legal services, eg deportation defense $10M to ensure cities & counties can defend against Trump ‚Äî Senator Scott Wiener (@Scott_Wiener) December 2, 2024 Newsom called for the special session just days after Trump won the presidential election, claiming that the ‚Äúfreedoms we hold dear in California are under attack.‚Äù As governor, Newsom has turned California into sanctuary for people seeking abortions and transgender surgeries and treatments; mandated that all new vehicles sold in the state be electric, hydrogen-powered or plug-in hybrids by 2035; and expanded state-funded health care to include all low-income residents, including illegal immigrants. Newsom‚Äôs request for the litigation fund comes as California faces a deficit of about $2 billion next year, according to a projection from the nonpartisan Legislative Analyst‚Äôs Office. The state‚Äôs budget shortfall is projected to reach about $30 billion by fiscal 2028-29, with one analyst telling reporters recently that California has ‚Äúreally no capacity for new commitments.‚Äù Send a tip to the news team at NR.
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Left  
The article predominantly focuses on California Governor Gavin Newsom's initiatives aimed at countering federal actions under a Trump administration, highlighting progressive values and concerns surrounding federal overreach. It presents Newsom's litigation fund proposal favorably, emphasizing its intention to protect state funding and civil rights. The inclusion of dissenting opinions from Republican leaders, while present, does not diminish the overall emphasis on defending progressive policies, aligning the piece more closely with a lean left bias.

title: Bain Capital To Invest $157 Million In Indonesian Billionaire Tahir-Backed Mayapada Hospital
body: U.S. private equity firm, Bain Capital, plans to invest $157 million in Sejahteraraya Anugrahjaya, a company that runs the Mayapada Hospital chain backed by Indonesian billionaire Tahir. Boston-Bain Capital through its affiliate BCCS Maverick Holdings will invest in Mayapada Hospital by subscribing to new shares worth $32 million and bonds valued at $125 million, according to a regulatory filing by Sejahteraraya to the Indonesia Stock Exchange this week. Tahir, who goes by one name, is actively expanding Mayapada Hospital. In June, he partnered with Indian billionaire Prathap Reddy‚Äôs Apollo Hospitals to build a hospital on Batam island, which is less than an hour by ferry from Singapore. To be named Mayapada Apollo Batam International Hospital, the hospital will be built on a three-hectare site within a special economic zone to be managed by Tahir‚Äôs Mayapada Group. Sejahteraraya said it plans to invest up to two trillion rupiah ($128 million) in the hospital. In October, the Jakarta-listed company opened its seventh Mayapada Hospital (another joint venture with Apollo Hospitals) located in Nusantara, Indonesia‚Äôs proposed new capital in East Kalimantan. Sejahteraraya aims to double its bed count to more than 2,200 and operate up to 12 hospitals by 2027. It had 1,120 beds across six hospitals at the end of 2023. Other companies have also been increasing their investment in Indonesia‚Äôs healthcare sector. In August, Luxembourg-based private equity firm, CVC Capital Partners, took control of Indonesian-listed Siloam Hospitals from billionaire Mochtar Riady‚Äôs cash-strapped Lippo Karawaci after it agreed to buy an additional 45% stake for 16.6 trillion rupiah. Saratoga Investama Sedaya, backed by tycoon Edwin Soeryadjaya, also acquired the Brawijaya Hospital in Jakarta. Tahir has an estimated net worth of $5.2 billion according to Forbes‚Äô real-time data. Besides healthcare, Mayapada Group has interests in banking and real estate.
Ai bias and explanation:
Center  
The article presents factual information about Bain Capital's investment in Mayapada Hospital and the expansion of healthcare facilities in Indonesia without expressing a particular political ideology or bias. It focuses on economic activity and partnerships without advocating for or against any political stance, making it a neutral report suitable for a center classification.

title: Ron DeSantis Could Be Getting Another Season on the Trump Show
body: Nominating Fox News personality Pete Hegseth to be secretary of defense was, from the start, one of the least serious choices Donald Trump made in assembling his broadly unserious slate of second-term Cabinet nominees. But information that has come out since Hegseth‚Äôs nomination was announced makes the selection look even less responsible. A newly published police report shows that he was accused of sexually assaulting and possibly raping a woman he met at a 2017 conference in California. (Local authorities concluded that there was not enough evidence available to bring charges, and he denies the allegation.) A New Yorker investigation found that he was forced out of two jobs leading veterans‚Äô groups over ‚Äúserious allegations of financial mismanagement, sexual impropriety, and personal misconduct‚Äù that included being heavily intoxicated at work events. (Hegseth‚Äôs attorney told the magazine that the claims were ‚Äúoutlandish‚Äù and blamed ‚Äúa petty and jealous disgruntled former associate‚Äù for circulating them.) And the New York Times obtained an email written to Hegseth in 2018 by his mother in which she described him as someone who ‚Äúlies, cheats, sleeps around and uses women for his own power and ego.‚Äù (Hegseth, 44, has been married three times. His mother says she regrets writing the email and that it does not fairly characterize her son.) The allegations themselves are obviously not disqualifying per se to Trump, who was found liable last year for defaming a woman that the jury determined he had raped in 1996, and was found guilty this year of committing fraud to cover up evidence of a sexual affair conducted soon after his third wife gave birth to their child. But he is reportedly peeved that Hegseth did not tell his transition team about the rape allegation, and has a long-standing suspicion of heavy drinkers that derives from his late brother Fred‚Äôs alcoholism. In fact, both the Wall Street Journal and the New York Times are now reporting that Trump is annoyed enough with Hegseth, and skeptical enough of his chances of being confirmed, that he is considering bringing back a beloved character from previous seasons of the Trump Show to take the SecDef role instead: Yes ‚Ä¶ YES!!!! That‚Äôs our Meatball Ron, who rose to the dizzying heights of running about even with Trump in presidential primary polls on the strength of his campaigns against COVID precautions and wokeness ‚Ä¶ but then fell back to the dismal depths of having to actually manage the state of Florida after voters discovered that he is an awkward, over-scripted campaigner so ineffective that when Slate ran a piece about political strategists‚Äô suggestions for improving his chances, we concluded that his two best options were ‚Äúdropping out or becoming a different person.‚Äù He also once allegedly ate a cup of pudding with his fingers on an airplane. You‚Äôve got Meatball Questions, we‚Äôve got Meatball Answers: ‚Ä¢ But what about all the harsh things that DeSantis said about Trump during the primary, many of which were quite obviously true? Old stuff doesn‚Äôt matter that much to Trump so long as someone is willing to suck up to him in the present. ‚Ä¢ Is he qualified for the role? DeSantis served when he was younger as a Navy ‚ÄúJAG,‚Äù or judge advocate general, deploying to Iraq. While he never held a major leadership role in the military, by Trump administration standards, he is basically Dwight Eisenhower. ‚Ä¢ Would he actually want to do this? Sure‚Äîeliminating ‚Äúwokeness‚Äù (i.e., diversity programs) from American institutions, including the military, has long been DeSantis‚Äô main goal as a politician. It‚Äôs also an important and high-profile job and he probably wants to run for president again. ‚Ä¢ Is anyone else under consideration? Iowa Sen. Joni Ernst‚Äîwho would be a much more qualified candidate, but also a less funny one‚Äîreportedly is. So that‚Äôs the lay of the land. And the stakes are high: In a normal administration, the secretary of defense is responsible for supervising the operations and maintaining the readiness of the United States‚Äô armed forces, but in Trump administrations, he or she holds the even more important job of persuading the president not to invade Mexico, install himself as king, or order the special forces to conduct a ‚Äúsmash-and-grab extraction‚Äù of Rosie O‚ÄôDonnell. Stay careful out there, folks.
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Left  
The article critiques Donald Trump and his potential Cabinet nominee Pete Hegseth, using negative language and highlighted allegations that paint them in an unfavorable light. The use of phrases like "broadly unserious slate" and "awkward, over-scripted campaigner" suggests a disapproving stance towards Trump and his administration. Additionally, the sarcastic tone employed throughout implies a skepticism towards right-wing politics and governance, aligning the article more closely with a Lean Left perspective.

title: North Dakota governor charts his path to Interior with a rosy state oil and gas outlook
body: BISMARCK, N.D. (AP) ‚Äî President-elect Donald Trump has given his choice for Interior secretary a mandate to ‚ÄúDrill baby drill,‚Äù and on Wednesday his pick, North Dakota Gov. Doug Burgum, offered a rosy budget picture to lawmakers based largely on his state‚Äôs success in extracting near-record levels of oil and gas from the ground. Burgum, whose term ends next week, noted North Dakota‚Äôs status as the nation‚Äôs No. 3 oil-producing state in his final proposed budget before he begins his role in Trump‚Äôs administration, pending Senate confirmation. Besides serving as Interior secretary, Trump has chosen Burgum to lead a newly created National Energy Council that intends to ensure U.S. ‚Äúenergy dominance.‚Äù ‚ÄúWe look forward to the next four years where we believe that there‚Äôs going to be a shift towards innovation over regulation and an opportunity for North Dakota and our mineral owners to be able to more quickly and easily get permitting to access those natural resources for our country,‚Äù Burgum told a packed House chamber, also lamenting dozens of energy-related federal regulations his state is fighting. Burgum, a two-term governor and wealthy software entrepreneur, would seem a good choice to carry out Trump‚Äôs mandate for both the new council and Interior, where he would oversee public lands and natural resources. Environmentalists are worried about what Trump‚Äôs second term will mean for climate-change initiatives. Trump has said he will roll back President Joe Biden‚Äôs policies. Oil and gas are key to the economy of North Dakota, where hydraulic fracturing and horizontal drilling began an oil boom in the late 2000s. State officials pegged a preliminary all-time high of 19,200 producing oil and gas wells in September. Oil taxes have come in 13% over forecast in the state‚Äôs 2023-25 budget cycle, or $475 million more than projected, according to a November report. Oil production hit nearly 1.2 million barrels per day in September. North Dakota set its record annual oil production in 2019 ‚Äî under Burgum ‚Äî at 524 million barrels, according to a historical report. Last year was the state‚Äôs No. 4 year for oil production. Burgum‚Äôs $19.5 billion two-year budget recommendation projects oil production of 1.1 million barrels per day in the 2025-27 budget cycle, with oil prices of $62 and $60 per barrels in each year of the next two budget years, respectively. Oil tax revenue is a huge driver of the state budget, which relies on oil taxes for everything from school funding to help with property tax relief, health and human services, and infrastructure projects around the state, said longtime Republican Rep. Mike Nathe, a House budget writer. ‚ÄúOil revenue touches every community in the state,‚Äù Nathe said. Oil taxes also feed the state‚Äôs sovereign wealth fund, which has grown to over $11 billion since voters created it in 2010. Hundreds of millions of dollars in earnings come off that fund for lawmakers to put to use. But oil‚Äôs volatility hit the state hard in 2016, resulting in a massive revenue shortfall that led to budget cuts and a drain on reserves. Oil forecasts are key to the Legislature‚Äôs budget process. Other states revenues are in healthy shape. Total general fund revenues are 12% over forecast, or $392 million, according to a report last month. Sales taxes are 12% ahead, or $182 million. Burgum‚Äôs budget includes a $6.5 billion general fund, the state government‚Äôs main operating account. The 2023 Legislature approved a record $19.6 billion 2023-25 budget, with a $6 billion general fund and billions in federal money. That total budget was over $1 billion more than what Burgum had recommended. His final template for lawmakers includes increases for state employee salaries and benefits and K-12 education. He outlined focus areas of workforce, housing, infrastructure, information technology and other big items. His recommendations include millions for child care initiatives, addiction help, and housing programs and grants. The Legislature‚Äôs budget writers will consider Burgum‚Äôs budget in their work, but they will also be getting a budget proposal in mid-January from Burgum‚Äôs successor, Republican Gov.-elect-Kelly Armstrong, who takes office Dec. 15. The Legislature convenes in early January. Republicans hold supermajority control of the House and Senate.
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Right  
The article primarily discusses North Dakota Governor Doug Burgum's optimistic budget proposal and the benefits of oil and gas production in the state, aligning with pro-energy and conservative economic perspectives. The quotes from GOP legislators and emphasis on energy independence reflect a Lean Right bias, presenting the economic advantages of fossil fuels while downplaying environmental concerns raised by critics.

title: Wisconsin Democratic Leader Ben Wikler Enters Race to Lead the National Party
body: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. ‚Äî Ben Wikler, chair of the Democratic Party in Wisconsin, said Sunday he has joined the race to lead the national party after an election that swept Donald Trump and Republicans to power in Washington. ‚ÄúIn Wisconsin, we‚Äôve built a permanent campaign,‚Äù Wikler said in his candidacy announcement. ‚ÄúWe organize and communicate year-round in every corner of the state ‚Äî rural, suburban, urban, red, blue and purple areas alike.‚Äù Since losing control of the White House, the Senate and the House, Democrats are looking for new leadership to tackle the nation's problems with the additional challenge of confronting four more years of a Trump presidency. Top announced candidates to lead the Democratic National Committee include Ken Martin, chair of the Minnesota Democratic-Farmer-Labor Party and a vice chair of the national party, and Martin O‚ÄôMalley, a former Maryland governor and current Social Security administrator. The DNC will choose its successor in February, an election that will speak volumes about how the party wants to present itself during four more years of Trump in the White House. Wikler, who was elected state chair in 2019, cites his experience leading the party's efforts in a state that shifted less toward Trump than other battlegrounds in 2024 and where Democrats won key downballot races. He said that during his tenure, Democrats flipped the majority on the Wisconsin Supreme Court and reelected Tony Evers as governor. This year, the state returned Sen. Tammy Baldwin for a third term and retook 14 state legislative seats, which he says puts Democrats on track for majorities in both chambers in 2026. ‚ÄúWhat has made a difference in Wisconsin can made a difference everywhere,‚Äù Wikler said. Wikler, 43, has served as a Washington director for MoveOn.org, a progressive advocacy group and as a campaign director for Avaaz, a group that mobilizes members to take on issues such as poverty, climate change and human rights. Wikler told CNN's ‚ÄúInside Politics Sunday‚Äù that Democrats need to show Americans that "we‚Äôre on their side and show who Republicans are for. If we don‚Äôt do that, then we‚Äôre going to lose."
Ai bias and explanation:
Left  
This article presents the perspective of Ben Wikler, a Democratic leader, focusing on his strategies and the need for new leadership within the Democratic Party. The language used is supportive of Democratic initiatives and critical of Republican leadership, reflecting a pro-Democrat stance. Additionally, it quotes Wikler‚Äôs call for Democrats to better communicate their values, further emphasizing a liberal viewpoint. Overall, the framing and tone strongly align with left-leaning perspectives in political discourse.

title: Trump Nominates ‚ÄòTremendous Fighter‚Äô Kelly Loeffler For SBA¬†Administrator
body: President-elect Donald Trump announced late on Wednesday that he has nominated business leader and former U.S. Senator Kelly Loeffler (R-GA) to be the next administrator of the Small Business Administration (SBA).‚ÄúKelly will bring her experience in business and Washington to reduce red tape, and unleash opportunity for our Small Businesses to grow, innovate, and thrive,‚Äù Trump said in a statement. ‚ÄúShe will focus on ensuring that SBA is accountable to Taxpayers by cracking down on waste, fraud, and regulatory overreach.‚ÄùTrump praised Loeffler as a ‚Äútremendous fighter‚Äù when she served in the U.S. Senate during his first term in office, noting that she helped pass the first-ever bill to protect women in sports.‚ÄúPrior to her tenure in the U.S. Senate, Kelly built a 25 year career in financial services and technology,‚Äù Trump added. ‚ÄúAlong with her amazing husband, Jeff, she helped build a Fortune 500 company from 100 employees to over 10,000, as Executive VP. She and Jeff also helped me secure the Big Election Win in Georgia!‚ÄùOver the last four years, Trump said that Loeffler has worked to promote election integrity, outreach, and voter registration through her nonprofit, Greater Georgia.AdvertisementCHECK OUT THE DAILY WIRE HOLIDAY GIFT GUIDE‚ÄúIn addition to SBA Administrator, I‚Äôve appointed her Co-Chair of the Presidential Inaugural Committee,‚Äù Trump added.Loeffler responded to the announcement by saying that she was ‚Äúdeeply honored‚Äù as she accepted the nomination.Advertisement‚ÄúSmall businesses are huge for America,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre the beating heart of our economy and the gateway to the American Dream.‚ÄúThe America First Agenda will unleash a new era of growth and opportunity for job creators and innovators!‚Äù she added.Advertisement
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Right  
The article primarily focuses on President Trump's nomination of Kelly Loeffler, presenting her in a positive light and emphasizing her alignment with Trump's administration and business acumen. The use of quotes and phrases like "tremendous fighter" and "America First Agenda" indicates support for conservative values, which leans the article towards a right-leaning bias. However, it maintains a neutral tone without overtly expressing strong opinions, justifying the "Lean Right" classification.

title: EXCLUSIVE: Team Trump Promises Cabinet Nominees Will ‚ÄòMake America Safe¬†Again‚Äô
body: President Donald Trump‚Äôs cabinet nominees will ‚ÄúMake America Safe Again,‚Äù the president‚Äôs team said in a video first obtained by The Daily Wire.The video highlights the qualifications of Trump cabinet nominees Kristi Noem, Pam Bondi, Kash Patel, and Tom Homan, arguing that they bring a vast array of experience to the table ‚Äî and that they will support Trump‚Äôs agenda to end the weaponization of the government against the American people, secure the border, and more.‚ÄúPresident Trump was given a mandate to Make America Safe Again by securing our border, prosecuting dangerous criminals, supporting our police and Border Patrol, and rooting out corruption and crime,‚Äù Trump-Vance transition spokeswoman Karoline Leavitt told The Daily Wire. ‚ÄúPresident Trump‚Äôs nominees exemplify the leadership and experience needed to ensure the safety and security of all Americans.‚ÄùWATCH:Advertisement‚ÄúFrom Governor Kristi Noem‚Äôs proven record of upholding the rule of law, to Pam Bondi‚Äôs in combating crime and drug trafficking, these appointees are poised to restore integrity and justice across the nation,‚Äù Leavitt added. ‚ÄúKash Patel‚Äôs expertise in protecting Americans from a range of threats and Tom Homan‚Äôs unflinching efforts on border enforcement demonstrate their readiness to tackle the challenges ahead. Together, they form a team dedicated to protecting our communities, securing our freedoms, and Making America Safe Again.‚ÄùNoem is the governor of South Dakota, where the Trump team touts her work with the Department of Homeland Security, noting that she was the first governor to deploy National Guard soldiers to Texas to combat border crisis, which she did on seven other occasions. Florida Attorney General Pam Bondi has spent more than 18 years as a prosecutor and was the state‚Äôs first female attorney general.Homan is the former acting director of Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), and has a long history of service with the department. And Patel is the former chief of staff at the Department of Defense as well as the former Deputy Director of National Intelligence. Patel would be the first public defender to serve as director of the FBI, the Trump transition team said.AdvertisementThe video quotes Republican Tennessee Sen. Marsha Blackburn promising that Trump and his administration will not tolerate criminal activity at the United States border.‚ÄúYou‚Äôre going to see a very strong Kristi Noem at Homeland Security and Homan on the Border,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre going to get this issue under control, and I can assure you they will have the backing of the U.S. House and U.S. Senate as they carry forward on this work.‚ÄùSimilarly, Florida Rep. Cory Mills (R.) argues that ‚ÄúKash has seen from the inside with his qualifications and his time in the Administration what type of weaponization has gone forward, and he‚Äôs going to clean up the FBI.‚ÄùAdvertisement‚ÄúPam Bondi coming on as Attorney General is going to clean up the Department of ‚ÄòInJustice,'‚Äù he adds. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre going to have real rule of law, not the weaponization you see under this corrupt administration.‚ÄùThe video also features Fox News host Sean Hannity arguing that Bondi is a ‚Äúterrific nomination for many, many reasons.‚Äù‚ÄúPam worked as a prosecutor for nearly two decades, was the first woman elected ‚Äì two-time elected ‚Äì Attorney General for the great State of Florida where she served for 8 years,‚Äù Hannity says. ‚ÄúPam Bondi known for being tough on crime, worked hard to curb drug trafficking‚Ä¶ pill mills in Florida, and during her tenure Florida became one of the safest states in the country.‚ÄùFox News host Brian Kilmeade is also featured praising Homan as ‚Äúimpressive,‚Äù arguing: ‚Äúhe‚Äôs been successful with Republicans and Democrats. In fact, up until Donald Trump took over, before that, you‚Äôd have no idea where he stood politically.‚ÄùAdvertisement
Ai bias and explanation:
Right  
The article strongly promotes President Trump's cabinet nominees and their alignment with his agenda to improve safety and security in America. It highlights their qualifications and past achievements in a positive light while critiquing previous administrations, which indicates a clear bias in favor of the Republican perspective. The language used, along with the focus on conservative figures and their initiatives, reinforces a right-leaning bias.

title: Dem Rep. Lofgren: Musk, Ramaswamy‚Äôs DOGE Is ‚ÄòUnconstitutional and Illegal‚Äô
body: Representative Zoe Lofgren (D-CA) said Thursday on CNN‚Äôs ‚ÄúNewsroom‚Äù that the proposed Department of Government Efficiency, headed by Elon Musk and Vivek Ramaswamy, would be ‚Äúunconstitutional and illegal.‚Äù Host Jim Acosta said, ‚ÄúI want to ask you about something that is coming into your wheelhouse. Elon Musk and Vivek Ramaswamy apparently will be up on Capitol Hill talking about their ideas for this thing that they‚Äôre calling DOGE, the Department of Government Efficiency, which is a bit of a misnomer because it won‚Äôt be a part of the federal government, apparently but Congress controls the purse strings. What are your thoughts on Elon Musk and Ramaswamy deciding or trying to decide what stays and what goes in the federal government?‚Äù Lofgren said, ‚ÄúWell, it‚Äôs illegal. You know they haven‚Äôt asked to meet with me, but the impoundment of funds that have been appropriated by the Congress is unconstitutional and illegal. There is no such Department of Government Efficiency it‚Äôs made up. So good luck to them. I mean, if, um, if there is a plan that President Trump wants to propose to the Congress he should send it to us but the Constitution does not permit the president to simply avoid what the Congress has done, that that power of the purse is with the legislative branch, not the president.‚Äù Follow Pam Key on X @pamkeyNEN
Ai bias and explanation:
Lean Left  
The article primarily features the voice of a Democratic representative critiquing ideas put forth by Elon Musk and Vivek Ramaswamy, who are often associated with more conservative policies. The coverage and choice of quotes indicate a focus on the democratic perspective and its alignment with constitutional principles, highlighting differing viewpoints between left-leaning and right-leaning figures. The platform, CNN, is traditionally viewed as leaning left, further supporting this classification.

title: U.K. Supreme Court Hearing Arguments Over Definition Of The Word¬†‚ÄòWoman‚Äô
body: The United Kingdom‚Äôs Supreme Court has heard arguments in a case in which the justices must define ‚Äúwhat is a woman‚Äù as it pertains to the ‚ÄúEquality Act‚Äù by the Scottish government.Five Supreme Court justices ‚Äî three men and two women ‚Äî agreed to hear the case brought by the women‚Äôs rights group For Women Scotland (FWS) against the Scottish legislature after it passed a law stating that every Scottish public board should include an equal amount of men and woman. However, the Scottish government‚Äôs definition of ‚Äúwoman‚Äù includes trans-identifying men with a ‚Äúgender recognition certificate‚Äù (GRC), the Associated Press reported. It also claimed that the certificate entitled transgender individuals to the same protection under the Equality Act as those born female, the NewStatesmen reported.Lawyer for FWS, Aidan O‚ÄôNeill, told the justices that ‚Äúsex‚Äù should refer to biological sex as understood ‚Äúin ordinary, everyday language‚Äù when it comes to the Equality Act. A 2022 decision by Scotland‚Äôs Court of Session ruled that for the purpose of equality, sex was ‚Äúnot limited to biological or birth sex‚Äù and that it included those with a GRC.‚ÄúOur position is your sex, whether you are a man or a woman or a girl or a boy is determined from conception in utero, even before one‚Äôs birth, by one‚Äôs body,‚Äù O‚ÄôNeill said. ‚ÄúIt is an expression of one‚Äôs bodily reality.
